From July to December 2015, there was an increase in optimism regarding the U.S. military campaign against ISIS [6]. Views on whether the U.S. and its allies would succeed shifted positively, with more people believing in success by December 2015 ![The data indicate an increase in optimism from July to December 2015.](image5).

Specifically, the percentage of those who thought the U.S. and its allies would "definitely/probably succeed" increased from 55% in July to 66% in December [6]. Conversely, those who believed the U.S. and its allies would "definitely/probably fail" decreased from 36% to 27% during the same period [6].

Despite this increased optimism, overall ratings of the U.S. military effort remained somewhat negative [2]. However, there was a noticeable uptick in the belief that the U.S. and its allies would ultimately be successful [2].

In conclusion, perceptions of the U.S. military campaign against ISIS became more optimistic between July and December 2015, with more people believing in the likelihood of success.

Americans are divided on whether Islam is more likely to encourage violence, with $46\%$ saying it is and $45\%$ saying it is not [6, 7]. Views on this have been closely divided for much of the past decade [7].

The perception that Islam encourages violence more than other religions has become more politically polarized [6]. A significant partisan divide exists, with $68\%$ of Republicans saying Islam encourages violence, a historical high, while only $30\%$ of Democrats agree, a decrease from $42\%$ in September 2014 [11].  This divide is now as wide as it has ever been [11].

![The graph shows how opinions on this issue have changed over time.](image4)

Conservative Republicans are much more likely to believe Islam encourages violence ($77\%$) compared to liberal Democrats ($73\%$ say it does not) [4]. This ideological divide is growing [4].  The share of liberals who think Islam encourages violence has decreased by 14 points since 2014 [10].

![The image is a line graph depicting trends in percentages over time, from 2002 to 2015, for three groups: Republicans, Democrats, and Independents.](image2)

The perception of whether Islam encourages violence more than other religions has remained relatively stable overall, but political polarization on the issue has increased [5].

In conclusion, while overall perceptions have remained somewhat consistent, the gap between Republicans and Democrats regarding whether Islam encourages violence has widened, marking a significant increase in political polarization on the issue.

Americans are generally aware of the increasing possibility of automation impacting employment [2]. The public is more likely to express worry (72%) than enthusiasm (33%) about robots and computers doing jobs currently done by humans [1]. ![Americans express more worry than enthusiasm regarding automation technologies](image8).

Most Americans find the idea that machines might one day perform many human jobs plausible [6]. A significant 77% of Americans think it is realistic that robots and computers may be able to do many of the jobs currently done by humans [8].  ![Most of U.S. adults have heard, read or thought about the idea that robots and computers may be able to do many jobs currently done by humans](image5). Those who have heard more about the concept find it more realistic [12]. For example, 48% of Americans who have "heard a lot" about the concept find it extremely realistic compared to only 4% of those who have "heard nothing" [12, 4]. Additionally, those familiar with the idea express greater enthusiasm [4].

Americans are more worried than enthusiastic about machines doing many human jobs [5].   ![Americans are more worried than enthusiastic regarding machines doing human jobs](image6).
  Many anticipate negative outcomes, such as increased inequality [6]. ![Many survey respondents think inequality between rich and poor will be much worse than today](image1).

Overall, Americans perceive the concept of machines performing jobs currently done by humans with a mix of realism and concern, leaning towards worry about the potential negative impacts [6].

The public is concerned about the increasing capabilities of robots and computers in the workforce and how this might impact human jobs [3, 10]. A significant portion of the public supports policies that would limit the use of these technologies or integrate human involvement in their operations [3].

A large majority, 85% of Americans, favor limiting machines to performing jobs that are dangerous or unhealthy for humans ![Limiting machines to dangerous or unhealthy jobs has high support](image1). This is the most favored policy among those considered [6].

There is considerable support for other interventions, such as providing a guaranteed income (60% in favor) or a national service program (58% in favor) if robots and computers become widely competitive with human workers [4]. While views differ across political affiliations, with Democrats more strongly favoring a universal basic income and national service programs than Republicans [7, 12], limiting machines to dangerous and dirty jobs receives broad support across party lines [7].

The public is divided on whether there should be limits on how many jobs businesses can automate, with 58% feeling there should be limits and 41% believing businesses are justified in replacing humans with machines if it results in better work at a lower cost [1]. This divide exists across party lines, with slightly more Democrats (60%) than Republicans (54%) feeling there should be such limits [5]. The public is evenly divided on whether the government or individuals should be responsible for providing for displaced workers [2].

Overall, the public generally supports limiting the use of machines in the workforce, particularly for dangerous or unhealthy jobs, and is open to policies that would support displaced workers [9].

There is a notable partisan divide in how Republicans and Democrats view the availability of jobs [2, 3].  Republicans are more likely to perceive that there are plenty of jobs available compared to Democrats [3, 11].

<![The chart illustrates differing perceptions of job availability based on political affiliation, with Republicans more optimistic than Democrats.](image6)>

For instance, a clear majority of both Republicans (71%) and Democrats (53%) agree that there are plenty of jobs available locally [12]. However, these perceptions are divided along partisan lines [5, 12].  As of January 2019, 71% of Republicans believed jobs were widely available, while only 53% of Democrats shared this view [2]. In contrast, when considering "good jobs," the partisan divide widens, with 58% of Republicans and only 39% of Democrats believing good jobs are plentiful [image6]. This divide is also reflected in broader economic views, where Republicans are more likely to rate the economy positively compared to Democrats [6, 8].

Republicans are more optimistic about job availability than Democrats.

Latino Democrats are more inclined to perceive racial discrimination as a significant issue compared to their Republican counterparts [2, 3, 9]. A substantial $75\%$ of Latino Democrats believe that people not seeing racial discrimination where it exists is a major problem, in stark contrast to only $36\%$ of Latino Republicans [2].

This disparity is further highlighted in image1, which visually represents these diverging perceptions among Latinos, with 73% of Democrats/Lean Democrats saying that people not seeing racial discrimination where it exists is a bigger problem, compared to only 36% of Republicans/Lean Republicans.

Even among those who lean towards either party, the trend persists, with Democratic leaners being significantly more likely to recognize the existence of racial discrimination than those leaning towards the Republican Party [2]. This divide underscores fundamental differences in how Latino Democrats and Republicans perceive and interpret issues of racial discrimination in the country. Latino Democrats   $(55\%)$   are more likely than Republicans   $(44\%)$  to report having experienced racial discrimination [7]. However, among independents, similar  shares of Democratic leaners   $(57\%)$  and Republican leaners   $(56\%)$  say they’ve experienced  racial discrimination [7].

Latino Democrats are far more likely than Latino Republicans to perceive the lack of recognition of racial discrimination as a significant problem.

Many factors contribute to the underrepresentation of women, blacks, and Hispanics in STEM fields. A significant portion of Americans, specifically $39\%$, believe a major reason for the lack of women in STEM is the absence of encouragement from an early age, with $41\%$ holding a similar view regarding the underrepresentation of blacks and Hispanics [1]. ![Many Americans attribute the limited diversity of the STEM workforce to a lack of encouragement for girls and blacks and Hispanics to pursue STEM from an early age](image5).

Furthermore, perceived discrimination plays a role, as highlighted by the fact that $72\%$ of blacks in STEM believe discrimination in recruiting, hiring, and promotions is a major cause of underrepresentation, a sentiment less strongly shared by whites ($27\%$) and Asians ($28\%$) [4]. In addition to discrimination, limited access to quality education is seen as a critical barrier, with about half of STEM workers agreeing that this significantly contributes to the underrepresentation of blacks and Hispanics [3]. A substantial $42\%$ of Americans also attribute the underrepresentation to limited access to quality education [11].

Moreover, the lack of belief in one's ability to succeed and the absence of role models are also factors. Approximately a third of STEM workers believe that blacks and Hispanics are underrepresented because they don't believe in their ability to succeed ($34\%$) and because of the lack of role models ($32\%$) [7]. People working in STEM jobs are more likely than those in non-STEM jobs to highlight lack of access to quality education ($52\%$ vs. $42\%$), lack of early encouragement ($45\%$ vs. $40\%$), and lack of role models ($32\%$ vs. $27\%$) as major reasons [8].

In summary, the major reasons for the underrepresentation of women, blacks, and Hispanics in STEM jobs include lack of early encouragement, discrimination in recruitment and promotions, limited access to quality education, lack of belief in their ability to succeed, and the absence of role models.

The assessment employs specific language to articulate uncertainty, distinguishing between confidence and likelihood [9]. Confidence in a finding's validity hinges on the nature, extent, quality, strength, and consistency of evidence, alongside the degree of expert agreement [9]. This is expressed qualitatively, ranging from low confidence, where evidence is inconclusive or experts disagree, to very high confidence, characterized by strong evidence and high consensus [9]. The image illustrates the characteristics of evidence that determine different levels of confidence, from very high to low ![The chart categorizes the strength and reliability of evidence based on its source, consistency, and the degree of consensus among experts.](image8).

Likelihood language, conversely, describes the probability of occurrence based on uncertainty measures, expressed probabilistically through statistical analysis, model results, or expert judgment [2]. It allows a quantitative estimate of uncertainty to be associated with projections, with specific probabilities ranging from very unlikely (less than or equal to a 1 in 10 chance) to very likely (greater than or equal to a 9 in 10 chance) [3]. The applicable numerical ranges for the terms from "Very Likely" to "Very Unlikely" are illustrated in the image ![This is a visual representation of probability terms and their corresponding numerical ranges. It helps to convey the likelihood of an event occurring based on subjective assessments.](image4).

Both confidence and likelihood levels are grounded in the expert assessment and consensus of the chapter author teams [11]. These teams evaluate the available literature, assess the quality and quantity of evidence, and consider the level of agreement across different studies to determine the appropriate level for each finding [11].

Confidence is based on the evidence, while likelihood is based on probability; both are determined by expert assessment.

The public holds similar views regarding the Republican and Democratic parties when it comes to policy ideas and ethical standards [12]. However, the Republican Party is viewed as "too extreme" by more Americans compared to the Democratic Party [8]. Despite this, the percentage of Americans who find the Republican Party too extreme has decreased since June [8].

Views on ethical standards differ among educational groups. Among those with a college degree, a notable percentage believes that "high ethical standards" describe neither the GOP nor the Democratic Party ![A bar chart illustrates the perceptions of ethical standards and policy ideas for both Republican and Democratic parties, with "too extreme" also gauged.](image1). A considerable portion thinks it describes one party but not the other, while a smaller percentage believes it applies to both [10]. Combining views on ethics, a quarter of the public feels that neither party possesses "high ethical standards" [7].

![The image presents opinions on political parties, segmented by whether they "describe both parties," "describe one party, not the other," or "describe neither party".](image4)

Opinions on the traits of both parties are deeply divided along partisan lines [11]. Independents are more inclined than partisans to say that neither party has "high ethical standards" [5]. While majorities of Republicans and Democrats describe their own party as having high ethical standards, partisans are somewhat less positive about their own party [9]. There are significantly diverging views by ideology among Republicans and Republican leaners [6].

In summary, perceptions of political parties' ethics and extremism vary significantly across educational levels and political affiliations, with independents and those with higher education levels often holding more critical views.

Views on ethical standards are fairly consistent, with 41% believing the GOP has high ethical standards and 42% saying the same about the Democratic Party [4]. A quarter of the public feels that "high ethical standards" describes neither party, while 47% think it describes one but not the other [6].

![The bar chart shows that both parties are rated almost equally on having high ethical standards.](image1)

These perceptions are deeply divided along partisan lines [11]. Independents are more likely than partisans to say that neither party has "high ethical standards" [5]. Specifically, about a third of independents (34%) feel this way, including equal shares of Republican and Democratic leaners (33% each) [5]. In contrast, only about two-in-ten Republicans (19%) or Democrats (18%) share this view [5].

![The bar chart displays how different demographics perceive political parties.](image4)

Critiques about ethical standards extend to both parties [4]. However, more people view the Republican Party as "too extreme" (48%) compared to the Democratic Party (42%) [7]. This difference in perception of extremism, while present, has slightly decreased for the Republican Party since the previous year [7]. Opinions on party traits continue to be deeply divided along partisan lines [11].

Perceptions of ethical standards and extremism differ slightly between the Republican and Democratic parties, influenced by education and political affiliation, with independents more likely to view neither party as having high ethical standards.

Views on ethical standards differ across educational levels, with a notable portion of college graduates expressing skepticism towards both parties [5]. Nearly a third of college graduates believe that neither the Republican nor the Democratic party has high ethical standards [5]. A similar sentiment is echoed by a quarter of the general public, who also feel that neither party upholds high ethical standards [7].

Independents are more inclined than partisans to say that neither party has high ethical standards [9].  About a third of independents (34%) feel this way, a sentiment shared by equal shares of Republican and Democratic leaners (33% each) [9].  In contrast, only about two-in-ten Republicans (19%) or Democrats (18%) share this view [9].

![The bar chart illustrates perceptions of U.S. adults regarding the Republican and Democratic parties' policy ideas and ethical standards.](image4)

Views on which party has "high ethical standards" are nearly identical, with 41% for the GOP and 42% for the Democratic Party [1]. This perception is further influenced by political affiliation, as partisans tend to view their own party more favorably in terms of ethical standards [6]. Majorities of Republicans (66%) and Democrats (64%) describe their own party as having high ethical standards [6].

![This bar chart illustrates varying perceptions of political parties among different education levels, highlighting whether attributes describe both, one, or neither party.](image5)

Educational attainment also plays a role in shaping political preferences [8].  Those with a postgraduate degree show a strong preference for the Democratic candidate over the Republican candidate by roughly two-to-one (62% to 30%), and those with a four-year college degree favor the Democrat, 53% to 40% [8].  However, voters without a college degree show more divided preferences [8].

![This image displays a bar chart that highlights political party preferences among various demographic groups of registered voters.](image3)

In summary, perceptions of ethical standards and political party preferences vary significantly based on education level and political affiliation, with independents and college graduates being more critical of both parties' ethical standards.

Public confidence in Trump's handling of economic policy is mixed [4, 6, 12].  A narrow majority (53\%) express at least some confidence in his economic decisions, while 46\% have little or no confidence [6]. This confidence has slightly increased since January [12].
Views on Trump's ethical standards are also divided along partisan lines [9].  While 75\% of Republicans give the administration high marks for ethics, 86\% of Democrats rate them negatively [9].  Even within the Republican party, there's a divide, with only 15\% of conservative Republicans holding negative views on the ethical standards of the Trump administration, compared to 36\% of moderate and liberal Republicans [5].

Views about President Trump's ethical standards are divided among different political groups, and confidence in his handling of economic policy is mixed.

Public confidence in Trump to handle international crises and economic policy has seen an increase since January [1]. Specifically, confidence in his ability to handle an international crisis rose from 35% in January to 43% by May 2018 [12].

![Public confidence in Trump's ability to handle an international crisis has increased between January and May 2018](image3)

Similarly, public confidence in Trump's handling of economic policy has also increased from 46% in January to 53% in May [10]. Despite these improvements, views on Trump’s conduct remain mixed, with 54% of the public disliking his behavior as president [4].

![The public's overall assessment of Trump's conduct remains largely negative](image7)

Partisan divides remain stark; while Republicans have grown more confident in Trump’s ability to handle an international crisis since January (84% now, 73% then) [9], Democrats overwhelmingly disapprove of his conduct (85%) [8]. Eight-in-ten Republicans (80%) now agree with Trump on many or all issues, which is up 11 percentage points from the previous August [3].

![Republicans largely agree with Trump on the issues, while Democrats overwhelmingly disapprove of his conduct](image8)

Although there has been improvement in public confidence regarding Trump's ability to handle international crises and economic policy, substantial partisan divisions and overall disapproval of his conduct persist.

Since January, there has been an increase in public confidence regarding Trump's ability to handle both international crises and economic policy [6, 9]. Specifically, confidence in his handling of international crises rose from 35% in January to 43% in May [4]. Similarly, confidence in his economic policy decision-making increased from 46% to 53% over the same period [9]. Republicans have shown increased confidence in Trump's ability to handle an international crisis, with figures rising from 73% in January to 84% [11].

![The graph illustrates trends in public opinion regarding Trump's performance in handling international crises, economic policy, immigration, and working with Congress.](image2)

However, opinions on Trump's conduct are divided.  A significant portion of Republicans, about 38%, express liking Trump's conduct, while 45% have mixed feelings, and 16% dislike it [2].  Conservative Republicans are more likely to approve of Trump's conduct compared to moderate or liberal Republicans [1]. In stark contrast, the vast majority of Democrats, 85%, disapprove of Trump's conduct, with only 5% expressing approval [8].

![The bar chart compares opinions among Republicans and Democrats regarding whether they like, have mixed feelings about, or dislike Trump's conduct.](image5)

Overall, while confidence in Trump's handling of specific issues like the economy and international crises has increased, opinions on his conduct remain deeply divided along party lines.

Public confidence in Donald Trump's ability to handle various critical tasks has seen some shifts. Confidence in his handling of an international crisis has experienced fluctuation, declining from 48% in April 2017 to a low of 35%, before rising to 43% by May 2018 [11, image8].

Conversely, public confidence in Trump’s handling of economic policy has shown an increase since January, rising from 46% to 53% by May 2018 [12, image8]. These shifts indicate that perceptions of Trump's capabilities in these two key areas have evolved differently over time.

Other arenas, such as immigration, working effectively with Congress and managing the executive branch, there has been little change over the past several months of Trump’s presidency [5].
![The image is a bar chart that evaluates different tasks, showing the percentage of respondents who feel various aspects of performance are done "Not at all," "Not too," "Somewhat," and "Very" effectively](image7)
This is further demonstrated in a bar chart showing effectiveness in various tasks [image7].

Public confidence in Trump's ability to handle an international crisis has fluctuated, while confidence in his economic policy decisions has increased since January.

Views on Trump's conduct are significantly divided along party lines, with Democrats being overwhelmingly critical [4]. There's also internal criticism within the Republican party itself, with a notable percentage expressing mixed feelings [3]. Just 38% of Republicans say they like the way he conducts himself, while 45% say they have “mixed feelings about the way he conducts himself as president" [3].

Over time, opinions within the Republican party have consolidated, with more agreeing with Trump on policy issues ![This image shows the changing opinions among Republicans and Democrats between August 2017 and May 2018.](image2). Specifically, agreement among Republicans and Republican leaners has increased by 11 percentage points since August [12].

Views on the ethical standards of the Trump administration also show a stark partisan divide ![This image shows the distribution of ratings of ethical standards among the total population, Republicans/leaners, and Democrats/leaners.](image3). A large majority of Democrats and those leaning towards the Democratic party give low marks [10].

There are differences in views even within the Republican party, as conservative Republicans are more likely to approve of Trump's conduct compared to moderate or liberal Republicans [6]. Furthermore, negative views on the ethical standards of the administration are more prevalent among moderate and liberal Republicans compared to their conservative counterparts [11].

Overall, public evaluation of Trump's job handling has remained relatively stable [8], while significant differences persist across political ideologies regarding his conduct and the ethical standards of his administration. The ethical standards of the Trump administration were rated lower than those of previous administrations [1].

In summary, opinions on Trump's conduct and the ethical standards of his administration remain significantly divided along partisan lines, with Democrats largely critical and Republicans showing internal divisions based on ideology.

The public generally gives low marks to the ethical standards of the Trump administration [7]. A significant $58\%$ rate the administration's ethical standards as "not good or poor" [7, 11]. This contrasts with past administrations, where ethical standards were viewed more favorably [11]. The image shows that Trump's approval rating in May 2018 was 39%, lower than Obama's rating at a similar point in his presidency ![The image is a bar chart showing approval ratings of U.S. presidents over various years.](image7).

Public opinion on Trump's handling of his job remains relatively consistent with the beginning of his presidency [3]. However, disapproval is intense, with $42\%$ strongly disapproving [4]. This disapproval is echoed in views on ethical standards, where a majority express negative opinions [7, 11]. There are significant differences in these views based on political affiliation, with Republicans generally viewing the ethical standards more positively than Democrats ![The image is a bar chart comparing opinions among Republicans and Democrats in May 2018 and August 2017.](image6). Even among Republicans, there's a divide, with conservative Republicans more likely to view the ethical standards positively compared to moderate and liberal Republicans [10].

The public views the ethical standards of Trump administration officials lower compared to past administrations, which aligns with his consistent but polarized job approval ratings.

Adults with varying educational backgrounds differ on whether either political party possesses high ethical standards [4, 12]. Those with a college degree are more likely to say that neither the Republican nor Democratic party has high ethical standards ![The image is a bar chart showing people's opinions, categorized by political affiliation](image5). Independents are more inclined than partisans to believe that neither party upholds high ethical standards [9].

Views on Trump also vary significantly across educational levels [2]. Younger adults and those with higher education levels are more likely to disapprove of Trump's job performance [2]. A gender gap exists in Trump's approval ratings, with men showing more approval than women [10]. The public has similar views of the Republican and Democratic parties in assessments of their policy ideas and ethical standards [11].

Ethical concerns extend to both major parties, with similar percentages of Americans believing that each party has high ethical standards [3]. While most Republicans view their own party favorably regarding ethical standards, independents are generally more negative about the ethical standards of the Trump administration [1, 7].

Educational levels and political affiliations correlate with differing perceptions of ethical standards in political parties and approval ratings of Trump.

Voter reactions in 2016 were notably negative, with many considering the campaign one to forget [4]. Assessments of the press and pollsters were also more critical compared to previous elections [8]. This election was perceived as more negative and with less focus on issues [5].

Reactions to Trump's victory included a mix of emotions, with 51% feeling hopeful, while others felt uneasy, sad, scared or angry [9].
![The chart shows "hopeful" is the dominant positive emotion while "uneasy" is the dominant negative emotion](image2)
In comparison, reactions to Obama's 2008 election were more positive; 69% felt hopeful and only 35% felt uneasy [12].
![The chart shows the levels of surprise among different voter groups](image8)
A significant 73% of all voters expressed surprise at Trump's win, including 87% of Clinton voters and 60% of Trump voters [3].
![This chart compares the emotions of Trump voters and Clinton voters, showing a stark contrast in feelings such as hopeful, proud, uneasy, sad, scared, and angry](image3).

Voter reactions in 2016 were more negative and surprised compared to previous elections, with mixed emotions following Trump's victory, contrasting with the more positive reactions after Obama's 2008 election.

Trump voters were overwhelmingly hopeful (96%) and proud (74%) following his election [3]. Conversely, Clinton voters predominantly felt uneasy (90%), sad (77%), and scared (76%) [7].

![Clinton voters mainly felt uneasy, sad, scared and angry, while Trump voters mainly felt hopeful and proud.](image5)

A mere 7% of Clinton voters expressed hope, and only 1% felt proud [7].  These emotional reactions highlight a stark contrast in post-election sentiments.  Only 15% of Clinton supporters believed Trump's first term would be successful, compared to the 76% who anticipated it would be unsuccessful [9].

![The image shows what percentage of people believed Trump's first term to be a success and compares it to the percentage of people that believed Obama's first term to be a success.](image1)

Despite negative feelings, a majority (58%) of Clinton voters were "willing to give Trump a chance and see how he governs" [2]. These contrasting emotions and expectations reflect the deep divisions and uncertainties surrounding Trump's presidency.

In conclusion, Trump voters experienced positive emotions and high expectations, while Clinton voters felt negative emotions and anticipated an unsuccessful first term for Trump, though a majority were willing to give him a chance.

Voters' expectations for Trump's first term success varied significantly between Trump and Clinton supporters, with Trump voters being far more optimistic [9, 10]. Overall,  $56\%$ of all voters anticipated a successful first term for Trump [6].

Trump voters overwhelmingly expressed confidence in Trump, with an overwhelming  $97\%$ expecting his first term to be successful ![97% of Trump voters were satisfied in 2016.](image8). This mirrors the optimism Obama voters had in 2008 [9]. Moreover,  $88\%$ of Trump voters were confident in the kind of president he would be ![88% of respondents are confident about the kind of president Trump will be.](image2).

Conversely, Clinton voters held largely negative views, with only $15\%$ believing Trump's first term would be successful and a notable $76\%$ anticipating it would be unsuccessful [10]. The emotional reactions immediately following Trump's election highlighted this divide, with Clinton voters predominantly feeling uneasy, sad, scared and angry, in stark contrast to the hopefulness and pride expressed by Trump voters ![Trump voters predominantly felt hopeful and proud, while Clinton voters felt uneasy, sad, scared, and angry.](image1). Despite low expectations, a majority of Clinton voters ($58\%$) were initially "willing to give Trump a chance to see how he governs" [1, 11]. However, a substantial minority ($39\%$) expressed an inability to give him a chance "because of the kind of person he has shown himself to be" [1, 11, 3].

In summary, Trump voters were overwhelmingly optimistic about his first term and confident in his leadership, while Clinton voters were largely pessimistic but with a slight majority willing to give him a chance.

Voters have varied ideas regarding Trump's priorities as president [5]. A significant portion of Clinton voters, approximately 23%, suggest Trump should focus on healing divisions [6]. Specifically, 12% believe he should prioritize unifying the country, and 11% want him to change his personal behavior and address the divisions he created during his campaign [6].

![Clinton voters suggest Trump should focus on healing divisions](image5)

Trump voters, on the other hand, prioritize issues such as healthcare, the economy, and immigration [10].  29% of Trump voters believe healthcare should be Trump's first priority, while 15% feel the economy and immigration should be prioritized [9, 10].  These differences highlight the divergent expectations and concerns of each group [10]. Most Clinton voters do not have a clear sense of Trump's goals [1]. As the graphic indicates, a large percentage of Clinton voters feel that Trump's goals are unclear ![Most of Clinton voters do not have a clear sense of Trump's goals](image4).

These differing priorities and perceptions suggest a deep divide in how Trump's leadership is viewed, with Clinton voters focusing on unity and Trump voters emphasizing specific policy areas.

Trump voters generally express more confidence in Trump's ability to handle key issues, but this confidence varies depending on the issue [1]. For example, 70% of Trump voters have a great deal of confidence in his handling of the economy, while only 47% have a great deal of confidence in his foreign policy decisions [1].

Conversely, most Clinton voters express little to no confidence in Trump's ability to handle these same issues ![Clinton voters generally have little to no confidence in Trump's handling of key issues, especially illegal immigration and foreign policy.](image7). Specifically, nearly two-thirds of Clinton supporters have no confidence at all in Trump's ability to handle illegal immigration (64%) or foreign policy (63%) [9]. Despite this, 29% of Clinton's voters indicated that they have at least a fair amount of confidence in Trump's handling of foreign policy, while 63% indicated that they have no confidence at all [12].

When it comes to race relations, there is a significant divide between Trump and Clinton voters. Half of Trump voters (50%) expected race relations to improve, and 38% believed his election would make no difference [7]. ![Trump voters believe that race relations will get better or stay the same after the election of Trump.](image6) In stark contrast, 84% of Clinton voters anticipated that race relations would worsen under Trump [5, 11]. Only a small percentage of Clinton voters believed that race relations would improve (2%) or remain unchanged (13%) [11]. ![Clinton voters overwhelmingly believed that race relations would worsen after the election of Trump.](image6)

In summary, there is a significant disparity between Trump and Clinton voters regarding their confidence in Trump's handling of foreign policy and their expectations for race relations following the election.

Following Trump's election, voters were generally skeptical about improvements in race relations [3]. A significant $46\%$ believed race relations would worsen, and only $25\%$ anticipated improvement [3]. However, there was a stark contrast between Trump and Clinton voters. Half of Trump voters ($50\%$) expected race relations to improve, while $84\%$ of Clinton voters anticipated they would worsen ![Opinions on presidential elections reveal stark differences, with Trump's election in 2016 viewed more negatively than Obama's in 2008, especially among opposing voters.](image8).

Similarly, regarding political cooperation, few expected improvements after Trump's election [12]. While $47\%$ of Trump voters were optimistic about better partisan relations, only $9\%$ thought they would worsen [9]. In contrast, Clinton voters were more likely than McCain voters in 2008 to say relations would get worse ($43\%$ vs. $31\%$) [6].

Voter confidence in Trump's ability to improve race relations and political cooperation was significantly divided along party lines, with Trump voters expressing optimism and Clinton voters anticipating deterioration.

Following Trump's election, voters were generally skeptical about improvements in race relations, with only $25\%$ expecting things to get better, while $46\%$ anticipated they would worsen [8]. In contrast, expectations for partisan relations were more divided, with $27\%$ believing relations between parties would improve and an equal percentage thinking they would worsen [11].  Trump voters were more optimistic about partisan relations, but Clinton voters were more pessimistic [6].

These sentiments diverge significantly from the optimism surrounding Obama's 2008 election, where $52\%$ of voters believed race relations would improve [3]. This stark contrast highlights a significant shift in voter sentiment and expectations following the 2016 election.  ![Voters held differing views on whether President Trump's election would improve race relations.](image5)

Furthermore, there's a notable difference in how voters perceive the impact of enthusiastic supporters.  A majority of all voters, including substantial majorities of both Trump and Clinton voters, disagreed with the idea that enthusiastic supporters of a president mean less gets done [1].  This suggests a general belief that strong support for a president is not necessarily detrimental to progress. ![Most voters, regardless of who they voted for, felt enthusiastic supporters do not impede a president's ability to get things done.](image1)

Overall, voters were less optimistic about race relations under Trump compared to partisan relations, and most believed enthusiastic supporters wouldn't hinder his ability to govern.

Following the 2016 election, there's a notable divergence in how Democratic and Republican voters perceive their party's direction. Republican voters overwhelmingly prefer the GOP to maintain a conservative stance, a trend consistent over the years [9].  As shown in ![Republicans consistently prefer a conservative direction for their party.](image1), approximately 60% of Republicans and Republican-leaning voters favored a more conservative direction in November 2016, a figure that has remained relatively stable since 2008.

Conversely, Democratic voters show a more divided opinion, with a nearly equal split between those wanting a more liberal direction and those preferring a more moderate one [3].  Notably, support for a more liberal direction has increased significantly compared to previous elections [10]. The image ![The Democratic party has seen a shift toward a more liberal stance since 2008.](image2) illustrates this shift, with the percentage of Democratic voters favoring a more liberal direction rising from around 33% in 2008 and 2010 to 49% in 2016.

These shifts in political orientation correlate with voters' reactions to the 2016 election outcomes. Trump voters were overwhelmingly happy that the Republican Party retained congressional control, while Clinton supporters were largely unhappy [2]. As shown in ![Trump voters are happy, while Clinton voters are unhappy with the GOP retaining congressional control.](image3), 94% of Trump voters reported being happy about the GOP's control of Congress, compared to only 10% of Clinton supporters.

In summary, Republican voters have consistently favored a conservative direction, while Democratic voters have become more divided, with increasing support for a more liberal stance, and these orientations strongly influenced their reactions to the 2016 election results.

In 2008, a significant majority of voters, including those who supported Obama and McCain, favored bipartisan cooperation, with 78% of Obama's voters and 76% of McCain's voters wanting Democratic leaders to work with Republicans [6]. ![The image shows survey results from 2008 and 2016, comparing public opinion on how political leaders should approach working with newly elected presidents.](image8)However, by 2016, this sentiment had shifted, especially among Democratic voters. A large percentage of Democratic voters (65%) preferred their leaders to stand up to Trump, even if it meant less progress in Washington [12].

This shift is further illustrated by comparing Republican support for working with Obama in 2008 to Democratic support for working with Trump in 2016 [1]. In November 2008, 59% of Republicans were inclined to have their party's leaders collaborate with Obama [2], whereas in 2016, only 32% of Democrats wanted their leaders to work with Trump [12]. ![The image shows that 65% of Democrats want their leaders to stand up to Trump, while 32% prefer them to work with him, signifying a preference for opposition over cooperation.](image8) This indicates a notable polarization and a decreased willingness to compromise across party lines in 2016 compared to the post-2008 election environment.

Voter expectations in 2016 showed a stronger preference for party leaders to oppose the newly elected president compared to the widespread support for cooperation seen in 2008.

Voters perceived the 2016 election as extraordinarily negative [12]. A significant majority, 92%, indicated that there was more "mudslinging" compared to past elections, a notable increase from previous years ![The graph indicates an increasing trend in the perception that there is more mudslinging in recent elections.](image1). This negativity wasn't just limited to the candidates; it extended to the parties, the press, and even the voters themselves [4, 11].

Assessments of the press and pollsters were notably negative [10], with only 22% giving the press an A or B grade and an even smaller 21% awarding pollsters similar grades [7]. The average grades for Trump, the Republican Party, the Democratic Party, the press, and the pollsters were all below C+ ![The table presents survey data on public perception and grading of various entities related to a political context.](image4).

This widespread negativity influenced how voters felt about the election outcome, with 53% feeling "uneasy" about Donald Trump's election ![The image is a bar chart with six emotions: Hopeful, Proud, Uneasy, Sad, Scared, and Angry.](image5). While 81% felt they had enough information about the candidates [6], a record 73% believed there was less discussion of issues compared to previous campaigns [6].

Voter perceptions of political entities and campaign negativity in the 2016 election were overwhelmingly negative, impacting their feelings about the election's outcome.

The 2016 election outcome evoked varied emotional responses from voters, largely influenced by their candidate preference [8]. Trump's victory was unexpected for a majority of voters [1].

![The table shows the emotional reactions of Trump and Clinton voters, with the number of voters who felt each emotion listed](image2).

Among Trump supporters, "happy" was a frequently mentioned sentiment, alongside surprise, whereas Clinton voters most often expressed feeling "shocked," "disappointed," and "disgusted" [10, 2]. This divergence highlights the profound emotional impact of the election results on each group [5]. Overall, many voters reported feeling "uneasy" [8].

![The image is a bar chart with six emotions: Hopeful, Proud, Uneasy, Sad, Scared, and Angry. Each emotion is paired with a numerical value, probably representing a percentage or score](image8).

Adding to the emotional reactions, a significant number of voters, across party lines, felt that the 2016 election had excessive "mudslinging" [7].

![The graph indicates an increasing trend in the perception that there is more mudslinging in recent elections](image6).

Voters gave low grades to both parties [11]. The emotional reactions to the 2016 election strongly differed between Trump and Clinton voters, with many voters believing the election had excessive mudslinging [5, 7].

The emotional reactions to Donald Trump's victory varied significantly between Trump and Clinton voters, reflecting differing expectations before the election. Among Trump supporters, "happy" was the most frequently mentioned sentiment, alongside surprise [7]. ![Trump voters were most likely to be happy following Trump's victory](image8). This suggests that while many Trump voters were pleased with the outcome, a considerable portion did not anticipate his win. Voter sentiments reveal a mix of emotions and expectations following Trump's victory. The unexpected nature of Trump's win is reflected in the responses, with a significant percentage of both Trump and Clinton voters expressing surprise [1, 9].  Specifically, 60% of Trump voters and 87% of Clinton voters were surprised by the outcome, highlighting the widespread shock across the political spectrum ![This image is a horizontal bar chart comparing the levels of surprise among different voter groups.](image1).

Trump voters predominantly expressed happiness, while Clinton voters cited feelings like shock and disappointment [10, 11]. Since 2001, Americans' views on the government's efforts against terrorism have shifted, with current ratings lower than any point since the September 2001 attacks [2]. Now, more Americans believe the government is doing "not too well or not at all well" (52%) compared to those who think the government is performing "very or fairly well" (46%) [2]. This represents a 26-point drop in positive ratings since January [2]. ![The graph illustrates a shift in public opinion over time.](image1)
Since early 2015, opinions on the government's counter-terrorism efforts have become more negative across the political spectrum [3]. Although a majority of Democrats (64%) still rate the government's efforts positively, this is down from 85% in January [3]. Independents' positive ratings have fallen 25 points from 69% to 44%, and only 27% of Republicans now give positive ratings, a decrease from 63% [3]. ![The graph suggests how each group's metrics have changed over the specified years.](image2)
There are notable differences based on age, with older Americans being more critical of the government's efforts [4]. A majority (57%) of those 50 and older believe the government is performing poorly, while younger adults (18-29) are more likely to give positive ratings (53%) [6]. ![The table displays survey results on opinions about the balance between civil liberties and national protection across different age groups.](image8)

In conclusion, public perception of government efforts to combat terrorism has declined since 2001, with variations across political affiliations and age groups, older Americans and Republicans are more critical.

Older Americans and those with less education tend to rate government efforts against terrorism more negatively [1, 11]. For example, a majority of those 50 and older feel the government isn't doing well in reducing the terrorist threat, while younger adults are more likely to view the government's performance positively [4].
![This table indicates how different age groups view the balance between protecting civil liberties and national security](image1)
As shown, older age groups are more concerned about the government not doing enough to protect the U.S [image1].

Since early 2015, assessments of government efforts have become more negative across the political spectrum [3].
![This chart illustrates how concern over government restrictions on civil liberties has changed between 2004 and 2015](image6)
The shift in concern over government restrictions on civil liberties shows that, over time, more people have become concerned that the government isn't doing enough to protect the country [image6]. This is further supported by the fact that concern over government restrictions on civil liberties has fallen dramatically since July 2013 [8].

Age and political ideology both significantly influence perceptions of government efforts to reduce the terrorist threat, with older individuals and those across the political spectrum showing increased concern over time.

Older Americans tend to view the government's efforts to reduce terrorist threats more negatively compared to younger adults [6, 12]. For example, 57% of those 50 and older believe the government is not doing well in reducing the terrorist threat, while only 46% of those aged 18-29 share this view [6].

![The table displays survey results on opinions about the balance between civil liberties and national protection across different age groups.](image5)

This difference in perception extends to concerns about anti-terrorism policies.  Adults under 30 are more divided, with 43% concerned about excessive restrictions on civil liberties and 44% feeling policies don't go far enough [7]. In contrast, older age groups are more concerned that policies do not go far enough, with this sentiment increasing with age; 71% of those 65 and older express this concern [7].  Generally, concerns about government restrictions on civil liberties decreased since 2013 [9].

In 2015, older Americans were more critical of the government's efforts against terrorism and more likely to believe that anti-terror policies have not gone far enough to protect the country, compared to younger adults who were more concerned about civil liberties.

Currently, a greater proportion of Americans express concern that anti-terrorism policies do not extend far enough to adequately protect the country [4]. Public apprehension about anti-terrorism policies infringing on civil liberties has decreased to a five-year low [2]. A survey shows opinions about the balance between civil liberties and national protection across different age groups, with 71% of people over 65 saying policies do not go far enough to protect the U.S. ![The table displays survey results on opinions about the balance between civil liberties and national protection across different age groups.](image4)

Since 2013, both Republicans and Democrats have increasingly felt that government anti-terrorism measures are insufficient, with a more significant shift among Republicans [5]. Currently, similar proportions of conservative Republicans (71%), moderate and liberal Republicans (74%), and conservative and moderate Democrats (67%) share the concern that anti-terrorism policies are inadequate [6]. A graph indicates how metrics for Republicans, Democrats, and Independents have changed between 2004 and 2015. ![The image is a line graph showing data trends over time from 2004 to 2015 for three political affiliations: Republican, Democrat, and Independent.](image7)

These opinions vary across age groups, with younger adults (under 30) being split between concerns about excessive restrictions on civil liberties (43%) and insufficient protection (44%), while older demographics are more concerned about security [8].

In recent years, Americans have become more concerned that government anti-terrorism efforts do not go far enough to protect the country, with notable differences in opinion across age groups and political affiliations.

Public perception of the U.S. military campaign against ISIS has generally remained negative, although there's been a notable increase in optimism regarding its ultimate success [1]. The assessment of the campaign's current state has not significantly shifted despite events like the Paris and San Bernardino attacks [3].  ![The percentages of people who rated something "Not too/at all well" versus "Very/Fairly well" over time is displayed](image1). As of December 2015, 58% felt the U.S. effort was "not too/at all well," while 35% rated it "very/fairly well" [7].

However, views on the likelihood of success have become more positive [12]. ![The percentage of people who responded "Definitely/Probably fail" or "Definitely/Probably succeed" in July 2015 and December 2015 is displayed](image6). A two-thirds majority (66%) believed that the U.S. and its allies would succeed against ISIS, up from 55% in July [9].  This indicates growing confidence in the long-term outcome, even if present assessments remain critical [1].

There are significant partisan divides in how the campaign against ISIS is viewed [2]. Republicans are more inclined to think the U.S. isn't doing enough [6]. ![The image shows survey results about whether a policy will go far enough to stop militants, divided by age groups, political affiliation, and political leanings within parties](image2). A large majority of Republicans (75%) are concerned about the U.S. not going far enough, while only 18% fear over-involvement [6]. Conversely, liberal Democrats are more concerned about the U.S. becoming too involved [10]. Despite these differences, majorities across party lines believe the campaign will ultimately be successful [2].

Overall, public perceptions reveal steady approval for the U.S. military campaign, alongside increasing confidence in its ultimate success, though partisan divides persist in assessing the intensity and approach of the intervention [11].

In contrast, only 30% of Democrats share this view, a decrease from 42% in September 2014 [8, 12]. This divide highlights a growing partisan gap in perceptions of Islam and violence [7, 12].

The perception of the government's effectiveness in combating terrorism varies across political affiliations [5]. A majority of Democrats (64%) believe the government is doing at least fairly well, a figure that has decreased from 85% earlier in the year.  Independents' positive ratings have dropped significantly from 69% to 44%.  Only 27% of Republicans think the government is handling the terrorist threat effectively, a sharp decline from 63% at the beginning of the year [5]. The starkest shift is among conservative Republicans, with positive views plummeting from 59% to just 18% [7].

![The table highlights that Republicans, Democrats and Independents view defense/national security, immigration, terrorism, ISIS/War in Iraq/War in Syria, economy, gun control, unemployment and political gridlock differently.](image7)

These differences in views on the importance of terrorism correlate with the perception of the government's efforts [5, 6].  Republicans, who are more likely to view terrorism as a critical problem, are also more critical of the government's efforts to reduce the terrorist threat [6]. Conversely, Democrats, who are less likely to prioritize terrorism as the most important problem, are more likely to view the government's efforts positively [6].

In summary, Republicans prioritize terrorism more than Democrats or Independents, leading them to be more critical of the government's efforts in addressing the terrorist threat.

Independents' views on government regulation and economic fairness reveal a nuanced position compared to the more clearly defined stances of Democrats and Republicans. Independents are more likely to say immigrants do more to strengthen than burden the country [10].
 

 In contrast, majorities of Republicans feel immigrants are a burden on the country [2]. Independents opinions on the government system unfairly favors powerful interests versus those who think it is generally fair to most Americans. The survey indicates that 66% of independents believe the government system unfairly favors powerful interests, while 30% think it is fair ![Independents are more likely to believe the government system unfairly favors powerful interests.](image2).
 

 While most Democrats (85%) and Democratic leaners (81%) share the view that the U.S. economic system unfairly favors powerful interests [3], Republicans hold a different perspective, with 63% believing the U.S. economic system is fair to most Americans [12]. Opinions on government regulation also vary; most Democrats believe government regulation is necessary to protect the public interest while most Republicans say it does more harm than good ![This image represents public opinions on government size and regulation.](image3).
 

 Overall, independents have mixed preferences regarding the size of government and its regulation of business [8]. A significant percentage of Republican-leaning independents (78%) favor a smaller government providing fewer services [9], mirroring the views of Republicans [6].
 

 Independent voters' views on government regulation and economic fairness fall between those of Democrats and Republicans, showing a more divided and moderate stance.

Over time, negative views of both major parties have shifted among independents, though this varies among subgroups. A notable portion of independents hold unfavorable views towards both the Republican and Democratic parties ![The percentage of people who are unfavorable to both parties has increased from 6% in 1994 to 12% by 2018.](image7). However, the percentage of independents with negative views toward both parties has decreased in recent years [8].

Independents who do not lean toward either party are more likely to have negative opinions of both parties [11].
  Currently, 37% of independents without a lean view both parties unfavorably [4].
  In contrast, independents who lean towards a party often mirror the sentiments of party identifiers; for example, a majority of GOP leaners view the Republican Party favorably [1, 7].
   ![Data shows the percentage of different political affiliations that have unfavorable opinions of the Republican and Democratic parties.](image5)

The dislike of the opposing party has increased among independents who lean towards either the Republican or Democratic parties [3, 9]. The share of Democratic-leaning independents with a very unfavorable view of the Republican Party has significantly increased from 8% in 1994 to 37% in 2018 [5]. A similar trend is observed among Republican leaners, with very unfavorable opinions of the Democratic Party increasing from 15% in 1994 to 39% in 2018 [5].
  ![The graph illustrates increasing polarization over the years, with growing unfavorable views of the opposite party among partisan groups.](image8)

In summary, while a segment of independents harbors unfavorable views towards both major parties, especially those without any partisan lean, the trend among those who lean towards a party reflects increasing negativity towards the opposing party, mirroring broader partisan polarization.

Over the past two decades, negative views of opposing parties have increased among both Republicans and Democrats, a trend mirrored by independents who lean toward a party [7]. Intense dislike of the opposing party has surged among partisans and similarly among independents who lean toward either the Republican or Democratic parties [5].  ![The graph illustrates increasing polarization from 1994 to 2018, showing growing unfavorable views of the opposite party among partisan groups.](image6) Specifically, the share of Democratic-leaning independents with a very unfavorable view of the Republican Party has more than quadrupled from 8% in 1994 to 37% in 2018; a similar increase occurred among Republican leaners viewing the Democratic Party, rising from 15% to 39% [4].

Currently, large majorities of both Republicans and Democrats hold unfavorable views of the opposing party [2]. $87\%$ of Republicans view the Democratic Party unfavorably, and $88\%$ of Democrats view the Republican Party unfavorably [2].  Independents who do not lean toward a party are more likely to have unfavorable views of both parties [1]. ![The bar chart displays the percentage of people with favorable or unfavorable opinions of the Republican and Democratic parties, broken down by different political affiliations.](image7) As of now, $28\%$ of independents have an unfavorable opinion of both parties, which is higher than both Republicans ($10\%$) and Democrats ($9\%$) [8].  However, this is a decline from 2015, when $36\%$ of independents held negative views of both parties [9]. Although independents without leaning are more likely to have an unfavorable opinion of both parties at $37\%$, about $22\%$ have favorable opinions of both parties; only $11\%$ view the Democratic Party favorably and $9\%$ view the GOP favorably [12].

Unfavorable views toward the opposing party have increased significantly since 1994, and independents are more likely than partisans to dislike both parties, though this has decreased in recent years.

Americans are highly critical of China’s handling of the coronavirus outbreak [7]. Around three-quarters of Americans believe that China's initial handling of the outbreak in Wuhan contributed significantly to the global spread of the virus [10]. The image shows that 64% of respondents view China's handling of the outbreak as "Bad" ![This image shows that 64% of respondents view China's handling of the outbreak as "Bad."](image6).

However, significant partisan divisions exist. Republicans are more critical of China's response to COVID-19 [5]. Republicans are more likely to say China has done a bad job dealing with the coronavirus, with 82% holding this view compared to 54% of Democrats [9]. A greater percentage of Republicans (73%) believe China's early handling of the pandemic contributed a great deal to its spread, compared to Democrats (38%) [10]. The image visually represents that 82% of Republicans/leaning Republicans view China's handling of the outbreak as "Bad", compared to 54% of Democrats/leaning Democrats ![The bar chart illustrates that a higher percentage of Republicans perceive China's handling of the outbreak negatively compared to Democrats.](image1).

This partisan divide extends to views on how the U.S. should respond. Republicans are about twice as likely (71%) as Democrats (37%) to say the U.S. should hold China responsible, even at the expense of worsening economic relations [11]. A survey indicated that 51% of people believe that the U.S. should hold China responsible, even if relations worsen ![This image indicates that a majority feels that the U.S. should hold China responsible, even if relations worsen.](image5).

Republicans are more likely to have very unfavorable views of China and favor a tougher policy approach [12]. Older Americans are also more critical of China’s response [5, 9]. Overall, those who believe China did a poor job handling the outbreak are more likely to have negative views of the country [8].

In summary, Republicans are significantly more critical of China's handling of the coronavirus outbreak and are more inclined to prioritize holding China accountable, even if it harms U.S.-China relations, compared to Democrats.

Republicans are significantly more critical of China's handling of the coronavirus outbreak compared to Democrats [4, 8]. Specifically, 82% of Republicans and Republican-leaning independents believe China has done a bad job dealing with the coronavirus, compared to 54% of Democrats and Democratic leaners [4]. Furthermore, Republicans are about twice as likely to think China has done a "very bad job" (61% vs. 30%) [4]. Older people are also more critical, with 73% of those ages 50 and older finding fault in China's pandemic response [4].

![The graph indicates changes over time in percentages or scores associated with Republican and Democrat groups.](image4)

Over time, negative views of China have increased across the political spectrum [6].  A majority (63%) of Republicans now believe bilateral economic ties are bad, a 15-point increase from the previous year. Among Democrats, roughly three-quarters (73%) say ties are bad, up 12 points from the prior year [6]. This increase in negative sentiment is also reflected in how Americans view China's handling of the COVID-19 outbreak [7].

![The bar chart indicates shifts in perception of economic ties as "Bad" or "Good" between 2019 and 2020.](image6)

In conclusion, Republicans are more critical of China's COVID-19 response than Democrats, and negative perceptions have increased in both groups over time.

Americans are highly critical of China's handling of the coronavirus outbreak, with approximately two-thirds expressing negative views [4]. Around three-quarters of Americans believe that the Chinese government's initial response in Wuhan significantly contributed to the global spread of the virus [9].  ![The bar chart shows that 64% of the total respondents think China has done a bad job dealing with the coronavirus outbreak](image2) .

Half of Americans believe that the U.S. should hold China accountable for its role in the coronavirus outbreak, even if it damages economic relations [3]. However, a significant percentage still prioritize strong U.S.-China relations, even if it means overlooking China's role in the outbreak [3]. ![The pie chart shows that half of the respondents think the U.S. should prioritize strong U.S.-China relations, even if it means overlooking any role China played in the outbreak](image4). Republicans are significantly more critical of China's handling of the pandemic compared to Democrats [2]. A large majority of Republicans believe China’s early handling of the pandemic contributed a great deal to its spread, while a smaller percentage of Democrats share the same view [9]. Republicans are also more inclined to favor holding China responsible, even if it worsens economic relations [3]. ![The line graph compares the percentage of Republicans/leaning Republicans and Democrats/leaning Democrats views from 2011 to 2020](image3).

Americans' views on China's role in the coronavirus outbreak and U.S.-China relations reveal a critical stance, particularly among Republicans, with a notable division on prioritizing accountability versus maintaining strong relations.

Americans' views of China have become increasingly negative, especially concerning China's handling of the COVID-19 pandemic [11]. A significant majority, 64%, believe China handled the coronavirus outbreak poorly, and 78% place a considerable amount of blame on the Chinese government for the global spread of the virus ![The image shows a bar graph with percentages representing opinions on the Chinese government’s initial handling of the coronavirus outbreak in Wuhan. According to the graph, 64% of respondents view it as "Bad," while 31% view it as "Good."](image1).

This negative perception influences how Americans view the broader U.S.-China relationship.  Those who think China did a poor job handling the outbreak are more likely to have unfavorable views of the country [7]. Specifically, negative views of China have increased sharply, with 73% of U.S. adults now holding an unfavorable view, a 26-percentage-point increase since 2018 [11]. This increase in unfavorable views is evident across different age groups, with those aged 50 and older showing the most significant increase in negative sentiment [11]. ![The image is a bar chart showing the percentage of people with favorable and unfavorable views across different age groups and political affiliations.](image4)
![The graph shows the percentage of people who say they have a favorable or unfavorable opinion of China from 2005 to 2020.](image8)
Furthermore, many Americans believe that China should be held accountable for its role in the coronavirus outbreak, even if it means worsening economic relations [3, 6]. However, when it comes to economic and trade policy, Americans are slightly more inclined to pursue a strong economic relationship with China rather than adopting a tough stance [3]. Still, there's increasing support for getting tough on China [3]. The belief that China is responsible for the global pandemic correlates with viewing China as an enemy [10].

In summary, American perceptions of China's handling of COVID-19 have largely been negative, contributing to souring views of the U.S.-China relationship, with a notable portion of Americans favoring holding China accountable even at the expense of economic ties.

Americans' views of China have become increasingly negative, especially among older adults [4, 9, 10]. Overall, unfavorable views of China have reached a high of 73% [8, 10]. ![The chart shows that unfavorable views of China are at 73% while favorable views are at 22%.](image7)
Since 2018, negative views have increased by 26 percentage points [8, 10]. In March, negative views increased by 7 points [8, 10].

There are notable differences across age groups, with older Americans holding more negative views [4, 5]. Americans ages 50 and older are more negative (81%) than those ages 30 to 49 (71%) or those under 30 (56%) [5]. ![The line graph illustrates that negative views of China have risen among all age groups since 2005, with those 50 and older showing the most significant increase.](image2) This represents an increase of 10 percentage points since March for those ages 50 and older [5]. Older Americans are also much more likely to view China as an enemy [11].

There is a growing partisan divide in views of China [1, 2, 3]. Republicans continue to hold more unfavorable views of China than Democrats, 83% vs. 68% respectively [1]. Republicans are also more likely to say they have a very unfavorable view of China (54%) than Democrats (35%) [1]. ![The line graph shows an increasing divergence in views of China between Republicans and Democrats from 2005 to 2020.](image3) The share of Republicans who see China as an enemy has increased 21 percentage points since 2012, compared to an 8 percentage point increase among Democrats [2].

In conclusion, negative perceptions of China have increased across all demographics, with older Americans and Republicans showing the most significant increases.

Americans' views of China have become increasingly unfavorable, with a notable rise in negative sentiment across different demographics [5]. Overall, $73\%$ of U.S. adults hold an unfavorable view of China, a significant increase of 26 percentage points since 2018 [5].
