Political affiliation in both the U.S. and Germany shapes attitudes toward foreign policy partners and desired levels of cooperation [1]. In the U.S., Republicans show a greater inclination towards Israel as a key partner, while Democrats emphasize Canada and Mexico ![Republicans favor Israel, while Democrats favor Canada and Mexico as foreign policy partners.](image8). Despite these differences, both Republicans and Democrats generally agree on Germany's importance as a foreign policy partner [2].

![This chart compares political party alignment with numerical percentages in the U.S. and Germany, showing varying levels of approval or support.](image3)

However, preferences for cooperation levels diverge along political lines. Democrats in the U.S. are more inclined towards greater cooperation with Germany than Republicans [12]. Similarly, in Germany, supporters of the CDU/CSU are more inclined to seek greater cooperation with the U.S. compared to those who support the Greens and SPD [12]. This aligns with data indicating that those on the ideological right in Germany tend to view the U.S. more favorably overall [12].

![The preferences for relationships with the U.S. and Russia differ between West and East Germany.](image1)

Views on Russia also differ, with Republicans in the U.S. and Germans living in the former East Germany showing a greater preference for increased cooperation with Russia [10]. This divergence is further highlighted by the fact that Democrats are more likely to prefer close ties with Germany, while Republicans show a greater inclination towards closer relations with Russia [11]. Political affiliations influence preferences for foreign policy partners and desired cooperation levels in both the U.S. and Germany.

Germans are almost twice as likely as Americans to want greater collaboration with Russia [3]. Increased cooperation with Russia is a more common preference among Republicans in the U.S. (41%) than Democrats (32%), as well as among Germans living in former East Germany (75%) than in the former West (63%) [3]. ![The bar graph shows that those in West Germany have a preference for the U.S., while those in East Germany have a preference for Russia.](image6)
However, attitudes diverge when it comes to a rising China. Germans are about twice as likely to say they prefer a close relationship with the U.S. over China (50% to 24%), while Americans are almost equally divided (41% prefer Germany, 44% say China) [8]. ![The bar chart compares the opinions of Americans and Germans on the preference between Germany and Russia, and the preference between Germany and China.](image8)
Democrats in the U.S. are more likely to want greater cooperation with Germany than Republicans [9]. And in Germany, supporters of CDU/CSU are more willing to want greater cooperation with the U.S. than those who support the Greens and the SPD [9]. ![The image is a chart comparing political party alignment in the U.S. and Germany.](image2)
These differences highlight how national identity, historical context, and political ideology shape preferences for international cooperation in both the U.S. and Germany.

Germans are more inclined towards greater cooperation with Russia compared to Americans, while Americans are more divided on their preference between Germany and China, and political affiliations in both countries influence these preferences.

Political affiliations in both the U.S. and Germany influence attitudes toward international cooperation. In the U.S., Republicans are more inclined towards closer relations with Russia compared to Democrats [1]. Specifically, 41% of Republicans favor increased cooperation with Russia, while only 32% of Democrats share this view [11].  Conversely, Democrats are more likely to favor greater cooperation with Germany than Republicans [6].

![The chart uses horizontal lines to represent a 0-100% scale for party alignment or approval.](image6)

In Germany, supporters of the CDU/CSU are more inclined to seek greater cooperation with the U.S. compared to supporters of the Greens and SPD [6]. Germans overall are almost twice as likely as Americans to want greater collaboration with Russia [11].  However, when it comes to China, Germans are more likely to prefer a close relationship with the U.S. over China, whereas Americans are almost equally divided [9].

![The bottom part of the chart compares opinions on the preference between Germany and China.](image2)

This divergence extends to views on which countries should have more influence; Americans are more in favor of the UK, France, Japan, and Germany having more influence, while Germans are more in favor of France, Japan, Russia and China having more influence [8].  These preferences reflect broader ideological divides, where those on the right in Germany tend to be more favorable toward the U.S., aligning with international image data [6].

In both the U.S. and Germany, political party preferences shape attitudes towards cooperation with other countries, with Republicans in the U.S. and those on the right in Germany showing a greater inclination towards Russia, while Democrats in the U.S. favor cooperation with Germany.

Ideological differences within both the U.S. and Germany play a role in shaping attitudes toward cooperation with Russia [6]. Conservative Americans and Germans on the right of the ideological spectrum are more likely than their liberal counterparts to view Russia favorably [6]. Increased cooperation with Russia is a more common preference among Republicans in the U.S. (41%) than Democrats (32%) [8].

![This image illustrates the contrast in country preferences between Republican and Democrat voters](image3)

These trends highlight how political affiliations can significantly influence perspectives on international relations, particularly concerning cooperation with Russia.
In the U.S., Democrats are more likely to favor close ties with Germany, while Republicans show a greater inclination towards Russia [3].
![This chart compares political party alignment in the U.S. and Germany](image6)
This division is reflected in the willingness to cooperate with Russia, where Republicans show a greater interest compared to Democrats [8]. Therefore, political affiliations in both the U.S. and Germany influence attitudes toward cooperation with Russia, with conservatives generally more open to collaboration than liberals.

Americans and Germans hold notably different perceptions regarding the world's leading economic power [3, 4]. Half of Americans consider the U.S. as the leading economic power, while a significant 53% of Germans believe it is China [3].

These differing views extend to international organizations and relationships. Germans generally view entities like the EU more favorably than Americans do [6]. The image highlights these differences, showing that Germans have more favorable views of the EU, Russia, China, the UN, and NATO compared to Americans. ![Germans generally have more favorable views of the EU, Russia, China, the UN, and NATO compared to Americans.](image2)

When it comes to important partners, there are differences in who Americans and Germans prioritize.  Germans are more likely to view the U.S. as an important partner than Americans are to view Germany. ![Germans are more likely to view the U.S. as an important partner than Americans are to view Germany.](image1)

In summary, Americans and Germans diverge on which country is the leading economic power and have different opinions on relationships with entities like the EU and China [3, 6].

Americans and Germans hold different opinions on countries and international organizations, with Germans tending to view these entities more positively than Americans [10]. This is evident in their perceptions of the EU, where roughly seven-in-ten Germans are in favor, compared to about half of Americans [10]. ![The image shows the approval ratings of the EU, Russia, China, UN, and NATO from the U.S., a 32-country median, and Germany, highlighting the differences in perception between Germany and the U.S.](image5)
Germans have more favorable views of the EU, Russia, China, UN, and NATO than Americans [10].

When it comes to which country is the world’s leading economic power, Americans and Germans diverge significantly [7]. Half of Americans identify the U.S. as the leading economic power, while about a third (32%) choose China. In contrast, roughly half of Germans name China (53%) as the leading economic power, compared to 24% who name the U.S. [7]. ![The image shows a bar chart comparing the percentages of people from the U.S. and Germany who believe the U.S., China, Japan, and the EU are the world's leading economic power.](image1) Germans are more likely to name China as the top economic power, whereas Americans favor the U.S. [8].

Political divides also play a role in shaping these attitudes [6]. Ideological differences influence views of the UN, EU, and Russia [2]. ![The image compares the views of Americans (Conservative, Moderate, Liberal) and Germans (Right, Center, Left) towards the UN, EU, and Russia based on their political ideologies.](image6)
Conservative Americans are more likely to view Russia favorably, while liberals are more inclined to favor the UN and EU [11]. Similarly, Germans on the right of the ideological spectrum are more likely to view Russia favorably, while those on the left are more likely to favor the UN and EU [11].
East and West Germany also have differing views: Germans in the former East Germany tend to view Russia more favorably and the EU less favorably than those in the former West [4]. ![The bar chart compares the preferences of people from West and East Germany regarding the U.S., Russia, or Both, showing a higher preference for Russia in the East compared to the West.](image2)
There are ideological differences in views of the UN, EU, and Russia [2].

In summary, Americans and Germans differ in their views of international organizations and economic powers, influenced by factors such as political ideology and historical context.

Americans are more inclined than Germans to consider military force as sometimes necessary [5, 9]. About eight-in-ten Americans believe in using force to maintain global order, whereas only about half of Germans agree [9].

This difference extends to defense spending, where half of Americans think European allies should maintain current spending levels [3]. This contrasts with 2017, when a greater percentage of Americans felt that these allies should increase their defense budgets [3].
![Americans' opinions on defense spending have shifted since 2017, with fewer now supporting increased spending by European allies.](image6)

Germans, however, are divided on whether to increase or maintain their national defense spending [7, 8].
In the U.S., Republicans are more likely to favor increased defense spending in Europe compared to Democrats [2]. However, fewer Republicans think that European allies should increase their defense budgets, a view that has declined since 2017 [2].
![There has been a decline in the percentage of both Republicans and Democrats who think that European allies should increase their defense budgets.](image1)

Despite these differences, younger individuals in both the U.S. and Germany hold more positive views of the U.S.-German relationship [4, 11]. For example, in the U.S., a higher percentage of 18- to 29-year-olds view the relationship as good, compared to those aged 65 and older [11]. A similar trend is observed in Germany [11].
![Younger people in both the U.S. and Germany generally have a more positive view of the U.S.-Germany relationship than older people.](image3)

Americans are more inclined to view military force as necessary and are more supportive of increased defense spending by European allies, though support has decreased since 2017, while younger generations in both countries hold more positive views of their bilateral relationship.

Americans are more inclined than Germans to support the use of military force to maintain global order [3]. Approximately eight-in-ten Americans believe military intervention is sometimes necessary, whereas only about half of Germans share this view [3].

This difference extends to the perception of the necessity of military force, with nine-in-ten American conservatives supporting its use, compared to roughly six-in-ten on the German right [1]. ![The chart illustrates that a higher percentage of U.S. respondents view the subject as "Very important" compared to German respondents, who tend to view it as less important overall.](image2)
This is further highlighted by the fact that 85% of Americans consider U.S. military bases in Germany important for U.S. security interests, while only about half of Germans agree on the importance of these bases for their own national security [5, 8].

There is a notable difference in the perception of whether to defend NATO allies against a potential Russian attack. Six-in-ten Americans believe their country should use military force to defend a NATO ally, while an equal percentage of Germans believe their country should not [11]. ![The image is a chart comparing the opinions of people from the U.S. and Germany on an unspecified issue about whether something should or should not be done.](image3)

Regarding defense spending, half of Americans believe that European allies should maintain their current levels [12]. Opinions on defense spending within Germany are divided, with the public split between increasing or maintaining current levels [9]. ![The data shows changing opinions in both countries regarding national defense spending over the three-year period.](image5)

In summary, Americans are generally more supportive of military intervention and maintaining or increasing defense spending compared to Germans, who are more hesitant about the use of force and divided on increasing defense expenditure.

Both Americans and Germans show shifting opinions on defense spending between 2017 and 2019, but they also have different opinions on the U.S. military presence in Germany [5].
![Americans' and Germans' opinions on national defense spending from 2017 to 2019](image1)
The image shows that in 2017, $45\%$ of Americans thought European allies should increase defense spending, but this decreased to $35\%$ by 2019 [3]. Meanwhile, Germans are divided on increasing or maintaining their defense budgets [12].

Views on defense spending also reveal partisan differences within each country [9, 11].
![Percentage of people who voted for each party in the 2017 Bundestag elections who say Germany should increase its defense spending](image6)
In the U.S., Republicans are more likely than Democrats to favor increased defense spending in Europe [9]. In Germany, CDU/CSU supporters favor increased spending, while Green supporters are more skeptical [11].

In summary, while both American and German opinions on defense spending have evolved since 2017, with fewer Americans now favoring increased spending by European allies, partisan divisions persist within each country regarding the ideal approach to defense budgets.

Between 2017 and 2019, there have been shifts in how Americans and Germans view national defense spending. In the U.S., the percentage of those who believe European allies should increase their defense spending decreased from 45% in 2017 to 35% in 2019 [7]. Meanwhile, the percentage of Americans who felt spending should remain the same increased from 37% to 50% [7].

![Americans' opinions on whether European allies should increase, keep the same, or decrease spending on national defense](image4)

Similarly, in Germany, opinions on their own national defense spending have also shifted. In 2017, about half of Germans were content with the current level of spending, while about a third felt it should be increased [3]. By 2019, 40% of Germans supported an increase, and 41% favored maintaining current levels [image4].

Partisan differences exist within both countries.  In the U.S., Republicans are more likely than Democrats to favor increased defense spending in Europe, although support among Republicans has decreased from 2017 to 2019 [12].  There is a partisan divide in Germany as well, supporters of the CDU/CSU are more inclined to favor increased defense spending, while Greens supporters are more skeptical [1]. SPD members fall in between [1].

![Numerical values associated with three different political parties](image8)

The data indicates a divergence in attitudes towards defense spending, with a general trend towards maintaining rather than increasing budgets in both the U.S. and Germany, alongside notable partisan divisions [1, 7].
The views on national defense spending have shifted in both countries, with partisan divides influencing these perspectives.

In the U.S., there's a partisan divide regarding increased defense spending in Europe, with Republicans initially more in favor, though their support decreased by 14 percentage points between 2017 and 2019 [2]. A similar but smaller decline occurred among Democrats [2]. The line graph depicts trends over three years, from 2017 to 2019, showing that the percentage of Republicans who think the U.S.’s European allies should increase their defense budgets has fallen, while a similar decline happened among Democrats ![The percentage of Republicans and Democrats who think the U.S.’s European allies should increase their defense budgets has fallen from 2017 to 2019](image7).

In Germany, partisan gaps are evident, with CDU/CSU supporters generally favoring increased defense spending, while Greens supporters are more skeptical, with only 28% supporting an increase [9]. SPD members fall in the middle, with 41% favoring increased spending [9]. This data shows the percentage of people in the U.S. and Germany who agree or disagree, with a higher percentage of people agreeing in the U.S. than in Germany ![Germans and Americans have different opinions on national defense spending](image5). The bar chart shows how supporters of CDU/CSU are more in favor of defense spending increases compared to supporters of the Greens and SPD ![CDU/CSU has the greatest numerical values](image4).

Opinions on defense spending have shifted over time in both countries, as reflected in the changes in percentages supporting increased spending between 2017 and 2019 [2, 9]. The comparative bar chart shows changing opinions in both countries regarding national defense spending over the three-year period from 2017 to 2019 ![A comparative bar chart depicts the public opinion of Americans and Germans on national defense spending over the years 2017, 2018, and 2019](image8).

Political affiliations in both the U.S. and Germany influence opinions on increasing defense spending, with Republicans in the U.S. and CDU/CSU supporters in Germany being more in favor, although support has seen some decline over time.

In Germany, age significantly influences opinions about U.S. military bases, with younger Germans being more skeptical about their importance [10]. Roughly six-in-ten Germans ages 18 to 29 think U.S. military bases in Germany do not contribute to German national security, while $61\%$ of those 65 and older believe the bases are important to Germany’s defense [10]. This divergence is visually represented, highlighting the generational gap in perceiving the importance of these bases.

![The bar chart shows that younger age groups tend to view the topic as less important compared to older age groups.](image8)

In the U.S., political affiliation shapes views on foreign policy partners [9]. While both Republicans and Democrats agree that the UK is their most important partner, Republicans are keener on Israel as a partner $(26\%)$ than Democrats $(9\%)$ [9]. Democrats also place more emphasis on Canada and Mexico [9]. The graphic illustrates these preferences, showing the UK as a top partner for both groups, but with notable differences in the prioritization of Israel, Canada, and Mexico.

![The image shows the UK as a top partner for both groups, but with notable differences in the prioritization of Israel, Canada, and Mexico.](image1)

Age differences in Germany and political affiliations in the U.S. significantly shape perceptions, with younger Germans doubting the importance of U.S. military bases and U.S. political parties prioritizing different foreign policy partners.

Americans have differing views on whether the U.S. should focus on its own problems versus helping other nations, and these views are often shaped by political affiliation and education [5].  A significant partisan divide exists, with Republicans generally favoring the U.S. dealing with its own problems, while Democrats are more inclined to support helping other countries [4, 3, 7].  Specifically, around three-quarters of Republicans believe the U.S. should focus domestically, while more than half of Democrats think the U.S. should assist other countries, although this view is more prevalent among liberal Democrats (64%) compared to conservative and moderate Democrats (44%) [3, 7].

![Republicans are more inclined to believe that the U.S. should focus domestically.](image5)

Education also plays a role, as those with higher levels of education are more supportive of international engagement [6].  Six-in-ten postgraduates believe the U.S. should help other countries, while college graduates are evenly split. In contrast, majorities of those with some college experience or a high school diploma or less think the U.S. should prioritize its own issues [6].
![Postgraduates are more inclined to believe that the U.S. should deal with its own issues.](image5)

These differences extend to evaluations of the U.S.'s handling of the coronavirus outbreak, with liberal Democrats holding more negative views compared to conservative Republicans [1, 12].  While 81% of liberal Democrats think the U.S. has done an only fair or poor job, only 22% of conservative Republicans share that view [12].

In summary, political affiliation and education level significantly influence Americans' views on U.S. global engagement and the handling of international issues.

Americans' views on how the U.S. handled the coronavirus outbreak are significantly divided along political lines [5, 7]. A large majority of Democrats and Democratic-leaning independents are critical of the U.S.’s response, while most Republicans and Republican-leaning independents praise it [7]. ![This image shows the political leanings towards Democratic/Lean Democrat and Republican/Lean Republican in various countries, highlighting the difference in opinions.](image6)

This partisan divide extends to views on China's handling of the outbreak, with Republicans being more critical than Democrats [9]. Conservative Republicans, in particular, are very likely to say China has not handled the crisis well [9]. ![The bar chart compares opinions on a scale of "Only fair/poor" to "Good/excellent" across various demographic groups.](image2)

Education also plays a role, as more educated Americans are generally more critical of the U.S.'s handling of the pandemic [10]. Those with postgraduate degrees are more likely to say the U.S. has done a poor job compared to those with a high school degree or less [10]. However, education has little impact on perceptions of China’s handling of the virus, with majorities across all educational groups expressing that China has not handled the pandemic well [1].

In summary, political affiliation and, to some extent, educational background influence Americans' perceptions of the U.S.'s handling of the COVID-19 pandemic, while views on China's handling are more consistent across educational levels but still divided along political lines.

Americans' evaluations of how well the U.S. is dealing with the outbreak are significantly divided along partisan lines [3, 10]. Overall, while $47\%$ of adults say the U.S. has done a good or excellent job, only $27\%$ of Democrats and Democratic-leaning independents share this view, compared to $71\%$ of Republicans and Republican-leaning independents [3]. This divide highlights a stark contrast in how each political group perceives the country's response to the pandemic. The image shows that there is a wide partisan gap in how the U.S. has dealt with coronavirus outbreak ![The bar chart illustrates different political leanings towards Democratic/Lean Democrat and Republican/Lean Republican in various countries](image7).

Evaluations of China's handling of the coronavirus outbreak are also quite partisan [11]. Republicans are much more likely to say China has not done a good job compared to Democrats, with conservative Republicans particularly critical [9]. The image shows the percentage of people holding the opinion of "Only fair/poor" versus "Good/excellent" based on political affiliations, highlighting the partisan divide ![The image shows a bar chart showing people's evaluation as "Only fair/poor" or "Good/excellent."](image3). The partisan divide significantly shapes perceptions of both the U.S.'s and China's handling of the COVID-19 pandemic.

There is a significant partisan divide regarding the U.S.'s ability to learn from the international response to the coronavirus [5]. Democrats are much more inclined to believe the U.S. can learn a great deal from other nations, with 60% of Democrats and Democratic-leaning independents holding this view, compared to only 28% of Republicans and Republican leaners [5]. Specifically, 67% of liberal Democrats think the U.S. can learn a great deal, while only 25% of conservative Republicans agree [8].

Those who believe the U.S. can learn from other countries tend to have a less positive assessment of the U.S.'s handling of the pandemic [1]. Fewer than half (44%) of those who think the U.S. can learn from abroad rate the country's handling of the outbreak as excellent or good, compared to 63% of those who don't think the U.S. can learn much from overseas [1]. ![Those who think the U.S. can learn from other countries are more likely to think other nations are handling the outbreak well.](image5)

Partisan divisions also extend to trust in international organizations. There's a pronounced partisan divide on views about the WHO, with 86% of liberal Democrats trusting information from the WHO at least a fair amount, compared to only 27% of conservative Republicans [2]. Similar, though smaller, divisions exist in trust in information from the EU [2]. Americans' views on the WHO's handling of the outbreak also fall along partisan lines, with 62% of Democrats and Democratic-leaning independents saying the organization has done at least a good job, compared to only 28% of Republicans and GOP leaners [4]. Conservative Republicans are less likely to approve of the organization’s handling of the virus than moderate or liberal Republicans [4]. ![Trust levels in international organizations like the WHO and EU vary significantly across different political groups.](image3)

Political affiliation significantly influences perceptions of the U.S.'s ability to learn from other countries and trust in international organizations, with Democrats generally more open to learning from abroad and trusting international sources compared to Republicans.

Americans are divided on whether the international influence of the U.S. will be strengthened, weakened, or remain the same after the pandemic [4].  Partisan divisions significantly shape these views, as Republicans are about twice as likely as Democrats to believe the U.S.'s international influence will be strengthened, while Democrats are four times more likely to expect it to weaken [1].  ![The image shows a bar chart displaying survey results about people’s perceptions on a particular topic](image1)

Education also plays a role, with those having higher education levels more likely to foresee a decline in U.S. global influence [10].  For example, 45% of those with postgraduate degrees believe the country’s global influence will recede [10]. This contrasts with views on the EU, where majorities across both parties believe its international influence will remain unaffected [3]. Opinions on China's influence also vary; about half of Americans think China will emerge with less influence [9]. There is a notable partisan divide, with six-in-ten Republicans believing China's international clout will diminish, compared to only 40% of Democrats [6].  ![The image is a bar chart showing the perceptions of some variable (unspecified here) by different demographic groups](image7)

In summary, political affiliation and education level significantly influence perceptions of how the U.S., EU, and China will fare in terms of international influence after the coronavirus outbreak.

Americans are divided on whether the pandemic will strengthen, weaken, or have no impact on the U.S.’s international influence [8]. While half of Americans think China's global influence will decrease, fewer say the same for the U.S. or the EU [10].

There are notable partisan gaps regarding beliefs about how the pandemic will affect the international influence of the U.S. Democrats are more inclined to believe that the U.S.'s influence will weaken, while Republicans are more likely to believe it will be strengthened ![Democrats are more optimistic about global influence, while Republicans are less so](image3). Education also plays a role, with those having higher education levels being more likely to think the U.S.'s global influence will decline [9].

  
Older Americans and Republicans are more likely to hold negative views of China [1]. A majority of Republicans believe that China’s global influence will diminish, while fewer Democrats share this view [12]. There are also age divisions, with older adults being more likely than younger adults to predict a decrease in China's global influence [12].

Attitudes about China's influence after the coronavirus outbreak vary across age groups, with older individuals more likely to anticipate a decline in China's global influence [11]. A large percentage of the population thinks China will have less influence in world affairs after the pandemic [6].

Predictions about the global influence of the U.S. and China after the coronavirus outbreak differ significantly among demographic and political groups, with partisan affiliation, age, and education level playing key roles in shaping these perceptions.

Many Americans hold a negative view of China's handling of the coronavirus outbreak [9]. Nearly two-thirds of Americans believe that China has not done a good job, with $37\%$ saying they have done a "poor" job [9]. Furthermore, few Americans trust the coronavirus information coming from the Chinese government [7].

![Most Americans believe China has handled the coronavirus poorly](image3)

There are significant partisan differences in these perceptions [2, 10]. Republicans are more likely than Democrats to say that China has not handled the outbreak well [2]. Specifically, conservative Republicans are particularly critical, with eight-in-ten holding this view [2]. Evaluations of the handling of the outbreak by the United States and China are quite partisan [12].

![Republicans are less likely than Democrats to agree with the statement](image5)

Looking ahead, many Americans believe that the coronavirus crisis will have a long-term impact on China’s global stature, with $50\%$ saying China will have less influence in world affairs after the pandemic [3]. However, there is a partisan divide on this question, as roughly six-in-ten Republicans believe China’s international clout will diminish, while just $40\%$ of Democrats say the same [5].

![Many Americans believe that China's influence will decrease](image7)

In summary, most Americans view China's handling of the coronavirus outbreak negatively and anticipate a decline in China's global influence, with significant partisan divisions in these perceptions.

Partisan divisions significantly shape opinions on the U.S.'s role in global affairs and its influence following the coronavirus outbreak [9]. There are sharp partisan and ideological differences on questions about foreign policy [1].

![The chart highlights differences in perceptions between political groups regarding the U.S. job in dealing with the coronavirus outbreak, learning from other countries, WHO’s performance, helping other countries and the U.S. influence after the outbreak.](image6)

Notably, Republicans are about twice as likely as Democrats to believe the U.S.’s international influence will be strengthened because of the crisis, whereas Democrats are about four times more likely than Republicans to expect American influence to weaken after the outbreak [4].  Liberal Democrats are notably more pessimistic, with 56% believing the U.S. will have less influence, a stark contrast to the 8% of conservative Republicans who share this view [1]. Furthermore, while 60% of Democrats believe the U.S. can learn a great deal from other nations about slowing the spread of coronavirus, only 28% of Republicans agree [10].

![The graph illustrates the diverging opinions between Republicans and Democrats on whether the U.S. does too much in helping to solve world problems.](image3)

As illustrated in the graph, a growing partisan gap exists regarding whether the U.S. does "too much" in addressing global challenges, with 62% of Republicans holding this view compared to just 26% of Democrats [7]. The partisan gap in these views was far more modest in Pew Research Center telephone surveys dating back to 2013 [7].

In summary, partisan views diverge significantly on the U.S.'s role in solving world problems and its influence after the coronavirus outbreak, with Republicans favoring a reduced global role and expecting strengthened influence, while Democrats hold the opposite views.

There are significant partisan and ideological divides regarding the U.S.'s role in global affairs and its capacity to learn from other countries, particularly during the coronavirus pandemic [3, 11]. A large majority of liberal Democrats, 81%, believe the U.S. has handled the coronavirus outbreak poorly, whereas only 22% of conservative Republicans share this view [3].
![The chart highlights differences in perceptions between political groups regarding these issues.](image5)
Liberal Democrats are also more inclined to think that the pandemic will diminish America's global influence, with 56% holding this belief, a stark contrast to the views of moderate and conservative Democrats, as well as Republicans [3]. The line graph highlights the growing partisan divisions over the U.S.'s role in solving world problems from 2013 to 2020, with diverging opinions between Republicans and Democrats [1].
![The chart highlights differences in perceptions between political groups regarding these issues.](image5)
Furthermore, while a majority of Americans believe the U.S. can learn from other countries on how to slow the spread of the coronavirus, there are partisan differences in the extent to which this is believed [6, 11]. 60% of Democrats think the U.S. can learn a great deal, compared to only 28% of Republicans [11]. This disparity is further illustrated by the fact that 67% of liberal Democrats believe the U.S. can learn a great deal from other nations, while only 25% of conservative Republicans agree [5].
![The image is a chart displaying survey data on opinions about the U.S. response to the coronavirus outbreak and related topics.](image5)
These partisan divisions extend to the question of whether the U.S. should assist other countries with their problems, with 64% of liberal Democrats supporting such assistance, compared to much lower percentages among Republicans [9]. Partisan views significantly diverge on the U.S.'s ability to learn from other countries and its role in global affairs during the coronavirus pandemic.

Americans are divided on whether the U.S. should focus on its own problems or help other countries [4].  Specifically, $60\%$  believe the U.S. should deal with its own problems, while  $39\%$  think it should help other countries [4].  However, these views differ significantly across political affiliations and educational levels.  

There's a notable partisan divide, with Republicans more inclined to prioritize domestic issues. A large majority of Republicans, approximately three-quarters, prefer that the U.S. handle its own problems and allow other countries to manage as best they can [11].  This sentiment is consistent across both conservative and moderate/liberal Republicans [11]. Conversely, Democrats are more supportive of international assistance, with over half believing the U.S. should help other countries, though a significant $46\%$  still think the U.S. should focus internally [6]. This divide is further nuanced by ideology, as $64\%$ of liberal Democrats support helping other countries, compared to $44\%$ of conservative and moderate Democrats [6].  ![The bar chart shows that 76% of Republicans/Lean Republicans think that the US should deal with its own problems as best as it can.](image6)

Educational attainment also plays a role in shaping these views [2].  Individuals with higher education levels are more inclined to support helping other nations [3].  Six-in-ten postgraduates believe the U.S. should assist other countries, while college graduates are evenly split on the issue [3]. In contrast, clear majorities of those with some college experience or no more than a high school diploma think the U.S. should prioritize its own problems [3].  ![The bar chart illustrates that the higher the education the more the belief that US should help other countries.](image6)

In summary, political affiliation and educational level significantly influence opinions on whether the U.S. should prioritize its own problems or help other countries.

Currently, there is a significant partisan divide regarding the U.S.'s role in addressing global issues [5, 10]. A majority of Republicans (62%) believe the U.S. is doing too much to solve world problems, while a plurality of Democrats (48%) think the U.S. is doing too little [2]. ![The bar chart illustrates that 76% of Republicans/Lean Republicans believe that the U.S. should deal with its own problems and let other countries deal with their own problems as best as they can.](image1) This divergence is evident when comparing the opinions of Republicans and Democrats where 62% of Republicans think that the U.S. does too much, while only 26% of Democrats share this view [10].

The partisan gap has widened considerably over time [5]. ![This line graph illustrates how Democrats' opinions on whether the U.S. is doing "Too little," "Right amount," or "Too much" to help solve world problems have changed from 2013 to 2020.](image6) For Republicans, the percentage who believe the U.S. does "too much" has increased from 52% in 2013 to 62% in 2020 [10]. ![This line graph illustrates the opinions of Republicans on whether the U.S. is doing "Too much," "Right amount," or "Too little" to help solve world problems from 2013 to 2020.](image7) In contrast, Democrats increasingly feel the U.S. is not doing enough, as shown by the shift in opinions over the years [12].

These diverging views reflect fundamental differences in the political ideologies and priorities of Republicans and Democrats [3, 12].

In summary, perceptions of the U.S. role in solving world problems are sharply divided along political lines, with Republicans increasingly believing the U.S. does too much and Democrats often feeling it does too little, and this divide has grown significantly over time.

There are significant differences in views on U.S. global engagement based on political affiliation. A majority of Republicans (62%) believe the U.S. does too much to solve world problems, while a plurality of Democrats (48%) think the U.S. does too little [1].  ![Republicans predominantly think the U.S. does too much to solve global problems, while Democrats believe it does too little.](image8) This partisan divide has widened considerably since 2013 [11].  About three-quarters of Republicans favor the U.S. addressing its own issues and letting other countries manage theirs [8].  ![Most surveyed believe the U.S. should address its own problems.](image7)

Education also influences opinions on this matter.  Those with higher education levels are more inclined to support the U.S. helping other nations [3]. Six-in-ten postgraduates believe the U.S. should assist other countries, whereas majorities of those with some college experience or a high school diploma think the U.S. should focus on its own problems [3].  However, when it comes to dealing with the coronavirus outbreak, opinions are sharply divided along party lines, with Democrats being critical and Republicans being supportive of the U.S.'s response [5]. ![Democrats generally view the U.S. response to the coronavirus outbreak negatively, while Republicans are more supportive.](image6) More educated Americans are also more critical of the U.S.'s handling of the pandemic [6].

In summary, political affiliation and educational attainment are key factors shaping views on U.S. global engagement and the handling of domestic issues.

Americans express considerable concern regarding the U.S.-China relationship, with many specific issues standing out as very serious [12]. These include cyber attacks from China, the loss of U.S. jobs, China’s growing military power, and human rights policies [12].

Despite these concerns, only around half of Americans are confident in Biden's ability to effectively handle China, which is the lowest confidence level among several foreign policy issues [5]. ![The graph shows confidence levels in President Biden regarding various foreign policy issues, with the lowest confidence expressed in dealing with China.](image6)
As the graph illustrates, only $53\%$ of Americans express confidence in Biden's ability to deal effectively with China [5]. This contrasts with higher confidence levels for improving relationships with allies ($67\%$) and dealing with terrorism and climate change (around $60\%$ each) [5].

Notably, there are significant partisan differences in confidence levels [7, 11]. A large majority of Democrats have confidence in Biden on China, whereas only a small fraction of Republicans share this view [7]. ![The image shows confidence levels in Biden to deal effectively with China, broken down by political affiliation.](image4) The data indicates that confidence in Biden's ability to handle China is significantly divided along partisan lines [7, 11].

Specific concerns, such as the loss of U.S. jobs to China, have increased in perceived seriousness [6]. ![The image highlights increasing concern among both Republicans and Democrats regarding issues like job losses and military power related to China.](image2) The percentage of Americans viewing the loss of U.S. jobs to China as a very serious problem has risen since 2020 [6].

Overall, while Americans express substantial concern about various issues related to China, their confidence in Biden's ability to manage the relationship effectively is relatively low compared to other foreign policy matters.

Confidence in President Biden's ability to handle China varies significantly across different demographic groups [7]. Women ($59\%$) are more confident than men ($48\%$), and Black ($82\%$) and Hispanic adults ($70\%$) express more confidence than White adults ($43\%$) [10].  Also, those with a college degree are more likely to express confidence in Biden's capabilities compared to those with less schooling ($60\%$ vs. $50\%$) [10]. However, it is important to note that Americans have the least confidence in Biden to deal with China compared to other foreign policy issues [2, 4].

![The image is a chart depicting the percentage of people with Democratic or Republican leanings who view different countries as a threat.](image3)

Partisan divides are particularly evident, with $83\%$ of Democrats and those leaning towards the Democratic Party expressing confidence in Biden on China, while only $19\%$ of Republicans and those leaning towards the Republican Party share the same sentiment [7].  Conservative Republicans have even lower confidence ($10\%$) compared to moderate or liberal Republicans ($30\%$) [7].  As the image shows,  63% of Republicans view China as a threat, compared to 36% of Democrats.

![The image is a bar chart showing survey results on various perceived serious issues related to China.](image8)

Americans express substantial concern regarding several specific issues in the U.S.-China relationship [12].  Major concerns include cyberattacks from China (65% very serious), the loss of U.S. jobs to China (53% very serious), China’s growing military power (52% very serious), and China’s policies on human rights (50% very serious) [12]. These issues highlight the multifaceted nature of American anxieties related to China, spanning economic, security, and ethical dimensions.

In summary, confidence in Biden's ability to handle China differs significantly across demographics, with the primary concerns including cyberattacks, job losses, military power, and human rights.

Confidence in President Biden's ability to handle China is varied across different demographics and political affiliations. Women (59%) are more confident than men (48%), and Black (82%) and Hispanic adults (70%) show more confidence than White adults (43%) [11].  ![The graph illustrates varying confidence levels in different demographics, split into "No Confidence" and "Confidence."](image3)

Those with a college degree also express more confidence (60%) compared to those with less schooling (50%) [11]. Americans express substantial concern over several issues in the U.S.-China relationship [5]. Confidence in President Biden's ability to handle China varies significantly across different demographic groups [7, 11]. Women $(59\%)$ are more confident than men $(48\%)$, and there are also differences across ethnic groups. Black $(82\%)$ and Hispanic adults $(70\%)$ express more confidence than White adults $(43\%)$ [7]. Major concerns among Americans regarding China include cyber attacks [2, 12], the loss of U.S. jobs, China's growing military power [6, 12], and China's policies on human rights [12].  Specifically, cyber attacks from China evoke the most concern, with roughly two-thirds considering digital attacks a very serious problem [2].  The loss of U.S. jobs to China is also a significant concern, with $53\%$ viewing it as a very serious problem [6].  Notably, concern over various China-related issues has generally increased more among Republicans than Democrats [8]. Confidence levels in Biden's ability to deal with China differ across demographics, and major concerns Americans have about China include cyber attacks, job losses, military power, and human rights policies.

Americans hold critical views regarding both China's handling of the COVID-19 pandemic and its respect for personal freedoms. More than half of Americans believe China has done a bad job dealing with the outbreak [2]. A significant percentage, 54%, think China is doing a bad job, in contrast to the 43% who think they are doing a good job [4]. This perception is further illustrated, with 45% saying China has done a very bad job handling climate change ![45% of respondents believe China has done a very bad job in handling climate change](image1).

However, Americans are also critical of the U.S.'s own handling of the pandemic, with 58% describing it as bad [4, 10]. This is visually represented in the graph, which shows that 54% think China is doing a "bad job," while 58% think the U.S. is doing a "bad job" ![A bar graph comparing the perceptions of whether China and the U.S. are doing a "bad job" or a "good job"](image7).

In addition to concerns about the pandemic response, there is widespread concern over China's human rights practices [1, 9]. A large majority, 90% of adults in the U.S., believe that the Chinese government does not respect the personal freedoms of its people ![The majority of Americans believe China does not respect personal freedoms](image6). This concern about human rights also influences the priorities Americans believe the U.S. should have in its relationship with China. 70% of Americans believe that the U.S. should prioritize promoting human rights, even if it harms economic relations [6] ![The majority of Americans think the U.S. should prioritize promoting human rights in its relationship with China](image6). Despite these concerns, China has pledged to become carbon neutral by 2060 [8].

Overall, Americans are critical of China's handling of COVID-19 and have serious concerns about its human rights record, and prioritize human rights over economic relations.

Americans prioritize human rights over economic ties with China, with $70\%$ choosing human rights [6]. This is reflected in the desire to get tougher with China on trade [3, 10]. Despite overall agreement on prioritizing human rights, there are nuances among different political affiliations [1].

Conservative Republicans and liberal Democrats are more likely to prioritize human rights over economic ties with China [9].  As the image shows, 77% of conservative Republicans prioritize human rights, while only 21% prefer to focus on economic issues, and 76% of liberal Democrats prioritize human rights, while 23% prefer to focus on economic issues ![The bar chart represents percentage distributions between prioritizing economic relations and promoting human rights, segmented by political affiliations.](image2).

Most Americans want the U.S. to prioritize promoting human rights in China, even if it harms economic relations [6].

Many Americans prioritize promoting human rights in China over strengthening economic ties, even if it harms economic relations [7]. A significant $70\%$ of Americans choose human rights [7].  ![This image shows that 70% of Americans believe that the U.S. should prioritize promoting human rights in China, even if it harms economic relations between the two countries.](image1)

Conservative Republicans and liberal Democrats are more likely to prioritize human rights over economic ties with China [4, 6].  Specifically, when considering economic and trade policies with China, more Americans prefer the U.S. to adopt a tougher stance rather than focusing on building a stronger relationship [12]. This view is particularly strong among Republicans and Republican-leaning independents, with $72\%$ favoring a tougher approach [12].  Among conservative Republicans, this sentiment is even more pronounced, with $81\%$ advocating for a tougher stance [12]. In contrast, approximately six-in-ten Democrats and Democrat-leaning independents prefer focusing on building stronger ties with China [12].  ![This image shows that the majority of Republicans/Lean Republicans believe that the U.S. should "get tougher" with China, while the majority of Democrats/Lean Democrats believe that the U.S. should "build a strong relationship" with China.](image7)

The prevailing sentiment among Americans is to prioritize human rights in China, even if it harms economic relations, while a tougher stance on trade with China is favored more by Republicans, especially conservative Republicans, compared to Democrats who prefer building stronger ties.

Americans hold varied perspectives on trade policies with China, often divided along political lines [9]. Overall, more Americans favor getting tougher with China on economic issues [4]. However, when evaluating the effects of tariffs, partisan differences emerge, with Republicans more inclined to view them positively compared to Democrats [5].
![Republicans are more likely to think tariffs are good for the U.S.](image1)
Republicans are more likely to view tariffs on Chinese and other foreign goods as having a positive effect for the U.S., while Democrats generally disagree [3]. A significant percentage of Republicans and Republican-leaning independents support a tougher stance on China [2]. Conversely, Democrats tend to favor building stronger ties with China [2]. Younger Americans are also more likely to prioritize building stronger relationships with China [12].

Even when increased tariffs on goods from foreign countries including China, the result was more Americans say they were ultimately bad for the U.S [9].
![Most people believe current economic relations between the U.S. and China are bad.](image6)
A substantial portion of Americans perceive the economic relationship between the U.S. and China as unfavorable [11]. Despite these differing views on economic strategies, there's a bipartisan consensus on promoting human rights in China, even if it harms economic relations [10].

In summary, U.S. political affiliations significantly influence perceptions of trade policies with China, with Republicans generally favoring a tougher stance and viewing tariffs more positively, while Democrats lean towards building stronger relationships, although a bipartisan agreement exists regarding promoting human rights.

The perspectives on tariffs and international students in the U.S. vary significantly between different political affiliations. Generally, the U.S. public holds varied views on tariff policies, with more people saying they were ultimately bad for the U.S. [6]. However, partisan divides emerge when assessing the effects of tariffs, as illustrated in ![Political groups' perspectives on the effects of tariffs, categorized as "Bad," "No real effect," or "Good" for the U.S.](image2). About half of Republicans believe increased tariffs on foreign products were beneficial for the U.S. [4]. This view is particularly strong among conservative Republicans [4]. Democrats, conversely, generally consider these tariffs to be detrimental to the U.S. [4].

  

Those who believe the U.S. economy is in good condition are more inclined to view the tariffs positively [5]. Most Americans report that the tariffs have not significantly affected their personal lives [7]. Opinions on tariffs' personal effects do not vary much based on income or geographical location [6]. 

  

Regarding international students, most Americans view them favorably, with 80% believing it is beneficial for U.S. colleges and universities to accept them [11]. This positive sentiment is particularly strong among Democrats, with 92% holding this view, compared to 67% of Republicans [1]. Despite the generally positive view of international students, there are divisions when it comes to Chinese students specifically [8]. A majority of Americans (55%) support limiting the number of Chinese students studying in the U.S [8]. Republicans are more inclined than Democrats to support limitations on the number of Chinese students attending U.S. colleges or universities [12].

In summary, Republicans are more likely to view tariffs as beneficial and support limiting Chinese students, while Democrats tend to view tariffs as detrimental and are more supportive of international students.

Older Americans are more inclined to support limits on Chinese students in U.S. universities [7]. Specifically, about 70% of Americans aged 50 and older favor these limits, while those aged 30 to 49 are evenly split, and nearly two-thirds of those aged 18 to 29 oppose them [7]. ![The image is a chart displaying survey results on opinions toward an unspecified topic, categorized by various demographics in the U.S.](image4)

Republicans are more likely than Democrats to support limiting the number of Chinese students [4, 7]. These differences in opinion extend to confidence in the Chinese President, Xi Jinping, where older Americans express less confidence [10]. A substantial 53% of those aged 65 and older report having no confidence in Xi, compared to only 35% of those aged 18 to 29 [10]. ![The image is a bar chart showing levels of confidence in a certain topic, divided by different demographic groups.](image6)

Overall, a majority of Americans support limiting Chinese students in the U.S. [8]. However, those with a college degree tend to oppose such restrictions, while a majority of those without a college degree favor them [9].

Opinions on limiting Chinese students in U.S. universities vary significantly across age groups and political affiliations, with older Americans and Republicans showing more support, which correlates with a lack of confidence in Chinese leadership.

Since 2018, American perceptions of China have become substantially more negative [7, 9]. A significant portion of Americans now hold "cold" feelings toward China, with the percentage increasing from 46% in 2018 to 67% [7].

This shift is further highlighted by the increase in those expressing "very cold" feelings, which has roughly doubled [1]. Republicans and Democrats both show this trend, although it's more pronounced among Republicans [3]. ![The graph illustrates the changes in opinions towards China from 2018 to 2021 among Republicans, Democrats, and the total sample, highlighting an increase in negative sentiment.](image4)

Several key concerns drive these negative perceptions. Human rights issues are frequently mentioned [10], with a notable focus on the treatment of Uyghurs in Xinjiang [5, 10]; China's human rights policies are seen as a very serious problem by half of Americans [8]. When Americans think of China, human rights and the economy are top of mind [11]. Economic issues, including the U.S.-China economic relationship, China's dominance in manufacturing, and concerns about job losses, also play a significant role [4]. A large percentage of Americans describe the economic relations between the two countries as somewhat or very bad [4]. Also, many Americans think that limiting the power and influence of China should be a top foreign policy priority for the country [6]. ![The bar chart shows that human rights issues are one of the primary concerns Americans have when they think about China.](image1)

In summary, American perceptions of China have grown more negative since 2018, driven by concerns over human rights, economic issues, and China's growing influence.

Americans hold significant reservations about China, spanning human rights, economic practices, and cybersecurity [1, 3, 7]. Perceptions of China are increasingly negative, with concerns rising over the past year [1, 8].

Americans express growing worries about cyber attacks, human rights, job losses, and China's military and technological advancements, as the percentages for each of these issues have increased from 2020 to 2021 ![The percentage of Americans concerned about cyberattacks from China, human rights, job losses, and China's military and technological advancements has increased from 2020 to 2021.](image2). These issues are viewed as very serious problems by a significant portion of the population [3].

Views on whether to prioritize human rights over economic relations with China also reveal key concerns, with a strong preference for promoting human rights even at the expense of economic benefits ![A majority of Americans prioritize promoting human rights in China even if it harms economic relations.](image4). When Americans think of China, human rights and the economy are top of mind [7]. Many are critical of China's approach to global issues like climate change [6].

There are notable partisan divisions in attitudes toward China. Republicans are more inclined to favor a tougher stance on economic issues, view China as an enemy, and support restrictions on Chinese students in the U.S. [9]. This divergence is evident in data comparing Republican and Democratic viewpoints on various China-related issues ![Republicans are more likely than Democrats to view China as an enemy and support a tougher stance on economic issues.](image1).

Overall confidence in President Biden to handle China is lower compared to other foreign policy matters, reflecting broader concerns [4, 11]. Confidence levels also vary significantly along partisan lines [12]. From 2018 to 2021, there has been an increase in the percentage of Americans, particularly Republicans, who feel limiting China's power and influence should be a top priority and who express "cold" feelings toward China ![From 2018 to 2021, there has been an increase in the percentage of Americans who feel limiting China's power and influence should be a top priority and who express "cold" feelings toward China.](image7).

Americans' key concerns regarding China encompass human rights, economic practices, cybersecurity, and geopolitical influence, with these concerns generally increasing over time and exhibiting notable partisan divisions.

Latinos are generally optimistic about their financial futures, with significant increases in optimism observed across various subgroups since 2008 [4, 6]. Overall, eight-in-ten Latinos (81%) expected their family's financial situation to improve in the coming year, a 14 percentage point increase from 2008 [4].  This rise in optimism among Latinos outpaces that of the general population, where the increase was only 6 percentage points [5].

Notably, economic optimism grew faster among Latinos with some college education (+20 percentage points) compared to those with a high school diploma (+9) or less education (+11) [9].  The percentage of Latinos aged 18 to 29 reporting excellent or good financial shape in 2015 saw a substantial increase of 27 percentage points from 2008 [7].  This highlights a significant improvement in younger Latinos' financial well-being.

There are differences in optimism based on age; older Latinos were less upbeat about their short-term economic future compared to younger and middle-aged Hispanics [2]. Specifically, about six-in-ten (59%) Latinos aged 65 or older expected their family’s finances to improve, whereas nine-in-ten Hispanic adults under 30 held this expectation [1].  

Optimism about family finances increased by 14 percentage points among both U.S.-born and foreign-born Hispanics, reaching 81% in each group [3]. Similarly, both Latino men (+18 points) and Latina women (+11 points) showed increased financial optimism compared to seven years prior [3]. The line graph compares the percentage of favorable opinions between Hispanic and general public from 2004 to 2015, showing a higher optimism among Hispanics in 2015 ![The line graph compares the percentage of favorable opinions between Hispanic and general public from 2004 to 2015, showing a higher optimism among Hispanics in 2015.](image5).

The financial optimism among most Latino subgroups has increased since 2008, surpassing the gains observed in the general population [5].

Hispanics generally hold optimistic views about their children's future financial prospects, with a significant percentage expecting their children to be better off than themselves [1, 7]. ![Hispanics predominantly anticipate a better financial future for their children.](image3)

Those who view their current financial situation positively are more likely to anticipate further improvements in their family's finances [4, 5]. The expectation that children will be better off financially is common across different levels of educational attainment [10].  Specifically, 72% of all Hispanics expect their children to be better off financially [1, 7]. This view is held by 69% of those with some college experience and 71% of those with less than a high school education. Interestingly, high school graduates are even more optimistic, with 79% believing their children will surpass their own financial status [10].

Therefore, Hispanics generally have high hopes for their children's financial future, and while educational attainment shows some variation, optimism remains prevalent across all levels.

Since the Great Recession, Latinos have become more optimistic about their finances [1]. From 2008 to 2015, the percentage of Latinos expecting their family finances to improve increased by 14 percentage points [4].

This increase is evident when compared to the general public ![Hispanics show higher measures and more increase over the time period.](image4). In 2015, $81\%$ of Latinos expected their finances to improve, compared to $61\%$ of the general public [4]. This optimism extends to their children's financial future, with $72\%$ expecting them to be better off [3, 11].

Despite increased optimism, data reveals a mixed economic picture for the Hispanic community [6]. While the unemployment rate has decreased from a high of $12.8\%$ in 2010 to $6.4\%$ in 2015, it remains above the 2006 low of $5\%$ and higher than that of non-Hispanic workers [6]. This is further illustrated in the graph ![The graph shows the unemployment rate for Hispanics is consistently higher than non-Hispanics.](image7).

The Hispanic median household income was essentially unchanged since the Great Recession [5]. This is displayed in a graph comparing financial metrics for Hispanic households and all U.S. households over time ![The graph illustrates economic disparity.](image2). The Hispanic poverty rate, while down from its peak in 2010, remains above pre-recession levels [5].

In summary, while Latinos show increased optimism about their financial future, unemployment trends and income levels reveal a more complex economic reality, with persistent disparities compared to the general population.

Since the Great Recession, there's been a mix of progress and ongoing challenges in the economic well-being of the Hispanic community. While unemployment rates have decreased from a high of 12.8% in 2010 to 6.4% in 2015 [8], they still remain above the 5% low recorded in 2006 [8]. This is visually represented in the graph, which shows that Hispanic unemployment rates have consistently been higher than those of non-Hispanic workers from 2000 to 2015 ![The graph illustrates Hispanic unemployment rates are consistently higher than non-Hispanic rates from 2000 to 2015.](image8).

Despite these challenges, many Latinos express optimism about their financial futures [5]. A significant 72% believe their children will be better off financially than they are ![Most Latinos expect their children to be better off financially.](image1). Moreover, a Pew Research Center survey in December 2015 indicated that 35% of Hispanics felt that current economic conditions were good or excellent, which is higher than the 25% reported among White individuals [5]. Looking at financial situations before the recession reveals a striking difference: Latino views are more positive now than in 2004, while the general public's view is lower ![The graph compares the views of the general public and Hispanics from 2004 to 2015.](image6).

However, this optimism contrasts with the reality of stagnant median household income for Hispanics since the Great Recession, which was about $42,491 in 2014 [2]. This income level is essentially unchanged since the recession [2]. Additionally, the Hispanic poverty rate, at 23.6% in 2014, remains above pre-recession levels [2]. Hispanic households experienced the largest percentage decline in net worth through 2009 compared to other racial or ethnic groups, and unlike White households, their net worth continued to decline after the recession [2].  The graphs illustrate disparities in income, poverty rate and wealth between Hispanic households and all U.S. households ![The image visually demonstrates the economic disparity between Hispanic households and the broader U.S. population in terms of income, poverty rate, and wealth.](image2). These factors contribute to the income and wealth disparities observed between Hispanic and non-Hispanic populations.

While Latino perceptions of their economic well-being have increased [1], driven particularly by those with some college experience or more and those who are U.S.-born [9], federal data presents a mixed economic picture [8].

In summary, Hispanic unemployment rates remain higher than non-Hispanic rates, and despite optimism and increased economic perceptions among Latinos, income and wealth disparities persist due to factors like stagnant household income and higher poverty rates compared to pre-recession levels.

Hispanics' views of their financial situation are more positive now than in 2004 [1]. The line graph compares the attitudes of Hispanic individuals and the general public from 2004 to 2015, showing Hispanic opinions generally higher and increased more than the general public's ![The data indicates that Hispanic opinions or attitudes have remained generally higher and increased to a greater extent than the general public's over this time period on whatever topic the graph represents.](image3). However, many Hispanics say their family income is falling behind the cost of living [3]. From 2000 to 2015, the quarterly unemployment rates for Hispanics were consistently higher than non-Hispanic rates ![The graph shows fluctuations in unemployment rates, with Hispanic rates consistently higher than non-Hispanic rates throughout the period.](image4).

The trends for median household income, poverty rate and household wealth from 2000 to 2014 show significant economic disparities between Hispanic households and all U.S. households ![The image visually demonstrates the economic disparity between Hispanic households and the broader U.S. population in terms of income, poverty rate, and wealth.](image5). In 2014, the median income for Hispanic households was $42,500, lower than the $53,700 for all U.S. households. The Hispanic poverty rate in 2014 was 23.6%, much higher than the 14.8% for all U.S. households. In 2013, Hispanic households had a median wealth of $13,700, while all U.S. households had $81,400 [8]. Although the Hispanic unemployment rate has improved since the Great Recession, it remains above its 2006 low [7, 9]. Half of all Hispanic adults felt their income was falling behind in both 2014 and 2015 [10].

Compared to all U.S. households, Hispanic households face greater economic challenges in terms of higher unemployment rates, lower median income and wealth, and a higher poverty rate from 2000 to 2015.

Between 2008 and 2015, Latino groups experienced improvements in their perceptions of personal finances [8, 9]. Specifically, the percentage of Latinos who reported being in "excellent" or "good" financial shape increased by 17 percentage points, from 23% in 2008 to 40% in 2015 [10]. This positive shift contrasts with the general American population, where similar views remained relatively stable during the same period [10].

![The bar chart compares the percentage of various demographic groups' support or approval in 2008 and 2015, with the most significant increase among the 18-29 age group.](image6)

Notably, this improvement was seen across most major Latino demographic subgroups [6]. For instance, U.S.-born Hispanics saw a 17 percentage point increase, while foreign-born Hispanics experienced an 18 percentage point increase [6]. Similarly, both Latino men and women reported gains in their positive views of economic well-being [6]. The age group of 18 to 29 year olds reported a substantial increase in positive financial perceptions [2].  In 2015, 48% of Latinos in this age group felt they were in excellent or good financial shape, marking a 27 percentage point increase from 2008 [2].

![The bar chart compares perceptions of family income relative to cost of living among Hispanic, White, and Black adults in 2014 and 2015, showing similar views across groups.](image1)

However, not all indicators showed improvement.  Between 2014 and 2015, about half of all Hispanic adults felt their family income was falling behind the cost of living [4]. This perception remained relatively unchanged during that one-year period [4].  In 2015, 53% of Latinos felt their family income was not keeping pace with the cost of living [11].

Overall, between 2008 and 2015, Latino groups generally experienced improved perceptions of their personal financial situations, though concerns about family income relative to the cost of living persisted.

Device ownership among older adults differs notably from the population as a whole [2]. For example, as shown in ![This bar chart compares technology adoption rates between all adults and those aged 65 and over, showing lower adoption rates among seniors for cell phones, internet, and broadband.](image2), the percentage of adults 65+ using the internet (59%) and having broadband (47%) is significantly lower than that of all adults (86% and 70% respectively). Smartphone ownership is also lower among older adults [10].

However, seniors who do use the internet tend to incorporate it into their daily routines [1, 7]. Among seniors who use the internet, 71% go online every day or almost every day, and an additional 11% go online three to five times per week [1]. As illustrated in ![The bar graph shows that older internet users (65+) go online every day or almost every day (71%), with 11% going online 3-5 times per week.](image4), a substantial portion of older adults who are online access the internet frequently.

Internet usage and device ownership are generally lower among seniors compared to all adults, but those seniors who do use the internet tend to access it frequently as part of their daily life.

Device ownership among older adults differs from the general population [8, 11]. While smartphone ownership is common among the general public, only 18% of older adults own smartphones [7]. However, ownership of tablets and e-readers is as popular as smartphones among older adults [4].
![Older adults have a lower percentage of smartphone ownership, but a comparable percentage of tablet or e-reader ownership, when compared to all adults.](image6)
Notably, 59% of seniors report using the internet [6].  Among those who do use the internet, a large percentage makes it a regular habit [5]. A considerable portion of older adults need assistance learning to use new technologies [3].

The frequency of going online also varies among older adults, with 71% going online every day or almost every day [5].
![A higher percentage of younger age groups use the internet daily or almost daily compared to older adults, but a sizable percentage of seniors still use the internet frequently.](image3)

The trends of internet use among older adults has increased over time [6].
![Internet usage among adults aged 65+ has increased from 2000 to 2013, but still lags behind the general adult population.](image4)

Device ownership among older adults does not directly correlate with their internet usage patterns, as many own basic cell phones and tablets, and a significant percentage regularly use the internet.

Device ownership among older adults shows distinct patterns compared to the general population [10]. While smartphone ownership is more prevalent among all adults, tablets and e-readers are comparably popular among older adults [1]. A significant portion of seniors, specifically 27%, own either a tablet, an e-book reader, or both, surpassing the 18% who own smartphones [1].

![This image compares device ownership between all adults and seniors, highlighting the higher adoption of tablets/e-readers among seniors.](image1)

In terms of overall internet adoption, seniors lag behind the general adult population [11].  While 59% of seniors report using the internet, this is lower than the 86% of all U.S. adults who go online [11]. However, internet adoption among older adults has more than doubled over a five-year period, increasing from 35% in 2008 [2, 11]. The trend of internet adoption among seniors and all adults from 2000 to 2013 shows the increasing usage of the internet for both groups, but seniors still remain behind all adults [11].

![This image displays the trend of internet adoption over time, showing a growing gap between seniors and all adults.](image4)

Certain subgroups of seniors, such as those who are younger, more educated, and have higher incomes, exhibit internet and broadband adoption rates closer to those of the general public [8]. Conversely, older seniors (80+), those with lower incomes, and those without a college education tend to be less connected [12]. Only 37% of those 80 or older use the internet, and just 21% have a broadband connection at home [12].

![This image illustrates the disparities in internet usage and broadband adoption based on age, education, and income among seniors.](image6)

Device ownership and online activity differ notably between seniors and the general adult population, with seniors showing lower overall adoption rates but significant growth in recent years, particularly among certain subgroups.

Seniors' device ownership and social networking habits reveal interesting patterns. While a notable portion of older adults uses social networking sites, device ownership varies [1, 4].  About 27% of the total older adult population uses social networking sites [4]. Conversely,  59% of seniors report using the internet [8].

Notably, tablet and e-reader ownership is significant among seniors. A total of 27% of seniors own a tablet, an e-book reader, or both, whereas only 18% own a smartphone [7]. ![The image is a bar chart showing the percentage of ownership of smartphones and tablets or e-readers among two groups: all adults and people aged 65 and over.](image3)

This suggests that while internet usage is growing among seniors, social networking is adopted by a smaller segment [8, 9].  Specifically, 46% of online seniors use social networking sites [4].

The "Do not go online" segment is 41%, while 32% of seniors go online but do not use social networking, and 27% use social networking [4]. ![The image is a pie chart showing different categories of online usage.](image4)

Device ownership among seniors is also correlated with factors such as income and education [10].  Rates of internet and broadband adoption among seniors are increasing, yet remain below the national average [2].

In summary, while internet usage and device ownership are growing among seniors, social networking is utilized by a smaller, but significant, subset of this population, and tablets/e-readers are more popular than smartphones among seniors.

Internet usage among seniors is steadily increasing, but it still lags behind the general population [1, 12]. In 2013, 59% of seniors reported using the internet, compared to 86% of all U.S. adults [1].  However, these rates vary significantly within the senior population itself, particularly across different age brackets, levels of education, and household incomes, as illustrated in ![The table presents data on internet and broadband usage among seniors based on age, education, and income.](image6).

Specifically, internet use and broadband adoption tend to decline notably starting around age 75 [3, 5].  While 74% of those aged 65-69 go online, this figure drops to 37% for those 80 and older; similarly, broadband adoption decreases from 65% to 21% across these age groups, as shown in ![The table presents data on internet and broadband usage among seniors based on age, education, and income.](image6). These differences highlight a significant digital divide within the older adult population [2].

Education and income also play crucial roles in determining internet and broadband adoption rates among seniors [8].  Seniors with higher levels of education and income are more likely to use the internet and have broadband at home [7]. For instance, 90% of seniors with a household income of $75,000 or more go online, compared to only 39% of those with an income less than $30,000 [6].
