Broadband adoption follows a similar pattern, with 82% adoption among the higher income group and 25% among the lower income group, as illustrated in ![The table presents data on internet and broadband usage among seniors based on age, education, and income.](image6). Similarly, college graduates show significantly higher adoption rates compared to those with only a high school education [6].

In summary, internet and broadband adoption rates among older adults vary significantly based on age, education, and income, with younger, more educated, and higher-income seniors showing adoption rates closer to the general adult population.

Seniors' adoption of technology like the internet, broadband, cell phones, and smartphones is greatly influenced by their income and education levels [9]. For instance, a significant disparity exists in internet usage between seniors with higher versus lower incomes, as well as those with different levels of education [1]. ![The table shows the percentage of people aged 65 and older who go online and have broadband at home, categorized by age, education, and household income.](image3) As shown in the table, 90% of seniors with an annual household income of $75,000 or more use the internet, while only 39% of those earning less than $30,000 annually do so [8]. Similarly, broadband adoption is at 82% for the higher income group and only 25% for the lower income group [8].

 
Education also plays a key role, with 87% of seniors with a college degree using the internet compared to just 40% of those who have not attended college [6]. ![The table shows the percentage of people aged 65 and older who own cell phones and smartphones, broken down by age, education, and household income.](image8) Furthermore, cell phone ownership is more prevalent among higher-income and more educated seniors [12]. Smartphone adoption also follows this trend, with only 18% of seniors overall using smartphones, but this percentage increases with higher income and education levels [3].

In summary, seniors with higher incomes and more education are significantly more likely to adopt the internet, broadband, cell phones, and smartphones compared to their lower-income and less-educated counterparts.

Affluent and well-educated seniors are more likely to adopt the internet and broadband [1]. Seniors with higher education levels and incomes are more likely to use technology and have internet access ![The table shows the percentage of people aged 65 and older who go online and have broadband at home, categorized by age, education, and household income.](image1). For example, 90% of seniors with an annual income of $75,000 or more go online, and 82% have broadband at home, compared to 39% and 25%, respectively, for those with incomes less than $30,000 [1]. Similarly, 87% of college graduates aged 65+ go online, and 76% have broadband, compared to 40% and 27% of those with a high school education or less ![The table shows the percentage of people aged 65 and older who go online and have broadband at home, categorized by age, education, and household income.](image1).

While cell phone ownership is common among seniors, smartphone adoption is lower, especially among those in their mid-70s and older [5, 6, 7]. Just 18% of seniors are smartphone adopters, which is significantly below the national rate of 55% [10]. However, even among affluent seniors, smartphone ownership (42%) is lower than that of high-income adults in the general population (76%) [9]. Tablet and e-reader usage also follows this pattern, being more prevalent among college graduates and higher-income seniors [4]. For instance, seniors with a household income of $75,000 or more are about four times as likely to own these devices as those with an income less than $30,000 [4]. Although only 18% of adults aged 65+ own a smartphone, 27% own a tablet or e-reader ![The image is a bar chart showing the percentage of ownership of smartphones and tablets or e-readers among two groups: all adults and people aged 65 and over.](image5).

Internet and smartphone adoption rates among older adults vary significantly based on income and education, with higher rates among wealthier and more educated seniors, though these rates generally lag behind those of younger adults.

Seniors' adoption of technology varies significantly with their level of education. Seniors with more education are more likely to embrace internet and smartphone technologies [1].  Internet use and broadband adoption each drop off dramatically around age 75 [5].

![The table shows the percentage of people aged 65 and older who go online and have broadband at home, categorized by age, education, and household income.](image1)

As shown in the table, among seniors with a college degree, 87% use the internet and 76% have broadband at home, while those with a high school diploma or less have significantly lower adoption rates, with only 40% using the internet and 27% having broadband [image1].

![The table shows the percentage of people aged 65 and older who own cell phones and smartphones, broken down by age, education, and household income.](image8)

Similarly, smartphone ownership is significantly higher among seniors with more education.  Only 10% of seniors with a high school education or less own a smartphone, compared to 35% of college graduates [image8].

Therefore, seniors with higher educational attainment are more likely to use the internet and own smartphones compared to those with lower levels of education.

Seniors' adoption of technology varies significantly based on education and income. Seniors with a college degree show higher rates of both internet and broadband adoption [2].  Specifically, 87% of seniors with a college degree go online, and 76% are broadband adopters [2]. This contrasts sharply with seniors who have not attended college, where only 40% go online and 27% have broadband at home [12].  ![College graduates among seniors are more likely to use the internet and have broadband at home.](image2)

A similar trend is evident when considering income levels. Among seniors with an annual household income of $75,000 or more, 90% go online, and 82% have broadband at home [12]. In comparison, only 39% of seniors earning less than $30,000 annually go online, and just 25% have broadband at home [12].

Cell phone ownership is more widespread among seniors than smartphone adoption. Overall, 77% of seniors own cell phones, but only 18% own smartphones [11, image5]. Even among affluent seniors (those with an income of $75,000 or more), smartphone ownership is only 42%, which is lower than the smartphone ownership rate among high-income adults in the general population [9].  ![Higher income and education levels correlate with increased cell phone and smartphone ownership among seniors.](image5) Among seniors with a college degree, 35% own smartphones, while only 10% of seniors with a high school diploma or less own smartphones [image5]. Therefore, seniors with higher education and income levels are more likely to adopt both internet/broadband and cell phone/smartphone technologies, though smartphone adoption lags behind cell phone adoption across all demographics.

Seniors with a college degree are more likely to adopt broadband at home compared to those who have not attended college [9]. For example, 76% of seniors with a college degree are broadband adopters, while only 27% of seniors who have not attended college have broadband at home [9].
![College graduates are more likely to have broadband at home, with 76% adoption, compared to 27% among those who haven't attended college.](image5)
Furthermore, broadband adoption rates also vary significantly based on household income [9]. A substantial disparity exists, as 82% of seniors with an annual household income of $75,000 or more have broadband at home, compared to only 25% of those earning less than $30,000 annually [9].
![Seniors with higher household incomes exhibit greater broadband adoption, with 82% among those earning $75,000+ compared to 25% for those earning under $30,000.](image5)
In summary, broadband adoption at home among seniors is strongly influenced by both educational attainment and household income, with higher education and income levels correlating with higher adoption rates.

Among older adults, tablets and e-book readers are considered "elite" devices [1]. Tablet and e-book reader adoption is notably influenced by education levels [4]. Seniors who have graduated from college are about three times as likely to own both an e-book reader and a tablet compared to those who have not attended college [12]. For seniors with a high school education or less, only 12% use e-book readers, and 11% use tablets, while for college graduates, these figures rise to 30% and 31%, respectively ![A table showing the percentage of people aged 65 and older who use e-book readers and tablet computers, broken down by age, education, and household income.](image8).

In comparison, technology adoption trends across different age groups show a consistent increase from 2006 to 2013 ![The image is a line graph showing the percentage of people in different age groups using some form of technology or service over time, from 2006 to 2013.](image1). While younger demographics (18-29 and 30-49) have higher adoption rates, the 65+ group also shows growth, albeit from a lower starting point. As of 2013, about 46% of seniors were using some form of technology or service [image1]. Overall, 27% of seniors own a tablet, an e-book reader, or both [11].

Higher education levels significantly correlate with increased adoption of tablets and e-readers among seniors, mirroring broader trends of technology adoption across different age groups, where younger individuals tend to have higher adoption rates.

Educational attainment significantly shapes perceptions of workforce technologies [10]. College graduates are more likely to view technology as a positive force that enhances their work and career prospects, whereas those with less education are less inclined to share this positive view [1, 2].

Compared to workers with only a high school diploma or less, college graduates are more likely to say that technology has made their work more interesting and has increased their opportunities for career advancement [2]. ![Individuals with higher education levels are more likely to feel that their education made their work more interesting and increased their opportunities for advancement.](image7) For instance, a notable difference exists in the perception of office productivity tools, like word processing or spreadsheet software, where 90% of college graduates see a positive impact compared to only 45% of those with a high school diploma or less [12]. ![The chart shows the perceived impact of various technologies on different educational groups.](image3)

Regarding future technologies, such as driverless vehicles, there's widespread awareness and anticipation of their adoption [6, 8]. A large majority of Americans are aware of the development of driverless vehicles, and roughly two-thirds anticipate that most vehicles on the road will be driverless within the next half-century [8]. ![The image shows the expectation of when driverless cars will become common.](image1)

Educational attainment significantly influences how individuals perceive the impact of workforce technologies on their careers, and there is widespread anticipation for the development and adoption of automation technologies like driverless vehicles.

Workers hold diverse opinions regarding the influence of technologies on their jobs [3, 6, 10, 11]. Generally, they express more positive views than negative ones [2, 5]. However, these views vary significantly depending on the level of education [4, 8].

![Individuals with higher education levels tend to view technology as making their work more interesting and increasing opportunities for advancement.](image1)

Workers with higher education levels tend to view technology as making their work more interesting and increasing opportunities for advancement, as evidenced by the bar chart, which shows that 64% of college graduates felt that technology made their work more interesting, compared to only 38% of those with a high school diploma or less [1, 9]. Similarly, 53% of college graduates felt that technology increased their opportunities for advancement, while only 32% of those with a high school diploma or less agreed [9].

![The bar chart shows that individuals with higher educational attainment generally have more positive views on the impact of various technologies in the workplace.](image5)

The positive impact of technologies like word processing software, smartphones, and email is perceived differently across educational levels. A substantial 90% of college graduates see word processing software as having a positive impact, compared to just 45% of those with a high school diploma or less [9]. Similar trends are observed for smartphones (76% vs. 54%) and email or social media (72% vs. 45%) [9]. In fact, nearly a quarter (24%) of workers with only a high school diploma believe that none of these technologies have had a positive impact on their careers, while this figure is only 2% for college graduates [9].

![The bar chart illustrates the varying expectations among Americans regarding the timeline for driverless vehicle adoption.](image4)

Looking forward, many Americans anticipate the increased adoption of automation technologies like driverless vehicles [1]. A large portion of the public (66%) believes that most vehicles will be driverless within the next half-century, with 9% predicting this will happen within the next 10 years [1].

In summary, perceptions of workforce technologies vary significantly based on education level, with higher education generally correlating with more positive views, and many expect driverless cars to become commonplace in the coming decades.

Many Americans foresee substantial progress in automation technologies, with driverless vehicles as a prime example [1]. A significant majority, roughly two-thirds, anticipates that driverless vehicles will be common within the next half-century [1]. ![Most Americans expect driverless vehicles will be on the road in the next 50 years](image8). However, when it comes to current workforce technologies, U.S. workers express diverse views [8].

While a notable share of workers acknowledges the positive impact of technologies like word processing software (70%), smartphones (67%), and email (60%) on their careers [8], opinions vary across different educational groups.  Workers generally express more positive views on the impact of technology on their careers [3]. Roughly half of workers (53%) feel that technology in general has made their work more interesting [12]. ![A little over half of workers said technology has made their work more interesting](image3).

Interestingly, the benefits of these tools are most likely to accrue to workers with high levels of formal educational attainment [5]. For instance, a substantial majority of college graduates perceive word processing software as having a positive impact, whereas less than half of those with a high school education or less share this view ![Those with more education are more likely to view technology as having a positive impact](image2).

In conclusion, while there's considerable anticipation and some optimism about future automation like driverless vehicles, current experiences with workforce technologies reveal mixed feelings and disparities based on education levels among U.S. workers.

Workers' views on technology in the workplace vary significantly depending on their level of education [10]. Those with higher education levels generally express more positive opinions about how technology impacts their careers [3, 5].

![Workers with higher education are more likely to find their work more interesting and see increased career opportunities because of technology](image1)

College graduates are more likely to report that technology has made their work more interesting and has increased their opportunities for career advancement compared to those with only a high school diploma or less [8].  For instance, 64% of college graduates feel that technology has made their work more interesting, while only 38% of those with a high school diploma or less share this view [8]. Similarly, 53% of college graduates believe that technology has increased their career opportunities, compared to just 32% of those with a high school diploma or less [8].  This divide is also evident when evaluating specific technologies; a notable 45-percentage point difference exists between college graduates and those with high school diplomas or less who feel that office productivity tools have positively impacted them [1].

![College graduates are far more likely to view technologies like word processing and smartphones as having a positive impact on their jobs](image4)

Workers with higher education levels have more positive views of workplace technology, leading to increased opportunities and more interesting work.

Workers with higher levels of education generally have more positive views regarding how technology impacts their careers [7]. College graduates are more likely to report that technology has made their work more interesting and increased their opportunities for career advancement compared to those with a high school diploma or less [12].

![The chart illustrates how different education levels affect work factors, showing those with higher education are more likely to find their work interesting and have increased opportunities for advancement.](image1)

Specifically, a survey found that 64% of college graduates believe technology has made their work more interesting, compared to only 38% of those with a high school diploma or less [12].  Similarly, 53% of college graduates feel that technology has increased their career advancement opportunities, while only 32% of high school graduates or those with less education share this view [12]. These figures highlight the significant disparities in how different educational groups perceive the impact of technology on their professional lives [5].  The differences in perception are also evident when considering specific technologies such as word processing software, smartphones, and email [11]. A substantial percentage of workers with only a high school education believe that technology has not impacted their careers in any meaningful way [3].  In fact, nearly one-quarter of workers with a high school diploma or less say that none of the six technologies listed in the survey had a positive impact on their jobs or careers [6].

Workers with higher educational attainment view technology as a more positive force in making work more interesting and providing opportunities for advancement.

Workers with higher education levels generally have more positive views on how technology impacts their careers [8, 9]. College graduates are more likely to report that technology has made their work more interesting and increased their opportunities for career advancement compared to those with high school diplomas or less [10].

![Workers with higher education find technology makes their work more interesting and increases opportunities](image1)

Specifically, 64% of college graduates find that technology has made their work more interesting, compared to only 38% of those with a high school diploma or less [10].  Similarly, 53% of college graduates believe technology has increased their career opportunities, while only 32% of those with a high school education feel the same [10].  This divide is further emphasized by the fact that nearly a quarter (24%) of workers with only a high school diploma believe that none of the measured technologies have positively impacted their jobs, compared to just 2% of college graduates [1].

![Workers with higher education levels tend to view technologies more positively than workers with lower education levels](image7)

Workers with higher education levels perceive technology as having a more positive impact on their job opportunities and interest in their work.

Americans who are more familiar with the idea of machines taking over human jobs are more likely to find the concept realistic and express enthusiasm, but they also express substantial concerns [6].  For example, 48% of those who have "Heard a lot" think the concept seems extremely realistic, compared to only 4% of those who have "Heard nothing" ![The image is a horizontal bar chart showing the percentages of people with different levels of awareness who find the concept of machines taking over jobs extremely realistic.](image1).

Even with increased enthusiasm among those with high awareness, worry remains consistent across all awareness levels [11].  Specifically, 76% of those who have "Heard a lot" about the concept express worry, which is comparable to the 72% of those who have "Heard a little" and 69% of those who have "Heard nothing" [5]. This suggests that greater familiarity does not necessarily alleviate concerns about widespread automation.

Despite varying levels of awareness and familiarity, Americans generally anticipate more negative than positive outcomes from widespread automation [7]. A significant majority, 76%, expect much greater economic inequality, and 64% anticipate that people will struggle to find meaningful activities [4]. ![The bar chart illustrates that 76% of respondents believe automation will likely worsen inequality between rich and poor.](image6). Only a small fraction, 25%, believe the economy will create new, well-paying jobs for humans [9, 12].

In summary, Americans' increased awareness of automation leads to greater realism and enthusiasm, but not less worry, as they anticipate mainly negative outcomes like increased inequality and difficulty finding purpose.

Democrats are more inclined than Republicans to favor a universal income and a national service program if automation leads to job displacement [1, 7]. ![The bar chart illustrates support for various policies among Democrats and Republicans, highlighting differences in opinion regarding guaranteed basic income and national service programs.](image6) However, a substantial majority across party lines agrees that machines should primarily handle dangerous or unhealthy jobs [1]. Overall, there's notable support for limiting the number of jobs that businesses can replace with machines, with $60\%$ of Democrats and $54\%$ of Republicans agreeing on this point [1, 2].

Americans strongly support limiting robots and computers to tasks that are dangerous or unhealthy [3, 10, 11]. ![The bar chart shows that 47% of respondents strongly favor and 38% favor limiting machines to dangerous jobs.](image1) Specifically, $85\%$ of Americans favor policies that restrict robots and computers to performing jobs that are dangerous or unhealthy for humans [3]. Even if automation displaces workers, Democrats are more likely to believe the government should provide support, even if it means higher taxes [5]. However, limiting machines to dangerous and unhealthy jobs has broad support across the political spectrum [12].

In general, there is strong public support for limiting machines to dangerous or unhealthy jobs, and while Democrats and Republicans differ on certain policies like universal basic income and national service programs, they show similar levels of support for limiting job replacement by machines.

Political affiliations and education levels significantly shape opinions on government obligations to displaced workers and limits on automation. Attitudes toward the government’s role in caring for workers displaced by automation are strongly divided along partisan lines [4]. A majority of Democrats (65%) believe the government should provide support, even if it requires raising taxes, while a nearly identical share of Republicans (68%) feels individuals should be responsible for their own financial well-being, even with widespread job automation [4]. ![This bar chart shows that Democrats are more in favor of a guaranteed basic income and national service program, while opinions are closer regarding limiting machines to dangerous jobs and paying extra for human interaction.](image6)

Educational attainment also plays a role, particularly regarding limits on job automation [6].  Those with lower education levels are more supportive of limiting the number of jobs businesses can replace with machines [6]. Specifically, 70% of those with a high school diploma or less support such limits, compared to only 41% of those with a four-year college degree [6]. ![This bar chart highlights the opinions on government obligations and automation limits, broken down by education and political affiliation.](image8)

In summary, political affiliation and education level are key factors influencing opinions on government obligations to displaced workers and the extent to which businesses should be limited in automating jobs.

Americans are divided along political lines regarding policies related to automation and job displacement [2]. Democrats are more inclined to support government interventions, such as guaranteed income and national service programs, in response to job losses from automation [7, 4]. For example, 77% of Democrats favor a universal basic income, compared to only 38% of Republicans [4, 9]. Similarly, 66% of Democrats support a national service program, while only 46% of Republicans do [4, 9]. These differences are highlighted in ![This bar chart compares policy support between Democrats and Republicans.](image6).

However, there is more bipartisan agreement on certain issues, such as limiting machines to dangerous or unhealthy jobs [9]. Specifically, a large majority of both Democrats (85%) and Republicans (86%) support this policy. Similarly, opinions on limiting the number of jobs businesses can replace with machines are relatively aligned, with 60% of Democrats and 54% of Republicans supporting such limits [9, 11]. ![This bar chart shows public opinion on various policies related to automation, broken down by level of support.](image7)

Regarding the responsibility for displaced workers, opinions diverge sharply along partisan lines. A majority of Democrats (65%) believe the government has an obligation to care for workers displaced by automation, even if it means higher taxes, while a nearly identical share of Republicans (68%) feel that individuals should be responsible for their own financial well-being [3]. This divide is visually represented in ![This bar chart illustrates opinions on government vs. individual responsibility for displaced workers, broken down by education and political affiliation.](image1), showing the stark contrast between Democratic and Republican viewpoints.

Political affiliations significantly influence American views on policies addressing workforce automation and job displacement, with Democrats generally favoring government intervention and Republicans emphasizing individual responsibility.

Workers have mixed opinions about how technology has impacted their jobs [11]. For workers who have experienced automation in the form of job loss or reduced pay, there can be strong negative views about technology's impact on their careers [1]. In fact, 46% of these workers believe technology has decreased their opportunities, and 57% anticipate their jobs being mostly done by machines, which is double the rate of other workers [1].

![The image is a bar chart showing the percentage of U.S. adults in different age groups who either lost a job or had their pay or hours reduced.](image4)

Younger adults (ages 18-24) are more likely to have been personally impacted by workforce automation [3].

![The image is a bar chart comparing the perceived benefits of education level in terms of making work more interesting and increasing opportunities for advancement.](image5)

In contrast, individuals with higher education levels generally have more positive views of workplace technologies [4]. College graduates are more likely to say technology has made their work more interesting (64% vs. 38%) and increased career opportunities (53% vs. 32%) [2, 5]. Workers lacking a college education are much less likely to express positive attitudes toward technology [10].  Just 38% of workers with a high school diploma or less believe technology has made their jobs more interesting [12].

Attitudes toward workforce automation and technology's impact differ significantly among age groups and education levels, with younger, less-educated workers more likely to report negative experiences.

Workers hold diverse opinions regarding the influence of technology on their jobs and careers [7, 8]. A large percentage of workers acknowledge the positive effects of technologies like word processing software (70%), smartphones (67%), and email or social media (60%) [8]. ![The bar chart illustrates how technologies like word processing, smartphones and social media have a positive impact.](image6)

However, these perceptions vary significantly based on education level [1, 6]. Those with higher education levels are more likely to view technology as a positive force, enhancing their work and career prospects [1, 9]. College graduates, for instance, are more inclined to agree that technology has made their work more interesting (64% vs. 38%) and increased opportunities for career advancement (53% vs. 32%) compared to those with only a high school diploma [9]. ![The bar chart illustrates that people with higher education are more likely to say tech has increased opportunities and made their jobs more interesting.](image1)

Conversely, workers without a college education are less likely to express positive attitudes toward workforce technologies [11]. Just 38% of workers with a high school diploma or less feel that technology has made their jobs more interesting, and only 32% believe it has increased career advancement opportunities [10].

Therefore, perceptions of workforce automation and technology's impact differ significantly, with education level being a key factor influencing these views.

Workers have varied perspectives on how technology impacts their jobs and careers [2, 4]. While many workers hold positive views, a significant portion find technology damaging or neutral to their career prospects [4]. Roughly half of workers (53%) feel that technology in general has made their work more interesting ![A bar graph shows that 53% of workers feel that technology has made their work more interesting, while 12% find it less interesting](image1), while 46% feel that technology has increased their opportunities for career advancement ![A bar chart shows that 46% of workers believe technology has increased their career opportunities, 13% think it has decreased them, and 40% see no impact](image4).

However, these perceptions differ significantly based on education level [1, 5].  Workers with college degrees are substantially more likely to report positive impacts from technology on their jobs or careers [8]. For instance, 64% of college graduates find that technology has made their work more interesting, compared to only 38% of those with a high school diploma or less [5].  Similarly, 53% of college graduates believe technology has increased their career advancement opportunities, while only 32% of those with a high school diploma or less agree [5].

![This image shows that higher education levels correlate with a greater likelihood of perceiving technology as having made work more interesting and increasing career opportunities.](image5)

Specific technologies like word processing software, smartphones, and email have generally been viewed positively by workers [10].  However, workers with college degrees are more likely than those without to view each of these technologies as having a positive impact [8].

In summary, higher education levels correlate with more positive perceptions of technology's impact on job interest and career advancement opportunities, and specific technologies are generally viewed positively, with more educated workers reporting greater benefits.

Social media platforms elicit a range of emotional responses, with amusement being the most common [5].  A significant 88% of users report encountering content that makes them feel amused, with 44% frequently experiencing this emotion [5]. However, negative emotions such as anger are also prevalent, affecting 25% of users frequently [2].

![The bar chart shows how frequently social media users encounter different emotions; amusement is the most frequent.](image7)

Younger adults are more likely to experience amusement, loneliness, and depression frequently compared to older adults [6, 7, 8]. Specifically, younger adults are twice as likely to encounter amusing content (54%) as they are angry content (27%) [6]. Conversely, older adults experience amusement (30%) and anger (24%) at more comparable rates [6, 7].

![This chart compares the frequency of different emotions experienced by various age groups on social media, showing amusement is more common among younger adults, while anger is relatively consistent across age groups.](image8)

While amusement is a commonly felt emotion, users frequently encounter posts that are overly dramatic or exaggerated (58%) and posts where people make accusations or start arguments without having all the facts (59%) [11]. This suggests that while social media can be a source of amusement, it also exposes users to negative behaviors and content [3].

In summary, social media elicits a spectrum of emotions, with amusement being the most frequently experienced, and younger adults tend to experience stronger emotions, both positive and negative, compared to older adults.

Younger adults are more likely to report feeling amused, lonely, and depressed on social media compared to older adults [1]. For example, a significantly larger share of younger adults report frequently feeling amused by content on social media, while older adults encounter amusing and angry content with similar frequency [4].
![Younger adults are more likely to feel amused, angry, connected, inspired, depressed and lonely than older adults](image5)
Younger adults (18-29) are more likely to encounter content that makes them feel lonely compared to older adults [6]. In contrast, older adults are less likely to be frequently amused, with similar percentages feeling amused and angry [6]. The most common types of content that social media users frequently encounter include posts that are overly dramatic or exaggerated and people making accusations or starting arguments without all the facts [12].
![Social media users frequently see posts that are overly dramatic](image1)
These differing emotional experiences may relate to the types of content various age groups engage with and their perceptions of online interactions [2].

In summary, younger adults experience a wider range of intense emotions such as amusement, loneliness, and depression more frequently on social media, while frequently encountering dramatic and argumentative content.

Social media users' emotional experiences vary across age groups [7].  Younger users (18-29) report feeling amused, but also lonely and depressed more often than older adults [5].
![Younger adults are more likely to feel lonely and depressed from social media content, while older adults are more likely to be amused or angry.](image3)
The largest share of users, $88\%$, report seeing content that makes them feel amused, with $44\%$ frequently experiencing amusement [6].  However, negative emotions like anger are also prevalent, with $25\%$ of users frequently feeling angry [7]. Political affiliation also plays a role, as conservative Republicans ($31\%$) and liberal Democrats ($27\%$) are more likely to feel angry compared to their moderate counterparts [2].

![A larger percentage of men find others being mean or bullying, and being deceptive in social media , while a larger percentage of women find others being kind or supportive, and being point out inaccurate info in social media.](image6)

In terms of behaviors, most social media users frequently encounter drama, exaggeration [3, 10], and arguments based on incomplete information [3, 10, 5]. Most users see an equal mix of kind and bullying behaviors [4, 12]. Men are more likely than women to perceive deceptive behavior [9], while women are slightly more inclined to see acts of kindness and support [12]. Despite these differences, the majority of both men and women observe a balance between supportive and bullying behaviors [12] and also deceptiveness and attempts to correct misinformation [9].

Overall, social media's emotional impact and behavioral observations differ across age and gender, with frequent exposure to drama and arguments.

Social media users encounter a mix of positive and negative behaviors, with about half (54%) seeing an equal mix of kindness and bullying [3]. However, experiences can vary, with some users seeing more kind behavior (21%) and others more bullying (24%) [3]. Men are slightly more likely than women to encounter mean or bullying behavior online, with 29% of men reporting this compared to 19% of women [9]. Conversely, women are slightly more likely to see kind or supportive behavior [9]. However, most men (52%) and women (56%) report seeing an equal mix of both [9].

![The bar chart compares the percentage of men and women who perceive different types of online behavior, such as meanness/bullying, kindness/support, deception, and pointing out inaccuracies.](image7)

Younger social media users report experiencing a wider array of emotions, including amusement, loneliness, and depression, more frequently than older users [4].  A significant percentage of users frequently see overly dramatic posts (58%) and people making accusations without having all the facts (59%) [8].

![This bar chart shows the frequency with which social media users encounter different types of content, such as overly dramatic posts and people making accusations without full information.](image3)

Different age groups also vary in how frequently they feel certain emotions; for instance, younger users are more likely to feel amused, but also more likely to feel lonely and depressed [4]. The acceptability of using personal data also varies across age groups and depends on the context, as depicted in the image showing attitudes toward different types of data use by social media sites [7].

![The image displays a chart comparing the acceptability of social media sites using user data for various purposes across different age groups.](image2)

Overall, social media users frequently encounter overly dramatic content and argumentative behavior, and experiences can vary by age and gender [8].

Men are more inclined than women to perceive bullying and deception on social media platforms, while women are slightly more likely to observe acts of kindness and support [2, 10]. Specifically, 29% of men report frequently seeing mean or bullying content, compared to only 19% of women [2]. Conversely, women are slightly more likely to see people being kind or supportive; however, the majority of both men (52%) and women (56%) believe they see an equal mix of supportive and bullying behavior ![The chart compares how men and women perceive different online behaviors, showing that men are more likely to see bullying and deception, while women are more likely to see kindness and support.](image4).

Regarding deceptive behavior, 24% of men report more often seeing people being deceptive compared to 13% of women [12]. Despite these differences, most men (58%) and women (67%) feel they see an equal mix of deceptiveness and efforts to correct misinformation [12]. Simultaneously, a large percentage of social media users frequently encounter overly dramatic or exaggerated posts [1]. A notable 58% of users report frequently seeing posts that are overly dramatic or exaggerated, and 59% frequently see people making accusations or starting arguments without all the facts ![This image shows the frequency of encountering different types of content on social media, highlighting that dramatic or exaggerated posts and accusations without facts are commonly seen.](image2).

Men are more likely to see bullying and deception, while women are more likely to see kindness, though both genders frequently encounter drama and exaggeration.

Men are almost twice as likely as women to perceive deception on social media [1]. As the bar chart illustrates, 24% of men report frequently seeing deceptive content compared to only 13% of women ![Men are more likely than women to see deceptive behavior online](image4).

However, most men (58%) and women (67%) perceive an equal mix of deception and attempts to correct misinformation [1].  A slightly larger percentage of men (29%) report frequently seeing mean or bullying behavior compared to women (19%), while women are slightly more inclined to observe acts of kindness and support; nevertheless, the majority of both men (52%) and women (56%) perceive an equal mix of supportive and bullying behaviors [3].

These differences suggest tailored approaches may be necessary. Social media platforms could adjust content moderation and recommendation algorithms to cater to these varying perceptions [7]. For example, given that men are more likely to perceive deception, platforms might prioritize fact-checking initiatives more prominently for male users. Conversely, given women are slightly more inclined to observe acts of kindness and support, positive content might be highlighted for female users.

Social media usage comfort also depends on data usage [12]. Majorities across age groups find it acceptable for social media sites to use their data to show them local events, but not for political campaign ads [2]. Acceptance of data usage for recommendations varies with age, older users being less accepting of recommendations for new contacts [5]. The bar chart shows the opinions on acceptability of recommendations to users; older users are much less accepting of social media sites using their data to recommend other people they might know ![Older users show less acceptance for data usage in recommending contacts](image8).

Perceptions of social media content and behavior differ between men and women, necessitating tailored approaches in content moderation and recommendations.

User comfort levels with social media data usage are heavily influenced by context [5]. Notably, there are differences across age groups regarding the acceptability of data use. For example, a larger percentage of users aged 18-49 find it acceptable for social media to use their data to recommend connections, compared to those 65 and older [1, 4].

![Older users are less accepting of social media sites using their data for recommending connections](image3)

Younger social media users are more likely to find it acceptable for platforms to use their data to suggest people they may want to know [1]. In contrast, older users are much less accepting of social media sites using their data for various reasons outside of recommending local events [4]. The use of data to recommend events is generally acceptable across age groups [8]. A significant majority oppose platforms changing their sites in certain ways for some users but not others [3].

![Users show varied acceptance for how social media sites use their data, with higher acceptance for event recommendations and lower acceptance for political messaging](image2)

A majority of social media users are comfortable with their data being used to recommend events [6, 10, 12]. Most users find it unacceptable for social media platforms to use their data to deliver political campaign messages [2, 8]. Overall comfort depends on the how and why their data are being used [6, 9].

In summary, user comfort with social media data practices varies significantly across age groups and depends heavily on the specific purpose for which the data is used.

The public's views on the fairness and effectiveness of automated programs vary, influencing their overall acceptability [6]. In general, opinions on fairness and effectiveness tend to align, but the "personal finance score" is a notable exception [1].

![The image is a chart comparing the perceived effectiveness and fairness of different automated systems.](image8)

While a significant percentage believe the personal finance score algorithm is effective at identifying good customers (54%), only a smaller fraction consider it fair to consumers (32%) [8, 9]. This discrepancy is highlighted in contrast to the criminal risk score, where similar percentages find it effective (49%), but a larger share believe it's fair (50%) [8]. This difference suggests context matters significantly [6]. People are more skeptical about systems like personal finance scores and video job interviews, with only around one-third considering them fair to applicants or consumers [2, 4].

![The image is a chart depicting people's opinions on the acceptability of different automated processes.](image2)

The lack of perceived fairness often stems from concerns that these systems remove the human element from important decisions and fail to capture the nuance of complex situations [7]. As a result, a majority find the use of personal finance scores (68%) and computer-aided video job analysis (67%) unacceptable [2].

The public is more willing to accept algorithms in certain contexts. For instance, although views on the effectiveness of personal finance scores and criminal risk scores are similar, the latter is generally considered fairer [8]. However, broad concerns about fairness persist across algorithmic decision-making examples [5]. Many Americans (58%) believe computer programs will always reflect some human bias, despite some (40%) thinking they can be designed to be bias-free [6].

![The image is a bar chart comparing perceptions of different age groups on whether programs can make decisions without human bias versus whether they will always reflect the bias of designers.](image4)

These differences imply that public trust in automated systems is highly dependent on the perceived fairness and the specific application, with skepticism arising when systems are seen as unfair, lacking human nuance, or biased.

The public holds a critical view of the ethical standards of top Trump administration officials, with only $39\%$ rating them as excellent or good, while $59\%$ consider them not good or poor [5]. These views are notably lower than those for previous administrations dating back to Reagan [5].

![Views of Trump administration officials ethical standards are lower than those of officials in the previous five administrations](image1)

There's a significant partisan divide on this issue, where $76\%$ of Republicans and Republican leaners view the ethical standards of top Trump officials as excellent or good, while $90\%$ of Democrats and Democratic leaners consider them not good or poor [1]. This divergence highlights the polarized perceptions of Trump's administration [1].

![Democrats are more likely to distrust Trump's statements compared to previous presidents](image4)

A majority of the public, $58\%$, expresses less trust in what Trump says compared to previous presidents [3].  Distrust in Trump's statements has increased since April 2017 [8].  Specifically, $94\%$ of Democrats and Democratic leaners trust Trump less than previous presidents [7].

![Republicans are more likely to say Trump's economic policies have improved conditions](image2)

In summary, compared to previous presidents, Trump's ethical standards and trustworthiness are perceived more negatively by the public, particularly among Democrats, while Republicans generally hold more positive views.

Public perception indicates a majority believes Trump should release his tax returns [10]. This view is strongly held by Democrats, with nearly all (91%) supporting the release, while a smaller percentage of Republicans (32%) agree [10].

Moreover, a majority (58%) trusts Trump's statements less than those of previous presidents, a sentiment that has increased since April 2017 [6, 12]. Republicans tend to trust Trump more (58%) compared to past presidents, but Democrats overwhelmingly trust him less (94%) ![Democrats overwhelmingly trust Trump less than past presidents](image6).

Views on the ethical standards of Trump administration officials are also notably low compared to previous administrations [1, 4]. There's a significant partisan divide, with most Republicans viewing the ethical standards positively and most Democrats viewing them negatively [9]. Even regarding the economy, where Trump receives relatively positive marks, partisan divisions are pronounced, with Republicans largely viewing his policies as improvements and Democrats growing more negative ![Partisan views on Trump's economic policies](image5).

Overall, the public places less trust in Trump's statements, and views on his administration's ethical standards are low compared to previous presidents, with partisan divisions significantly shaping these perceptions.

Views on Trump's presidency are significantly divided along partisan lines, particularly regarding ethical standards and long-term success [3, 7].  Republicans generally hold more positive views compared to Democrats. For example, a large majority of Republicans believe that Trump's economic policies have improved conditions in the country, while most Democrats disagree ![Republicans largely believe Trump's economic policies improved conditions, while Democrats mostly think they made things worse.](image4).

The ethical standards of Trump administration officials are viewed more negatively than those of previous administrations, with a significant partisan divide; Republicans are more likely to view them favorably, while Democrats overwhelmingly view them as poor [3, 10].

There is a notable difference in how partisans view Trump's potential for long-term success compared to previous presidents.  A large share of Democrats think that Trump will be an unsuccessful president [4]. Republicans' views of Trump's long-term outlook are similar to how they viewed Bush in his third year [8].

Compared to views on previous presidents at similar points in their terms, fewer people say it is "too early to tell" whether Trump will be successful, indicating more firm opinions [2, 5].  Democrats are far more likely to believe Trump will be unsuccessful compared to how they viewed Bush or Clinton at comparable points ![A comparison of perceptions of presidential success among party affiliates shows Trump has the biggest difference between Republicans and Democrats.](image8).

While there are low expectations for Trump’s legacy overall, a notable portion of the public sees a positive impact on the economy [5, 11]. Since 2017, the share of people saying Trump's economic policies have not had much of an effect has decreased [9]. Views on Trump's economic policies have become more polarized since 2017, with Republicans becoming more positive and Democrats more negative ![Views on the impacts of economic policies are divided by political affiliation.](image4).

In summary, perceptions of Trump's presidency are highly polarized, with Republicans generally holding more positive views on his ethical standards, economic impact, and long-term success compared to Democrats, and these views are often more entrenched than those held about previous presidents.

Perceptions of Trump's presidency are notably more polarized compared to those of Obama, Bush, and Clinton at similar points in their administrations. Democrats and those leaning towards the Democratic party overwhelmingly believed that Trump would be an unsuccessful president, with  $80\%$ holding this view [1].  This contrasts sharply with Republican opinions, where $65\%$ of Republicans and Republican-leaning independents anticipated Trump would be successful ![Republicans are more optimistic about Trump's success compared to Democrats](image2).

Compared to his predecessors, fewer people said it was "too early to tell" whether Trump would be successful [5]. For example, at the start of Barack Obama’s third year in office, nearly half of the public   $(47\%)$   said it was too early to tell whether he would be successful [3].  This suggests a quicker crystallization of opinions regarding Trump's presidency.

Looking at the long-term outlook,  $47\%$ of Americans believed Trump would be an unsuccessful president, a higher share than what was observed for Obama and George W. Bush at comparable times [5, 11]. This negative sentiment is further reflected in trust levels, where distrust in Trump compared to other presidents had increased since April 2017 [12].

Partisan views on Trump’s economic policies have become more divided, with Republicans increasingly viewing them positively and Democrats becoming more negative ![Republicans are more likely to say that Trump's economic policies improved conditions in the country](image1). Public confidence in Trump's handling of his business interests also reveals partisan divides, with Republicans being more confident than Democrats that he kept his business separate from his presidential decision-making ![Republicans have more confidence in Trump keeping his business interests separate from his decision-making](image4).

Overall, perceptions of Trump's presidency are characterized by strong partisan divides and a quicker formation of opinions compared to his predecessors.

Views on President Trump's potential success are sharply divided along partisan lines, mirroring the divide in confidence regarding the Mueller investigation. Democrats overwhelmingly believe Trump will be unsuccessful, while Republicans generally anticipate his success. Specifically, a large majority of Democrats and those who lean Democratic, 80%, anticipate that Trump's presidency will ultimately be unsuccessful [9]. ![Democrats are far more likely to view President Trump as unsuccessful compared to Republicans.](image6)

Conversely, approximately two-thirds of Republicans and those who lean Republican, 65%, express confidence that Trump will achieve long-term success as president [12]. This partisan split is also evident when compared to views of past presidents; for instance, Republicans' current views on Trump's long-term outlook closely resemble their views on Bush during his third year in office [4].
This partisan divide extends to confidence in the Mueller investigation; a notable 72% of Democrats and those leaning Democratic express at least some level of confidence in the fairness of Mueller's investigation [10]. In stark contrast, a significant portion of Republicans and those leaning Republican, 58%, indicate that they have little to no confidence in Mueller [10]. Overall, 55% of the public expresses confidence in the fairness of Robert Mueller’s investigation [1]. ![Democrats tend to have much more confidence in the fairness of Mueller's investigation compared to Republicans.](image7)

In summary, perceptions of Trump's potential success as president and confidence in the Mueller investigation are heavily influenced by political affiliation, with Republicans and Democrats holding sharply contrasting views.

Perceptions of job availability and economic conditions often diverge along partisan lines, with Republicans generally holding more positive views than Democrats [3, 6]. Currently, a significant majority of Republicans $(71\%)$ believe there are plenty of jobs available, compared to a smaller majority of Democrats $(53\%)$ [1, 6]. This partisan gap has been a consistent trend, as noted in October 2017, when $58\%$ of Republicans and $47\%$ of Democrats felt jobs were widely available [6].

Views on personal finances also reflect this divide, with Republicans more likely to rate their financial situation as excellent or good compared to Democrats [3]. Furthermore, Republicans are more optimistic about their financial future, with a larger percentage expecting their finances to improve over the next year [7].

![The graph illustrates the divergence in perceptions of job availability between Republicans and Democrats from 2000 to 2019.](image3)

The divergence in perceptions is further illustrated when considering whether family incomes are keeping up with the cost of living, highlighting demographic and partisan differences [11]. Despite a majority of adults acknowledging the availability of jobs, the perception of "good jobs" being readily accessible is less widespread [12]. ![This survey chart shows a partisan divide in perceptions of job availability, especially regarding 'good jobs'.](image4) Republicans tend to view the availability of good jobs more favorably than Democrats.

Over time, there have been fluctuations in these perceptions, influenced by political periods such as the Bush, Obama, and Trump administrations, as shown in the trends from 2001 to 2019 [2]. The public’s view of local job availability is currently among the most positive in decades, but these positive views are not uniformly shared across party lines [4, 5, 8].

![The line graph shows how perceptions of job availability have shifted from 2001 to 2019, with a notable rise in the belief that "plenty of jobs are available".](image7)

In summary, perceptions of economic conditions and job availability differ significantly between Republicans and Democrats, with Republicans generally holding more optimistic views, a trend that has persisted and evolved over the past two decades.

Currently, a significant partisan gap exists in views regarding job availability [6]. Republicans are more likely than Democrats to view jobs as widely available, with $71\%$ of Republicans expressing this view compared to $53\%$ of Democrats [4, 6]. This divide is also evident when considering "good jobs," where Republicans are more likely to perceive their availability compared to Democrats ![Republicans are more optimistic about the availability of jobs than Democrats.](image5).

Over time, perceptions of job availability have shifted within both parties [5, 11]. As shown in the provided graph, positive views of job availability have generally risen since October 2017, tracking with more positive views of the economy [11]. The graph highlights the diverging trends between Republicans and Democrats in their assessment of job availability from 2001 to 2019 ![Republicans have shown a greater increase in positive job market perceptions compared to Democrats over time.](image1). Although views of local job opportunities are among the most positive in decades for both parties [2, 3], this partisan gap remains a notable feature of the economic landscape [8, 9].  The percentage of people who think that Wall Street impacts the American economy in different ways varies significantly based on political affiliation ![Republicans are more inclined to believe that Wall Street helps the American economy, whereas Democrats are more skeptical.](image8).

Perceptions of job availability differ significantly between Republicans and Democrats, with Republicans holding more positive views, and these perceptions have evolved over time, generally trending positively but maintaining a partisan divide.

Public opinions on Wall Street's impact on the economy are significantly divided along partisan lines [2]. A majority of Republicans believe Wall Street helps the economy, while Democrats are more divided on this issue ![The chart shows that Republicans are more likely to believe Wall Street helps the economy, while Democrats are more divided](image1). Specifically, 55% of Republicans think Wall Street helps the economy more than it hurts, compared to 31% who think it hurts [2]. In contrast, Democrats are almost equally split, with 46% believing Wall Street hurts the economy and 41% thinking it helps [7].

Public satisfaction with national conditions has seen fluctuations over the years, with a general trend of dissatisfaction [3, 5]. Currently, about 70% of Americans are dissatisfied with the way things are going in the country [5]. The graph illustrates the trend of public opinion on the state of the nation from 1990 to 2019 ![The graph shows that dissatisfaction is increasing while satisfaction is decreasing](image5). This dissatisfaction has increased, with only 26% expressing satisfaction, a drop from 33% in September [3]. Republican satisfaction has also decreased, marking the lowest GOP satisfaction rating since late 2017 [1]. Democrat dissatisfaction is notably high, with only 8% expressing satisfaction [8].

These divided opinions on Wall Street and the broader dissatisfaction with the state of the nation highlight the partisan polarization and general discontent among Americans.

Public satisfaction with the state of the nation has seen a noticeable shift, with dissatisfaction higher than it has been in the past year [11]. In fact, seven-in-ten Americans express dissatisfaction [5]. The "Dissatisfied" line increased from 54% to 70% between 1990 and 2019, while the "Satisfied" line decreased from 41% to 26% ![The graph depicts a decline in satisfaction and an increase in dissatisfaction with the country's direction from 1990 to 2019.](image5).

Views on Wall Street's impact are divided along partisan lines [6]. In early 2019, 55% of Republicans felt Wall Street helped the economy, while 31% thought it hurt; Democrats were more split, with 46% seeing harm and 41% seeing benefit [6, 7]. ![This chart illustrates that Republicans are more likely to believe Wall Street helps the economy, while Democrats are more inclined to think it hurts.](image8). This polarization has increased since 2017, with Republicans becoming more supportive of Trump's economic policies and Democrats becoming more negative [8]. Currently, Republican satisfaction is at its lowest in a year [2]. While a majority of Americans now say there are plenty of jobs available [9], this hasn't translated into higher satisfaction [4].

Overall, public satisfaction has declined, and partisan divisions on economic issues like Wall Street's impact have become more pronounced.

Public confidence in Trump varies significantly between Republicans and Democrats across different areas. For instance, 89% of Republicans are confident in Trump’s ability to negotiate favorable trade agreements, compared to just 19% of Democrats [6]. This stark contrast is evident in the ability to negotiate favorable trade agreements with other countries, where Republicans show much higher confidence levels compared to Democrats ![Republicans and Democrats have different level of confidence in various issues](image7).

Trump's ability to make good appointments to federal courts shows a similar partisan divide. While 64% of Republicans are very confident and 24% are somewhat confident, only 2% of Democrats are very confident and 10% are somewhat confident [7]. This mirrors the general trend where Republicans express greater confidence in Trump's abilities across various domains, including economic policy and handling international crises [2, 7]. However, when it comes to Trump’s handling of matters related to investigations, 92% of Democrats express a lack of confidence [4].

Looking at overall confidence levels, about half of the public expresses confidence in Trump's ability to negotiate favorable trade agreements (51%) and make good decisions about economic policy (49%) [7]. However, confidence diminishes when it comes to managing the executive branch effectively, using military force wisely, or handling international crises [9].  In fact, only 45% are at least somewhat confident in his ability to make good appointments to the federal courts [11].

![Confidence in Trump to handle governmental tasks is varied](image3).

The public’s confidence in Trump to handle key issues is mixed, with economic conditions faring better than his ability to work effectively with Congress [1]. Republican confidence in Trump is generally high across most issues, but they rate him lower on his ability to work with Congress [3, 8]. These differences highlight the partisan divide and the varying levels of confidence the public has in Trump's capabilities depending on the specific task or issue.

Public confidence in Trump's ability to make good appointments to the federal courts is significantly higher among Republicans than Democrats, reflecting a broader trend of partisan divergence in confidence levels across various governmental tasks.

The public is largely not confident in Trump's ability to separate his business interests from his presidential decisions [8]. Specifically, only 28% are very confident, and 13% are somewhat confident, while a majority are either not too (16%) or not at all (41%) confident [8]. ![The chart shows the percentage of U.S. adults expressing different levels of confidence in Trump's ability to separate his business interests, broken down by political affiliation and ideology.](image8)

Republicans generally express more confidence, with 55% being very confident and 23% somewhat confident [5]. However, this confidence varies within the Republican party, as 66% of conservative Republicans are very confident, compared to 39% of moderate and liberal Republicans [5]. Democrats are deeply skeptical, with 69% not at all confident and 20% not too confident [6]. Liberal Democrats are particularly skeptical, with 83% not at all confident [6].

Regarding Trump's responsibility to release his tax returns, 64% of the public believes he has this responsibility [9]. However, Republicans largely disagree, with only 32% believing he has this responsibility and 64% saying he does not [10]. ![The image shows the percentage of U.S. adults who believe Trump has a responsibility to release his tax returns, broken down by political affiliation, for January 2019 and January 2018.](image2)

Confidence levels in Trump's ability to separate business interests and views on his tax returns responsibility are deeply divided along party lines.

Partisan divides significantly influence perceptions of the COVID-19 response and trust in institutions, with Republicans and Democrats holding divergent views on many aspects of the pandemic [8, 10]. Democrats are more likely than Republicans to view the federal government's response as inadequate and believe that lifting COVID-19 restrictions occurred too quickly [2]. ![Democrats are more likely to think that not enough people social distancing and wearing masks](image8) This difference in opinion extends to whether reducing coronavirus infections is more effective for economic recovery, with Democrats more strongly agreeing regardless of their county's death rate from COVID-19 [2].

There's a notable partisan gap in assessing the U.S. response compared to other wealthy nations; most Democrats consider it less effective, while Republicans are more divided, though still only a minority believe the U.S. response has been more effective [8]. ![Most people think the U.S. response to the coronavirus is less effective than other wealthy countries](image7) Views on public health officials' response, such as those at the CDC, also diverge sharply along party lines [9].

While positive views of hospitals' response to COVID-19 tend to cross party lines [3], confidence in other institutions and leaders varies significantly.  Democrats generally express more confidence in public health officials and state and local government officials compared to Republicans [5]. ![Democrats have more confidence in public health officials such as those at the CDC](image1) The partisan divide is particularly stark when it comes to opinions of Donald Trump's handling of the situation, with Democrats overwhelmingly disapproving and Republicans largely approving [4].

These partisan divides overshadow geographic differences in opinions about the pandemic, indicating that political affiliation is a stronger predictor of views than the actual impact of COVID-19 in a person's area [6, 10].

Partisan divides significantly shape perceptions of COVID-19 response effectiveness and trust in institutions, with Democrats and Republicans holding contrasting views on various aspects of the pandemic and the actors involved.

There are significant partisan differences in the views of how public health officials and Donald Trump responded to the coronavirus outbreak, with opinions diverging notably along political lines [7, 8]. Republicans' positive ratings of public health officials have declined sharply, while Democrats' views have remained relatively stable ![Democrats generally have more confidence in public health officials than Republicans](image8). This is evidenced by the drop in positive ratings among Republicans for public health officials, decreasing from $84\%$ to $53\%$ [2, 10]. Conversely, Democrats' views have remained largely consistent (approximately $74\%$ in March and $72\%$ currently) [2, 10].

The perception of Donald Trump's response to the outbreak also varies significantly between Democrats and Republicans [5].  A large majority of Democrats rate Trump's response as "poor," and this sentiment has increased substantially since March [3]. The share of Democrats who rate Trump’s response as “poor” has risen steeply since then; $56\%$ of Democrats in March to $82\%$ [3].  ![Most Democrats disapprove of Donald Trump's performance as president](image6). Overall, Donald Trump receives lower ratings for his response to the outbreak compared to March [5]. ![Approval ratings for Donald Trump have decreased overall from March to August](image2).

In summary, partisan divides significantly influence the evaluation of the COVID-19 response by public health officials and Donald Trump, with Republicans showing decreased confidence in public health officials and Democrats expressing increased disapproval of Trump's handling of the crisis.

Public health officials' approval ratings have decreased significantly from March to August, with a notable partisan divide [4]. Overall approval for public health officials dropped from 79% to 63% [4].

Views of Donald Trump's handling of his job as president also show a divide, with 77% of Republicans and Republican leaners approving, compared to only 5% of Democrats and Democratic leaners [2].

There's a significant partisan divide in how public health officials are viewed, as illustrated in the chart ![Public health officials' approval ratings have decreased from March to August, with a notable partisan divide](image7). Democrats' views remained relatively stable (74% in March, 72% currently), while Republicans' positive ratings plummeted by 31 points (from 84% to 53%) [1]. Positive assessments of Donald Trump dealing with the coronavirus have fallen since the early weeks of the outbreak in March [10]. Currently, 37% say he is doing an excellent or good job [10].

The partisan differences in views of public health officials are substantial [7]. 72% of Democrats and those leaning towards the party say public health officials are responding well to the outbreak [7]. This contrasts sharply with the Republican view, where approval has significantly declined [6].
![Public health officials are viewed differently based on political affiliation](image5).

In conclusion, approval ratings for both public health officials and Donald Trump have declined since March, with a significant partisan divide in these changes, particularly among Republicans.

Americans hold different views on the effectiveness of state governments versus Donald Trump's handling of the COVID-19 pandemic. Perceptions of state and local government officials' responses have declined since March [8]. While 56% view state officials' response as excellent or good, and 60% hold this view of local officials [8], a large portion of U.S. adults, 69%, express greater concern that state governments have been lifting restrictions on public activity too quickly ![Respondents believe restrictions are being lifted too quickly.](image1).

Conversely, views of Trump's response are largely negative, with nearly half of Americans (48%) rating his response as "poor" [3, 9]. The inadequacy of the federal government's response is seen as a major reason for the continued outbreak by a majority of Democrats (82%) [4].
![The chart categorizes each reason as a major, minor, or not a reason for the spread, using different shades of color.](image4)
This is in contrast to Republicans, only 21% of whom share this view [4].  Furthermore, when comparing the U.S. response to other wealthy nations, 87% of Democrats and Democratic leaners consider the U.S. response less effective [5]. Even among Republicans, only a small fraction (22%) believe the U.S. has been more effective [5, 11].

In summary, Americans are more critical of Trump's COVID-19 response compared to state governments, with concerns about his effectiveness and the federal government's role being major points of contention.

Americans hold broadly negative assessments of the overall U.S. response to the coronavirus outbreak, including increasingly critical evaluations of how Donald Trump, state and local government officials, and public health officials have dealt with the crisis [4]. Positive evaluations of state and local government officials' responses to the coronavirus outbreak have declined since March [1]. Views of the performance of public health officials have also decreased, with 63% now saying they are doing an excellent or good job, down from 79% in March [5].

When compared to other wealthy countries, 62% of Americans say the U.S. response to the coronavirus outbreak has been less effective ![62% of the respondents believe the U.S. response to the coronavirus has been less effective.](image1).

There are divided opinions about which level of government is primarily responsible for policies to limit the spread of COVID-19 [8].
However, the public continues to express overwhelmingly positive views of the response of local hospitals and medical centers [1].  ![Hospitals and medical centers in your area are rated as excellent or good by 88% of the respondents.](image2)

A major reason for the continued coronavirus outbreak, according to three-quarters of Americans, is that too few people are abiding by guidelines about social distancing and mask-wearing [2]. Political affiliation influences these opinions, with Democrats more likely than Republicans to say that an inadequate federal government response and the quick lifting of COVID-19 restrictions are major reasons for the continued outbreak [11]. ![Democrats are more likely than Republicans to attribute the continued outbreak to an inadequate federal response.](image3)

Americans perceive the effectiveness in handling COVID-19 differently among elected officials and public health officials, with declining positive evaluations for both, and the continued outbreak is attributed mainly to non-adherence to guidelines and, to a lesser extent, the lifting of restrictions.

Political affiliations significantly shape perceptions of government responsibility and the reasons behind the ongoing COVID-19 outbreak [9]. Democrats are more inclined to fault the federal government's response, while Republicans often point to state and local governments [8]. A majority of Democrats (82%) consider the federal government's response as a major reason for the continued outbreak, compared to only 21% of Republicans [11].

![Democrats are much more likely than Republicans to see the federal government response as a major reason for the continued outbreak.](image2)

This divide extends to views on lifting COVID-19 restrictions too quickly, with 82% of Democrats versus 31% of Republicans viewing it as a major reason for the continued outbreak [11]. Overall, the public is almost evenly split on whether state (51%) or federal (48%) governments should be primarily responsible for limiting the spread [8]. This difference highlights fundamental disagreements between Republicans and Democrats regarding the handling of the pandemic [9].

![The majority of every group except conservatives believe restrictions were lifted too quickly.](image7)

Insufficient social distancing and mask-wearing are widely recognized as major factors contributing to the continued outbreak, with 75% of the public agreeing [12]. However, even on this point, there is a partisan divide: 89% of Democrats and Democratic-leaning independents see insufficient adherence to social distancing and mask-wearing as a major reason, compared to 57% of Republicans and GOP leaners [1].

![Most people agree that insufficient social distancing and mask-wearing is a major reason.](image1)

Partisan divides significantly influence perceptions of government responsibility and the primary reasons for the ongoing COVID-19 outbreak, with Democrats more critical of the federal response and Republicans emphasizing individual adherence to guidelines.

Political affiliation significantly shapes perceptions regarding the primary drivers behind the ongoing COVID-19 outbreak. Democrats are far more inclined than Republicans to view the federal government's response as inadequate and to believe that the premature lifting of COVID-19 restrictions has prolonged the outbreak [1, 8].  Specifically, 82% of Democrats consider both an inadequate federal response and the rapid easing of restrictions as major factors, whereas only 21% and 31% of Republicans share these views, respectively [1].

![The image is a chart that compares opinions on several issues related to COVID-19, segmented by political affiliation: Republicans/Lean Republican (in red) and Democrats/Lean Democrat (in blue).](image2)

Conversely, Republicans are more inclined to attribute the continuation of the outbreak to the perceived limitations in controlling its spread, although this view is held by a minority within both parties [2]. A significant partisan divide exists concerning the role of social distancing and mask-wearing, with 89% of Democrats believing that insufficient adherence to these guidelines is a major reason for the continued outbreak, compared to 57% of Republicans [6]. Despite this difference, "not enough people following social distancing and mask-wearing guidelines" is the most commonly cited reason across both political affiliations [5, 6, 7].  Overall, a majority of Americans recognize insufficient social distancing as a key factor in the continued spread of COVID-19 [3, 4].

![The image is a bar chart showing reasons for the spread of an issue, with different levels of perceived importance.](image7)

Political affiliations correlate strongly with differing views on the significance of government response and adherence to public health guidelines as factors influencing the continuation of the COVID-19 outbreak.

Democrats are far more critical of the federal government's response to COVID-19 than Republicans [11]. A significant 82% of Democrats consider the federal response inadequate, while only 21% of Republicans share this view [11]. This partisan divide highlights fundamentally different assessments of the government's role during the pandemic.

![The bar chart illustrates how opinions on COVID-related issues differ between Republicans and Democrats.](image7)

Major reasons for the continuation of the outbreak, cited by the general public, include insufficient social distancing and mask-wearing, with 75% viewing it as a major reason [3, 4].
