SWEMs compared to CNN/LSTM models exhibit comparable or even superior performance in the majority of cases [4, 6]. For topic prediction tasks, SWEM models show stronger performance relative to both LSTM and CNN compositional architectures by leveraging both the average and max-pooling features from word embeddings [1]. SWEM-concat model outperforms even a 29-layer deep CNN model when predicting topics [1]. On the ontology classification problem (DBpedia dataset), SWEM exhibits comparable or even superior results, relative to CNN or LSTM models [1].

However, on sentiment analysis datasets, SWEM yields inferior accuracies compared with CNN/LSTM compositional functions, as seen in document categorization [5]. This is further supported by the observation that SWEM is generally less effective at extracting representations from short sentences than from long documents, possibly because word-order features are more important for shorter text sequences [5].  `Makes me wonder why everyone likes`(image1).

SWEM demonstrates the best results compared with those with CNN or the LSTM encoder on most of the datasets considered (except WikiQA) [12]. With only 120K parameters, SWEM-max achieves a test accuracy of 83.8%, which is very competitive among state-of-the-art sentence encoding-based models [12].

The model complexity in text classification problems is measured using subspace training [11]. SWEM shows significantly higher accuracy than CNN for a large range of low subspace dimension, indicating that SWEM is more parameter-efficient to get a decent solution [10]. ![SWEM demonstrates higher accuracy with lower subspace dimensions.](image5) In achieving a performance threshold of 80% testing accuracy, SWEM exhibits a lower  $d_{\mathrm{int}}$  than CNN on the AG News dataset [10].

Hierarchical pooling is more suitable than average/max pooling for Chinese text classification, by taking spatial information into account [7].

SWEM models, particularly SWEM-concat, often outperform CNN and LSTM models on topic prediction and ontology classification tasks, while CNN and LSTM tend to perform better on sentiment analysis; SWEM also demonstrates parameter efficiency, achieving competitive accuracy with lower subspace dimensions.

The performance of aspect-level sentiment classification models benefits from document-level knowledge, with improvements observed across various datasets when different components are included or when the percentage of document-level training examples is varied [2, 4, 7].  Specifically, pretraining and multi-task learning are effective methods for transferring knowledge from the document level to the aspect level [11].

Experiments varying the percentage of document-level training examples for PRET  $^+$  MULT show stable improvements in accuracies across all datasets, and stable improvements in macro-F1 scores for datasets D1 and D2 ![The plot shows that as the percentage of document-level training examples increases, both accuracy and Macro-F1 scores generally improve for all four datasets (D1, D2, D3, D4).](image3). There are sharp increases in the macro-F1 scores of D3 and D4 when changing the percentage from 0 to 0.4, which could be related to their unbalanced nature [4]. Datasets D3 and D4 have a small number of neutral examples in their test sets, meaning even a small prediction difference can largely affect the recall on the neutral class and, consequently, the macro-F1 scores [3]. The unbalanced label distribution of D3 and D4 means that sentiment information is not adequately captured by GloVe word embeddings, and the embeddings trained by aspect-level classification may not effectively capture the true semantics of relevant opinion words; the transfer of the embedding layer can greatly help in this case [8].

Ablation tests on PRET indicate that transfer is helpful in all settings, with improvements observed even when only one layer is transferred ![The table shows the performance of different model settings on four datasets (D1, D2, D3, D4) in terms of accuracy (Acc.) and macro-F1 score (Macro-F1), when different components of the model are included or excluded.](image4). Overall, the LSTM and embedding layer transfers are more useful than the output layer, as the output layer is typically more task-specific [8].

In summary, incorporating document-level knowledge, especially through pretraining and multi-task learning, enhances the performance of aspect-level sentiment classification models, with the LSTM and embedding layers playing a crucial role and performance being influenced by the percentage of document-level training examples and the balance of sentiment labels in the datasets.

The TRADE model demonstrates state-of-the-art performance on the MultiWOZ dataset, particularly in scenarios involving multiple domains [9]. TRADE achieves a joint goal accuracy of 48.62% on the full MultiWOZ dataset [2]. It obtains 96.92% on slot accuracy, showcasing its capability to accurately predict dialogue states [11].

The TRADE model's performance in zero-shot settings varies across different domains, as seen in the provided data. The table compares "Trained Single" and "Zero-Shot" performance across five categories [image7]. The "Trained Single" method consistently outperforms the "Zero-Shot" approach in both Joint and Slot metrics for all categories [image7]. Notably, in the Taxi domain, TRADE achieves a joint accuracy of 60.58% in the zero-shot setting [2], which is highlighted as a significant result [image7].

When focusing on individual domains, TRADE's performance varies.  For instance, in a domain expansion experiment, a base model is pre-trained on four domains, and a held-out domain is reserved for fine-tuning [7].  The results indicate that fine-tuning from the base model generally achieves better results on the new domain compared to training from scratch [6].  This is further supported by the error analysis of zero-shot dialogue state tracking, which shows the model's ability to transfer knowledge across domains [image2]. The model successfully transfers knowledge to track slots like people, area, price range, and day from other domains during training in Hotel domain [image2]. TRADE achieves the highest joint scores for both the full MultiWOZ dataset and the restaurant subset [image3].

TRADE exhibits robust performance across various domains in the MultiWOZ dataset and demonstrates promising zero-shot capabilities, particularly in certain domains like taxi.

The TRADE model demonstrates state-of-the-art performance on the MultiWOZ dataset, achieving $48.62\%$ joint goal accuracy and $96.92\%$ slot accuracy [10, 11]. As shown in ![The TRADE model achieves the highest joint scores for both the full MultiWOZ dataset and the restaurant subset, indicating its superior performance in understanding and predicting dialogue states across these tasks.](image7), TRADE outperforms other models like MDBT, GLAD and GCE in joint accuracy on both the full MultiWOZ dataset and the restaurant subset [10].

Furthermore, TRADE's effectiveness is highlighted in domain expansion scenarios. Fine-tuning TRADE on a new domain, even with limited data ($1\%$), yields better results than training from scratch [3, 5]. For instance, fine-tuning with only $1\%$ of training data in a new domain achieves $59.83\%$ joint accuracy, surpassing the $44.24\%$ achieved by training solely on that domain [3]. The table ![The table presents results from an evaluation of a Base Model (BM) trained on four domains and its fine-tuning on a new domain.](image5) illustrates the results achieved by training from scratch using $1\%$ of the new domain data and also shows the performance of TRADE on the four pre-trained domains and the new domain [5].

When fine-tuning, the choice of strategy is also critical.  Using Gradient Episodic Memory (GEM) helps to mitigate catastrophic forgetting, maintaining higher performance on the original domains compared to naive fine-tuning [5, 9]. For example, joint accuracy on the hotel domain only drops from $58.98\%$ to $53.54\%$ with GEM, while naive fine-tuning causes a more significant drop to $36.08\%$ [9].

In summary, the TRADE model excels in both multi-domain dialogue state tracking and domain adaptation, surpassing other models in joint and slot accuracy and demonstrating effective transfer learning capabilities.

Fine-tuning TRADE with GEM maintains high performance, demonstrating better knowledge retention on original domains compared to naive fine-tuning [1]. For instance, in the hotel domain, joint accuracy only drops by 5.44% with GEM, while naive fine-tuning causes a 22.9% drop [1].

```
![The table displays performance scores for various models on the MultiWOZ dataset, highlighting TRADE's effectiveness in both full and restaurant-specific dialogues.](image5)
```

GEM outperforms Naive and EWC fine-tuning in mitigating catastrophic forgetting on the four domains when expanding to a new domain [5, 10]. Furthermore, fine-tuning from a base model often achieves better results on the new domain compared to training from scratch [5]. For example, TRADE achieves 59.83% joint accuracy after fine-tuning with only 1% of Train domain data, which outperforms training the Train domain from scratch that achieves 44.24% with the same amount of data [6].

```
![The table shows that GEM outperforms naive and EWC fine-tuning in overcoming catastrophic forgetting when expanding the model to new domains.](image3)
```

Learning to maintain tracking ability from learned domains improves performance in new domains [4].  GEM obtains 34.73% joint accuracy on the attraction domain, while naive fine-tuning achieves only 29.39% [4]. Additionally, knowledge about slots like people, area, price range, and day can be successfully transferred across domains, enhancing zero-shot performance [2]. The cosine similarity heatmap shows relationships between slot embeddings, which may influence transfer learning effectiveness; slots with high similarity could benefit from shared knowledge, improving tracking performance [image8].

```
![The heatmap visualizes cosine similarity between different slot embeddings, showing how some slots share semantic similarities.](image8)
```

In adapting the model to new domain data, GEM outperforms naive and EWC fine-tuning strategies, and slot similarities enhance knowledge transfer and tracking performance.

The study evaluates gender bias in machine translation (MT) across different systems and languages [2, 3, 6]. The analysis reveals that commercial MT systems exhibit gender bias in their translations [2, 4, 6, 9].

The overall system accuracy is determined by the percentage of instances where the translation maintains the gender of the entity from the original English sentence [7]. The best performing model on each language often does not do much better than a random guess for the correct inflection [7]. An exception to this is the translation accuracies on German, where three out of four systems achieve their best performance, possibly due to its similarity to English [7].

The study uses metrics such as gender accuracy (Acc), the difference in performance between masculine and feminine scores (ΔG), and the difference in performance between pro-stereotypical and anti-stereotypical gender role assignments (ΔS) to measure gender bias [1]. Higher numbers in ΔG and ΔS indicate stronger biases [1].  All tested systems show a significant and consistently better performance when presented with pro-stereotypical assignments [11]. For example, ![Google Translate accuracies on stereotypical and non-stereotypical gender roles across languages.](image1) shows Google Translate's absolute accuracies on stereotypical and non-stereotypical gender roles across all tested languages [11].

The performance of different MT systems varies across languages, as shown in ![Accuracy and error metrics for translation services across languages.](image4). For example, Google Translate has a high accuracy score for French and Hebrew, while Microsoft Translator performs best with German [image4]. The ΔG and ΔS metrics also vary across languages and systems, indicating different levels of gender bias [image4].

Adding stereotypical gender adjectives can improve translation accuracy and reduce bias in some languages [5, 10]. For example, ![Original values, adjusted values after adding adjectives, and the difference between them for ES, RU, and UK.](image6) shows that adding adjectives improves performance in Spanish, Russian, and Ukrainian [5, 10]. This suggests that mixing signals can help correct profession bias [5]. For example, ![Examples of translation bias and gender issues in machine translation from English to Spanish and French.](image2) demonstrates how adding the adjective "pretty" can correct the translation of "baker" from male to female in Spanish [image2].

In summary, machine translation systems exhibit gender bias, with performance varying across languages and systems, and the addition of stereotypical adjectives can sometimes mitigate these biases.

Machine translation (MT) systems often exhibit gender bias, which can be influenced by stereotypical gender role assignments [4, 6]. When translating sentences, these systems perform better with stereotypical assignments (e.g., a female nurse) but show reduced accuracy with counter-stereotypical roles (e.g., a male receptionist) [2].

![The bar chart shows that the accuracy for stereotypical translations is consistently higher across all tested languages compared to non-stereotypical translations.](image4)

This difference in accuracy highlights a significant bias in how these systems process and translate gender-related information [2]. For example, in the translation from English to Spanish, if the English source sentence does not specify the gender of a doctor, a biased system might default to a stereotypical male assignment, altering the meaning if the context implies otherwise [7].

![This table demonstrates examples of translation bias and gender issues in machine translation from English to Spanish and French.](image5)

However, adjustments can be made to mitigate these biases. Adding gendered adjectives (e.g., "pretty doctor") can "correct" the profession bias by providing a stronger signal towards a specific gender [9].  Such adjustments improved performance in some languages, notably reducing bias in Spanish, Russian, and Ukrainian [9]. The sentence "The pretty doctor asked the nurse to help her in the operation" can guide the translation towards a female inflection [9].  The accuracies on Spanish, Russian, and Ukrainian improved when stereotypical gender adjectives were added [9].

![The table shows the original values, adjusted values, and the difference between them for each entity.](image7)

In conclusion, stereotype-based adjustments, like adding gendered adjectives, can improve gender bias accuracy in machine translation, but the effectiveness varies across different languages [9].

Different training and evaluation strategies significantly impact F1 scores, particularly in the context of multi-hop and single-hop question answering. Models trained on adversarial distractors show improved performance when evaluated on similar data. When models are trained on the adversarially selected distractors, they can recover most of their original accuracy [1, 4]. The original model's accuracy degrades significantly (drops to 40.73 F1), but the model trained on the adversarially selected distractors can recover most of its original accuracy (increases to 58.42 F1) [1]. Adversarial training enhances robustness, leading to better generalization on challenging datasets, as shown in the table ![The table shows a comparison of F1 scores for original and adversarial training data evaluated on original, adversarial, and adversarial + type datasets.](image8).

The type of distractors used during training influences the model's performance. For example, using adversarial distractors in training can mitigate the drop in accuracy observed with standard distractors [4]. When the same procedure is done on the training set and the model is re-trained, the accuracy increases to 60.10 F1 on the adversarial distractors [4]. Filtering distractors by entity type further affects performance, as seen in the decline in accuracy when the original model is tested on adversarially selected distractors with entity type filtering [1]. Type distractors can help to eliminate the entity type bias described in Section 4.1 [1].

The complexity of the question also plays a crucial role.  As seen in the image ![The table categorizes comparison questions into three types: Numerical, Logical, and String, each with example questions and operations.](image3), different types of questions, such as numerical, logical, and string-based comparisons, require different reasoning approaches. The percentage breakdown and corresponding F1 scores indicate varying levels of difficulty across these question types ![The table contains data showing the relationship between question types (multi-hop, context-dependent, single-hop), example questions, percentages, and F1 scores.](image1). Single-hop models often struggle with comparison questions, highlighting the need for multi-hop reasoning capabilities [7]. BERT achieves near chance accuracy on these types of questions [7]. Open-domain settings also pose challenges, largely due to the retrieval of relevant paragraphs [8].  Table 5 shows that the model achieves 39.12 F1 given 500 retrieved paragraphs, but achieves 53.12 F1 when additional two gold paragraphs are given, demonstrating the signiﬁcant effect of failure to retrieve gold paragraphs [8]. The table shows that providing the gold paragraph significantly boosts the F1 score ![The table displays the F1 scores for various settings: Distractor, Open-domain 10 Paragraphs, Open-domain 500 Paragraphs, and Open-domain 500 Paragraphs + Gold Paragraph.](image7).

Different training and evaluation strategies significantly impact F1 scores in both multi-hop and single-hop question answering, with adversarial training and careful consideration of question complexity being crucial factors.

The creation of an adversarial dataset for the Argument Reasoning Comprehension Task (ARCT) significantly impacts the performance of BERT models by addressing the issue of spurious statistical cues [1]. The original ARCT dataset contains statistical cues that BERT can exploit, leading to inflated performance metrics that do not accurately reflect argument comprehension [2].

To counter this, an adversarial dataset is created by negating the claim and inverting the label for each data point [8, 9]. This mirroring of statistical cues across labels eliminates the signals that BERT exploits in the original dataset. As shown in ![The table presents a comparison of the performance metrics for different BERT models, namely "BERT", "BERT (W)", "BERT (R, W)", and "BERT (C, W)", based on their test performance.](image3), BERT's performance drops significantly when trained and evaluated on the adversarial dataset [6]. Specifically, BERT's peak performance reduces to 53% [6].

![The table presents test performance metrics (Mean, Median, and Max) for different models and configurations.](image1)

The table contrasts the performance of BERT on the original dataset, where it achieves a peak performance of 77%, with its performance on the adversarial dataset [1, 6]. This drastic reduction in performance indicates that BERT's initial success was largely due to exploiting dataset-specific cues rather than genuine argument comprehension [10].

![The table presents a comparison between "Original" and "Adversarial" viewpoints concerning whether Google is a harmful monopoly.](image6)

The original ARCT data comes with a training set created similarly to the adversarial dataset [4]. Experiments using this training data have led to random accuracy, indicating that high similarity between data points may make the problem too difficult for simple models [4]. The application of this transformation to the entire dataset is necessary to obtain a more robust evaluation by eliminating spurious statistical cues over the labels [4]. The architecture of BERT models used for processing input data, where claims, reasons, and warrants are tokenized and input into the model, highlights the complexity of the model, but also its susceptibility to statistical cues [5].

By using the adversarial dataset, researchers can obtain a more accurate evaluation of argument comprehension capabilities, as it eliminates the misleading statistical cues present in the original dataset [3, 8].

The adversarial data setup reveals that BERT's high performance on the original ARCT dataset was primarily due to exploiting spurious statistical cues, rather than true argument comprehension [10].

The COMET model's performance varies based on the decoding method used, with greedy decoding showing the best results among automated methods, although still falling short of human-level performance [5]. For instance, greedy decoding achieves an average score of 77.53, whereas human validation scores 86.18, indicating a performance gap that highlights the continued superiority of human commonsense reasoning ![Greedy decoding performs best among automated methods but still does not reach the performance level of human validation.](image5).

Different amounts of training data significantly impact the quality and novelty of the knowledge produced by COMET [7]. Using only 1% of the training data diminishes the quality of generations, while increasing the training data to 10% or 50% improves performance [7]. Training with the full dataset yields the best results, particularly when combined with pre-trained weights ![The table shows how different percentages of training data impact model performance metrics like perplexity and BLEU scores.](image8). The model's ability to generate novel tuples, with a substantial percentage not present in the training set, demonstrates its capacity to extend knowledge graphs [2]. The quality of generated knowledge is high, as indicated by low perplexity scores and high classifier scores, further confirmed by human evaluations deeming a large portion of generated tuples as correct [1].

The effect of different generation policies on knowledge quality reveals that greedy decoding, despite its simplicity, approaches human performance with only a 10% relative performance gap compared to human evaluation [5]. Fine-tuning the model and using techniques like pre-training also lead to significant improvements in performance, highlighting the importance of leveraging pre-existing knowledge for commonsense reasoning [4]. The model's ability to generate novel and high-quality knowledge makes it a promising alternative to extractive methods for automatic commonsense KB completion [9]. COMET excels in generating more novel tuple objects compared to baseline models, showing consistent improvements across various relation types [8]. BLEU-2 results also confirm that COMET exceeds the performance of all baselines, achieving a substantial relative improvement [11]. Ultimately, COMET is able to generate novel knowledge that humans rate as high quality, approaching human performance for these resources [9].

In summary, the COMET model's performance is influenced by the decoding method, the amount of training data, and the use of pre-trained weights, with greedy decoding offering a strong automated approach and full training datasets yielding the best results, but human validation still outperforming automated methods in generating commonsense inferences.

COMET demonstrates high accuracy and novelty in generating commonsense knowledge, often approaching human-level performance [7]. The model's ability to generate novel tuples, a significant portion of which are not present in the training set, indicates its capacity to create new connections and expand knowledge graphs [1]. For instance, COMET can infer that "mango IsA fruit," even if the training set only contains "mango UsedFor salsa," showcasing its ability to generalize beyond explicit training data [10].

The graph illustrates that COMET maintains high classifier accuracy even as the edit distance from training tuples increases, indicating its robustness in generating novel and correct knowledge.

Furthermore, comparisons with other models highlight COMET's superior performance. As shown in the results, COMET achieves a high score (95.25) and closely approximates human performance (91.69) [11]. Ablation studies, such as those comparing COMET with and without pre-training, reveal the importance of pre-training on large language corpora for enhancing generalization [6].  ![The table presents performance metrics of two models, COMET and COMET (+ hierarchy meta-tokens)](image8). The table illustrates that while adding hierarchy meta-tokens can improve specific categories, the overall performance of COMET remains superior, highlighting the effectiveness of its core architecture. The relatively low perplexity scores also indicate high model confidence in its predictions [11].

COMET excels in generating high-quality and novel commonsense knowledge for ConceptNet, demonstrating its effectiveness in automatic knowledge base construction compared to other models.

The sensitivity and word error rate (WER) vary significantly between closed and open vocabulary models, depending on the backoff strategy employed. Open vocabulary models, such as char-only, word+char, and word-piece models, treat each unique combination of characters differently, making the pass-through version more sensitive than the background variant because it passes words as they are [6]. However, word-only models, which are closed vocabulary, render all out-of-vocabulary (OOV) character combinations identically, making pass-through less sensitive [6].

![The image consists of two scatter plots, each representing the relationship between sensitivity and word error rate (WER) for two types of models: word-only models (left plot) and char-only models (right plot).](image3)

Figure 2 visualizes the trade-off between WER and sensitivity, showing that a lower error rate often increases sensitivity [12]. The neutral backoff variant generally exhibits the lowest sensitivity because it maps UNK predictions to a fixed neutral word, reducing the number of unique outputs [3, 8].  The hybrid model architecture, combining background and foreground models, addresses rare and unseen words, impacting WER and sensitivity [4].

![The image illustrates a diagram representing a hybrid model combining two components: a "Background Model" and a "Foreground Model".](image1)

The background model backoff strategy generally achieves a lower WER but does not consistently translate to robustness in all settings [3, 10].  The pass-through strategy can be more sensitive, especially in open vocabulary models, as each unique character combination is considered differently [6]. In summary, closed vocabulary models generally have lower sensitivity, especially with neutral backoff, while open vocabulary models can have higher sensitivity, particularly with pass-through strategies; WER is often reduced by using background models, but this does not guarantee robustness [6, 8, 12].

Therefore, sensitivity and word error rate exhibit different behaviors based on vocabulary type and backoff strategy, with closed vocabularies and neutral backoff generally reducing sensitivity, while open vocabularies and pass-through strategies can increase it.

The BiDAF model generally outperforms the FastQA model across various datasets and test conditions, as evidenced by several performance metrics. ![The table shows the performance of different models, including BiDAF and FastQA, on the WikiHop and MedHop datasets under standard and gold chain conditions](image1). Both BiDAF and FastQA are extractive RC models that have shown robust performance across several datasets [11].

Specifically, in the standard test conditions on the WIKIHOP dataset, BiDAF achieves a test accuracy of 42.9 and a test* accuracy of 49.7, while FastQA scores 25.7 and 27.2, respectively. When masking is applied, BiDAF mask improves to 54.5 (test) and 59.8 (test*), and FastQA mask also increases to 35.8 (test) and 38.0 (test*) ![The table presents the performance results of BiDAF and FastQA models, with and without a "rem" modification, across different datasets and test conditions](image2).

![The table presents performance metrics for various models under "standard" and "masked" conditions, highlighting the performance of BiDAF and FastQA among others](image6). Furthermore, the BiDAF model shows a more significant ability to leverage cross-document information compared to FastQA [8]. The iterative latent interactions in the BiDAF architecture contribute to its increased importance in tasks where information is distributed across documents [5]. When only documents leading to the correct answer are used ("gold chain"), BiDAF's performance drastically improves, reaching up to 81.2%~/~85.7% on WIKIHOP in the masked setting, and 86.4%/89.8% on MEDHOP, further underscoring its effectiveness [12].

In summary, BiDAF generally exhibits superior performance compared to FastQA across different datasets and test conditions, demonstrating a greater capacity to integrate information from multiple documents.

The BiDAF model generally outperforms the FastQA model across both the WIKIHOP and MEDHOP datasets, as seen in the standard test conditions  ![The table shows results for BiDAF and FastQA models on WikiHop and MedHop datasets under standard and gold chain conditions.](image3).  BiDAF benefits from iterative conditioning across multiple layers, which helps integrate information from different locations in the document [2].

When only relevant documents are used (gold chain setup), both models improve significantly, especially on MEDHOP, with BiDAF achieving near-perfect scores in the masked setting.  ![The table presents the performance results of different models on two datasets, WIKIHOP and MEDHOP.](image1). This highlights that the models can identify the answer when presented with fewer irrelevant candidates [1].  However, the models' answer selection process is vulnerable to the introduction of unrelated, type-consistent documents [1].

In standard test conditions, BiDAF achieves 54.5% on WIKIHOP and 33.7% on MEDHOP, while FastQA scores 35.8% and 31.3%, respectively.  When answers are masked, BiDAF's performance improves on WIKIHOP but decreases on MEDHOP, indicating that the models can leverage the textual context of the candidate expressions [10].  The table showcases the performance metrics for different models evaluated under both standard and masked conditions, providing a comprehensive view of their effectiveness [4].

BiDAF generally demonstrates superior performance compared to FastQA on both WIKIHOP and MEDHOP datasets, particularly when dealing with relevant documents, but is sensitive to irrelevant information.

The RetNRef models enhance dialogue generation by leveraging both retrieval and generation methods, outperforming traditional Seq2Seq models and approaching human-like conversational statistics [1, 5]. The "Retrieve and Refine" model addresses the disadvantages of purely retrieval-based or generation-based approaches [5].

The RetNRef++ model particularly excels in mirroring human utterance statistics by utilizing more rare words and creating longer sentences, as it boosts the use of retrieved content which improves the diversity and engagingness of the responses [8].

![RetNRef++ makes the statistics much closer to human ones](image4)

While Seq2Seq models tend to produce short, common sentences, RetNRef models, especially RetNRef++, generate more complex and engaging responses [8]. The comparison of word overlap between retrieved and generated sentences shows that RetNRef++ effectively uses the retriever while also generating novel content [9].  The model strategically decides when to adopt the retrieved utterance and when to generate its own response [6].

However, RetNRef+ can sometimes make counterproductive changes, a problem addressed in RetNRef++ by copying the retrieved text exactly when word overlap is insignificant [2].  The models were evaluated against each other, with human annotators judging the responses [11].

![The table specifies the methods being compared in each evaluation.](image6)

Engagingness scores also reveal the superiority of RetNRef variants over Seq2Seq, demonstrating that integrating retrieval mechanisms into generation enhances the quality of dialogue [4].

![Engagingness scores superior to Seq2Seq for all RetNRef variants](image3)

RetNRef models enhance dialogue by using a combination of retrieval and generation, achieving more human-like word statistics and improved engagingness compared to traditional Seq2Seq models.

The YiSi metrics show high performance in system-level evaluation across multiple language pairs [3]. Specifically, YiSi-1 achieves the highest correlations and is rarely outperformed by other metrics [3].

Different evaluation metrics are used for assessing the quality and accuracy of translated text across various language pairs ![The table presents evaluation metrics for different language pairs in machine translation, focusing on human evaluation (DArr) and QE (Quality Estimation) as a metric.](image1). For system-level evaluation, metrics can achieve high Pearson correlation, even exceeding 0.95 for certain language pairs [11]. For example,  YiSi-1_srl  reaches .947 for Chinese-English and .936 for English-German [11].

YiSi-1 and its variations exhibit strong performance in direct assessment human evaluation of machine translation metrics across different language pairs ![The image shows a series of heatmaps representing system-level metric significance test results for direct assessment (DA) human evaluation of machine translation metrics.](image7).

In the WMT19 Metrics Task, several metrics demonstrated high correlations with human assessments in the newstest2019 dataset. For language pairs involving English, metrics like the YiSi series achieved the highest correlations in several language pairs [7].  Specifically, at the system-level, the best metrics reached over 0.95 Pearson correlation or better across several language pairs [4].

For language pairs not involving English, segment-level metric results are shown in Table 9 [2, 9].  Absolute Pearson correlation of out-of-English system-level metrics with DA human assessment in newstest2019 are shown in Table 6 [6, 8].

![This table compares the human evaluation and QE metrics for machine translation across language pairs like de-cs, de-fr, and fr-de.](image4)

The YiSi metrics are often not significantly outperformed by any other metrics, marking them as a "win" for almost all language pairs [7]. Evaluation metrics are important in determining translation quality [1].

![This table presents evaluation metrics and QE metrics for different language pairs in machine translation with human evaluation (DArr).](image1)

The YiSi series of metrics generally showed the highest correlation with human assessments for both language pairs involving English and those not involving English in the newstest2019 dataset.

The WMT19 Metrics Shared Task evaluated various metrics for machine translation, focusing on how well these metrics correlate with human assessments at both system and segment levels [7]. Significance tests were conducted to compare the performance of different metrics, and the results are visualized in heatmaps that indicate whether one metric significantly outperforms another.  The series of YiSi metrics achieve the highest correlations in several language pairs [8].

Across various language pairs, some metrics demonstrate consistent statistical significance. For segment-level evaluation, the performance of metrics for language pairs not involving English reveals that YiSi-1 often shows significant wins compared to other metrics, as shown in the green cells of the heatmap ![Yisi-1 shows the most significant wins across the metrics in each of the language pairs](image2).

When translating into and out of English, different metrics exhibit varying degrees of success.  Metrics such as BERTr, ESIM, and YiSi, which incorporate semantic features, often perform well in judging the best systems [10].  The heatmaps in the image compare system-level metric performance for various language pairs involving English, with green cells indicating statistically significant improvements ![The heatmaps compare system-level metric performance for various language pairs involving English](image3).

The evaluation also considered the impact of penalizing ties in metric predictions. Penalizing ties promotes discerning metrics, especially when discrepancies are substantial, and human judgments are clear [12]. The absolute Pearson correlation of system-level metrics with direct assessment (DA) human evaluation in newstest2019 highlights the correlations of metrics that are not significantly outperformed by any other for specific language pairs [1, 9].

Metrics incorporating semantic features, such as YiSi and ESIM, generally achieve higher performance [11].
Ultimately, metrics like YiSi-1 consistently perform well across different language pairs due to their incorporation of semantic features.

The evaluation of translation metrics varies across different language pairs. For system-level evaluation, the YiSi metrics show high correlations and are often not significantly outperformed by other metrics [1]. In fact, YiSi metrics achieve the highest correlations in several language pairs [1].

For the language pair en-kk, some QE systems, like YiSi-2, show upward correlation trends when other metrics degrade [8]. This suggests that certain QE systems may perform better for top-performing systems or systems that are closer in quality [8].

 Examining specific metrics, ![This image shows correlation data for different metrics used to evaluate machine translation.](image6) shows the performance of various metrics for different language pairs, including en-fi and en-kk. The correlation values indicate the strength of each metric's alignment with human judgments.  Furthermore,  ![Heatmaps are used to compare the statistical significance of different translation evaluation metrics against human assessments for various language pairs involving English.](image8) displays system-level metric significance test results for direct assessment (DA) human evaluation of machine translation metrics. Green cells indicate statistically significant improvements in correlation with human assessment.

In conclusion, the performance of translation evaluation metrics varies across language pairs, with some metrics like YiSi showing strong correlations and QE systems like YiSi-2 demonstrating unique trends for specific language pairs such as en-kk.

The investment allocations vary between U.S. and non-U.S. defined benefit plans. The investment policy is designed to better match the interest rate sensitivity of the plan assets and liabilities [8]. The appropriate mix of equity and bond investments is determined primarily through the use of detailed asset-liability modeling studies that look to balance the impact of changes in the discount rate against the need to provide asset growth to cover future service cost [8]. Most of our plans around the world have a greater proportion of fixed income securities with return characteristics that are more closely aligned with changes in the liabilities caused by discount rate volatility [8].

The target allocation ranges for U.S. Defined Benefit plans include 65% - 80% in fixed income securities and cash equivalents and 20% - 35% in equity securities ![The table displays investment allocation percentages for different types of benefit plans.](image2).

Actual allocations for U.S. Defined Benefit plans in 2020 were 70% in fixed income securities and cash equivalents and 30% in equity securities ![The table shows the allocation percentages of fixed income securities and cash equivalents, as well as equity securities for different types of plans across two years, 2020 and 2019.](image3).

For Non-U.S. Defined Benefit plans, the target allocation ranges include 60% - 100% in fixed income securities and cash equivalents and 0% - 40% in equity securities ![The table displays investment allocation percentages for different types of benefit plans.](image2). The actual allocations for Non-U.S. Defined Benefit plans in 2020 were 76% in fixed income securities and cash equivalents and 24% in equity securities ![The table shows the allocation percentages of fixed income securities and cash equivalents, as well as equity securities for different types of plans across two years, 2020 and 2019.](image3).

In 2020, U.S. and Non-U.S. Defined Benefit plans had varying target allocation ranges and actual allocations for fixed income and equity securities.

Novo Nordisk acknowledges that foreign exchange risk is a significant financial risk, influencing the income statement, comprehensive income, balance sheet, and cash flow statement [12]. To mitigate the negative effects of exchange rate fluctuations on earnings and cash flow, contributing to more predictable financial results, Novo Nordisk employs various strategies [4, 11].

Novo Nordisk strategically hedges its assets, liabilities, and expected cash flows in key currencies up to 24 months forward [1]. They utilize forward exchange contracts and currency options to hedge forecast transactions, assets, and liabilities, with the overall policy to hedge the majority of total currency exposure [5].

Financial contracts are expected to impact the income statement within 12 months, with deferred gains and losses on cash flow hedges being transferred to financial income or expenses [7]. The majority of Novo Nordisk's sales are in USD, EUR, CNY, JPY, CAD, and GBP, with the most significant foreign exchange risk in USD, CNY, and JPY [3].

Novo Nordisk actively manages foreign exchange risk to reduce its impact on financial results by using financial instruments, which affects comprehensive income and cash flow [11].

The net deferred tax asset/(liability) decreased by DKK 678 million during 2020, primarily due to adjustments in other comprehensive income and exchange rate effects.

In FY2021, a significant number of reports were submitted via EthicsPoint, providing insights into the company's culture and organizational learning [12]. There were 4,162 reports received, with 3,541 classified as business conduct concerns, marking a 52 percent increase from FY2020 [9]. This increase is attributed to enhanced training on the company's code of conduct and efforts to ensure line leaders log all concerns in EthicsPoint [9].

![The table shows the percentages of different types of incidents reported, with harassment and bullying being the most common at 61%.](image7)

The most reported category was "Harassment and bullying, including sexual harassment and sexual assault" with 61% [7]. In 2018, the company formally defined sexual assault and sexual harassment as a health and safety risk and introduced a range of controls, including security measures and a dedicated support service [2]. The company also recognized the need to improve coordination in addressing this issue [2]. The Sustainability Committee considered sexual assault and sexual harassment when assessing performance against the FY2021 HSEC KPI [1].

Thus, harassment and bullying, including sexual harassment and sexual assault, was the most reported type of business conduct case in FY2021.

The company actively repurchased shares and managed its capital structure between 2016 and 2020 [1]. Stock repurchases were a significant component of capital allocation, with \$17.9 billion in 2018, \$7.6 billion in 2019, and \$3.5 billion in 2020 [1].

In addition to stock repurchases, the company also focused on returning value to shareholders through dividends [2]. The company increased its dividend payments, with a 10% increase in the quarterly cash dividend to \$1.60 per share in 2020 [3].  ![The table displays share repurchase data for specific periods in 2020, including the number of shares purchased, the average price per share, and the remaining dollar value authorized for repurchases](image4).

The consolidated statements of income show an increase in total revenues from \$22,991 million in 2016 to \$25,424 million in 2020, while net income decreased from \$7,722 million to \$7,264 million during the same period ![The table presents the consolidated statements of income data, highlighting revenues, operating expenses, net income, and diluted earnings per share from 2016 to 2020](image1). Total product sales also increased from $21,892 million in 2016 to $24,240 million in 2020 [image1].  Despite the revenue growth, operating income decreased by 6% to $9,139 million and net income decreased by 7% to $7,264 million [image8].

The company sustained its commitment to returning capital to stockholders while navigating fluctuations in financial performance between 2016 and 2020.

From 2020 to 2021, revenue from direct-to-consumer services increased [2]. Sky's direct-to-consumer revenue went up by 2.0% between 2020 and 2021 ![Direct-to-consumer revenue increased from 2020 to 2021.](image1). This increase reflects the impact of events postponed in the previous year because of COVID-19 [5]. In addition to the overall revenue increase, the average monthly direct-to-consumer revenue per customer relationship also saw a rise from $54.56 in 2020 to $59.29 in 2021 ![Average monthly direct-to-consumer revenue per customer relationship increased between 2020 and 2021.](image5).

The revenue and average monthly direct-to-consumer revenue per customer relationship increased from 2020 to 2021.

P&G has a long history of dividend payments, consistently rewarding its shareholders over many years [4, 6, 10]. The company has increased its dividend for 66 consecutive years and has paid a dividend for 132 consecutive years since its incorporation in 1890 [4, 6, 10]. In 2022, the dividend per common share increased by 9% to $3.5227 [4].

![The graph illustrates the steady increase in dividends per share from 1956 to 2022.](image4)

A review of the dividend history shows a significant increase over the decades; the dividend per share was just $0.01 in 1956, growing to $3.52 by 2022 ![The table highlights the significant increase in dividend per share over the decades, with $3.52 in 2022.](image5). The board declared a 5% increase in the quarterly dividend in April 2022, raising it from $0.8698 to $0.9133 per share on Common Stock and Series A and B Employee Stock Ownership Plan (ESOP) Convertible Class A Preferred Stock [4].

![The graph compares P&G's shareholder return with the S&P 500 and Consumer Staples Index, showing steady growth.](image8)

The dividend per share has significantly increased over time, reaching $3.52 in 2022, marking 66 years of consecutive increases.

In 2020, ExxonMobil's financial landscape saw significant shifts compared to 2019, impacting both capital expenditures and tax obligations. Capex in 2020 was $21.4 billion [12], while the corporation aimed to reduce 2021 capital spending in a range of $16 billion to $19 billion [12].

The total taxes reported on the Corporation’s income statement were $22.8 billion in 2020, a notable decrease of $15.7 billion from 2019 [9]. Income tax expense reflected a benefit of $5.6 billion, contrasting with the $5.3 billion expense in 2019, primarily due to asset impairments recorded in 2020 [9]. The effective tax rate also decreased, landing at 17 percent in 2020 compared to 34 percent the previous year, influenced by changes in the mix of results across different tax jurisdictions [9]. Total other taxes and duties also saw a reduction of $4.8 billion, amounting to $28.4 billion in 2020 [9].

![The table provides financial data regarding taxes for the years 2020, 2019, and 2018, expressed in millions of dollars.](image1)

Capital investments in the Downstream sector totaled $4.2 billion in 2020, a decrease of $0.2 billion from 2019 [10]. Chemical capital expenditures also saw a reduction of $0.5 billion, totaling $2.7 billion, mainly due to reduced spending on growth projects [10]. Industry conditions in 2020 led to lower realized prices for the Corporation’s products, resulting in substantially lower earnings and operating cash flow compared to 2019 [2].

![The table shows financial data for the "Upstream" segment over three years (2020, 2019, and 2018) in millions of dollars.](image4)

ExxonMobil's capital expenditures and tax obligations decreased from 2019 to 2020, reflecting lower earnings and strategic adjustments in investment and operations.

Berkshire Hathaway's financial activities include stock repurchases and diverse segment earnings. The company's stock repurchase program allows for repurchases when the price is below intrinsic value, as determined by Warren Buffett and Charlie Munger [4, 12]. In 2021, Berkshire spent $27.1 billion on repurchasing its Class A and B common stock [12].

![The table presents data on Class A and Class B share repurchases during the fourth quarter of 2021, detailing the number of shares purchased, average price, and shares repurchased under the publicly announced program.](image7)

This table illustrates the specifics of share repurchases during the fourth quarter of 2021 [7]. In October, November, and December, Berkshire repurchased both Class A and Class B shares, with the average price paid per Class A share ranging from approximately $430,172.46 to $439,625.92 and the average price paid per Class B share ranging from approximately $282.86 to $287.62 [7].

Looking at net earnings across different segments, there are significant variations. Investment and Derivative Gains/Losses show the most considerable fluctuation, from $57,445 million in 2019 to $31,591 million in 2020 and then $62,340 million in 2021 [4]. The Manufacturing, Service, and Retailing segment also show notable growth, with earnings of $9,372 million in 2019, $8,300 million in 2020, and $11,120 million in 2021 [4].

![The table details Berkshire Hathaway's net earnings across various segments from 2019 to 2021, showing fluctuations in earnings for each segment.](image4)

The insurance underwriting segment experienced earnings of $325 million in 2019, $657 million in 2020, and $728 million in 2021 [4]. The railroad business saw earnings of $5,481 million in 2019, $5,161 million in 2020, and $5,990 million in 2021 [4].  The Utilities and Energy segment displayed steady growth, with $2,840 million in 2019, $3,091 million in 2020, and $3,495 million in 2021 [4]. These segment results reflect the diverse nature of Berkshire's operations and their varying performance across these years.

Berkshire Hathaway strategically repurchased its stock while experiencing fluctuating net earnings across its diverse business segments between 2019 and 2021.

The financial commitment to rural development projects is significant, with a focus on holistic and sustainable initiatives [10]. The total strategic investments changed from $1,302 million on January 31, 2019, to $1,963 million on January 31, 2020. To determine this change, we can reference figures from different tables for each year. For January 31, 2019, strategic investments totaled $1,302 million across fair value, measurement alternative, and other categories ![Strategic investments in 2019 totaled $1,302 million.](image5). The corresponding figure for January 31, 2020, is $1,963 million ![Total strategic investments in 2020 were $1,963 million.](image4).

The change can be attributed to shifts within these measurement categories. In 2019, the investments were distributed among Fair Value ($436 million), Measurement Alternative ($785 million), and Other ($81 million) ![The investment distribution as of January 31, 2019.](image5). By 2020, these values changed to Fair Value ($370 million), Measurement Alternative ($1,502 million), and Other ($91 million) [2, 9]. There was a net unrealized gain of $290 million recognized in fiscal year 2020 for strategic investments still held as of January 31, 2020 [12].

The total value of strategic investments increased by $661 million from January 31, 2019, to January 31, 2020, with the measurement alternative category showing the most significant increase.

McDonald's experienced a $10\%$ decrease in total company-operated sales and franchised revenues in 2020 [5]. This decline was significantly influenced by sales decreases in the International Operated Markets segment due to COVID-19 [5]. ![The table shows the reconciliation of diluted earnings per share for the years 2020, 2019, and 2018, along with percentage changes.](image1)

The reconciliation of diluted earnings per share shows a decrease in GAAP earnings per share from $7.88$ in 2019 to $6.31$ in 2020, a change of $(20)\%$ [image1]. Similarly, Non-GAAP earnings per share decreased from $7.84$ in 2019 to $6.05$ in 2020, marking a $(23)\%$ change [image1]. These declines align with the overall revenue decreases experienced by the company, as the revenues from franchised restaurants decreased from $11,656$ million in 2019 to $10,726$ million in 2020, a decrease of $8\%$ [image6].

Breaking it down by market, the International Operated Markets saw a $17\%$ decrease in total company-operated sales and franchised revenues [image3]. ![The table displays percentage changes for different market segments over two years, 2020 and 2019.](image2) The U.S. market, however, experienced a smaller decrease of $2\%$ [image3]. The percentage changes excluding currency translation for the International Operated Markets was $(14)\%$ in 2020 [image2].

The International Developmental Licensed Markets & Corporate segment also experienced a decrease of $5\%$ [image3]. Overall, the total revenues decreased by $10\%$ from 2019 to 2020 [image3]. ![The table presents financial data, likely from a corporate financial report, broken down by geographical segments and ownership types.](image7) The total for geographical regions decreased by $(6)\%$ [image7].

The declines in company-operated and franchised revenues, particularly in international markets, contributed to the decrease in both GAAP and Non-GAAP earnings per share for McDonald's from 2019 to 2020.

The assumptions used in calculating the grant-date fair value for stock options include risk-free interest rates, expected volatility, expected dividend yields, and expected life of options [3, 11]. The company uses U.S. Treasury yields to determine risk-free interest rates and historical data to estimate option exercises and forfeitures [3]. The risk-free interest rate ranged from 0.2% to 1.4% in 2020 ![The table shows that risk-free interest rates ranged from 0.2% to 1.4% in 2020.](image4).

Future minimum lease payments under non-cancelable operating leases as of December 31, 2020, were detailed for the upcoming years, starting with $865 million in 2021 and decreasing to $441 million in 2025, with $1,781 million thereafter [4].  ![The table shows total future minimum lease payments amount to $5,046 million.](image6).

The principal assumptions for stock options focus on factors influencing the option's value, while the minimum lease payments reflect the company's obligations under lease agreements. The assumptions used for stock options include interest rates and volatility while the lease payments are based on contractual obligations.

The assumptions used for calculating grant-date fair value for stock options differ significantly from the future minimum lease payments, as the former involves estimations of financial factors affecting option values, while the latter represents actual contractual obligations for lease payments.

Chevron's U.S. upstream earnings saw a significant increase in 2021, reporting \$7.3 billion compared to a loss of \$1.6 billion in 2020 [4]. Similarly, international upstream earnings improved substantially, reaching \$8.5 billion in 2021, a stark contrast to the \$825 million loss in 2020 [7].

Additionally, U.S. downstream earnings also experienced a turnaround, reporting \$2.4 billion in 2021 compared to a loss of \$571 million in 2020 [12]. However, international downstream earnings decreased to \$525 million in 2021, down from \$618 million in 2020 [2].

The company's dividend growth has been substantial over the years, as illustrated by the indexed dividend growth from 2006 to 2021, with Chevron showing a compound annual growth rate of 6.7% ![Chevron's dividend growth from 2006 to 2021, outpacing the S&P 500 and peer group, demonstrates a strong commitment to shareholder returns.](image5).

Chevron's net income increased significantly, and the return on stockholders' equity improved from 2020 to 2021.

In 2020, the APAC segment's financial performance was influenced by several factors affecting both its GAAP and non-GAAP measures. The reported percentage change based on GAAP measure was 18% ![The table shows the reported percentage change, impact of foreign exchange, acquisitions/divestitures, organic growth, volume, and net pricing for various segments, including APAC.](image4). However, this was significantly impacted by acquisitions and divestitures, which negatively affected the segment by 10% ![The table presents the impact of mark-to-market, restructuring, impairment, inventory adjustments, and foreign exchange on the performance of various business segments, including APAC.](image6). The impact of acquisitions and divestitures can be seen with reference to [11].

McDonald's comprehensive income in 2020 was $4,626.4 million. In comparison, the comprehensive income for 2019 was $6,152.2 million and for 2018 it was $5,493.2 million [image7].

Operating income decreased by 19% in 2020 (20% in constant currencies), including a net strategic gain of $268 million related to the sale of McDonald's Japan stock [8]. The consolidated statement of comprehensive income provides a breakdown of factors influencing the changes in comprehensive income, including foreign currency translation adjustments, cash flow hedges, and defined benefit pension plans [image7].

![The consolidated statement of comprehensive income provides a breakdown of factors influencing the changes in comprehensive income.](image7)

Additionally, total assets increased by $5.1 billion in 2020, primarily due to an increase in cash and equivalents driven by lower capital expenditures and fewer treasury stock purchases compared to the prior year, as well as proceeds from the sale of McDonald's Japan stock [4]. Cash used for investing activities decreased by $1.5 billion in 2020, largely due to lower capital expenditures and proceeds from the McDonald's Japan stock sale [6].

McDonald's comprehensive income decreased in 2020 compared to 2019 and 2018, influenced by factors like operating income changes, strategic gains, currency translation adjustments, cash flow hedges, and pension plan adjustments.

In 2021, Sandoz experienced varied financial performance compared to 2020. Operating income for Sandoz increased significantly, while core operating income decreased.
The operating income for Sandoz increased by 53% in USD and 48% in constant currencies, rising to USD 1.6 billion in 2021 from USD 1.043 billion in 2020 ![Sandoz's operating income increased significantly by 48% in constant currencies, reaching $1.6 billion in 2021.](image3). This increase was "mainly driven by lower legal settlements, lower impairments and lower amortization partly offset by unfavorable gross margin and lower sales" [6].

However, core operating income for Sandoz decreased by 12% in USD and 14% in constant currencies, with the 2021 value being USD 2.064 billion compared to USD 2.334 billion in 2020 ![Core operating income for Sandoz decreased by 14% in constant currencies, totaling $2.064 billion in 2021.](image2).

Several factors influenced these changes; "the effects of the pandemic were still apparent in Oncology and Sandoz as we continued to see delays in cancer care and a weak flu season dampened generics sales" [2]. Additionally, "after the first two years of the three-year LTPP performance cycle, both net sales CAGR and operating income CAGR are tracking behind target, driven mainly by the negative and unexpected impact of COVID-19 in 2020 and 2021 as well as the safety update on Beovu " [5]. Also, the strategic review of Sandoz was initiated to position it as a long-term leader in the generics industry [4].

In summary, Sandoz saw an increase in operating income due to factors like lower legal settlements, but a decrease in core operating income influenced by the pandemic and other market dynamics.

From 2019 to 2021, there were notable changes in net interest income and card member receivables, influenced by various factors. The net interest income saw a decrease, while card member receivables experienced growth.

Net interest income decreased from $7,683 million in 2019 to $6,674 million in 2021 ![Net interest income decreased from 2019 to 2021.](image7).
This was primarily due to lower cost of funds, but it was partially offset by lower average revolving Card Member loan balances [12].

Card Member receivables, on the other hand, increased. Total receivables were $22.8 billion in 2019 and increased to $22.4 billion in 2021 ![Total card member receivables increased from 2019 to 2021.](image5).

The changes in receivables are also reflected in the U.S. and outside the U.S. segments, with the U.S. receivables increasing from $11.9 billion in 2020 to $14.7 billion in 2021, and outside the U.S. receivables increasing from $6.8 billion in 2020 to $7.7 billion in 2021 ![Card member receivables in US and outside US both increased from 2020 to 2021.](image5). This increase in card member receivables was partially offset by increases in the outstanding balances of receivables and loans [7]. Furthermore, provisions for credit losses decreased, resulting in a net benefit, which was primarily driven by reserve releases due to improved portfolio quality and macroeconomic outlook [7].

In summary, net interest income decreased due to lower cost of funds offset by lower loan balances, while card member receivables increased due to higher outstanding balances and improved economic conditions.

From 2019 to 2020, Tencent Music Entertainment Group experienced notable changes in both 'Retained Earnings' and 'Total Comprehensive Income for the Year'.  Retained earnings grew from RMB 11,111 million to RMB 14,194 million as shown in the changes in equity for the years [image1].  Total comprehensive income for the year increased significantly from RMB 5,268 million in 2019 to RMB 8,100 million in 2020 [image8].

![Retained earnings grew from RMB 11,111 million to RMB 14,194 million.](image1)

This surge in total comprehensive income can be attributed to several factors evident in the financial statements. The income statement shows an increase in gross profit, rising from RMB 8,673 million in 2019 to RMB 9,404 million in 2021[image4]. Additionally, there were fair value changes on financial assets at fair value through other comprehensive income and other comprehensive income of associates [image8].

![Total comprehensive income for the year increased significantly from RMB 5,268 million in 2019 to RMB 8,100 million in 2020.](image8)

These positive changes reflect improved financial performance and effective management of assets, as evidenced by the increase in retained earnings and total comprehensive income.

In 2019, there were differences in the asset allocation between U.S. and non-U.S. defined benefit plans, specifically regarding fixed income securities and equity securities. The investment mix of benefit plans includes low-cost, broad-market index funds [12].

In 2019, U.S. Defined Benefit plans held 65% in fixed income securities and cash equivalents, while equity securities accounted for 35% ![The table shows the allocation percentages of fixed income securities and cash equivalents, as well as equity securities for different types of plans across two years, 2020 and 2019.](image1). Non-U.S. Defined Benefit plans allocated 73% to fixed income securities and cash equivalents, with 27% in equity securities ![The table shows the allocation percentages of fixed income securities and cash equivalents, as well as equity securities for different types of plans across two years, 2020 and 2019.](image1).

The U.S. defined benefit plans held 65% in fixed income and 35% in equity securities, while non-U.S. defined benefit plans held 73% in fixed income and 27% in equity securities.

The company's provision for income taxes has shown an increasing trend from 2018 to 2020. The provision was $3,562 million in 2018, $3,742 million in 2019, and $4,973 million in 2020 ![The table shows total provision for income taxes increased over the years 2018-2020.](image3). The effective tax rate also varied across these years, as shown in the reconciliation of the tax provision [6].

Looking at the components of the provision for income taxes, the current and deferred portions play a significant role. For instance, the current federal tax provision increased from $2,897 million in 2018 to $4,098 million in 2020 ![The table shows the breakdown of current and deferred tax provisions from 2018 to 2020.](image3).  The deferred income tax provision or benefit reflects the net change in deferred income tax assets and liabilities during each year [9]. In 2020, there was a deferred benefit of $(8) million, while in 2019 there was a deferred provision of $230 million, and in 2018 a deferred provision of $42 million ![The table shows the deferred (benefit) provision.](image3).

Deferred tax assets and liabilities arise from differences between the financial and income tax reporting bases of assets and liabilities [3].  Key deferred tax assets include accrued expenses and allowances, net operating loss carryforwards, and lease liabilities, while deferred tax liabilities primarily consist of items like intangible assets, capitalized software, and depreciation and amortization ![The table shows the deferred tax assets and liabilities for 2019 and 2020.](image8). The net deferred income tax liabilities were $(3,367) million in 2020 and $(2,993) million in 2019, indicating a generally increasing difference between deferred tax liabilities and assets ![The table shows the net deferred income tax liabilities for 2019 and 2020.](image8).

The company's provision for income taxes increased from 2018 to 2020, influenced by changes in both current and deferred tax components, with deferred tax liabilities generally exceeding deferred tax assets.

From 2019 to 2020, there were notable shifts in both current and noncurrent liabilities. Current liabilities increased from $3,205 million to $5,342 million, while noncurrent liabilities increased from $5,351 million to $7,789 million ![The table shows a financial breakdown of liabilities for the years 2020 and 2019, divided into current and noncurrent categories.](image3). This overall increase in liabilities is reflected in the total debt, which decreased from approximately $21.7 billion in 2019 to $21.2 billion in 2020 [4].

The increase in contract liabilities from $806 million in 2019 to approximately $1.4 billion in 2020 also influenced these figures [8]. The components of the company's debt include items such as euro-denominated commercial paper, zero-coupon LYONs, and senior unsecured notes and bonds, which contribute to the overall debt structure ![This table lists various financial instruments, mainly senior unsecured notes and bonds, with their due dates and principal amounts. It shows amounts for 2020 and 2019 in USD.](image2). Despite the increase in both current and noncurrent liabilities, the total debt saw a slight decrease, indicating effective management and refinancing strategies [2, 4].

In summary, while both current and noncurrent liabilities increased from 2019 to 2020, the total debt decreased slightly during the same period.

In 2018, Amberjack's total revenues were $204 million, operating income was $157 million, and net income was $157 million ![Amberjack's Statements of Income for the year ended December 31, 2018, show revenues of $204, operating income of $157, and net income of $157.](image4).

By 2020, Amberjack's total revenues decreased to $102 million, operating income was $78 million, and net income was $78 million ![The 2020 Statements of Income for Amberjack show revenues of $102, operating income of $78, and net income of $78.](image7). Comparing these figures, the table shows data for Amberjack's total during the years from 2018 to 2020 [5]. Amberjack revenue was $80 in 2018, $125 in 2019 and $102 in 2020 [5].

From 2018 to 2020, Amberjack experienced a decrease in total revenues, operating income, and net income.

In 2020, the firm experienced a notable shift in its effective tax rate and net discrete tax provisions, which also corresponded with changes in compensation expenses. The effective tax rate increased from 18.3% in 2019 to 22.5% in 2020 ![The table presents financial data for the years 2020, 2019, and 2018, with measures in millions of dollars.](image5). This increase is primarily attributed to a higher level of earnings and lower net discrete tax benefits [3].

Net discrete tax benefits decreased from $475 million in 2019 to $122 million in 2020; these benefits were primarily related to the conversion of employee share-based awards [4].  In 2019, the net discrete tax benefits were associated with the remeasurement of reserves and related interest due to new information regarding the resolution of multi-jurisdiction tax examinations, as well as benefits from employee share-based awards [8, 10, 12].

Compensation and benefits expenses saw an 11% increase, reaching $20,854 million in 2020. This rise was mainly driven by increases in discretionary incentive compensation, higher formulaic payouts to Wealth Management representatives due to increased revenues, higher expenses related to certain deferred compensation plans linked to investment performance, and additional compensation resulting from the E*TRADE acquisition [1]. Examining deferred cash-based awards, the value was $1,263 million in 2020 compared to $1,233 million in 2019 ![The table presents financial figures related to compensation expenses over three years (2018, 2019, and 2020) in millions of dollars.](image7).  The total compensation expense recognized was $2,119 million in 2020, up from $1,878 million in 2019 [image7]. The estimated amount expected to be recognized in 2021 is $680 million [image3].

The effective tax rate increased while net discrete tax benefits decreased from 2019 to 2020, alongside an overall rise in compensation expenses during the same period.

From 2020 to 2021, there were notable shifts in card member loans and receivables [6]. Card Member loans increased, whereas reserve for credit losses decreased [7, 11].
![Card Member loans increased from $73.4 billion to $88.6 billion between 2020 and 2021.](image1)
As shown in the table, Worldwide Card Member Loans increased from $73.4 billion in 2020 to $88.6 billion in 2021 [image1]. Conversely, the reserve for credit losses for card member loans decreased, driven by improved portfolio quality and macroeconomic outlook [11].
![Total billed business rose by 25% in 2021, indicating strong growth in card member spending.](image2)
Billed business increased by 25% in 2021 [image2]. Additionally, network volumes increased by 24% [image2]. These increases reflect a recovery in economic activity and consumer spending after the initial impact of the COVID-19 pandemic [5]. Despite higher paydown rates, Card Member loans still saw substantial growth [7].

In summary, card member loans increased, credit loss reserves decreased, and there was a substantial increase in both billed business and network volumes from 2020 to 2021.

From 2019 to 2020, there were notable changes in net income and comprehensive income, as detailed in the financial statements. Net income decreased from $6,025.4 million in 2019 to $4,730.5 million in 2020 ![The table presents net income and other comprehensive income data for 2018-2020, showing a decrease in net income from 2019 to 2020.](image1). This is further supported by the statement that net income decreased $21\%$ ($22\%$ in constant currencies) to $4.7 billion [2].

Comprehensive income also experienced a decrease, moving from $6,152.2 million in 2019 to $4,626.4 million in 2020 ![The table presents net income and other comprehensive income data for 2018-2020, showing a decrease in net income from 2019 to 2020.](image1).

Several factors contributed to these changes. Cash provided by operations decreased in 2020 compared to 2019, primarily due to a reduction in operating earnings resulting from COVID-19 [5]. The operating margin also decreased from $42.5\%$ in 2019 to $38.1\%$ in 2020 [1]. Moreover, diluted earnings per share decreased $20\%$ ($20\%$ in constant currencies) to $6.31 [2].

In summary, both net income and comprehensive income decreased from 2019 to 2020, primarily due to the impact of COVID-19 on operating earnings and other financial factors.

In 2020, the company deployed 3.02 GWh of energy storage products and 205 megawatts of solar energy systems [6]. The total net value of solar energy systems can be found by examining the changes in specific line items related to solar assets and their depreciation ![Net value of Solar energy systems in service after depreciation decreased from 2019 to 2020.](image6).

The value of "Solar energy systems in service" increased slightly from $6,682 million in 2019 to $6,758 million in 2020. However, accumulated depreciation and amortization also increased, from $723 million in 2019 to $955 million in 2020. Thus, the total net value of these assets increased from $10,396 million in 2019 to $12,747 million in 2020 [See image5].

In summary, while the net value of solar energy systems decreased, the net value of property, plant, and equipment increased substantially from 2019 to 2020.

To understand the financial performance across PepsiCo's divisions, it's crucial to analyze both net revenue and operating profit. The "effective net pricing" is influenced by pricing actions, sales incentives, and product mix, while "net pricing" is affected by list price changes, package weight adjustments, and discounts [12].  Several factors influenced the operating profit, including net revenue growth, productivity savings, operating cost fluctuations, and COVID-19 related charges [6, 7, 9, 11].

The table provides net revenue and operating profit for the divisions between 2018 and 2020. ![This table shows the net revenue and operating profit for different divisions of a company over three years (2018, 2019, and 2020).](image2) For example, Frito-Lay North America (FLNA) shows consistent growth in both net revenue and operating profit.

The percentage distribution between beverages and food/snacks varies by region. ![This table shows the percentage distribution of beverage and food/snack categories across various regions and PepsiCo for the years 2020, 2019, and 2018.](image6)  LatAm consistently has a 90% food/snack and 10% beverage split.  Europe has a more balanced distribution, with approximately 50-55% beverages and 45-50% food/snacks.  AMESA shows variability, while APAC remains consistent with 75% food/snacks and 25% beverages. Siemens Healthineers experienced significant changes in cash flows from both financing and investing activities between 2020 and 2021.

Cash flows from financing activities saw a substantial increase of €12,087 million, reaching €11,839 million in 2021 ![Cash flows from financing activities significantly increased to €11,839 million in 2021](image3). This was primarily driven by financing related to the acquisition of Varian [5]. Further inflows from borrowings amounted to €10 billion, supplemented by an additional financing of €850 million from the Siemens Group to support the Varian acquisition [9].

Conversely, cash outflows from investing activities increased by €12,228 million to €14,140 million [6]. This surge in outflows was mainly due to the payout for the acquisition of Varian ![Cash outflows from investing activities increased significantly in 2021 due to the Varian acquisition](image3). Additionally, there was a €117 million increase in cash outflows related to additions to intangible assets, property, plant, and equipment, largely due to investments in capacity expansions [6].

To determine the total long-term capital and finance lease obligations, several components and calculations are involved. As of December 31, 2017, the gross capital lease obligations amounted to $14,811 million, with imputed interest of $534 million deducted to arrive at a present value of net minimum lease payments of $14,277 million. After subtracting the current portion of capital lease obligations of $5,839 million, the total long-term capital lease obligations were $8,438 million ![The table shows financial data related to capital lease obligations as of December 31, 2017](image8).

Similarly, for finance lease obligations, the gross amount was $6,265 million, and after deducting imputed interest of $1,238 million, the present value of net minimum lease payments was $5,027 million. Subtracting the current portion of finance lease obligations, which was $282 million, resulted in total long-term finance lease obligations of $4,745 million ![The table shows financial data as of December 31, 2017, related to finance lease obligations](image6). These long-term capital lease obligations and long-term finance lease obligations are recorded as part of the company's long-term liabilities [6].

Depreciation expense on property and equipment includes amortization of property and equipment acquired under capital leases, amounting to $5.4 billion for 2017 [3]. Additionally, the company capitalizes construction in progress and records corresponding long-term liability for build-to-suit lease agreements [8, 12].

In summary, the total long-term capital lease obligations were calculated by subtracting imputed interest and the current portion from the gross capital lease obligations, while the total long-term finance lease obligations were determined by subtracting imputed interest and the current portion from the gross finance lease obligations.
