Many people express concerns about the fairness and efficacy of automated programs [2, 7].  Some argue that algorithms assessing criminal risk lack individual focus and fail to account for personal growth [10, 11].
![The image is a chart showing the opinions of U.S. adults on the use of automated criminal risk scores by the criminal justice system.](image4)
However, others believe that using objective criteria to quantify risk could lead to fairer outcomes, potentially benefiting individuals who might otherwise face subjective bias [3]. There is also the belief that flawed human decisions are more flawed than such programs [1]. Some think algorithms should be used with other useful information [6].

Ultimately, opinions on automated criminal risk scores are divided, with concerns about fairness and individual circumstances balanced against the potential for objectivity.

Educational attainment appears to correlate with differing congressional vote preferences [2]. Registered voters with postgraduate degrees favor the Democratic candidate over the Republican candidate by a significant margin (62% to 30%) [1].  Similarly, those with a four-year college degree also show a preference for the Democrat, with 53% supporting the Democratic candidate compared to 40% for the Republican [1].

Preferences among voters without a college degree are more divided [1]. ![The bar graph shows political party preference among various demographic groups of registered voters.](image8) Voters who have attained higher levels of education are more likely to disapprove of the job Trump is doing [5].  Individuals with at least a college degree are more inclined to believe that neither the GOP nor the Democratic Party possesses high ethical standards [8].  Conversely, fewer of those with some college experience (26%) or a high school degree or less education (20%) think neither party has high ethical standards [6].

In conclusion, higher levels of education correlate with a stronger preference for Democratic candidates in congressional votes.

From 1994 to 2018, there was an increase in the proportion of Americans identifying as independents [9]. While the percentage of people identifying as Democrats has remained relatively stable, and the percentage identifying as Republicans has slightly decreased, the percentage of independents grew from 33% in 1994 to 38% in 2018 ![The percentage of independents in the U.S. grew from 33% in 1994 to 38% in 2018.](image4).

However, the majority of independents "lean" towards either the Republican or Democratic party [2]. In 2018, 17% leaned Democrat, and 13% leaned Republican; only a small fraction of Americans (7%) decline to lean toward a party [2]. Most independents are not truly independent politically, and those who are tend to have a low level of interest in politics [8]. Also, partisan leaners were less likely than partisans to say they registered to vote and voted in the congressional elections [6]. For example, approximately half of Democratic-leaning independents (48%) said they voted, compared to 59% of Democrats ![Independent voters are less likely to vote than those affiliated with a party.](image3).

The proportion of political independents in the U.S. increased from 1994 to 2018, but most still lean towards either the Democratic or Republican party.

Hamilton County has several major transportation routes. State Highway 14 connects Central City to Aurora, while US Highway 34 runs east to west from York to Grand Island [6]. Interstate 80 also bisects the county from east to west, a few miles south of Aurora [6]. These routes facilitate the transportation of goods and people across the region.

The county's grid-like pattern was established by the United States Public Land Survey in 1785 [1]. The routes also supported the development of local grain cooperatives, with farmers' elevators becoming focal points in each town ![Grain elevators serve as focal points in Hamilton County towns](image1).

Key communities within Hamilton County include Aurora, Marquette, Phillips, Murphy, Hampton, Giltner, Hordville and Stockham, all of which are marked on the map ![A map highlights Hamilton County in Nebraska and its communities](image2).

The major routes that pass through Hamilton County, Nebraska are State Highway 14, US Highway 34, and Interstate 80, and key communities include Aurora, Marquette, Phillips, Murphy, Hampton, Giltner, Hordville and Stockham.

Americans and Germans hold different opinions regarding their bilateral relations, as revealed by surveys conducted between 2017 and 2019 [7, 8].  Notably, Americans are more optimistic about the state of the relationship compared to Germans [11].

In 2019, three-quarters of Americans felt the relationship was in good shape, marking a 7 percentage point increase since 2017 [11].  However, only $34\%$ of Germans shared this positive sentiment in 2019, though this was an improvement from $24\%$ in 2018 [10].  This divergence in opinion is further highlighted when considering age demographics, where younger individuals in both countries tend to view the relationship more favorably [3].  For instance, in the U.S., $82\%$ of those aged 18 to 29 view the relationship positively, compared to $73\%$ of those aged 65 and older [3].  Similarly, in Germany, $40\%$ of young people hold a positive view, while only $31\%$ of older individuals agree [3].

The trends from 2017 to 2019 indicate that while Americans generally perceive the U.S.-German relationship as good, Germans are more critical, although there was some improvement in their evaluation by 2019 [10, 11]. This is visually represented in ![The image shows the trend of how people in the U.S. and Germany perceive the relations between their two countries from 2017 to 2019.](image8).

In summary, U.S. respondents generally view bilateral relations more positively than German respondents between 2017 and 2019, although there was a slight improvement in German sentiment by 2019.

Americans generally prioritize promoting human rights in China over prioritizing economic relations [9].  ![This bar graph shows that a majority of people overall, across age groups, and political affiliations favor promoting human rights in China over prioritizing economic relations.](image5)  This preference is consistent across different age groups [10]. As immigrant roots become more distant, connections with ancestral national origins decline among self-identified Hispanics [9]. Eight-in-ten immigrants (82%) who identify as Hispanics express a connection with their country of origin, but this feeling diminishes to 44% by the third generation [9]. ![The image is a bar chart showing the generational makeup of self-identified Hispanics and non-Hispanics.](image6)

This decline is mirrored in other aspects of cultural identity, such as language retention. Over time, unfavorable views of both the Republican and Democratic parties have seen significant shifts across different political affiliations. Specifically, negative perceptions of the opposing party have increased among both Republicans and Democrats, as well as those who lean toward either party [2, 11].

The share of Democratic-leaning independents with a very unfavorable opinion of the Republican Party has more than quadrupled between 1994 and 2018 [11].  A similar trend can be observed among Republican leaners' views of the Democratic Party [11].  This increasing negativity is not limited to partisan identifiers; independents who lean toward a party also display similar trends of intense dislike for the opposing party [4].

However, independents who do not lean toward either party are more likely to hold unfavorable views of both parties [5, 10]. ![Independents who do not lean to a party are most likely to have an unfavorable opinion of both parties](image3). Although a significant percentage of these independents view both parties unfavorably, this share has declined in recent years [8].  

The trend of increasing unfavorable views is evident when examining the shifts from 1994 to 2018. ![The graph illustrates increasing polarization over the years, with growing unfavorable views of the opposite party among partisan groups](image8).

In summary, while unfavorable views towards opposing parties have generally increased among partisan individuals, independents who do not lean towards either party remain more likely to view both parties unfavorably, although this trend has seen some decline recently.

Currently, twice as many Americans (56%) express greater concern that policies have not gone far enough to adequately protect the country [10]. The share expressing greater concern that policies do not go far enough is now roughly the same as the historical high seen in early 2010 [1].

The public opinion shifted from 2004 to 2015, with more people believing that anti-terror policies had not gone far enough to protect the country.

Hamilton County experienced significant population changes between 1870 and 2000. The population exploded in the late 1800s [1].

![The table shows population data for Hamilton County from 1870 to 2000](image2)

The population increased from 130 in 1870 to 8,267 in 1880, and reached its peak at 14,096 in 1890 [1]. This surge was influenced by the Transcontinental Railroad Act and the Homestead Act of 1862, which transformed Nebraska into a booming agricultural state and encouraged westward emigration [5]. The Homestead Act provided pioneers with 160 acres of land, provided they constructed a permanent structure and resided on the land for five years [5]. Many early settlers came from states like Missouri, Iowa, Illinois, Ohio, and New England, followed by immigrants from Germany, Sweden, England, and Russia, who settled in clusters across the county [2].

![This map shows Hamilton County in Nebraska and its communities, including Aurora, Marquette, and Giltner](image3)

After the peak in 1890, Hamilton County's population slowly declined [1]. Factors such as farm consolidation and changing transportation patterns led to shifts in population, causing some towns to disappear or be replaced [10]. While many small towns in the Midwest and Great Plains peaked in population between 1900 and 1940 [9], Aurora, however, peaked in population at the most recent census in 2000 [8]. Despite overall population decline in the county, some towns have demonstrated recent population gains [8].

The population of Hamilton County, Nebraska, initially surged due to the Homestead Act and railroad expansion, followed by a decline influenced by farm consolidation and shifting transportation patterns.

Republicans show more confidence in Trump's ability to negotiate trade deals than in his ability to work with Congress, while Democrats show low confidence in both.

Americans have less confidence in President Biden's ability to handle the U.S.-China relationship compared to other foreign policy matters [4, 7, 11]. Only about half of Americans, specifically 53%, express confidence in Biden's capability to deal effectively with China [12].

A plurality of $39\%$ anticipates that the number of people killed or injured in traffic accidents will decrease if driverless vehicles become widespread [4, 6]. In 2008, a significant majority of both Obama's and McCain's voters supported bipartisan cooperation, with 78% of Obama's voters and 76% of McCain's voters believing that Democratic leaders should work with Republicans [1]. Similarly, in 2012, 56% of Obama voters and 90% of Romney backers wanted Obama to collaborate with Republicans [6].  ![The bar chart illustrates the percentage of voters from 2016 believing Democratic leaders should work with President Trump, broken down by voter group.](image7)

However, by 2016, a notable shift occurred.  A larger percentage of voters suggested that Democratic leaders should stand up to Trump, even if it meant less progress in Washington [5]. Specifically, 63% of Clinton voters favored this approach [5].  This contrasted with the sentiment in 2008, when a larger share of McCain voters (58%) felt that Republican leaders should try to work with Obama [7].  ![The image contrasts voter opinions from 2008 and 2016 on whether political leaders should collaborate with newly elected presidents.](image7)

The willingness of the losing candidate's voters to see their party work with the winning candidate was notably different. In 2008, 58% of McCain voters wanted Republican leaders to work with Obama [7], while in 2016, only 35% of Clinton voters felt that Democratic leaders should work with Trump [5]. This divide highlights a growing partisan gap [12].  Trump's voters were also slightly less optimistic about improvements in partisan relations compared to Obama voters in 2008 [11].

In 2016, a significantly larger percentage of Clinton voters (43%) believed relations would worsen compared to McCain voters in 2008 (31%) [11].  This shift underscores increasing polarization and differing expectations regarding political cooperation.

Voter opinions shifted from favoring bipartisan cooperation in 2008 to a more divided stance in 2016, with a greater emphasis on opposition and standing up to the newly elected president, particularly among those who voted for the losing candidate.

The Pew Research Center's study in July and August 2020 provides insights into public opinion on the U.S. response to the coronavirus outbreak [1]. A significant portion of Americans believe that the U.S. response has been less effective compared to other wealthy countries [4].

Public concern shifted significantly between December 2014 and December 2015. Terrorism became a much greater worry, while economic issues declined in importance [4, 6].

The rise in concern over terrorism is evident as "Terrorism" increased from 1% to 18%, "Defense/National security" rose from 2% to 8%, and "ISIS/War in Iraq/War in Syria" increased from 2% to 7% [8]. Overall, concerns about terrorism, ISIS, and national security rose substantially [4]. Specifically, major concern over ISIS increased by 16 points from August 2014 [2].

![The table shows that terrorism increased from 1% to 18% in public concern, while economic issues decreased from 34% to 23% between December 2014 and December 2015.](image8)

Conversely, economic issues saw a decline. The percentage of the public mentioning economic issues such as the economy or unemployment decreased from 34% to 23% [8]. This shift indicates that terrorism and related national security matters took precedence in the public's perception of the most important problems facing the nation [4, 6].

In summary, public concern over terrorism and national security increased significantly, while concern over economic issues decreased from December 2014 to December 2015.

Voter opinions diverge on whether Donald Trump would prioritize the needs of his supporters over those of all Americans [3, 5].  An overwhelming majority of Trump voters (84%) believed he would give equal priority to all Americans, while a significant majority of Clinton voters (75%) thought he would prioritize his supporters ![75% of Clinton voters preferred greater priority to supporters, while 20% preferred equal priority to all.](image5).

These sentiments highlight a deep division in expectations and trust based on voters' preferred candidate [1, 6].  This divergence underscores differing perceptions of fairness and leadership priorities following the election.  Although, the overall percentage of all voters who say that as president, Trump will give equal priority to all Americans is slight greater than the percentage who say Trump will give greater priority to the needs of those who supported him in the election [3].

Ultimately, preferences for prioritizing the needs of Trump's supporters are highly divided, with most Trump voters believing in equal priority for all and most Clinton voters anticipating a focus on Trump's supporters.

Among self-identified Hispanics, perceptions of racial identity vary across generations, according to a Pew Research Center national survey [2, 7]. For instance, 78% of immigrants say strangers on the street would identify them as Hispanic or Latino, but that share decreases in later generations [1].

This is further illustrated in the racial identifications of self-identified Hispanics where the percentage of those who identify as Hispanic or Latino decreases across generations, while those who identify as White, Black, or Other increases `![The bar chart displays the racial identification among self-identified Hispanics and non-Hispanics, showing the distribution across different racial categories.] (image1)`.

Specifically, among self-identified Hispanics, 78% of the foreign-born believe they are seen as Hispanic or Latino. This percentage drops to 66% among the second generation and further to 46% among the third or higher generations [1]. This suggests that as generations progress, fewer Hispanics believe that strangers perceive them as Hispanic or Latino [1].

In contrast, 59% of self-identified non-Hispanics believe they are seen as White [4]. As generations distance themselves from their immigrant roots, there's a reduced likelihood of identifying as Hispanic or Latino [8]. The closer individuals are to their immigrant roots, the more likely they are to identify as Hispanic, with nearly all (97%) of immigrant adults from Latin America or Spain identifying as Hispanic [11]. Among U.S. adults with Hispanic ancestry who do not self-identify as Hispanic, 59% believe passersby would describe them as White, not Hispanic or Latino [5].

The likelihood of being identified as Hispanic decreases with each successive generation; a greater percentage of foreign-born Hispanics are perceived as Hispanic compared to second-generation and third or higher generation Hispanics.

Blacks in STEM jobs are more likely to report experiences of workplace discrimination due to race compared to other racial groups [8]. A significant 62% of blacks in STEM report such experiences, compared to 44% of Asians, 42% of Hispanics, and only 13% of whites [8].

This disparity extends to perceptions of fair treatment in hiring and promotions. Only 43% of blacks in STEM believe that blacks are usually treated fairly during recruitment, and 37% believe this is the case during promotion and advancement opportunities [6]. In contrast, most white STEM workers believe that blacks are usually treated fairly in these processes (78% in hiring, 75% in advancement) [6]. ![The chart compares experiences and perceptions of discrimination among racial/ethnic groups in STEM.](image5)

These differences in perception highlight a significant divide in how racial and ethnic groups experience and perceive workplace dynamics in STEM fields [10]. Specifically, a large majority of blacks in STEM (72%) believe that discrimination in recruitment, hiring, and promotions is a major reason for the underrepresentation of blacks and Hispanics in these jobs [7]. This contrasts sharply with the views of whites (27%) and Asians (28%), while 43% of Hispanics share this belief [7].

Black STEM employees are also more likely to feel their workplaces do not pay enough attention to diversity [9].
Overall, black STEM workers are more likely to perceive workplace discrimination and unfairness compared to their white counterparts.

![The image is a line graph that illustrates the percentage of the vote received by winning and losing presidential candidates in U.S. elections from 1988 to 2016.](image7)

Trump's voter grades were the lowest for any victorious candidate in 28 years [11].

Americans believe that the U.S. can learn from other countries regarding approaches to slow the coronavirus spread [5]. More than eight-in-ten Americans agree that the U.S. could learn either a great deal or a fair amount from other countries [9].

Caltrain's peak hour train car needs vary based on different service improvement scenarios, as detailed in a table that outlines these changes ![The table displays different scenarios related to train service and their corresponding peak service and peak hour train cars.](image4). Currently, with a peak service level of 5 trains per hour with 5 cars each, Caltrain uses 25 train cars during peak hours [1, 4]. If Caltrain uses Metrolink's used cars and maintains a peak service of 6 trains per hour with 5 cars each, it will require 30 train cars during peak hours ![The image shows a Metrolink passenger train traveling on a track.](image2). Electrification would lead to a peak service of 6 trains per hour with 6 cars each, increasing the requirement to 36 train cars. Extending platform to accommodate more cars, with a peak service of 6 trains per hour with 8 cars each, 48 train cars would be needed [2].  The highest demand would arise from increasing frequency potentially with High-Speed Rail (HSR) to 8 trains per hour with 8 cars each, necessitating 64 train cars during peak hours [8].  These changes aim to accommodate increased ridership and improve service [3, 6, 11].

The peak hour train car requirement increases from 25 to 64 based on different service improvement scenarios, with the highest demand resulting from increased frequency with potential High-Speed Rail integration.

From August 2014 to December 2015, there were fluctuations in the approval and disapproval ratings for the U.S. military campaign against ISIS. The approval rating started at 54% in August 2014 and increased to 64% by December 2015, showing a general upward trend ![The graph illustrates the trend of approval ratings increasing from 54% to 64% between August 2014 and December 2015.](image2). These attitudes reflect a broader sentiment that has shifted since ISIS became a major public threat [1]. While concern over ISIS has risen across the political spectrum, the partisan gap remains consistent [12]. Overall, a majority continues to support the U.S. military campaign, with 64% approving and 28% disapproving [8]. The approval rating for the U.S. military campaign against ISIS increased from 54% to 64%, while the disapproval rating decreased from 31% to 28% between August 2014 and December 2015.

Public confidence in Trump's handling of his business interests remains divided along party lines [3, 9]. Republicans, on the other hand, generally express confidence, but this confidence varies [9]. While most Republicans are at least somewhat confident, a smaller percentage are "very confident" [9]. A quarter of the public believes that "high ethical standards" describe neither the Republican nor the Democratic Party [7]. Specifically, those with higher education levels are more likely to view both parties as lacking ethical standards [5]. In contrast, fewer individuals with some college experience (26%) or a high school degree or less (20%) share this view [12].

In summary, perceptions of ethical standards differ notably among educational and political affiliation groups, with higher education and independence correlating with a more critical view of both parties' ethical standards.

Many Americans express concerns regarding the use of automated personal finance scores [6, 8]. A significant portion, 68%, find the use of personal finance scores unacceptable ![68% of U.S. adults find the use of automated personal finance scores not acceptable.](image6).

Concerns include the potential violation of privacy, with 26% of those who find the practice unacceptable citing this reason [10, 11]. These concerns highlight a broader skepticism about algorithmic decision-making and its potential impact on individuals [3, 5]. Political affiliations diverge significantly on the role of government regulation. Republicans are more inclined to believe that government regulation of business does more harm than good, while Democrats generally think that government regulation is necessary to protect the public interest ![Opinions on government regulation vary across political affiliations, with Democrats seeing it as necessary and Republicans viewing it as harmful](image5).

Specifically, 65% of Democrats believe that government regulation is necessary to protect the public interest, while only 29% think it does more harm than good [5]. In contrast, only 33% of Republicans believe regulation is necessary, whereas 61% feel it is harmful [5]. Independents are more divided, with 48% viewing regulation as necessary and 43% considering it harmful [5]. ![Views on government regulation of business, split by political affiliation, showing Democrats favor regulation while Republicans see it as harmful](image5)

These differences extend to those who lean toward either party. A substantial 69% of Democratic leaners believe in the necessity of government regulation, while only 27% think it is harmful [5]. Among Republican leaners, only 33% see regulation as necessary, and 58% consider it more harmful than beneficial [5].

Political affiliations have significantly different views on the necessity of government regulation to protect the public interest, with Democrats largely supporting it and Republicans generally opposing it.

Initially, a large percentage of both Democrats and Republicans held positive views regarding the performance of public health officials in addressing the coronavirus outbreak [7]. However, this perception shifted notably among Republicans over time [4].

![The image consists of four line graphs showing approval ratings from March to August for different groups and an individual.](image2)

Positive views of public health officials have declined significantly overall, from $79\%$ in March to $63\%$ [7]. This decline is largely attributed to a shift in Republican views [4]. The share of Republicans rating public health officials positively fell by 31 points, from $84\%$ to $53\%$ [8, 11]. In contrast, Democrats' views remained relatively stable, with $74\%$ in March and $72\%$ currently holding positive views [5, 8]. As a result, there are now wider partisan differences in views of how public health officials are responding to the outbreak [1].

The approval ratings for public health officials saw a significant decline among Republicans from March to August, while remaining relatively stable among Democrats.

Hispanics have shown consistently higher optimism regarding their financial prospects compared to the general public, particularly after the Great Recession [7]. Since 2011, Hispanic perceptions of their family's finances have significantly improved [1]. A survey indicates that  $81\%$ of Hispanic adults expected their family's financial situation to improve in the next year, a notable increase from $67\%$ in 2008 [3].

![The graph illustrates that between 2004 and 2015, Hispanics consistently had more favorable opinions about their finances compared to the general public.](image2)

This contrasts with the general public, where $61\%$ expected improvement, up from $56\%$ in 2008 [3]. The gap between Hispanic and general public financial expectations reached its largest point since 2004, with Hispanics at $81\%$ and the general public at $61\%$ [7]. This increase in optimism is evident across various demographics, including both U.S.-born and immigrant Hispanics, with each group showing a 14 percentage point increase to $81\%$ [2].

![This bar chart shows that between 2008 and 2015, the percentage of Hispanics expecting their family's financial situation to improve increased more than that of the general population.](image6)

Notably, Latino men and women also showed increased optimism, with men showing an +18 point increase and women an +11 point increase over seven years [2]. This rising optimism among Hispanics reflects a broader trend of faster financial expectation growth compared to the general population since the recession [4, 12]. While about half of Hispanic adults felt they were falling behind financially between 2014 and 2015, similar to the U.S. public, the overall trend indicates a more positive outlook among Hispanics [10].

Between 2004 and 2015, Hispanics consistently held more optimistic financial expectations compared to the general public, with a notable surge in optimism following the Great Recession.

After Trump's election, voters held contrasting views regarding its impact on race relations [9].  ![This image summarizes the feelings of different voter groups, showing a stark contrast in happiness levels based on their candidate preference.](image1)

European VC demonstrates strong fundamentals, benefitting from higher capital efficiency than the US [10]. The median multiple of cash invested in Europe is 7.2 compared to 4.5 in the USA, demonstrating a higher return on investment in Europe. Furthermore, 57.26% of European investments achieve a multiple of cash ≥ 5, while only 47.27% of USA investments reach the same threshold ![The image compares median multiples of cash invested in Europe (7.2) and the USA (4.5), indicating Europe's superior performance.](image2). This higher capital efficiency in Europe is attributed to lower entry valuations and increased selectivity due to the scarcity of VC money [4, 8]. Proportionally Europe yields higher exit multiples, compensating for smaller average exit values with lower entry valuations and greater capital efficiency [11]. While total capital invested and the number of exits exceeding US$100 million are higher in the USA, Europe shows a strong performance in achieving higher multiples on invested capital [image3].

European venture capital exhibits a superior median multiple of cash invested compared to the USA.

Americans have varying perceptions regarding their income relative to the cost of living, with several factors influencing these views. Some Americans believe that using data and algorithms in decision-making can provide objectivity, potentially correcting subjective biases [11]. For example, one man suggests that "If we can quantify risk by objective criteria that have shown validity in the real world, we should use it" [11]. He also points out the potential for these systems to promote fairness across different racial and ethnic groups [11]. However, only 42% of U.S. adults find the use of automated criminal risk scores acceptable ![42% of U.S. adults find the use of automated criminal risk scores acceptable](image4).

Conversely, many worry about the fairness and potential flaws of these systems. The most prominent concern is that these systems remove the human element from important decisions, especially in the context of automated resume screening [9]. Additionally, many believe that humans are complex, and automated systems may not be capable of capturing nuance [9]. Concerns over criminal risk scores often focus on the lack of individual focus and the ability of people to change [7]. A significant percentage of Americans, 56%, find the use of automated criminal risk scores unacceptable [4]. Some feel that every individual and circumstance is different (26%), and people can change (25%) ![The image shows U.S. adults' opinions on automated criminal risk scores, with 42% finding them acceptable and 56% not](image4).

In conclusion, about 42% of U.S. adults find it acceptable for the criminal justice system to use automated criminal risk scores.

Women in computer jobs are more likely to report experiences with and concerns about gender inequities in the workplace compared with men in these jobs [6]. Voter perception of the media's influence on presidential elections has shifted notably over time, with a recent increase in the belief that news organizations exert "too much" influence [10]. A majority of voters (57%) expressed this view regarding the most recent presidential election, whereas only 27% felt the press had the right amount of influence [1]. This sentiment marks the highest level since 2000 and the lowest point for those believing the press's influence was appropriate since 1992 [7].

Looking at historical trends, ![The chart displays survey results about the level of influence of news organizations on presidential elections from 1992 to 2016.](image2) shows the percentage of voters who believed news organizations had "too much" influence, "about the right amount," or "too little" influence on presidential election outcomes between 1992 and 2016. In 2016, 57% of respondents felt news organizations had too much influence [12]. It is important to note that perceptions can vary among different groups of voters; for example, 62% of Trump voters felt the press had too much influence [4, 11]. This negative grading of the press is part of a broader trend where post-election evaluations of various entities involved in the 2016 campaign are more negative than in previous elections dating back to 1988 [9]. As shown in ![The graph shows grades given to the press and pollsters from 1988 to 2016.](image8), the grades given to "the press" have declined over time, with a notable increase in "F" grades in 2016.

The perception that news organizations had "too much" influence on presidential elections has generally increased over time, reaching a high point in recent years.

Women in computer jobs are much more likely than men to experience discrimination at work [10]. A survey indicates that 74% of women in computer occupations report having faced gender discrimination at work, contrasting sharply with only 16% of men in similar roles [4, 5].

Experiences related to workplace fairness also differ significantly; women are less likely than their male counterparts to believe they are treated fairly regarding opportunities for promotion and advancement [7, 11]. While the majority of male computer workers (77%) perceive that women are usually treated fairly in promotion opportunities, only 43% of female computer workers share this view [7].

Moreover, female computer workers are more inclined to say their gender has made it harder for them to succeed in their job (31% vs. 6%) and that they have personally experienced sexual harassment at work (30% vs. 7%) [12]. ![The survey highlights the gender disparities faced by men and women in computer-related jobs.](image7)

Women in computer jobs are more likely to report pay inequities (46% vs. 29% of all women in STEM) and that they have been treated as if they were not competent at work because of their gender (40% vs. 29% of all women in STEM jobs) [9]. This is further confirmed in the survey where 74% of women in computer jobs say they have experienced discrimination because of their gender, compared to 16% of men in these jobs [5].

In summary, women in computer jobs experience significantly more gender-related discrimination compared to men.

Voter turnout varies among different political affiliations, with Republicans and those who lean Republican showing higher turnout rates compared to Democrats, those who lean Democrat, and independents. ![This bar chart illustrates voter registration and turnout percentages across different political affiliations, with Republicans and Lean Republicans exhibiting the highest rates.](image7)

Many seniors face physical challenges that make it difficult to use new technologies [8, 9, 11]. As a result, older adults are more likely to have physical or health conditions that make tech use challenging compared to all adults, as `![The chart compares the percentage of adults and those 65+ with conditions making reading difficult or preventing full participation in activities](image4)`.  Specifically, 23% of older adults report having a condition that makes reading difficult, compared to 16% of all adults; furthermore, 29% of older adults have a disability or chronic disease preventing full participation in activities, compared to 18% of all adults [8].  For seniors with disabilities or chronic diseases, or physical conditions impacting reading, tablet and e-reader adoption reaches approximately 22% [2].

These physical challenges correlate with lower technology adoption rates.  For example, 39% of older adults face physical challenges, making them significantly less likely to go online (49% vs. 66%) and have broadband at home (38% vs. 53%) [6].  Even the ownership of cell phones and smartphones is affected, with lower rates among seniors facing these challenges [6].  In fact, older adults are more likely to have physical or health conditions that make using technology challenging [11].  

Physical health conditions present a significant barrier to technology use among older adults compared to the general adult population.

The importance of abortion as a voting issue for Hispanic registered voters saw a notable increase between March and August [1, 4, 8]. This shift occurred after the Supreme Court's decision to end the federal guarantee of a right to legal abortion in the United States [4].

![The chart effectively visualizes how the perceived importance of issues has shifted over time.](image8)

Specifically, the percentage of Hispanic registered voters who considered abortion a very important voting issue rose from $42\%$ in March to $57\%$ in August [1, 4]. This increase was particularly pronounced among Hispanic Democrats and those leaning towards the Democratic party, with the percentage rising from $42\%$ to $63\%$ [1]. By comparison, the importance of abortion among Hispanic Republicans and Republican leaners remained relatively stable, with a slight increase from $43\%$ to $48\%$ [1]. Despite this increase, the economy remained the top issue for Latino registered voters, with $80\%$ considering it very important [6, 10].

![This image is a bar chart showing approval and disapproval ratings among different groups, likely in a political or social context.](image2)

In conclusion, abortion became a significantly more important voting issue for Latino registered voters between March and August.

Rock and Pop differ significantly in how their catalogs drive streams [1]. Streams constitute 82% of Rock's catalog share, whereas they make up 58% of Pop's [image3]. This contrast underscores that while Rock's catalog heavily influences its streaming activity, Pop is primarily driven by current hits [1]. The dominance of catalog streams in Rock suggests enduring appeal and sustained interest in older tracks [9]. Pop music's dependence on current releases highlights a market dynamic focused on newer songs and trends.

The disparity in catalog streaming share reflects different consumption patterns and success paths for these genres [10]. Rock maintains relevance through its extensive catalog, while Pop thrives on the popularity of current songs [11].

Rock music's catalog share of streams is significantly higher than that of Pop music, which reflects different market dynamics.

Latino Democrats and Republicans diverge significantly in their perceptions of how well each party courts the Latino vote.  A substantial percentage of Latino Republicans and those who lean Republican, specifically 56%, believe that the Democratic Party puts in the effort to earn Latino votes [10].  Conversely, only about a third of Latino Democrats and those leaning Democratic, around 35%, feel the same way about the Republican Party [10].

This difference in perception is further highlighted by the fact that 71% of Latinos say the Democratic Party works hard for Latinos' votes, while only 45% say the same about the Republican Party [6].  Further, views on whether the parties care about Latinos differ significantly between Latino Democrats and Republicans ![The image displays survey results regarding perceptions of how well the Democratic and Republican parties care about and work to earn Latino votes.](image1).  Specifically, 78% of Latino Democrats/leaners think the Democratic Party cares about Latinos, while only 21% think the Republican Party cares. Conversely, 68% of Latino Republicans/leaners think the Republican Party cares about Latinos, while only 36% think the Democratic Party cares.  

About half of Latino Democrats, approximately 51%, believe that the Democratic Party actively works to earn Latino votes [4].  In stark contrast, nearly half of Latino Republicans, around 46%, disagree with the notion that the Democratic Party works hard to earn Latino votes [4]. The survey results about whether Trump should remain a national political figure also show that political preference affect views, implying views on whether the parties care about Latinos are also affected by political leaning ![The image is a bar chart showing survey results about whether Trump should remain a national political figure.](image6).

In summary, Latino Democrats are more inclined to believe that the Democratic Party works diligently for their votes, while Latino Republicans tend to think the Democratic Party does not work hard to earn Latino votes, with inverse perceptions regarding the Republican Party's efforts.

Many Americans believe that a significant factor in the continuation of the coronavirus outbreak is the lack of sufficient and timely testing [6, 8].  Specifically, nearly half of Americans, or 49%, point to the absence of timely testing as a major contributor to the ongoing crisis [6, 8].

This concern is further illustrated in the data, which highlights that 49% of respondents consider "Not enough timely testing" as a major reason for the continued spread of the virus ![49% of respondents think timely testing is a major reason for the spread](image1). There is also a notable partisan divide regarding the importance of timely testing, as indicated by a comparison between Republicans and Democrats [7]. A significant 67% of Democrats feel that not enough timely testing is a primary cause for the continuation of the coronavirus outbreak in the U.S., while less than half that number of Republicans (30%) share the same sentiment [7].

In summary, 49% of Americans cite not enough timely testing as a major reason the COVID-19 outbreak has continued.

According to a Pew Research Center survey, a significant majority of Americans believe that the continuation of the coronavirus outbreak is primarily due to insufficient adherence to social distancing and mask-wearing guidelines [12].  ![The chart illustrates that 75% of people think that not enough people practicing social distancing and mask-wearing is a major reason for the continued spread of COVID-19.](image2)

Both Democrats and Republicans largely agree on this point, although the percentage is higher among Democrats [1, 8]. Therefore, the most cited major reason for the continuation of the COVID-19 outbreak is the lack of adherence to social distancing and mask-wearing guidelines.

Americans have several specific concerns regarding the relationship between the U.S. and China [4], and concerns about China have generally increased [9]. Issues such as cyber attacks, human rights, and job losses have become more pressing in the eyes of Americans [12].

Notably, cyber attacks from China evoked the most concern, with approximately two-thirds considering them a very serious problem [5]. ![Americans increasingly view cyberattacks from China as a serious issue.](image6) This represents a 7 percentage point increase from 2020 [5]. Similarly, China’s policies on human rights are viewed as a substantial problem by half of American adults, also reflecting a 7-point increase since 2020 [6, 12].

Concerns about the loss of U.S. jobs to China and China’s growing military power also rose, each increasing by 6 percentage points from 2020 to 2021 [image6]. ![Concerns over China's growing military power have increased since 2020.](image6) This indicates a growing apprehension among Americans regarding various facets of China's influence and actions.

Cyber attacks from China and China’s policies on human rights showed the greatest increase in concern among Americans from 2020 to 2021.

As generations move further away from their immigrant roots, the likelihood of identifying as Hispanic decreases [7]. This trend is evident when comparing different generations; nearly all immigrants (97%) identify as Hispanic, and this number remains high for second-generation adults (92%) [6]. However, by the third generation, the percentage drops to 77%, and by the fourth or higher generation, it falls to just half [8].

This generational shift is visually represented in ![The bar chart illustrates that as the generations move from foreign-born to fourth or higher generation, the percentage of Hispanic individuals decreases while the percentage of non-Hispanic individuals increases](image4), where the "Fourth or higher generation" shows an equal split between Hispanic and Non-Hispanic identities. Among self-identified non-Hispanics with Hispanic ancestry, only a small fraction (7%) report experiencing discrimination [9].  The generational makeup of self-identified Hispanics and non-Hispanics also differs significantly; most self-identified Hispanics are third generation or higher, while the vast majority of self-identified non-Hispanics are of the third or higher generation ![This image shows that 96% of self-identified non-Hispanics are of the third or higher generation](image7).

Therefore, the smallest bar in the graph represents the 3% of foreign-born individuals who identify as Non-Hispanic.

The frequency of attending Hispanic cultural celebrations during childhood varies significantly across immigrant generations [6, 11]. Among immigrant self-identified Hispanics, a majority (59\%) report frequent attendance at Hispanic cultural celebrations during their upbringing, reflecting their upbringing outside the U.S. ![Immigrant self-identified Hispanics mostly attended Hispanic cultural celebrations often during their childhood](image7). Second-generation self-identified Hispanics show a slightly lower rate, with approximately half (49\%) reporting frequent childhood exposure to these celebrations [3]. However, for third or higher generation self-identified Hispanics, the frequency declines further, with only 35\% reporting frequent childhood attendance [3].

In contrast, only 9% of Americans who have Latino ancestry but do not self-identify as Latino report that their parents often took them to Latino cultural celebrations when they were growing up [2]. The experiences and views on Hispanic culture and identity differ based on their proximity to their family’s immigrant experiences [4]. These experiences influence the degree of connection individuals feel to their Hispanic heritage later in life, with the number of Hispanic cultural activities decreasing across generations [8]. This trend mirrors the fading of Hispanic self-identity across generations [8]. The frequency of attending Hispanic cultural celebrations in childhood decreases from first-generation immigrants to third or higher generation Hispanics.

Women's representation in STEM jobs varies depending on the level of education [1]. ![Women's representation in STEM jobs increased more among those with advanced degrees from 1990 to 2016.](image1) As illustrated in the line graphs, the percentage of women in STEM jobs generally increases with higher educational attainment from 1990 to 2016, showing the most significant gains for women with advanced degrees. For instance, among all STEM workers holding a professional or doctoral degree, about 41% are women [11]. The representation of women in STEM jobs is generally lower among those with advanced degrees [11].

The overall representation of women in STEM jobs varies by education level [1].

Women's presence in STEM fields is not uniform; it differs significantly depending on the specific occupational cluster [9, 10]. For instance, healthcare occupations have a high representation of women, with approximately 75% of healthcare practitioners and technicians being female [7].  ![The pie charts and line graphs show gender distribution in different fields over time, highlighting that health-related jobs have the highest female representation.](image1)

However, in other areas such as computer and engineering jobs, women are notably underrepresented [9]. Engineering occupations have the lowest share of women, at about 14% [6]. Computer occupations fare only slightly better, with women making up about 25% of the workforce [6]. This disparity is further highlighted when examining specific occupations within these clusters. For example, mechanical and electrical engineering have some of the lowest shares of women among all STEM occupations, at 8% and 9% respectively [4].  ![This dot plot visually represents the share of women in various STEM job clusters, highlighting the underrepresentation in engineering and computer jobs.](image4)

In contrast, life sciences and mathematics show a more balanced representation, with women comprising approximately 47% and 46% of the workforce in these fields, respectively [6]. Physical sciences also show a lower representation than overall parity, with women comprising 39% of workers [6].  It's also important to note that even within occupational subgroups, there can be significant variation in the share of women [4].

Female representation varies considerably across different STEM job clusters, with higher representation in health-related fields and lower representation in engineering and computer occupations.

Latinos, as a whole, have shown a substantial increase in financial optimism. Since 2008, most Latino subgroups are more optimistic about their finances [9]. The share of Latinos who expect their family finances to improve has increased by 14 percentage points, from 67% in 2008 to 81% in 2015 [12].  ![The chart shows the percentage of the general population and Hispanics who anticipate their family's financial situation will improve in the coming year, comparing data from 2008 and 2015.](image1)

Specifically, Latinos with some college education experienced a significant increase in economic optimism [5]. Economic optimism has grown roughly twice as fast since 2008 among Latinos who had completed some college (+20 percentage points) than among those with a high school diploma (+9) or less education (+11) [5].  This increase in optimism spans various demographic subgroups within the Latino community [11]. The gains in economic optimism are similarly large among Latinos ages 30 to 49 and 50 to 64 (+16 points for each group) [6].  ![The bar chart compares the change in economic optimism from 2008 to 2015 across various demographic groups, highlighting differences based on nativity, gender, education, and age within the Latino community.](image2)

Latinos showed the largest increase in financial optimism from 2008 to 2015.

Americans’ views of China have become increasingly negative [11]. Notably, unfavorable views are more prevalent among older Americans [8].  Specifically, negative views of China are held by $81\%$ of those ages 50 and older, $71\%$ of those ages 30 to 49, and $56\%$ of those under 30 [8]. The percentage of unfavorable views of China for the 50 and older age group has increased by 10 percentage points since March [8].

This trend is visualized in a line graph that illustrates the changes in unfavorable views across different age groups from 2005 to 2020 ![The graph shows how unfavorable views of China have increased from 2005 to 2020 across three age groups, with the 50 and older group showing the most significant increase](image8).

In 2020, older Americans are also nearly three times as likely as their younger counterparts to view China as an enemy ($36\%$ vs. $13\%$) [9]. Perceptions of China’s relationship with the U.S. also differ by age [9].

The shift in unfavorable views of China among different age groups reveals a growing sense of negativity, particularly among older Americans, between 2005 and 2020.

Hamilton County experienced significant population changes between 1870 and 2000. The county's first permanent settlement occurred in June 1866 [10]. The population exploded in the late 1800s [2]. The population in 1870 was 130, increasing to 8,267 in 1880, and peaking at 14,096 in 1890 [2].

Since 1890, Hamilton County's population has generally declined ![Table illustrating Hamilton County population from 1870-2000](image3). The population decreased to 13,330 in 1900, then saw slight fluctuations before a more significant drop to 9,982 in 1940 [Table 3 in image3]. By 2000, the population was 9,403 [Table 3 in image3]. This demonstrates a substantial initial increase followed by a gradual decline over the specified period.

Hamilton County's population initially surged in the late 1800s but has generally decreased since its peak in 1890.

Democrats and Republicans hold divergent views regarding the automatic registration of all eligible citizens to vote, and these views have shown some shifts over time. Currently, a large majority of Democrats and Democratic-leaning individuals favor automatically registering all eligible citizens to vote [3]. Views among Democrats have remained relatively stable, with 82% in favor [3].

By contrast, Republicans show considerably less support for this policy, and their support has declined in recent years [4]. In 2018, 49% of Republicans supported automatic voter registration, but this figure has dropped to 38% [1, 4]. The image shows that from October 2018 to April 2021, support among Republicans/Lean Republicans decreased from 49% to 38%, while among Democrats/Lean Democrats, it increased from 78% to 82% ![Changes in voter registration policy support over time](image6).

There are also differences within the Republican party based on race and ethnicity, where Hispanic Republicans are more likely to support automatic voter registration than White Republicans [2, 11]. For instance, about half of Hispanic Republicans (51%) favor automatically registering all eligible citizens, compared to 35% of White Republicans [11]. The division in opinions is also evident when observing the overall data, where 82% of Democrats/Lean Democrats support automatically registering citizens compared to only 38% of Republicans/Lean Republicans ![The opinions of Republicans/Lean Republicans, Democrats/Lean Democrats on various voting-related issues](image8).

In summary, Democrats overwhelmingly support automatically registering all eligible citizens to vote, while Republicans show significantly less support, with a notable decline in their support over recent years.

Blacks in STEM are more prone to encountering discrimination and perceiving unfair treatment compared to their white counterparts [1, 5, 7]. A significant  $62\%$ of blacks in STEM report experiencing discrimination due to their race or ethnicity [7].

This contrasts sharply with the experiences of white STEM workers, where only $13\%$ report similar experiences  [7].  ![Black STEM workers are far more likely to experience discrimination than White STEM workers](image1).

Blacks are also less confident than whites that black employees are treated equitably in hiring and promotion processes [5]. Only $43\%$ of blacks in STEM believe blacks are treated fairly during recruitment, and $37\%$ believe this is the case for promotion opportunities [5].  In stark contrast, the majority of white STEM workers believe blacks are usually treated fairly in hiring ($78\%$) and advancement ($75\%$) [5].   This disparity highlights the divergent perceptions of fairness in STEM workplaces based on race.

Blacks working in STEM jobs are more likely to report experiences of workplace discrimination due to race than blacks in non-STEM jobs [9].  Overall, concerns about diversity are high among black STEM workers [11].  A substantial $40\%$ of blacks in STEM believe their race has made it harder to succeed, compared to only $5\%$ of white STEM workers [8].

In STEM jobs, blacks experience higher rates of discrimination and perceive less fairness in hiring and promotion compared to whites [7, 5].

The MMMU benchmark reveals variations in LMM performance across different disciplines [2]. Models generally perform better in areas like Art & Design and Humanities & Social Sciences, where visual data is less complex and requires less intricate reasoning [9, 11]. However, in fields like Science, Health & Medicine, and Tech & Engineering, which involve more complex visuals and reasoning, performance tends to be lower [9, 11].

The table shows performance metrics of various LMMs and LLMs across different validation and test sets, including specific disciplines ![The table shows performance metrics of various LMMs and LLMs across different validation and test sets, including specific disciplines.](image1). The comprehensive evaluation across 30 subjects highlights the challenges in multimodal understanding and reasoning, even for advanced models like GPT-4V [3, 2].

The benchmark's design, incorporating diverse subjects and question formats, aims to evaluate general multimodal perception and reasoning abilities [6]. The detailed subject coverage includes Humanities & Social Sciences, among other disciplines ![The image illustrates the distribution of questions across various disciplines, including Humanities & Social Sciences.](image3). The performance disparity between open-source models and proprietary ones like GPT-4V underscores the existing gaps in LMM capabilities [4, 5].

LMMs show relatively higher performance in the 'Humanities & Social Science' category compared to disciplines requiring more complex visual data and reasoning, but their overall performance indicates substantial room for improvement [9, 11, 3].

The SWEM model is significantly faster than the LSTM model due to its simpler architecture and fewer parameters [1, 4]. SWEM's computations are highly parallelizable, unlike LSTM, which requires sequential steps [1].

As shown in Table 4, SWEM achieves better results on Yahoo! Answer than CNN/LSTM, with only 61K parameters, a fraction of the training time relative to CNN or LSTM [4].
![SWEM has significantly fewer parameters and is faster than CNN and LSTM, as shown in the table.](image4)

Specifically, when $K=d$, SWEM is faster than LSTM by a factor of $d$ [1]. Therefore, SWEM is considerably more computationally efficient and requires less training time compared to LSTM [4]. The SWEM model trains considerably faster than the LSTM model.

Pre-training can significantly impact BLEU scores, especially for low-resource languages or when the training data is limited [2, 7]. The gains from pre-training are more pronounced when the baseline system's performance is poor but not excessively so, typically with a BLEU score in the range of 3-4 [11]. This suggests that a moderately effective system is needed for pre-training to take effect, but once the basic language characteristics are captured, pre-training becomes highly effective [11].

For instance, the table shows the dataset sizes for various language pairs translating into English ![The table shows the dataset sizes for various language pairs translating into English](image6). When pre-trained embeddings are applied, the gains in each translation pair tend to align with their similarity, with Galician/Portuguese (GL/PT) showing the most significant gains [10]. However, Belarusian/Russian (BE/RU) shows a small decrease [10].

The BLEU scores of ES, FR, and IT generally support this hypothesis ![The table presents data related to translation datasets from various source languages to Portuguese (PT), categorized by language family](image2). Languages like Russian (RU) and Hebrew (HE), which are more distinct, experience larger accuracy gains compared to their more similar counterparts, French (FR) and Italian (IT) [9].  The plots indicate that pre-training is more effective with smaller training sets; the gain decreases as the training set size increases ![The line graphs demonstrate how training set size affects BLEU scores, with pre-training showing more benefit with smaller datasets](image7).

Pre-training also aids in capturing rarer vocabulary and generating more grammatically well-formed sentences [1].  The best system translates names and multi-word phrases successfully, showcasing the usefulness of pre-trained embeddings in representing less frequent concepts when working with low-resource languages [1]. For example, pre-training allows the model to translate "chris", "big lawyer", and "patent legislation" [1].

In multilingual translation systems that share an encoder or decoder between multiple languages, pre-training ensures that the word embeddings of the two source languages are placed into similar vector spaces. This helps the model learn similarly to how it would if training on a single language [10]. The table highlights the effects of pre-training on multilingual translation into English ![The table displays the impact of pre-training on multilingual translation into English, showing results for standard and pre-trained models across different language pairs](image3). Aligning word embeddings can further increase BLEU scores for all tasks in such systems [10].

Pre-training generally improves translation accuracy across the entire vocabulary, especially for low-frequency words in the training corpus [7]. A comparison of f-measures for target words, bucketed by frequency in the training corpus, confirms this [7].

Pre-training positively influences BLEU scores, particularly for low-resource languages and smaller datasets, by improving vocabulary capture and grammatical accuracy.

The inclusion of reference translations generally improves the performance of the COMET-RANK metric across various language pairs involving English, as indicated by the positive Δτ values shown in the table ![The table shows the improvement in COMET-RANK scores when reference translations are included, with the most significant improvements in reverse language pairs (source to English).](image7).

The table presents COMET-RANK scores with and without reference translations for language pairs such as English to Czech (en-cs), English to German (en-de), English to Finnish (en-fi), and English to Turkish (en-tr), as well as their reversed pairs [9]. The "Δτ" row shows the difference between the COMET-RANK score without using reference translations and the score using reference translations, indicating the improvement when references are included.  For instance, the Δτ for en-cs is 0.051, while for cs-en it is 0.107. This suggests that the inclusion of references has a more significant impact on the performance of COMET-RANK when translating from a foreign language into English compared to translating from English into a foreign language. This trend is consistent across all language pairs examined in the table, with the reverse language pairs (e.g., cs-en, de-en, fi-en, tr-en) exhibiting higher Δτ values than their corresponding forward language pairs (e.g., en-cs, en-de, en-fi, en-tr) [12].

Inclusion of reference translations enhances the COMET-RANK metric, especially for translations into English.

In relative evaluations, annotator agreement levels vary when comparing Chameleon to other models.  For instance, when comparing Chameleon to Gemini+, annotators unanimously agreed in 31.5% of cases, whereas there was no agreement in 10.3% of cases ![This table shows the annotator agreement levels between Chameleon and other models in relative evaluations.](image5). When juxtaposed with GPT-4V+, complete agreement occurred in 35.4% of instances, with disagreement present in 9.3% of cases ![This table shows the annotator agreement levels between Chameleon and other models in relative evaluations.](image5).

Compared to the original Gemini responses, unanimous agreement was at 30.2%, with disagreement at 10.5%. The comparison with GPT-4V showed 28.6% unanimous agreement and a higher disagreement rate of 13.1% ![This table shows the annotator agreement levels between Chameleon and other models in relative evaluations.](image5).

The relative evaluation results indicate that Chameleon performs comparably to other baselines, making definitive judgments challenging [4]. The agreement levels suggest that in a notable portion of cases (around 10%), annotators' judgments vary, which could be interpreted as Chameleon performing similarly to other models, thus complicating the relative assessment [4]. This is supported by data showing that in approximately 28% to 35% of pairs, all annotators agreed, while in 55% to 60% of pairs, only one annotator differed from the other two [4]. These agreement variations highlight the nuances in assessing the model's performance and the challenges in achieving consistent human evaluations [4].

Inter-annotator reliability for Chameleon's performance suggests that the model's performance is on par with other models, making relative evaluation difficult due to the inconsistent judgment among annotators.

The AUPRC values reflect the quality of token scores in relation to human annotations [1]. In the BoolQ dataset, several models are evaluated using different explanation methods.

Based on the data, we can identify the highest and lowest AUPRC values for the BoolQ dataset, and determine the corresponding model combinations. The table presents performance metrics for different NLP approaches, including AUPRC scores, across several datasets ![The table presents performance evaluation metrics for different NLP approaches across several datasets.](image1). Models are rewarded for assigning higher scores to marked tokens, as measured by the Area Under the Precision-Recall Curve (AUPRC) [5]. To assess the quality of token scores with respect to human annotations, the Area Under the Precision Recall Curve (AUPRC) is reported [1].

By examining the table, the highest AUPRC value for BoolQ is 49.8 achieved by the BERT + LSTM model using the Attention explanation method, while the lowest AUPRC value is 1.9, achieved by the same base model (GloVe+LSTM) using the Random explanation method ![The table presents the performance metrics of several model variants across different datasets.](image4).

The difference between the highest and lowest AUPRC values for the BoolQ dataset is 47.9, with BERT + LSTM/Attention yielding the highest AUPRC and GloVe + LSTM/Random yielding the lowest.

The number of demonstration samples significantly influences Micro-F1 performance, especially when combined with logical constraints.  When the number of demonstrations increases from 1 to 5, there is a notable improvement; however, subsequent improvements are limited with further increases [4]. ![The image visualizes the performance of different models/datasets with and without logical constraints as the number of demonstration samples increases.](image1)
Adding logical constraints into LLM instructions provides stable improvements, particularly with more demonstrations [4]. The performance achieved by incorporating logical constraints with fewer demonstrations can even surpass that of prompts with only a larger number of demonstrations [4]. This highlights the importance of balancing demonstrations ("What") and logical constraints ("How") for LLMs [4].

Step-Back Prompting on TimeQA reveals several error types, with reasoning and RAG errors being the most prominent [3]. This is further illustrated in ![The bar chart shows the distribution of errors, with Reasoning Error and RAG being the highest.](image7), where Reasoning Error accounts for 0.52 and RAG for 0.45 of the errors. Other error types include Scoring Error and StepBack errors [10].

Interestingly, StepBack itself rarely fails as an error source [1, 10]. In contrast, the difficulty of retrieving the correct information, despite the abstraction provided by step-back, contributes to a significant portion of errors [1].

![The chart compares the performance of Step-Back + RAG against baseline predictions and RAG predictions, highlighting error reduction and introduction.](image8) also highlights that Step-Back + RAG can fix a substantial percentage of errors from the baseline and RAG alone, while also introducing some new errors.

The primary errors in Step-Back Prompting on TimeQA are reasoning errors and failures in retrieval augmentation (RAG).

The Entity-GCN model's performance can be assessed against other models using the unmasked test results. The Entity-GCN model, both with and without coreference, is compared against other models, including those based on human performance [7].

The table shows the performance of different models on masked and unmasked datasets ![The table compares the performance of various models using masked and unmasked datasets](image8). Compared to other models, Coref-GRU reaches 59.3, Weaver/Jenga scores 65.3, and MHQA-GRN achieves 65.4 on the unmasked test set [7]. The ensemble Entity-GCN* model attains the highest score of 71.2 [8].

The Entity-GCN model with coreference performs comparably to other models on the unmasked test set.

The survey categorizes correction methodologies into Training-Time Correction, Generation-Time Correction, and Post-hoc Correction, based on when the correction occurs [10]. Training-time correction involves rectifying a flawed model during training by optimizing model parameters using collected feedback [4, 8].  ![Training-time correction optimizes model parameters using human feedback, reward models, or automated feedback during the training phase.](image4)

Generation-time correction uses automated feedback to guide the LLM to correct errors during the generation process [6]. Two main strategies are Generate-then-Rank and Feedback-Guided Decoding [12].  ![The language model generates multiple outputs evaluated by a Critic Model in "Generate-then-Rank", while "Feedback-Guided Decoding" refines outputs iteratively with feedback loops from the Critic Model.](image1)

Post-hoc correction refines the model output after it has been generated, without updating the model parameters [2]. This involves an iterative process of generating output, receiving feedback, and refining output and key strategies include Self-Correction, Correction with External Feedback, and Multi-Agent Debate [1, 2]. ![The image illustrates three post-hoc correction strategies: Self-Correction, Post-hoc Correction with External Feedback, and Multi-Agent Debate, each involving cycles of generation, review, feedback, and refinement to improve model outputs.](image5)

While the text describes all three strategies, it does not provide a quantitative comparison (e.g., number of papers) to determine which strategy has the most representative papers in the survey [9, 11]. Therefore, based on the provided quotes, it is not possible to determine which correction strategy (training-time, generation-time, or post-hoc) has the most representative papers in the survey.

The Tversky Index (TI) offers flexibility in controlling the trade-off between false negatives and false positives, and the hyperparameters  $\alpha$ and $\beta$ play an important role in TI [4]. Experiments conducted on the Chinese OntoNotes4.0 NER dataset and English QuoRef MRC dataset show how the F1 score varies with different  $\alpha$ values [4].

![The table shows that the highest F1 score for Chinese Onto4.0 is achieved when α is 0.6, while for English QuoRef, the highest F1 score occurs when α is 0.4.](image1)

As $\alpha$ changes, the performance varies significantly across different datasets, demonstrating the importance of these hyperparameters [4].  Specifically, the highest F1 score on Chinese OntoNotes4.0 is 84.67 when $\alpha$ is set to 0.6, while for QuoRef, the highest F1 score is 68.44 when $\alpha$ is set to 0.4 [4].

The optimal  $\alpha$ value for maximizing the F1 score is 0.6 for the Chinese OntoNotes4.0 dataset and 0.4 for the English QuoRef dataset.

BERT (Large) achieves a $77\%$ test set accuracy in its best run, which is only slightly below the average human baseline ![The table compares the performance of different models and humans on a development (Dev) and test set.](image1). This raises questions about what BERT has learned regarding argument comprehension [1]. Probing experiments indicate that BERT's $77\%$ performance can be attributed to exploiting spurious cues; considering warrants alone can achieve $71\%$ [2]. Further gains are achieved by adding cues over reasons and claims [2, 4]. When trained on an adversarial dataset designed to eliminate these cues, BERT’s peak performance drops to $53\%$ [5]. This suggests BERT's high accuracy is due to exploiting statistical cues rather than genuine argument comprehension [4, 5, 9, 10].

In its best run, BERT (Large) achieves a test set accuracy of $77\%$.
