The Graph-aware Co-Attention Networks (GCAN) model was developed to address the issue of fake news detection on social media [3, 5, 6, 9, 12]. The model's effectiveness was evaluated through experiments that compared its performance against state-of-the-art methods [1]. The experiments conducted on real tweet datasets demonstrated that GCAN significantly outperformed existing methods [3].

The GCAN model's ability to provide explanations is also a key feature. By analyzing the co-attention weights, the model can highlight evidential words and users that are crucial in predicting fake news [7]. For example, the traits of suspicious users in retweet propagation includes accounts that are not verified, have shorter creation times and descriptions, and shorter graph path lengths to the source tweet poster; they also focus on words like "breaking" [2].
![The image contains a visual representation related to the classification of a tweet as fake or real news. It displays a tweet, "Breaking: huge explosion of an #oil pipeline belonging to @saudi_aramco near sudair, #saudiarabia," which is classified as fake news. The key phrases "Breaking" and "pipeline" are highlighted.](image2)
The early detection capability of GCAN is notable; it can achieve high accuracy even with a limited number of retweeters [4].
![The image is a line graph showing the accuracy of different models as a function of the number of retweet users on the Twitter15 dataset.](image3)
![The image is a line graph depicting the accuracy of different models as a function of the number of retweet users in Twitter16.](image8)
Ablation analysis further shows the contribution of each component of the GCAN model [10].
![The image is a bar graph displaying the results of a GCAN ablation analysis focused on accuracy.](image6)
The results from Table 3 show that GCAN achieved a Recall of 0.8295 on Twitter15 and 0.7632 on Twitter16 [5]. Compared to the DTC method, GCAN shows an improvement [5]. The average Recall improvement of GCAN across both datasets is calculated as follows: on Twitter 15 it is 20.8% and on Twitter16 is 15.9%, thus the average is (20.8 + 15.9) / 2 = 18.35%.

The average Recall improvement of GCAN across both Twitter15 and Twitter16 datasets is 18.35%.

The SciIE framework uses a multi-task learning setup that extends previous span-based models [3]. When evaluating the effect of multi-task learning, performance in individual tasks improves when additional tasks are included [12]. For instance, entity recognition benefits from both coreference resolution and relation extraction [12].

![The table displays results from a series of experiments related to "Entity Recognition," "Relation," and "Coreference" tasks.](image1)

As shown in the table, Entity Recognition achieves a score of 67.5 when multitasked with Coreference Resolution [12]. The unified multi-task setup shows good results for entity recognition, relation extraction, and coreference resolution [7].

The performance score for Entity Recognition when multitasked with Coreference Resolution is 67.5.

In a single-task model, a single decoder attends to the states of an encoder to generate predictions ![Single-task model uses a single decoder attending to the encoder states](image6). Conversely, the multitask model uses a shared encoder, but features separate attention mechanisms and decoders for jointly modeling two output sequences [12].  Both decoders in the multitask model attend to the states of the same encoder, allowing each decoder to focus on different aspects of the encoded input [12]  ![Multitask model uses two decoders that attend to the same encoder's states](image6).

The key difference lies in the presence of multiple decoders, each with its own attention mechanism, in the multitask model, contrasting with the single decoder and attention mechanism in the single-task model.

Step-Back Prompting significantly enhances the performance of PaLM-2L across various challenging tasks, as highlighted in the provided information [1, 4]. The bar chart visually represents the performance of different models, including PaLM-2L with Step-Back Prompting (shown in green), across tasks such as MMLU Physics, MMLU Chemistry, TimeQA, SituatedQA, MuSiQue, and StrategyQA ![The image visually demonstrates how different prompting techniques and models perform across specific evaluation tasks.](image6).

The data indicates that Step-Back Prompting leads to substantial improvements in handling complex reasoning-intensive tasks [4]. For instance, it enhances PaLM-2L's performance on MMLU Physics and Chemistry by 7% and 11% respectively, and on TimeQA by 27% [1, 4]. On the MuSiQue dataset, baseline performances for PaLM-2L and GPT4 are 35.5% and 38.5% respectively; Step-Back Prompting significantly boosts performance to 42.8% [9]. In the ablation experiments, Step-Back Prompting demonstrates robustness against the number of exemplars used, indicating efficient learning of abstraction skills [2]. Also, the strong performance of Step-Back Prompting is displayed in figure 1 [12].

Based on Figure 1, there are six green bars representing PaLM-2L with Step-Back Prompting across the different tasks.

The RAR pipeline is designed to enhance perception tasks by combining retrieving and ranking with multimodal large language models [8]. It addresses limitations in fine-grained recognition and boosts accuracy across vision-language recognition tasks [12]. The pipeline consists of two main components: a multimodal retriever and a retrieving & ranking module [10].

The multimodal retriever is responsible for querying a large external memory to find relevant information [9].  As shown in the pipeline, the retriever uses image embeddings extracted from a dataset, stores and indexes these embeddings in a feature index, and uses k-NN for image-image and image-text retrieval ![The image depicts a two-part pipeline for a process labeled "RAR":](image1). To enhance retrieval speed, an index system employing the HNSW algorithm is implemented, which reduces dimensionality [7].

After constructing the memory, the pipeline integrates it with the retrieval process and uses MLLMs to rank the retrieval results [6]. During the inference stage, the input image is encoded into embeddings, and the top-k categories are retrieved from memory based on similarity [11]. The MLLMs then refine and rank these categories to output the final prediction [11]. The ranking process uses a prompt to merge the input image with the retrieved category information, guiding MLLMs to rank the candidate object categories based on similarity [5].
![The image is a visual example of a ranking prompt for few-shot image classification.](image6)

In summary, the RAR pipeline consists of a multimodal retriever for efficient information retrieval and a ranking module that uses MLLMs to refine and predict the final results.

The authors divide the causal inference process into key steps, as illustrated in the Causal Chain-of-Thought (CausalCoT) model [5]. The model includes a Preparation Phase and a Solution Phase, ensuring a structured approach to answering causal questions ![The image shows the framework for answering causal inference questions.](image6).

The process begins with four preparation steps: identifying the causal graph structure, determining the causal query type, formulating the query symbolically, and extracting relevant data from the prompt [5]. These steps ensure a solid foundation for causal reasoning. In the solution phase, the model deduces the estimand using causal inference techniques and evaluates the estimand to answer the question [5]. Deriving the estimand involves skills such as do-calculus and counterfactual prediction [9]. These steps are verbalized to explain the subskills required for causal inference, such as causal graph extraction, query type interpretation, and semantic parsing [8]. By following these steps, the model can correctly address causal questions, as demonstrated in examples involving vaccination and fatality rates ![The image outlines the steps to reach the conclusion about getting vaccination and increasing the likelihood of death.](image2).

The authors divided causal inference into six key steps.

The Tamil Mix Sentiment dataset, designed for sentiment analysis of YouTube video comments, includes a substantial amount of code-mixed data [2, 3]. The dataset was created to address the lack of annotated code-mixed data for low-resource languages like Tamil [3]. The ultimate goal was to create a dataset with fairly defined sentiments that would be useful for future research [10].

The dataset consists of 169,833 tokens in total, a vocabulary size of 30,898, and comprises 15,744 posts and 17,926 sentences, with an average of 10 tokens per post and 1 sentence per post ![The table presents data related to a Tamil-English language pair, detailing various linguistic characteristics.](image1). The dataset was split into training, validation, and testing sets, containing 11,335, 1,260, and 3,149 sentences respectively [1]. The dataset is unbalanced with a high percentage of positive sentiments [11].

The total number of tokens in the Tamil-English language pair dataset is 169,833.

LLM-based reranking enhances performance on hard samples but impedes performance on easy samples [2]. The filter-then-rerank paradigm integrates both SLMs and LLMs within the same system, using SLMs as filters to select the top candidates, which LLMs then rerank [5]. LLMs are more proficient than SLMs on hard samples, leveraging their extensive knowledge and reasoning [6]. The method selectively reranks hard samples, resulting in a substantial performance boost on those samples [8].

The filter-then-rerank approach leverages SLMs for efficiency and LLMs for accuracy on complex tasks, directing easy samples to SLMs and hard samples to LLMs for reranking, with demonstrations aiding the reranking process ![The adaptive filter-then-rerank paradigm architecture.](image8). As shown in the table, the performance comparison between overall, easy, and hard samples indicates a notable difference in performance metrics across different difficulty levels [2]. Particularly on the FewNERD (NER) dataset, the graph shows performance across different confidence scores, with and without reranking. ![The relationship between confidence scores and micro-F1 performance, with and without LLM reranking using RoBERTa-large as a filter and Instruct GPT as a reranker.](image6)

LLM reranking improves micro-F1 performance for hard samples in the FewNERD dataset, as indicated by performance improvements on those samples.

The DYGIE model leverages iterative propagation to refine span representations for information extraction [6].  The framework dynamically constructs span graphs by selecting confident entity spans and linking them with confidence-weighted relation types and coreferences [6]. This allows coreference and relation type confidences to propagate through the graph, iteratively refining the span representations [6].

The effect of the number of iterations on the F1 score for coreference propagation in the entity extraction task is shown in ![The coreference layer obtains the best performance on the second iteration.](image5). The best performance for the coreference layer is achieved at the second iteration [7].

Similarly, the effect of the number of iterations for relation propagation in the relation extraction task is shown in Figure 3b [3]. The model achieves the best performance on the second iteration for relation propagation [3]. In essence, the iterative refinement process peaks at two iterations for both coreference and relation propagation [3, 7].

In both entity and relation extraction tasks, the F1 score is maximized when the number of iterations for coreference and relation propagation is set to two.

The data sources for distant supervision include head words, entity linking with definitions, and entity linking with a knowledge base (KB). According to the study, each source has a different precision rate which indicates the accuracy and reliability of the signal [3, 5].

The precision for head words is 80.4%, demonstrating a high level of accuracy [3]. Entity linking combined with Wikipedia definitions has a precision of 77.7% ![Entity Linking + Definitions has a precision of 77.7%.](image1). Lastly, entity linking using a knowledge base (KB) has a precision of 77.6% ![Entity Linking + KB has a precision of 77.6%.](image1).

The precision rates for head words, entity linking with definitions, and entity linking with a KB are 80.4%, 77.7%, and 77.6%, respectively.

The "SL + IL 1000 + RL" model demonstrates a superior task success rate compared to other models as interactive dialogue learning sessions progress ![The graph demonstrates the varying success rates achieved by each method over time, with the interactive learning session sizes on the x-axis contributing to the performance escalation in task success rate on the y-axis.](image2). The supervised learning (SL) baseline model has a relatively flat success rate [10]. However, combining supervised learning with reinforcement learning (SL + RL) results in a steady increase in task success rate over time [5]. Further improvements are seen when imitation learning is introduced, as the "SL + IL 500 + RL" model and "SL + IL 1000 + RL" model achieve higher success rates than "SL + RL" [5].

The "SL + IL 1000 + RL" model, represented by blue star-shaped points, achieves high success rates quickly, stabilizing around 0.65 [5, image8]. In comparison, the "SL + RL" model, represented by red pentagon-shaped points, increases steadily but reaches a task success rate of slightly above 0.5 after 10,000 sessions [image8]. This shows that imitation learning effectively adapts the supervised training model to the dialogue state distribution during user interactions [5]. The "SL + IL 1000 + end-to-end RL" line in particular, starts the highest and reaches above 0.65, demonstrating the most significant improvement in task success rate among the settings [2]. The "SL + IL 1000 + RL" model shows hints that imitation learning may effectively adapt the supervised training model to the dialogue state distribution during user interactions [5].

The "SL + IL 1000 + RL" model achieves a higher task success rate more rapidly and plateaus at a higher level compared to the other models.

The SciIE model demonstrates competitive performance across various scientific information extraction tasks. The unified multi-task setup of SciIE shows better performance overall compared to most single-task configurations ![SciIE generally shows better performance in terms of precision, recall, and F1 scores across the tasks compared to the other models.](image7). Specifically, in entity recognition, relation extraction, and coreference resolution, SciIE achieves F1 scores of 68.1, 39.5, and 58.0 respectively [9].

SciIE outperforms previous models that use hand-designed features and shows significant improvement in span identification [12]. The model's ability to enumerate spans effectively, rather than relying on BIO tagging, contributes to this enhancement [12]. In comparison to the best system in the SemEval leaderboard, SciIE delivers competitive results, particularly in span identification [11, 12].

The integration of coreference links significantly enhances the quality and recall of the extracted information.  The system with coreference links has significantly higher recall [7]. This is visually supported by the precision/recall curves, where the knowledge graph with coreference linking outperforms the one without, achieving a higher area under the curve (AUC) [7]. ![The graph indicates that coreference leads to better performance.](image3).

The impact of coreference is also observed in specific detection tasks, where incorporating coreference generally improves performance, particularly in object and pedestrian detection ![Coreference generally improves performance in object and pedestrian detection.](image1). The multi-task setup effectively improves performance across all tasks by sharing span representations and leveraging cross-sentence information [1].

In summary, the SciIE model achieves state-of-the-art results in scientific information extraction, and the incorporation of coreference links further improves its performance, particularly in terms of recall and knowledge graph quality.

SenseBERT enhances word-meaning awareness through semantic level pre-training [2].
SenseBERT's architecture incorporates a masked-word supersense prediction task alongside BERT's original masked-word prediction task, improving its semantic understanding ![SenseBERT includes a masked-word supersense prediction task](image6).
SenseBERT excels in tasks requiring lexical semantic understanding, evidenced by its superior performance on the Word in Context (WiC) task [3].

The table compares BERT\(_{BASE}\) and SenseBERT\(_{BASE}\) across multiple NLP tasks, highlighting their performance differences ![The table compares the performance of two models: BERT\(_{\text{BASE}}\) (OURS) and SenseBERT\(_{\text{BASE}}\)](image1).
SenseBERT achieves an overall score of 77.9, slightly outperforming BERT\(_{BASE}\)'s 77.5 [5].
SenseBERT demonstrates improvements in CoLA, MRPC, and QNLI tasks compared to BERT\(_{BASE}\) [image1].
SenseBERT shows significant gains on a supersense variant of the SemEval Word Sense Disambiguation (WSD) data set [8].
SenseBERT surpasses BERT\(_{LARGE}\) in the Word in Context (WiC) task, showcasing better word-sense awareness [8].
In the SemEval-SS Frozen setting, SenseBERT introduces a dramatic improvement, implying that its word-sense aware pre-training yields easily extractable lexical semantic information [3].

SenseBERT BASE outperforms both BERT\(_{BASE}\) and BERT LARGE on a supersense variant of the SemEval Word Sense Disambiguation (WSD) dataset [8].
SenseBERT shows improvements in predicting the correct supersense of words in context, where BERT fails [12].
![The table presents a comparison of various language models and their performance on the "Word in Context" task](image3)

SenseBERT generally performs on par with or better than BERT, particularly in tasks requiring a high level of lexical semantic understanding [3, 5].
SenseBERT exhibits a clear advantage over BERT in tasks that demand a deeper understanding of word meanings and contexts.

Weighted decoding can be used to control attributes such as semantic relatedness of the model’s response [5]. However, it can lead to nonsensical output if extreme weights are applied [5]. The table in the image illustrates this point clearly.

With an input of "Yes, I'm studying law at the moment," the baseline response (Wt = 0.0) is "That sounds like a lot of fun!" with an NIDF of 17.1%. When a negative weight is applied (Wt = -5.0), the response becomes "Oh......................................" with a very low NIDF of 0.6%. As the weight increases, the responses become more unusual. At Wt = 7.0, the response is "I majored in practising my spiritual full-time philosophy test" with an NIDF of 38.5%, and at Wt = 10.0, it turns into "Oh wow! Merna jean isa paino yi hao hui bu acara sya gila [...]" with a high NIDF of 71.9% ![The table displays how different weights applied during weighted decoding affect the generated responses, using the input "Yes, I'm studying law at the moment".](image1)

The weight significantly impacts the generated response, with extreme weights leading to less coherent and nonsensical outputs [5].

The general architecture involves learning shared parameters to classify each warrant independently with the argument, resulting in logits [3]. These logits are then used to determine a probability distribution over the two warrants [5].

To classify each warrant independently with the argument, shared parameters are learned, yielding logits ![The image depicts the general architecture of a model.](image5). These logits are subsequently used to compute a probability distribution across the warrants [3, 5].

The probability distribution over the two warrants is determined using the softmax function.

SenseBERT uses supersenses to abstract the meaning of words in a sentence, which allows it to generalize semantically [4]. In the example, "Dan cooked a bass on the grill", SenseBERT abstracts the sentence to "[Person] [created] [food] on the [artifact]" [4]. This abstraction identifies "bass" as "noun.food" in this context, rather than just processing the word itself ![The image contains two sentences with parts of speech and word sense annotations for specific words](image4).

SenseBERT recognizes "bass" as food by understanding the context of the sentence.

The Graph-aware Co-Attention Networks (GCAN) model was developed to predict fake news using the source tweet and its propagation-based users [5]. It utilizes dual co-attention mechanisms to capture the correlation between the source tweet and user interactions [5]. GCAN aims to solve the fake news detection problem by predicting the authenticity of source tweets and providing explanations by highlighting suspicious retweeters [6]. The model's effectiveness was evaluated on Twitter15 and Twitter16 datasets [10].

![The table presents a comparison of datasets labeled Twitter15 and Twitter16, likely related to studies of tweet veracity.](image8)

The Twitter15 dataset contains 190,868 users, while the Twitter16 dataset includes 115,036 users, based on the data collected [10]. The dual co-attention mechanism in GCAN is quite powerful, and sequential features learned from the retweet user sequence in GCAN-G can significantly boost performance [11].  Even with a limited number of retweeters, GCAN can achieve high accuracy in early detection of spreading fake news [1].

The difference in the number of users between the Twitter15 and Twitter16 datasets is 75,832.

In the architecture described, each word of a sentence is initially processed through word embeddings before being fed into Recurrent Neural Networks (RNN) [1]. The word embedding serves as a numerical representation of the word. As illustrated in the neural network architecture, the input words are converted into word embeddings, which are then passed to bi-directional Long Short-Term Memory (LSTM) layers ![The image shows a word-level neural network architecture for Named Entity Recognition (NER).](image3). This process allows the model to capture contextual information from both previous and subsequent words in the sentence. The character embeddings transform each character into a numerical vector representation that can be processed by the neural network ![The image depicts a neural network architecture designed for character-level Named Entity Recognition (NER).](image1).

Each word in a sentence is converted into a word embedding before being input to the LSTM layers [1].

The utilization of retrieval augmentation (RA) demonstrates a positive impact on both accuracy and hallucination rates across different entity categories. The results show that retrieval augmentation can significantly enhance performance across various entity types [11]. ![The table illustrates the effects of Retrieval Augmentation (RA) on accuracy and hallucination rates across Head, Torso, and Tail categories, showing improvements in accuracy and reductions in hallucination when RA is applied.](image4)

Notably, the performance improvement for torso-to-tail entities far exceeds that of head entities, effectively addressing the challenge of hallucinations in long-tailed entities through retrieval augmentation [11]. This is because long-tail entities appear infrequently in training datasets, posing a challenge for vision-extended LLMs [4]. The comparison of accuracy and hallucination rates with and without RA across Head, Torso and Tail categories indicates that accuracy increases while hallucination decreases in all categories when RA is applied.

For "Head" entities, accuracy increases from 24.4 to 27.1, while hallucination decreases from 75.6 to 72.9. Similarly, "Torso" entities see an accuracy increase from 19.1 to 22.7, with hallucination decreasing from 80.9 to 77.3. The most significant improvement is observed in "Tail" entities, where accuracy jumps from 6.8 to 12.6, and hallucination drops from 93.2 to 87.4.

Retrieval Augmentation improves accuracy and reduces hallucination rates across Head, Torso, and Tail entity categories, with the most significant gains observed in Tail entities.

The Translation Ranking model uses the triplet margin loss to optimize the embedding space, ensuring that "better" hypotheses are closer to the source and reference embeddings than "worse" hypotheses [5, 6, 10]. This loss function plays a crucial role in training the model to discern quality differences between translations.

The architecture of the Translation Ranking model involves encoding the source, reference, and both "better" and "worse" hypotheses, then uses the triplet margin loss to minimize the distance between the "better" hypothesis and the source/reference "anchors" ![Translation Ranking model optimizes the embedding space to minimize the distance between the "better" hypothesis and the "anchors".](image7). The model is trained such that the distance between the anchors and the "worse" hypothesis is greater than the distance between the anchors and the "better" hypothesis by at least a margin  $\epsilon$ [10].

The triplet margin loss is optimized to create sentence embeddings; this allows closely related sentences to map near each other in the embedding space, while unrelated sentences are pushed farther apart ![Triplet Margin Loss is a loss function used during training.](image7).

The purpose of the triplet margin loss in the Translation Ranking model is to optimize the embedding space by ensuring that the "better" hypothesis is closer to the source and reference than the "worse" one.

Post-hoc correction refines model output after generation without updating model parameters, incorporating iterative feedback for a more flexible and explainable self-correction process [6]. This method allows for diverse natural language feedback, from diagnostic reports to writing suggestions [9].

In the 'Post-hoc Correction with External Feedback' strategy, a language model generates outputs, which are then reviewed by a critic model providing feedback, and external models/tools like knowledge bases and search engines assist in refining these outputs ![The image illustrates three post-hoc correction strategies:Self-Correction (a), Post-hoc Correction with External Feedback (b), and Multi-Agent Debate (c)](image3). External knowledge ensures the factual accuracy of the output by prompting LLMs to question their outputs and refining them using relevant evidence obtained through external retrievers [2]. The integration of external feedback is crucial, as it often necessitates superior performance compared to relying solely on self-feedback [12].

Post-hoc correction with external feedback enhances output refinement by using external tools and knowledge to improve and fact-check the generated content.

The provided information details the use of prompt templates within a filter-then-rerank paradigm for information extraction tasks. This paradigm leverages both smaller language models (SLMs) for filtering and larger language models (LLMs) for reranking to improve performance [2]. The approach involves converting candidate labels into question options using predefined templates [6].

The prompts consist of instructions, demonstrations, and a question [7]. These prompts are formatted using templates [1]. The use of multi-choice question (MCQ) prompts helps LLMs to rerank candidates more effectively [3, 9]. Templates are designed for different datasets like FewNERD, TACREV and ACE05 [6]. Examples of prompts on four IE tasks are available [7]. The filter-then-rerank approach uses SLMs to make preliminary decisions, and LLMs rerank the top N predictions for hard samples, using MCQ prompts [9].

RAPTOR employs two distinct querying mechanisms: tree traversal and collapsed tree, each offering unique advantages [7]. The tree traversal method selects the top-k most relevant root nodes based on cosine similarity, progressing layer by layer, selecting top nodes at each level until reaching the leaf nodes [8]. This approach allows for control over the specificity and breadth of retrieved information by adjusting the depth and the number of nodes selected [9].

In contrast, the collapsed tree approach simplifies the search by considering all nodes in the tree simultaneously, effectively flattening the multi-layered structure into a single layer for comparison, as illustrated in ![The image illustrates Tree Traversal Retrieval, which traverses the tree layer-by-layer, and Collapsed Tree Retrieval, which evaluates nodes collectively across all layers.](image3) [10, 11].

Experiments show that the collapsed tree approach often performs better because it retrieves information at the correct level of granularity for a given question by searching through all the nodes simultaneously [3]. The collapsed tree with 2000 tokens showed the best results in the QASPER dataset, as shown in ![The image shows the collapsed tree method performed better than the tree traversal method with different context lengths.](image4).

In summary, tree traversal navigates the tree layer-by-layer, while collapsed tree considers all nodes simultaneously for retrieval.

The latent space learned by VAE is smoother and more continuous than DAE [8]. Both DAE and VAE models are used to visualize the disentangled style and content spaces for Yelp data ![The image shows t-SNE plots that visualize the disentangled style and content spaces for Yelp data](image1). Sentences with different styles are noticeably separated in the style space, but are indistinguishable in the content space [8]. The style space plots show data points color-coded as either 'neg' (negative, in blue) or 'pos' (positive, in red); for DAE, the points are separated into distinct clusters for each class, while in VAE, the points are also noticeably clustered but less distinctly separated compared to DAE ![The image shows t-SNE plots that visualize the disentangled style and content spaces for Yelp data](image1).

VAE produces a smoother and more continuous latent space compared to DAE, as evidenced by the t-SNE plots showing style and content separation.

The "hard-to-contrast" querying strategy stands out as a robust choice for active learning across various datasets [4]. On PathMNIST, OrganAMNIST, and BloodMNIST, selecting hard-to-contrast data leads to significant performance gains compared to random selection [4]. For instance, querying 0.1% of the entire dataset using this strategy improves performance by 5.2% on BloodMNIST and 1.8% on PathMNIST [4].

This approach is particularly valuable in scenarios where ground truth labels are unavailable, making strategies like "easy-to-learn" or "hard-to-learn" impractical [4]. While "easy-to-learn" strategies can perform similarly, they rely on knowing the ground truths, a limitation in active learning [4].

The consistent outperformance of the "hard-to-contrast" strategy is visually represented in the bar chart ![The "hard-to-contrast” strategy tends to outperform others across different datasets.](image7), which compares map-based querying strategies across PathMNIST, OrganAMNIST, BloodMNIST, and CIFAR-10-LT using the AUC metric.  In each dataset, "hard-to-contrast" either leads or closely competes with the top-performing strategies.

Therefore, the hard-to-contrast querying strategy consistently performs best across different datasets based on AUC.

Experiments reveal that using more training data significantly increases accuracy [6]. Models trained on Common Crawl data show improved performance with larger datasets ![The graph illustrates that as more training data is used, the average GLUE score increases, indicating improved model performance.](image8). Specifically, models trained on up to 18B Common Crawl tokens suggest a trend where more data leads to better results [6].  The effects of varying the size of the training data, particularly Common Crawl data, impacts model performance [2].

Models were trained on Common Crawl data using the CNN base architecture with the same hyper-parameter settings for 600K updates [6]. The results suggest that increasing the amount of training data likely leads to further improvements in performance [6]. Data from Common Crawl benefits tasks like CoLA and RTE, and multi-sentence training examples enhance end-task performance for sentence pairs [2].

The Common Crawl dataset, which is web data, was pre-processed following the same steps as Grave et al. (2018), based on the May 2017 Common Crawl dump, with 20 copies of English Wikipedia added, making up about 14% of the final dataset [8]. Subsampling was done up to 18B tokens [8].

Training with 18B tokens of Common Crawl data resulted in the highest average accuracy across GLUE tasks.

Active querying strategies often struggle to surpass random selection, especially at the beginning of the learning process [6, 8]. This is because active learning strategies can be biased towards specific classes, leading to an unbalanced representation of the data [8]. The importance of label diversity in improving the performance and robustness of active querying strategies is highlighted, particularly in imbalanced datasets like CIFAR-10-LT [12].

![The graph demonstrates the impact of label diversity on active querying strategies across three datasets, indicating improved performance with label diversity.](image6)

Enforcing label diversity can significantly improve performance, suggesting that a lack of diversity is a cause for the poorer performance of active querying strategies compared to random selection [2]. The querying strategy that selects "hard-to-contrast" data is a label-free approach that outperforms random selection, addressing the cold start problem effectively [4]. Specifically, hard-to-contrast querying strategy significantly outperforms random selection by 21.2% and 24.1% by querying 20% and 30% of the entire CIFAR-10-LT dataset respectively [4].

![The data map illustrates querying strategies using ground truth and pseudo-labels, highlighting easy-to-learn, hard-to-learn, easy-to-contrast, and hard-to-contrast data points in the CIFAR-10-LT dataset.](image4)

Only one querying strategy, selecting hard-to-contrast data, is shown to outperform the random selection baseline on CIFAR-10-LT [4].

The combination layers, marked as "comb," serve to integrate information from processed states of each input token, as depicted in Figure 2 ![The illustration visualizes how information is aggregated and transformed to generate meaningful embeddings used for classifying based on sequence input, demonstrating specific adjustments during the fine-tuning phase.](image6). These layers gather information from the forward and backward passes to generate embeddings for classification [7]. The forward and backward representations are combined to predict the ablated word using a self-attention module followed by an FFN block [5]. During training, all states containing information about the target word are masked in the final self-attention block, but this masking is disabled during fine-tuning for downstream tasks to allow access to the full context, including the token itself [10].  The combination mechanism combines the outputs from the forward and backward sequences using a standard multi-head self-attention module, and the result is further processed by a classifier to predict the center token ![This combines the outputs from the green and blue sequences using a standard multi-head self-attention module.](image7).

The combination layers integrate information from forward and backward passes to generate embeddings used for classification.

GPT-4V's errors have been meticulously analyzed to understand its limitations and guide future improvements [2]. The analysis of 150 randomly sampled error instances revealed the distribution of these errors, identified by expert annotators [2].

![The pie chart illustrates the distribution of error types in GPT-4V, with perceptual errors being the most prevalent at 35%.](image8)

The error distribution indicates that perceptual errors are the most frequent, accounting for 35% of the inaccuracies [9]. These perceptual errors include both basic and domain-specific types [9]. Basic perceptual errors involve failures in elementary visual interpretation, while domain-specific errors stem from a lack of specialized knowledge [9]. For example, GPT-4V sometimes struggles with basic tasks that are easy for humans ![The image illustrates a basic perceptual error where GPT-4V struggles with a task easy for humans.](image10).

Therefore, the most common error type in GPT-4V's analysis is perceptual error.

End-to-end optimization in dialogue agent training has proven beneficial [10]. The task success rate varies across different reinforcement learning (RL) training settings, as illustrated in the learning curves ![The image is a line graph depicting the interactive learning curves for task success rate over time with different reinforcement learning (RL) training settings.](image6).

Models were compared using two different RL training settings: end-to-end training and policy-only training [10]. End-to-end RL training propagates the gradient from the system action output layer all the way back to the natural language user input layer [10]. Policy-only training updates only the policy network parameters during interactive learning with RL, keeping all other underlying system parameters fixed [10].

The model that combines supervised learning, 1000 episodes of imitation learning, and end-to-end RL (SL + IL 1000 + end-to-end RL) achieves the highest task success rate over time [2, 10].

The TRADE model, pre-trained on four domains, can be fine-tuned for domain expansion, and Gradient Episodic Memory (GEM) outperforms naive and EWC fine-tuning in mitigating catastrophic forgetting [3]. For example, after fine-tuning with GEM, the performance on the original four domains only drops from 58.98% to 53.54% (-5.44%) on joint accuracy in the hotel domain, while naive fine-tuning deteriorates the tracking ability, dropping joint goal accuracy to 36.08% (-22.9%) [8].

Furthermore, fine-tuning from the base model generally yields better results on the new domain compared to training from scratch [2]. GEM also outperforms naive fine-tuning on new domains; for instance, GEM achieves 34.73% joint accuracy on the attraction domain, whereas naive fine-tuning only achieves 29.39% [9].

The ACE2004 and ACE2005 corpora offer entity and relation labels across various domains [3]. DYGIE uses dynamically constructed span graphs to perform information extraction tasks [2]. Coreference and relation type confidence can propagate through the graph to refine span representations [2]. The frequent confusions associated with pronouns greatly improve with coreference propagation [7].

Regarding coreference resolution, ACE04 and SciERC include it, as indicated by checkmarks [image3]. However, ACE05 and WLP do not have coreference resolution [image3].

TRADE exhibits remarkable transfer learning capabilities, as demonstrated by its performance when expanding from four domains to a new one [6]. Fine-tuning with GEM also maintains higher performance [1]. The architecture of TRADE, which includes an utterance encoder, slot gate, and state generator, facilitates knowledge transfer, allowing it to predict (domain, slot, value) triplets not encountered during training ![The diagram includes flow arrows and components connected to form a pipeline from input utterance to output generation, with examples provided for domains (Hotel, Train, etc.) and slots (Price, Area, etc.).](image3).

When expanding domains, fine-tuning with GEM outperforms naive and EWC fine-tuning, mitigating catastrophic forgetting [4, 7]. For instance, TRADE achieves a joint accuracy of $59.83\%$ after fine-tuning using only $1\%$ of training domain data, surpassing training from scratch, which achieves $44.24\%$ using the same amount of new-domain data [6]. In domain expansion experiments, fine-tuning from the base model generally achieves better results on the new domain compared to training from scratch [7].

Examining zero-shot performance, the taxi domain achieves a high joint goal accuracy of $60.58\%$, close to the result of training on all taxi domain data ($76.13\%$) [9].  In the zero-shot setting, while performance varies across domains, TRADE still achieves around 50 to $65\%$ slot accuracy without in-domain samples [9].

Based on the provided information, the joint accuracy in the "Train" domain improved by 15.59% (59.83% - 44.24%) when using GEM fine-tuning compared to training from scratch.

When models are presented with only relevant documents, their performance improves significantly, particularly in the masked setting for BiDAF, reaching up to 81.2%/85.7% on WIKI HOP [2].  This demonstrates that RC models are more capable of identifying the answer when fewer plausible false candidates are present [2].

Conversely, the models' answer selection is not robust when unrelated documents with type-consistent candidates are introduced [2].  This highlights that intelligently selecting relevant documents before RC is a promising area for future model development [2].  For example, the TF-IDF retrieval baseline performs better than random for WIKI HOP, but is not very strong overall [3].

![The table presents the performance of different models on two datasets: WikiHop and MedHop.](image7)

In the gold chain setup, BiDAF mask achieves 81.2/85.7 on WikiHop and 99.3/100.0 on MedHop, while FastQA mask scores 65.3/70.0 and 51.8/55.1 respectively [image7]. This shows that the models' answer selection process is not robust to the introduction of unrelated documents with type-consistent candidates [2].

The performance of both BiDAF and FastQA models improves significantly on WIKIHOP and MEDHOP datasets when tested with only relevant documents.

Chameleon leverages a supervised fine-tuning (SFT) strategy that incorporates a cosine learning rate schedule, starting at an initial rate of 1e-5, combined with a weight decay set at 0.1, using a batch size of 128 and sequences up to 4096 tokens [10]. Balancing modalities within the SFT stage is crucial for high-quality alignment, preventing the model from developing an unconditional prior for generating a single modality [11]. The SFT dataset is categorized into Text, Code, Visual Chat, Image Generation, Interleaved Text/Image Generation, and Safety [2].

The SFT dataset statistics reveal the number of samples, tokens and images used in each category. For example, the text category contains 1.6 million samples and 940.0 million tokens while the Image Generation category contains 64.3 thousand samples and 68.0 million tokens ![The table presents information about different categories of data related to "Chameleon-SFT."](image5). The statistics highlight the importance of high-quality data collection, particularly for Visual Chat and Interleaved Text/Image Generation, using third-party vendors [4].

The model is capable of reasoning over and generating interleaved image-text documents [1]. By training on an interleaved mixture of images, text, and code, Chameleon is designed to be mixed-modal from inception, using a uniform architecture trained from scratch in an end-to-end fashion [9]. This allows for full multimodal document modeling, enabling the model to understand and generate images and text in any arbitrary sequence [5]. The models are evaluated on a comprehensive range of tasks, including visual question answering, image captioning, text generation, image generation, and long-form mixed modal generation [5].
![The image consists of two diagrams illustrating a Mixed-Modal Auto-Regressive Language Model (LM) called "Chameleon" that handles text and image tokens.](image1)

The supervised fine-tuning dataset statistics reflect the distribution of data types used to train Chameleon, influencing its ability to handle various tasks such as text generation, image generation, and interleaved multimodal content.

Step-Back prompting significantly boosts model performance, surpassing even GPT-4 in certain tasks [3, 4, 7]. For instance, it improves PaLM-2L's performance on MMLU Physics and Chemistry by 7% and 11%, respectively [7]. The error analysis reveals that Step-Back prompting effectively corrects many baseline prediction errors while introducing relatively few new errors [1, 6].

The table compares different methods and their performance on two datasets, MuSiQue and StrategyQA. The methods evaluated include variations of PaLM-2L with different techniques and GPT-4. ![PaLM-2L + Step-Back + RAG (ours) achieves the highest performance on both MuSiQue and StrategyQA datasets](image1)

On challenging multi-hop reasoning benchmarks like MuSiQue and StrategyQA, Step-Back prompting consistently demonstrates superior performance [2, 4]. While baseline models like PaLM-2L and GPT-4 struggle on MuSiQue, Step-Back prompting, especially when combined with retrieval augmentation (RAG), achieves the best results [4]. In fact, S TEP -B ACK  P ROMPTING  is helpful most of the time, signifying the need and effectiveness of doing Abstraction before directly addressing the original question [1].

PaLM-2L + Step-Back + RAG (ours) achieves the highest performance on both MuSiQue (42.8%) and StrategyQA (86.4%) datasets [image1].

The SciTAB dataset presents unique challenges for scientific fact-checking, revealing complexities in real-world claims [5, 10]. An analysis of refuted claims within SciTAB indicates a greater diversity of reasons compared to other datasets [9].

Incorrect calculation results account for a significant portion of refuted claims ![The table lists different reasons for refuting information along with their respective proportions (in percentage).](image5). However, SciTAB also includes unique error types reflective of real-world scientific complexities, such as incorrect approximation words and partially correct claims [9].

Examining the reasons for refuted claims in SciTAB, "incorrect calculation results" account for 41.7% of the errors, with "incorrect approximation words" following at 33.3% ![The table contains two sections titled "Refuted Reasons" and "NEI Reasons," each listing reasons along with their proportional percentages:](image1).

The most common reason for a refuted claim in the SciTAB dataset is incorrect calculation results.

The RAR pipeline combines a multi-modal retriever and a ranking system using MLLMs to enhance recognition tasks [3, 7]. The retriever uses image encoders and a feature index to find similar images, and the MLLMs rank the retrieved categories to provide a final prediction [4, 7]. As shown in the pipeline, an image is encoded into embeddings and top-K categories are retrieved from memory based on similarity ![The image depicts a two-part pipeline for a process labeled "RAR":](image2).

In the illustrated example within the "Retrieving & Ranking (b)" section of the pipeline, the input image used as a case is a "Monarch butterfly" [4]. The pipeline's goal is to accurately predict this label by retrieving similar images and ranking the possible categories using MLLMs [7]. This integrated approach leverages both retrieval and ranking to improve the accuracy of image recognition tasks [3].

The input image used in the RAR pipeline diagram is a Monarch butterfly.

The variability in question language is high, with only $44\%$ of questions starting with WH-words [2]. Instead, formulators sometimes use first names to create context or the word "if" to present hypothetical questions [2].

The distribution of the first and second words in the formulated questions is shown in the semicircular diagram ![The chart displays the frequency of starting words in questions, highlighting "What," "Where," and "The" as common choices.](image8). "What" appears in 21% of the questions, "Where" in 18%, and "The" in 13% [2]. Other common starting words include "If" (7%), "What would" (5%), and names like "James" and "John" (both 2%) [2]. The largest segment, "Other," accounts for 37% of the distribution [2].

The most common starting words in questions are "What" (21%), "Where" (18%), and "The" (13%).

The DETR model uses a transformer decoder that decodes $N$ objects in parallel at each decoder layer [5]. These $N$ input embeddings must be different to produce different results and are learnt positional encodings referred to as "object queries" [5].

![The image is an illustration of the DETR (Detection Transformer) model architecture, which is used for object detection tasks.](image5)

The object queries are transformed into an output embedding by the decoder and then independently decoded into box coordinates and class labels by a feed forward network, resulting in $N$ final predictions [5]. The model globally reasons about all objects together using pair-wise relations between them, while being able to use the whole image as context by using self- and encoder-decoder attention over these embeddings [5]. Positional encodings, including output positional encodings (object queries), are crucial, as removing spatial positional encodings can result in a significant drop in average precision (AP) [4].

![This table compares different detection models based on several metrics.](image6)

DETR uses learned positional encodings, known as object queries, to produce distinct outputs and enable parallel decoding of objects.

RAR benefits from both fine-tuning and in-context learning, with fine-tuning generally providing a more substantial boost in performance [12]. The results in Tab. 6 show a consistent improvement in accuracy for the fine-tuned model across almost all datasets for both QWen-VL and InternLM-XC2 [12].

![The table presents performance metrics for different methods evaluated on several datasets.](image5)

Specifically, when using InternLM-XC2, fine-tuning consistently enhances the model’s ranking capabilities across various datasets [12]. While in-context learning offers a training-free alternative, fine-tuning with datasets like FGVC-Aircraft often yields superior results [5, 12]. The choice of fine-tuning data, however, does not drastically impact the overall performance, indicating the robustness of the RAR method [10, 11]. Even with different datasets for fine-tuning, RAR maintains its ability to improve MLLM performance, confirming its reliability [10].

Therefore, fine-tuning generally outperforms in-context learning for RAR on the InternLM-XC2 model, providing a more consistent and significant improvement in accuracy across different datasets.

QAC HECK is a system designed to fact-check claims by guiding the model’s reasoning through a series of questions [1, 9]. It decomposes complex claims into simpler steps, enhancing accuracy through question-guided reasoning [3]. The system's architecture includes a claim verifier, question generator, QA module, QA validator, and reasoner, supporting a transparent and explainable fact-checking process ![The image is a flowchart illustrating the architecture of the QAC HECK system.](image1). The user can input a claim, and the system predicts its veracity, providing a detailed reasoning report based on (question, answer) pairs [1]. This multi-hop reasoning process, with explanations and retrieved evidence, addresses the limitations of systems that validate claims using only a single document [2].

QAC HECK demonstrates effective performance on datasets like HOVER and FEVEROUS [3, 12]. The HOVER dataset contains 1,126 two-hop claims, 1,835 three-hop claims, and 1,039 four-hop claims [4].

The table shows the performance of QAC HECK and other models like InstructGPT, Codex, and FLAN-T5 on the HOVER dataset, which includes 2-hop, 3-hop, and 4-hop claims ![The table presents the performance of different AI models on two datasets: HOVER and FEVEROUS.](image3). To find the average performance gap between ProgramFC and QAC HECK on the HOVER dataset, we calculate the difference for each hop:
- 2-hop: 55.67 (QAC HECK) - 54.27 (ProgramFC) = 1.40
- 3-hop: 54.67 (QAC HECK) - 54.18 (ProgramFC) = 0.49
- 4-hop: 52.35 (QAC HECK) - 52.88 (ProgramFC) = -0.53

Now, we find the average of these differences: (1.40 + 0.49 + -0.53) / 3 = 0.45333.

The average performance gap between ProgramFC and QAC HECK in the HOVER dataset is 0.45.

The "hard-coded personality" model uses a fixed, scaled 5-dimensional vector to represent a user's personality [1].  This vector is derived from the user's five personality traits, with each score scaled to sum to a unit value [1]. The diagram illustrates three methods of integrating personality traits, including the hard-coded method ![The diagram presents three methods for incorporating OCEAN scores, including the hard-coded method.](image2).

The process involves scaling the raw OCEAN scores to create a fixed personality vector, and this vector remains constant during training because no gradient is applied to it [2]. For instance, a user with OCEAN scores of {30, 70, 50, 30, 20} would have these scores scaled to create a personality vector of {0.3, 0.7, 0.5, 0.3, 0.2} [2]. This scaled vector is then combined with other latent vectors in a Multi-Layer Perceptron (MLP) to produce a score [2].

The personality scores, corresponding to the OCEAN model, are normalized to a range from 1 to 100, where a higher score indicates a more overt trait [12].
The experimental results demonstrate that NCF with Soft-labeled/Hard-coded outperforms NCF with the most salient personality in terms of NDCG, indicating that utilizing all five personality traits is more effective than relying on just the most salient one in NCF [11].  The table provides performance metrics for NCF models using different personality integration methods, including hard-coded personality ![The table presents performance metrics for NCF models using different personality integration methods, including hard-coded personality.](image4).

The personality scores for the hard-coded personality model, derived from scaling the OCEAN scores to sum to a unit value, are [20, 30, 30, 50, 70].

The ScRNN model is a semi-character based RNN that processes a sentence of words with misspelled characters, predicting the correct words at each step [2]. The architecture of ScRNN contains a background and foreground model to recognize the correct word [4].

The neutral backoff variant reduces the number of unique outputs it predicts, as it returns a ﬁxed neutral word whenever the ScRNN predicts an unknown word [1].  The most accurate variant involves backing off to the background model, resulting in a lower error rate and the best performance on word recognition [6].

The table shows that ScRNN with a background dataset of 10K words generally has the lowest scores across all types of errors, indicating superior performance in correcting spelling errors compared to ATD and other ScRNN variants. ![{The Background variant of ScRNN (10K) has the lowest scores across all types of errors compared to the other methods listed.}](image1)

The ScRNN model with background backoff performs the best across all types of spelling errors [6].

Contextual augmentation leverages a bi-directional language model to predict suitable substitute words within a sentence [9, 12]. For instance, in the sentence "the actors are fantastic," the word "actors" can be replaced with contextually relevant words such as "performances," "films," "movies," or "stories" ![The image illustrates the process of contextual augmentation using a bi-directional RNN language model. It begins with the sentence “the actors are fantastic.” The word "actors" is highlighted and is replaced with words like "performances," "films," "movies," and "stories," which are contextually predicted by the model. The sentences generated retain a positive sentiment label. The image visually shows how the RNN processes the context to predict suitable substitutions while maintaining the overall sentiment.](image3). This method aims to maintain the naturalness and label-compatibility of the augmented sentences [7].

The results indicate that the label-conditional architecture boosts performance [10]. As demonstrated in the example from the SST dataset, the word "fantastic" is replaced with positive expressions like "funny," "honest," and "good" when a positive label is used. Conversely, with a negative label, it's replaced with negative expressions like "tired," "forgettable," and "bad" [6]. The Sythus pipeline is designed for the automated generation of high-quality instruction-response pairs in multiple languages [4, 6]. It leverages ChatGPT to create these pairs based on visual content [4]. The process begins with a system message and visual annotations to guide ChatGPT ![The image is a flowchart explaining the Sythus process for generating high-quality instruction-response pairs in eight languages.](image2). The system message defines the desired tone and style, while visual annotations offer essential image information like bounding boxes and descriptions [4].

A "cold-start" strategy is employed to enhance in-context examples before large-scale querying, where ChatGPT is prompted using only system messages and visual annotations to collect satisfactory examples [4]. Subsequently, ChatGPT generates instruction-response pairs [4]. These pairs then undergo a filtering process to ensure their quality [4]. Finally, the instruction-response pairs are translated into eight languages [4]. This multi-step approach ensures the creation of diverse and contextually relevant instruction-response pairs [12].

In summary, the Sythus process involves system message and visual annotation, cold start for in-context examples, generation of instruction-response pairs using ChatGPT, filtering for quality, and translation into multiple languages.

The Translation Ranking model uses a specific set of inputs to assess and rank the quality of machine translations [4]. The model receives a tuple  $\chi=(s,h^{+},h^{-},r)$ as input, where $h^{+}$ is a higher-ranked hypothesis compared to $h^{-}$ [4]. This model is designed to minimize the distance between a "better" hypothesis and both its corresponding reference and its original source [8].

The architecture of the Translation Ranking model involves encoding these inputs independently using a pre-trained cross-lingual encoder ![The image shows a neural network architecture diagram for translation ranking, with source, reference, and hypotheses encoded and optimized using triplet margin loss.](image5). This process creates sentence embeddings for each segment, which are then used to compute the triplet margin loss in relation to the source and reference [4]. The model is optimized to minimize the distance between the "better" hypothesis and the anchors (source and reference) [1].

Including the source text improves the overall correlation with human judgments, suggesting its importance in the ranking process [2]. The model is trained using the WMT DA RR corpus [5].

In summary, the Translation Ranking model takes the source text, a better hypothesis, a worse hypothesis, and a reference translation as inputs to rank translation quality.

This indicates a substantial increase in efficiency when employing context compression with anchor states for this specific dataset and model.

GPT2-XL can speed up by 2.5x on AGNews using anchor-only context compression.

The Helpfulness Reward Model (RM) and the Safety RM show different levels of accuracy on the Meta Helpful test set, indicating varying degrees of success in determining helpfulness. The average accuracy of the Helpfulness RM on the Meta Helpful test set is 63.2, whereas the Safety RM has an average accuracy of 56.2 [image6]. This suggests that the Helpfulness RM is better at identifying helpful responses within the Meta Helpful test set compared to the Safety RM.

The results from the "Significantly Better" category in the Meta Helpful test set show that the Helpfulness RM scores 80.7, while the Safety RM scores 64.6 [image6]. This indicates that the Helpfulness RM is significantly better at distinguishing markedly superior responses in terms of helpfulness compared to the Safety RM.

The differing performance between the Helpfulness RM and Safety RM highlights the tension between optimizing for helpfulness versus safety [4, 12].  While the Safety RM prioritizes identifying safe responses, it appears less accurate in determining the helpfulness of responses, as evidenced by its lower scores on the Meta Helpful test set [5].  The Helpfulness RM, trained to identify helpful responses, performs better on the Meta Helpful test set [5].

In summary, the Helpfulness RM outperforms the Safety RM on the Meta Helpful test set, with an average accuracy of 63.2 compared to the Safety RM's 56.2 [image6].

The evaluation of the WMT19 News Translation Task involved scoring translation outputs with automatic metrics and comparing them against human judgments [1]. Direct Assessment (DA) was used as the primary form of manual evaluation [1]. The goal was to determine how well the automatic metrics correlated with human assessments at both the system and segment levels [1].

Several metrics, including variations of YiSi, were evaluated across different language pairs, and the results of significance testing for segment-level metrics are visualized for language pairs like German to Czech, German to French, and French to German ![Yisi-1 generally outperforms other metrics across language pairs, as shown by the significance tests.](image6). In system-level evaluation, the YiSi metrics often achieved the highest correlations [4]. Specifically, metrics based on word or sentence-level embeddings, such as YiSi and ESIM, demonstrated high performance [6]. The evaluation also involved converting pairs of DA scores to daRR better/worse preferences to address limitations in segment-level metric evaluation [12].

![This table compares human evaluation metrics and QE metrics for various language pairs involving English, highlighting the best scores in bold.](image8)

Looking at the table of results for the newstest2019 dataset, we can identify the highest score for the en-ru language pair among the listed evaluation metrics. For the en-ru pair, YiSi-1 achieves the highest score.

YiSi-1 has the highest score for the en-ru language pair in the newstest2019 dataset.

The relation extraction performance is influenced by the number of entities in a sentence, as shown in ![DyGIE generally outperforms DyGIE-RelProp across all categories, but performance decreases with more entities.](image7). As the number of entities increases, the performance of relation extraction tends to decrease. However, relation propagation aims to mitigate this decline, particularly in sentences with multiple relation instances [10]. The optimal performance for relation propagation is often achieved with a specific number of iterations, as indicated by the best performance at the second iteration [8].

DYGIE improves relation extraction, achieving a 25.8% relative improvement over the state of the art on ACE04 and a 13.7% relative improvement on ACE05 [5]. The relation propagation helps in sentences with more entities [1]. DYGIE uses dynamic span graphs to enhance interaction across tasks, using broader context without needing syntactic tools [2]. The computation cost of relation propagation is small relative to the baseline span-based model [2].

![The table presents performance metrics for different models on entity recognition and relation extraction tasks.](image5)

Relation extraction performance decreases as the number of entities in a sentence increases, but relation propagation can improve performance, especially in sentences with multiple entities and optimized iterations.

The DSC loss, when used with BERT, enhances performance on datasets like QuoRef [9]. The proposed method achieves 87.65 on EM and 89.51 on F1 for SQuAD v2.0 [9].

XLNet+DSC generally outperforms BERT+DSC on the QuoRef dataset.

The MMMU benchmark is designed to evaluate multimodal models on tasks requiring college-level knowledge and reasoning [10]. The benchmark includes a wide range of disciplines and heterogeneous image types, posing significant challenges to current models [10, 4]. GPT-4V achieves an accuracy of only 55.7% on the MMMU benchmark, highlighting the difficulty of the tasks [4, 12]. Open-source models like BLIP2-FLAN-T5-XXL and LLaVA-1.5 achieve approximately 34% accuracy, significantly lower than GPT-4V [4, 9].

The MMMU benchmark requires models to effectively interpret and integrate both textual and visual information [6]. Models perform relatively better in disciplines such as Art & Design and Humanities & Social Sciences, where images are more natural and questions involve less reasoning ![The MMMU benchmark includes questions from Art & Design, Business, Science, Health & Medicine.](image1). Conversely, performance is lower in fields like Science, Health & Medicine, and Technology & Engineering, where tasks involve intricate perception and complex reasoning [6, 9]. Error analysis reveals that a significant portion of errors are perceptual, stem from a lack of knowledge, or are due to flaws in the reasoning process ![The pie chart illustrates the error distribution in GPT-4V's performance on the MMMU benchmark, highlighting perceptual errors, lack of knowledge, and reasoning errors.](image6).

The presence of repetition control reduces question-asking [10]. As shown in ![The graph illustrates how question frequency in text can be modulated using different controls or techniques.](image4), the "Question-controlled CT with repetition control" line (purple line with squares) shows a more gradual increase in question percentage, reaching a lower maximum percentage near 80% as the control level increases [10]. This is in contrast to the "Question-controlled CT" line (blue line with circles) without repetition control, which shows a steep increase in the percentage of questions as the control level increases, approaching near 100% at higher levels [10].

The weighted decoding feature `extrep bigram`, which discourages bigrams that have appeared in previous utterances, prevents the model from producing bigrams that commonly occur in many questions, such as "do you" and "what is" [10]. To address this, a boost setting was introduced where the `extrep bigram` feature was not used for weighted decoding during beam search but was used to rerank candidates after beam search, yielding a higher question-asking rate [10]. Thus, controlling for multi-turn (self) repetition is important and should be incorporated alongside other attribute control methods [1].

Repetition control reduces the frequency of question-asking in generated text by preventing the use of common question-related bigrams [10].

The two methods for combining long-term and short-term user representations differ in how they integrate these representations [12].
![The image depicts two frameworks of the "LSTUR" (Long- and Short-term User Representation) approach for personalized news recommendation systems.](image2)
LSTUR-ini uses the long-term user representation to initialize the hidden state of the GRU network in the short-term user representation model [2]. LSTUR-con concatenates the long-term user representation with the short-term user representation to create the final user representation [2].

In LSTUR-ini, user embedding is obtained from the user's past click history and initialized into the model, while in LSTUR-con, the approach concatenates the user-level embedding derived from click history with a fixed user embedding, forming a combined user vector [2].
Therefore, LSTUR-ini initializes the GRU network with the long-term representation, while LSTUR-con concatenates the long-term and short-term representations [2].

The absence of QK-norm during training leads to instability, as evidenced by loss spikes early in the training process [6]. This is due to the problematic softmax operation when training with multiple modalities of significantly varying entropy [6].

![The graph shows that without both QK-norm and dropout, the output norm grows significantly, suggesting strong potential for training divergence and instability.](image1)

As illustrated in the training loss curves for Chameleon-7B, the model without QK-Norm diverges after approximately 20% of a training epoch [12]. QK-Norm directly controls the norm growth of input to the softmax by applying layer norm to the query and key vectors within the attention [1].

![The lines show that both approaches lead to a reduction in training loss over time, but the model employing QK-Norm consistently achieves a slightly lower training loss, indicating potentially better performance.](image7)

Therefore, without QK-norm, the loss spikes occur after approximately 20% of a training epoch.

The Retrieval-Augmented Generation (RAG) system employs various retrieval processes to enhance the accuracy and relevance of generated content [9]. Three notable approaches are iterative, recursive, and adaptive retrieval, each designed with specific improvements to overcome the limitations of simpler RAG implementations [7].

Iterative retrieval enhances robustness by offering contextual references through multiple retrieval iterations; however, it may face challenges with semantic discontinuity and irrelevant information accumulation [3]. This process alternates between retrieval and generation, aiming to provide richer and more targeted context from the knowledge base at each step `![Iterative retrieval alternates between retrieval and generation to enhance context](image2)`.

Recursive retrieval is designed to delve deeper into graph-structured data sources to extract interconnected information and is used to refine search queries iteratively based on previous search results [4, 11].  It gradually refines the user query and divides problems into sub-problems `![Recursive retrieval refines the query and divides problems into sub-problems](image2)`.

Adaptive retrieval refines the RAG framework, enabling LLMs to determine the optimal times and content for retrieval, enhancing the efficiency and relevance of sourced information [8, 12]. It allows the RAG system to decide when external knowledge retrieval is needed, determining when to stop retrieval and generation autonomously, often using special tokens `![Adaptive retrieval enables the RAG system to decide when external knowledge retrieval is needed](image2)`.

In summary, iterative retrieval alternates between retrieval and generation, recursive retrieval refines queries through iterative refinement, and adaptive retrieval allows the system to decide dynamically when external knowledge retrieval is needed.

The SCI TAB dataset addresses the need for more complex, table-based fact-checking in scientific contexts [1]. Unlike existing datasets that often rely on crowd-sourced claims and text evidence, SCI TAB focuses on authentic scientific papers and complex claims requiring multiple reasoning steps [1, 2].

SCI TAB contains claims derived from scientific tables and texts extracted from arXiv papers [4, 7]. These claims are manually filtered to ensure they are check-worthy and can be verified using only the table information [4, 9]. The creation of SCI TAB involved a human-model collaboration strategy to generate claims that are either contradicted or unverifiable based on the table's content [7].

Compared to other table fact-checking datasets, SCI TAB distinguishes itself through expert annotation, challenging claims, and a balanced distribution of veracity labels including a higher percentage of NEI (Not Enough Information) claims [2]. The dataset includes real-world scientific claims that necessitate comprehensive and nuanced reasoning skills [7].  ![SciTab is annotated by domain experts and contains more challenging claims.](image6)

The analysis of reasoning types in SCI TAB reveals a multifaceted range, including the need for both closed-domain and open-domain knowledge [5].  The dataset also exhibits diversity in refuted claims, addressing issues such as incorrect calculation results and incorrect approximation words [6].  ![The reasons for refuted claims and NEI claims with their proportion](image1)

The process of creating the SCI TAB dataset involved strict quality control procedures, including a two-round annotation by two different annotators, with review and resolution of errors by authors [3]. The inter-annotator agreement was substantial, indicating high reliability in the annotations [3]. Unverifiable claims were generated using Instruct GPT and then manually verified [10]. The reasoning depth required for verifying claims in SCI TAB is considerable, with an average depth of 4.76 and a maximum depth of 11 [11].  ![Distribution of reasoning steps in SCI TAB, showing complexity.](image5)

The Wiki Table datasets (TabFact and FEVEROUS) have 117,854 + 87,026 = 204,880 claims. The Scientific Articles datasets (SEM-TAB-FACTS and SciTab) have 5,715 + 1,225 = 6,940 claims. The difference between the number of claims is 204,880 - 6,940 = 197,940.

The Wiki Table datasets have 197940 more claims than the scientific article datasets.

The evaluation of different decoding strategies within the COMET framework reveals their impact on the quality of generated knowledge tuples [1]. The goal is to automatically construct common-sense knowledge bases, and the decoding method plays a crucial role in this process [2].

![The table displays the results of different training data percentages on model performance metrics.](image8)

The results indicate that greedy decoding achieves the highest average performance among the automated methods [11]. Specifically, greedy decoding yields an average score of 77.53, which is the highest among the decoding methods tested, approaching human performance [6, 11]. While beam search with varying beam sizes (2, 5, and 10) and top-k sampling (k=5, 10) are also evaluated, they do not surpass the performance of greedy decoding [1]. Although increasing the number of candidates can lower overall performance, greedy decoding demonstrates a balance between quality and efficiency [11]. It's also noteworthy that while COMET's performance is promising, human evaluation still outperforms the model, suggesting that incorporating human evaluators could further enhance the correctness of generated tuples [3].

Therefore, greedy decoding achieves the highest average performance in generating commonsense inferences in the COMET framework.

Data imbalance is a significant issue in NLP tasks, particularly in tagging and machine reading comprehension [10]. For machine reading comprehension (MRC) tasks, the negative-positive ratio ranges from 50 to 200 [10]. This imbalance arises because MRC is often framed as predicting the start and end indices based on a query and context, where only two tokens are positive, with the remainder being background [10].
![The table presents the count and ratio of positive and negative examples in different NLP tasks, showing a high negative-to-positive ratio, particularly for MRC tasks.](image11)
The QuoRef dataset, requires coreferential reasoning [4].  Table 1 provides examples of the number of positive and negative examples and their ratios for different data-imbalanced NLP tasks [10, 11].

The ratio of negative to positive examples for the QuoRef task is between 50-200 [10].

Adversarial training can significantly influence model performance depending on the evaluation data used. When a model is trained on adversarial distractors and evaluated on original distractors, its performance decreases [2]. For example, the F1 score of a model trained on original distractors is 67.08, but it drops to 59.12 when trained on adversarial distractors and evaluated on the original distractors ![The table shows a comparison of performance metrics (scores) for different combinations of evaluation and training data.](image2).

However, if the model is retrained on adversarial distractors, it can recover much of its original accuracy when evaluated on adversarial distractors [2, 3].  Specifically, when evaluated on adversarial distractors, the F1 score increases from 46.84 (original training) to 60.10 (adversarial training) ![The table shows a comparison of performance metrics (scores) for different combinations of evaluation and training data.](image2). Furthermore, filtering by entity type can degrade accuracy, but adversarial training helps to recover performance even in these scenarios [2]. As shown in Table 4, the original model’s accuracy degrades significantly (drops to 40.73 F1). However, similar to the previous setup, the model trained on the adversarially selected distractors can recover most of its original accuracy (increases to 58.42 F1) [2].
![The table shows a comparison of performance metrics (scores) for different combinations of evaluation and training data.](image2)

Therefore, adversarial training can help a model maintain or improve its accuracy when faced with adversarial or specifically filtered evaluation data.

The performance of multi-hop question answering models is significantly influenced by the inclusion of gold paragraphs and distractors.  Single-paragraph BERT struggles in open-domain settings due to the inadequacies of TF-IDF retrieval for multi-hop questions [5]. Table 5 shows the model achieves 39.12 F1 given 500 retrieved paragraphs, but achieves 53.12 F1 when additional two gold paragraphs are given [5].

![The table displays the F1 scores for various settings related to a task, presumably in the context of natural language processing or machine learning, judging by the terms used.](image4)

The F1 score increases from 39.12 to 53.12 when gold paragraphs are included in the open-domain setting, highlighting the importance of retrieving relevant evidence [5].  When models are retrained on adversarially selected distractors, they can recover much of their original accuracy [3, 8]. The original model’s accuracy degrades significantly (drops to 40.73 F1). However, similar to the previous setup, the model trained on the adversarially selected distractors can recover most of its original accuracy (increases to 58.42 F1) [8].  However, even with 500 distractors, the single-paragraph BERT model achieves only 53.12 F1, indicating the need for improved distractor collection methods [11].

![The table shows a comparison of performance metrics (scores) for different combinations of evaluation and training data. There are two types of training data: "Original" and "Adversarial." Evaluation is performed on three types of data: "Original," "Adversarial," and "Adversarial + Type."](image2)

The choice of distractors also plays a crucial role; carefully chosen distractor paragraphs are needed to induce multi-hop reasoning [6].  The accuracy declines from 67.08 F1 to 46.84 F1 [2]. How- ever, when the same procedure is done on the train- ing set and the model is re-trained, the accuracy increases to 60.10 F1 on the adversarial distractors [2].

The inclusion of gold paragraphs improves F1 scores, while the selection and retraining on adversarial distractors can mitigate performance declines, highlighting the importance of both relevant evidence retrieval and robust distractor handling for optimal model performance.
