Llama 2 models have been evaluated against both open-source and closed-source models regarding helpfulness and safety [3, 7]. Human evaluation, considered a gold standard, was used to rate the models on these key aspects [3]. The Llama 2-Chat models generally perform better than existing open-source models and are on par with some closed-source models based on human evaluations [7].

The training process of Llama 2-Chat involves pretraining, supervised fine-tuning, and reinforcement learning with human feedback (RLHF) to optimize for helpfulness and safety, ensuring iterative refinement using methods like Rejection Sampling and Proximal Policy Optimization (PPO) ![Llama 2-Chat is refined through pretraining, supervised fine-tuning and reinforcement learning.](image2).

Specifically, when compared to ChatGPT-0301, Llama 2 (70B) achieves approximately 20% win rate in helpfulness and close to 50% win rate in safety, as judged by GPT-4 ![Llama 2 (70B) has approximately 20% helpfulness and close to 50% safety win rates compared to ChatGPT-0301, according to GPT-4.](image8). Furthermore, after RLHF, Llama 2-Chat outperforms ChatGPT on both helpfulness and harmlessness axes, achieving win rates greater than 50% [12].

The safety evaluations reveal that Llama 2-Chat models have a lower violation percentage compared to models like MPT, Vicuna, and Falcon, making them relatively safer ![Llama 2-Chat models generally exhibit lower violation percentages, indicating enhanced safety.](image7). Fine-tuning significantly improves truthfulness and reduces toxicity in Llama 2-Chat, achieving the lowest toxicity levels among compared models [6]. Although Llama 2 70B is close to GPT-3.5 on benchmarks like MMLU and GSM8K, there remains a significant gap in coding benchmarks and overall performance compared to GPT-4 and PaLM-2-L [5].

Based on GPT-4's evaluation, Llama 2 exhibits competitive safety and helpfulness, often outperforming open-source models and rivaling some closed-source alternatives.

The function of 'Word LSTM-B' and 'Word LSTM-F' components in the neural network architecture is to process word embeddings in a bidirectional manner, allowing the model to capture contextual information from both previous and subsequent words in the sequence [image6]. This is similar to the function of 'Char LSTM-F' and 'Char LSTM-B' which process character embeddings in both directions to capture contextual dependencies at the character level [image3].The outputs from both the forward and backward LSTMs are combined to create a representation for each word [image5]. The bi-directional LSTMs at the word level (Word LSTM-B & Word LSTM-F) handle the sequences of words [image6].

In the architecture, 'Word LSTM-F' (forward LSTM) processes the word embeddings from left to right, while 'Word LSTM-B' (backward LSTM) processes them from right to left [image5, image6]. By processing the input sequence in both directions, the model can capture dependencies and contextual information more effectively, improving the accuracy of named entity recognition [image2, image5, image6].

'Word LSTM-B' and 'Word LSTM-F' capture bidirectional context for word representations, enhancing named entity recognition.

The COMET model excels in generating ConceptNet tuples by leveraging implicit knowledge from deep pre-trained language models [10]. The architecture of the COMET model, which includes multi-headed attention and transformer blocks, allows it to effectively learn and generate rich and diverse commonsense descriptions in natural language ![This diagram shows how key, value, and query inputs are processed through head-specific projections in the COMET model](image1).

The BLEU-2 results show that COMET exceeds the performance of all baselines, achieving a 51% relative improvement [5]. Moreover, human evaluation indicates an 18% statistically significant relative average performance increase over the top baseline [5]. The quality of knowledge generated by COMET is high, as indicated by low perplexity scores and a high classifier score of 95.25% [4].  A human evaluation scores 91.7% of greedily decoded tuples as correct, approaching human performance [4, 8]. This high score suggests the generated tuples are largely accurate.

   

COMET not only generates high-quality knowledge but also novel tuples, with 59.25% not present in the training set [12].  It can generate new edges between nodes and even create new nodes (3.75% of *o* nodes are novel) to extend the knowledge graph [12].  The ability to generate novel and plausible relationships is a key advantage of COMET, as it can infer new connections and nodes, expanding existing knowledge bases ![COMET learns to generate new knowledge from existing knowledge bases, inferring new connections and nodes](image3). As edit distance increases, classifier accuracy remains high, confirming the model's robust performance even with novel data ![Classifier accuracy remains high, close to 100%, even as edit distance increases](image7).
 
   

Table 1 shows that COMET produces more novel tuple objects than the baselines [1]. The results demonstrate that COMET achieves the lowest perplexity (4.32), the highest score (95.25), and is the closest to matching human performance (91.69) [8].  COMET frequently produces novel commonsense knowledge that human evaluators deem correct, which shows the effectiveness of the model [11].

COMET demonstrates the best overall performance in generating ConceptNet tuples due to its high accuracy, ability to generate novel content, and close alignment with human evaluations [8, 11].

Word-order information is crucial for sentiment analysis tasks, as models like LSTM can capture this information, unlike SWEM which generally ignores it [7, 9]. The phrase "not really good" and "really not good" exemplify how word order changes sentiment [7].

Experiments involving shuffled training sets demonstrate the importance of word order. On the Yahoo and SNLI datasets, shuffling the training data had little impact on LSTM's accuracy, suggesting word order isn't critical for topic categorization or textual entailment in those cases [8, 11]. However, a noticeable drop in accuracy occurred on the Yelp polarity dataset when the training data was shuffled ![The table shows the comparison of performance metrics on Yahoo, Yelp P., and SNLI datasets in original and shuffled conditions.](image4), indicating that word order significantly affects sentiment analysis [11]. This is further supported by the observation that LSTM's performance on the Yelp dataset with shuffled data closely mirrored SWEM's results [12].

The construction of the SnapNTell dataset involved multiple filtering steps to ensure data quality and relevance [3, 9]. Initially, a list of 14,910 entities was compiled across 22 primary categories [9]. The first filtering step involved cross-referencing each entity with its corresponding Wikipedia page, removing those without valid pages [9].  ![The image displays a table showing the number of entities filtered out at different stages, including original, 1st Wiki, 2nd Google, and 3rd Wiki filtering.](image4) After the first Wiki filtering, the remaining entities were further refined using Google Image Search API, retaining only those with a sufficient number of images [2, 9]. Finally, a third Wiki filtering step removed entity names with ambiguous Wikipedia pages [2]. The final dataset consists of 7,568 unique entities [4, 9]. Based on the table in image4, the number of entities after 1st Wiki filtering is 12,294, and after the 3rd Wiki filtering, the number of entities is 7,568. Thus the number of entities removed in the 1st Wiki filtering is 14,910 - 12,294 = 2,616, and the number of entities removed in the 3rd Wiki filtering is 9,241 - 7,568 = 1,673. So the 1st Wiki filtering removed 2,616 - 1,673 = 943 more entities than the 3rd Wiki filtering.

The 1st Wiki filtering removed 943 more entities than the 3rd Wiki filtering.

The dataset includes different types of queries distributed across three rungs, representing different levels of causal inference [8, 4, 5, 1]. Rung 1 focuses on basic probabilities, while Rung 2 deals with causal effects and adjustment sets, and Rung 3 involves counterfactual reasoning and effects analysis [8]. The number of samples in the dataset is 10,112 and they are split into Rung 1 (3,160), Rung 2 (3,160), and Rung 3 (3,792) ![The table provides a breakdown of a dataset across three categories labeled as "Rung 1," "Rung 2," and "Rung 3," along with an overall "Total" category.](image1).

Rung 1 includes "Cond. Prob." (conditional probability) and "Marg. Prob." (marginal probability) queries, focusing on basic probabilistic relationships [4, 8].  Rung 2 contains "ATE" (Average Treatment Effect) and "Adjust. Set" queries, addressing the average treatment effect and the identification of necessary adjustment sets for causal effect estimation [5, 8]. Rung 3 encompasses more complex causal reasoning queries such as "Counterf." (Counterfactual), "NDE" (Natural Direct Effect), "NIE" (Natural Indirect Effect), and "ATT" (Average Treatment effect on the Treated) [1, 8].

The distribution of query types across the three rungs includes marginal and conditional probabilities in Rung 1, average treatment effects and adjustment sets in Rung 2, and counterfactual, natural direct effect, natural indirect effect, and average treatment effect on the treated in Rung 3 ![The image is a circular chart that illustrates the distribution of different query types in a dataset labeled as "v1.0".](image3).

The "hard-to-contrast" method demonstrates superior performance compared to other selection strategies, especially in active learning scenarios. This method effectively addresses the cold start problem by selecting typical data for annotation and ensuring label diversity [9, 10].

The hard-to-contrast approach is label-free and yields high performance among existing active querying strategies [6]. For instance, it significantly outperforms random selection on PathMNIST, OrganAMNIST, and BloodMNIST by querying only a small fraction of the dataset [6]. The method's effectiveness is attributed to its ability to identify and select data points that the model finds difficult to discriminate, which often carry common visual patterns representative of the entire dataset [10].

Furthermore, "hard-to-contrast" queries exhibit a greater spread within each cluster, and this strategy can cover all classes, avoiding the selection of local outliers that may undermine active learning ![The hard-to-contrast queries have a greater spread within each cluster](image5). In comparison to other methods, such as "easy-to-learn," "hard-to-contrast" does not require manual annotation, making it more practical for vision active learning [10].

As shown in the figure, the "hard-to-contrast" method (red lines) generally outperforms other methods across different graphs, especially when fine-tuning from self-supervised pre-training ![The red line (Hard-to-Contrast) generally appears to outperform the other methods across the graphs.](image7). This indicates that models initialized with hard-to-contrast data achieve higher AUC scores with fewer labeled images.

The "hard-to-contrast" data selection criterion not only exploits contrastive learning, which improves the model, but also determines the typical data to be annotated first, resulting in a better query [12].

In summary, the 'Hard-to-Contrast' method generally outperforms other selection strategies in terms of AUC, especially in early cycles of active learning, because it selects more representative data.

The RAPTOR method isn't explicitly listed in the provided tables. However, based on the information about retrieval granularity, we can discuss the options and how they relate to different methods. Retrieval granularity refers to the level at which data is retrieved, which can range from fine to coarse [6]. Options include tokens, phrases, sentences, propositions, chunks, and documents [6]. Coarse-grained units can provide more relevant information but may also contain redundant content, while fine-grained units increase the retrieval burden and may not guarantee semantic integrity [12].

Different methods use different granularities depending on the task. For example, DenseX uses propositions as retrieval units [6]. The choice of granularity can be adapted to downstream tasks, such as retrieving Item IDs in recommendation tasks or sentence pairs [6].  The "Retrieval Granularity" column in the table ![The table organizes different methods based on these characteristics to show a comparative view of various retrieval techniques.](image4) lists options like Phrase, Sentence, Chunk, Item, Doc, and Sub-Graph, among others.

Without specific information about RAPTOR in the table, it's impossible to determine its retrieval granularity.

The Translation Ranking model uses a specific architecture to process inputs, as illustrated in Figure 2 [4]. This model is designed to determine the quality and accuracy of machine translations by comparing different translation hypotheses.

The model receives four segments as input: the source text, the reference translation, a "better" hypothesis, and a "worse" hypothesis [4]. These segments are independently encoded using a pre-trained cross-lingual encoder, which helps in understanding the context and meaning of the text in different languages [4]. After encoding, a pooling layer aggregates the encoded features to create a sentence embedding for each segment, ensuring a fixed-size vector representation [4]. Finally, the triplet margin loss is used to optimize the embedding space by minimizing the distance between the "better" hypothesis and the source and reference texts, effectively ranking the translation quality [1, 4].

![Translation Ranking model architecture, which encodes and compares source, reference, and translation hypotheses using triplet margin loss.](image6)

In summary, the Translation Ranking model encodes the source, reference, and two translation hypotheses, then optimizes the embeddings to minimize the distance between the better hypothesis and the source/reference.

In open-domain question answering, the performance of models can be significantly impacted by the inclusion of gold paragraphs. Single-paragraph BERT struggles in open-domain settings, which is attributed to the limitations of standard TF-IDF retrieval for multi-hop questions [3]. For instance, retrieving relevant information about "Bonobo apes" is challenging if the question lacks specific terms [3].

The F1 score of single-paragraph BERT in different open-domain retrieval settings highlights the importance of retrieving relevant paragraphs. ![The table displays the F1 scores for various settings related to a task.](image3) When using 500 retrieved paragraphs, the model achieves an F1 score of 39.12. However, when two additional gold paragraphs are included, the F1 score increases substantially to 53.12 [3]. This demonstrates that failure to retrieve gold paragraphs has a significant effect on the model's performance [3]. Therefore, the inclusion of a 'Gold Paragraph' significantly boosts the F1 score in open-domain settings.

DSGAN, an adversarial learning framework, improves distant supervision relation extraction by learning a sentence-level true-positive generator [2]. This generator filters noisy distant supervision datasets, reassigning false positive instances to the negative set, thus providing a cleaner dataset for relation classification [2]. The architecture of DSGAN includes a generator and a discriminator, both modeled by CNNs for effective sentence understanding [5]. The framework's effectiveness is evaluated by observing improvements in distant supervision relation extraction after applying the data set relocation strategy [4].

The original distant supervision (DS) data space includes true positives, false positives, and negative data, with a suboptimal decision boundary due to the presence of false positives ![The data space illustrates true positives, false positives, and negative data with corresponding decision boundaries.](image2). DSGAN aims to address this issue by refining the decision boundary through adversarial training [12]. The generator in DSGAN identifies true positive samples from the noisy DS dataset [4]. The process involves challenging a discriminator with generated samples labeled as negative and the remaining samples as positive [12]. A robust true-positive generator results when the discriminator's classification ability declines, indicating more true positives are generated, and more false positives remain in the rest set [12].

The performance of models with and without DSGAN is quantitatively presented, showing that models such as CNN+ONE, CNN+ATT, PCNN+ONE, and PCNN+ATT all experience improved performance when DSGAN is incorporated ![The table shows performance improvements across different models when DSGAN is added, along with corresponding p-values.](image8). The results of t-tests also indicate that the improvements are statistically significant [11]. In precision-recall curves, models incorporating DSGAN (CNN+ONE+DSGAN and CNN+ATT+DSGAN) generally exhibit better precision-recall trade-offs ![The graph displays the performance of CNN-based models with and without DSGAN in terms of precision and recall.](image4). Similarly, PCNN-based models also show improved precision-recall curves when DSGAN is added, especially the PCNN+ATT+DSGAN configuration ![The graph illustrates the performance of PCNN-based models with and without DSGAN using precision-recall curves.](image6).

In summary, the addition of DSGAN consistently improves the performance of various models by filtering noisy data and refining the training dataset, leading to more accurate relation extraction.

SPECTER is designed to learn task-independent representations of academic papers, using citations as an inter-document relatedness signal [9, 11]. The t-SNE visualization of paper embeddings in ![SPECTER shows more compact clusters compared to SciBERT](image2) highlights how SPECTER's embeddings are better at encoding topical information, as the clusters appear more compact [3]. This is further quantified using the DBScan clustering algorithm, where SPECTER achieves homogeneity and completeness values of 0.41 and 0.72, respectively, compared to SciBERT's 0.19 and 0.63 [3].

SPECTER appears to produce more tightly clustered groups representing different topics compared to SciBERT.

The introduction of repetition control impacts the question-asking rate, particularly at higher control levels. Conditional training is effective in controlling question-asking [6].  As the question-asking control level increases, the percentage of utterances containing a question mark also increases, but this effect is limited when repetition control is introduced ![This line shows a more gradual increase in question percentage, reaching a lower maximum percentage near 80% as the control level increases.](image2).

Specifically, without repetition control, a question-asking control level of z=10 should ideally produce 100% questions; however, with repetition control, this rate drops to 79.67% [6]. The weighted decoding feature `extrep bigram`, which discourages bigrams from previous utterances, prevents the model from generating common question-related bigrams [6].

To address this, an extra setting `z = 10 (boost)` was introduced where the `extrep bigram` feature is not used for weighted decoding during beam search but is used to rerank candidates after beam search. This adjustment allows the model to produce necessary question-asking bigrams, yielding a 99.54% question-asking rate, albeit with a slight increase in external bigram repetition [6].

The introduction of repetition control reduces the question-asking rate at the highest control level (z=10), but this can be mitigated by boosting the question-asking bigrams.

Isolating label words in shallow layers significantly impacts the model's outcome, but this influence diminishes in deeper layers, and a similar lack of impact is observed when random non-label words are isolated [12]. Isolating label words in the initial layers substantially affects the outcome, highlighting the importance of shallow-layer information aggregation via label words ![Isolating label words within the first five layers shows a substantial impact.](image2). The data from experiments with the LLaMA-30B model also supports this observation, showing that isolating label words in the first few layers has a more pronounced effect compared to isolating them in deeper layers or isolating non-label tokens ![Isolating label words in the first 5 layers has a significant effect.](image3). This is further supported by findings that isolating shallow layers has a significant impact, whereas isolating deep layers has a negligible impact, even with an increasing number of isolated layers [10]. The model extracts information from label words in deep layers to form the final prediction, with shallow layers showing negligible cumulative contributions, and a significant increase in middle and deep layers [2].

Yes.

The adversarial transformation significantly impacts BERT's performance, reducing it to near-random levels, indicating that the model heavily relies on spurious statistical cues present in the original dataset [3, 6].  This is highlighted by the contrast between BERT's performance on the original dataset and the adversarially generated dataset. In fact, BERT’s peak performance of $77\%$ on the Argument Reasoning Comprehension Task reaches just three points below the average untrained human baseline [1].

On the original ARCT data, BERT achieves a maximum of $77\%$ accuracy [4, 10]. However, this high performance is misleading because it is based on exploiting dataset-specific cues rather than true argument comprehension [1, 4, 9].

By introducing an adversarial dataset, these statistical cues are eliminated, and the models have to rely on actual argument comprehension [1, 3]. As shown in the table, the original data shows BERT achieving a test performance max score of 0.770 ![The table shows that BERT achieved a test performance max score of 0.770](image5).

When models trained on the original data are evaluated on the adversarial set, their performance drops below random, due to overfitting the cues in the original training set [5]. Training BERT from scratch on the adversarial dataset results in a peak performance reduction to $53\%$, with the mean and median around $50\%$ [3, 5]. This is shown in the "Results for BERT Large on the adversarial test set with adversarial training and validation sets" [7].

The table contrasts different BERT models, showing that the max performance for BERT is 0.533 on the adversarial dataset ![The table compares performance metrics for different BERT models on the adversarial dataset, showing a max performance of 0.533 for BERT.](image6).

This drastic drop in performance after the adversarial transformation indicates that BERT's initial success was primarily due to exploiting these superficial cues, rather than genuine argument comprehension [6, 9, 12].  The model's inability to perform well on the adversarial dataset, where these cues are removed, reveals its lack of true understanding of the task [5].

In summary, the adversarial transformation reveals that BERT's high performance on the original dataset was due to exploiting statistical cues, and its performance drops to near-random levels when these cues are eliminated, indicating a lack of true argument comprehension.

In total, CodeBERT is trained with 2,137,293 bimodal data points and 6,452,446 unimodal codes across all six programming languages.

Figure 3 illustrates the performance of tree traversal and collapsed tree methods on a subset of the QASPER dataset [3]. In tree traversal, the algorithm selects the top-k most relevant root nodes based on their cosine similarity to the query embedding [4]. The children of these selected nodes are considered at the next layer, and the top nodes are selected again based on their cosine similarity to the query vector [4]. This process is repeated until the leaf nodes are reached [4]. The collapsed tree approach offers a simpler way to search for relevant information by considering all nodes in the tree simultaneously, flattening the multi-layered tree into a single layer [8].

![The image is a graph comparing different querying methods based on the F1 score.](image6)

Figure 3 shows the performance of tree traversal with different top- sizes and collapsed tree with different maximum token numbers [3]. Collapsed tree retrieval is better due to offering greater flexibility than tree traversal [3].

The horizontal axis of Figure 3 represents the Context Length, and the vertical axis represents the F1 score.

The entities and their relationships are meticulously represented in the example annotation using a structured format that elucidates the connections between different elements within the text [4]. Each token in the text is associated with a mention type, indicating whether it's a new entity or related to an existing one [4].

The model picks  Super Mario Land  as the parent entity   $(p_{t})$  , and then follows the  Publisher  relation   $(r_{t})$   to se- lect  Nintendo  as the entity to render   $(e_{t})$ [1]. ![The image is an illustration of a process involving a model, likely a Knowledge Graph Language Model (KGLM), generating a token based on the context of a sentence and related knowledge graph information.](image3)

The relationship between entities is defined using relations. For example, "pub date" connects "1989" with the publication date of "Super Mario Land," and "genre" relates "video game" to "SML" [4]. These relationships, derived from Wikidata, provide plausible reasons for the mention of an entity, connecting it to already mentioned entities or marking it as a new, unrelated entity [10]. ![This table appears to be a structured representation of a text passage about the video game "Super Mario Land." It breaks down the passage into tokens, mentions, entities, relations, and parent entities.](image4)

The structured annotation clearly defines the relationships between entities, providing a comprehensive view of how information is interconnected within the text.

The Multi-domain Wizard-of-Oz (MultiWOZ) dataset contains 30 (domain, slot) pairs and over 4,500 possible values [6]. MultiWOZ is the largest human-human conversational corpus spanning over seven domains [6]. However, only five domains (restaurant, hotel, attraction, taxi, train) are frequently used due to the low dialogue counts in the hospital and police domains [6]. The dataset is split into training, validation, and testing sets, as shown in ![The table presents a breakdown of different "Slots" and data distribution for five categories](image1).

The "area" slot can be present in multiple domains, such as restaurant, attraction, and taxi [3]. Additionally, the "name" slot in the restaurant domain can share the same value as the "departure" slot in the taxi domain [3]. Slots like destination and departure track names of cities, while people and stay track numbers, leading to closer slot embeddings [12].  Some slots, such as price range and star in the hotel domain, are correlated because high-star hotels are usually more expensive ![The image is a heatmap visualizing the cosine similarity between embeddings for different slots in the MultiWOZ dataset](image8).

The MultiWOZ dataset includes restaurant, hotel, attraction, taxi and train domains [6]. The slots in each domain and the corresponding data size are reported in Table 1 [6].

The 'hard-to-contrast' querying strategy generally outperforms other methods in terms of AUC across different numbers of labeled images, particularly in the early stages of active learning [11, 9]. This is because the inclusion of hard-to-contrast data is a crucial criterion for effective annotation, especially when addressing the cold start problem [9].

![The image consists of ten graphs that compare different methods in terms of Area Under the Curve (AUC) percentage with varying numbers of labeled images](image5)

As shown in the graphs, the hard-to-contrast strategy (red line) consistently achieves higher AUC scores compared to other strategies such as Random, Entropy, Margin, BALD, and Coreset, whether training from scratch or fine-tuning from self-supervised pre-training [image5]. This is further supported by the observation that hard-to-contrast data consistently outperforms other initial queries in every cycle of active learning, as demonstrated on various datasets like OrganAMNIST, BloodMNIST, and PathMNIST [2].

![The image is a bar chart comparing map-based querying strategies across four datasets: PathMNIST, OrganAMNIST, BloodMNIST, and CIFAR-10-LT](image3)

The map-based querying strategies demonstrate that selecting hard-to-contrast data contributes to optimal models [image3, 11]. Specifically, hard-to-contrast querying significantly outperforms random selection on PathMNIST, OrganAMNIST, and BloodMNIST by querying only a small percentage of the entire dataset [11]. This highlights the practical advantage of using hard-to-contrast data, especially since strategies relying on ground truths (easy-to-learn or hard-to-learn) are not feasible for active learning [11]. The superior performance of hard-to-contrast queries stems from their ability to capture label diversity and identify typical data, which helps in mitigating the cold start problem [9, 8].

Therefore, the 'hard-to-contrast' querying strategy's superior AUC performance across different numbers of labeled images highlights its effectiveness in initial query selection for active learning, making it a robust baseline for image classification tasks.

The QAC HECK system uses several modules to perform fact-checking, and some of these modules are implemented with Large Language Models [3]. The architecture of the QAC HECK system includes modules such as a Claim Verifier, a Question Generator, a Question Answering Model, a Validator, and a Reasoner, which work together to verify claims ![The system relies on elements like the Wikipedia Corpus to provide context and evidence, and loops through its components to ensure accurate verification.](image3).

The Question Answering (QA) module, a critical component, has three different implementations [1]. These implementations provide flexibility, allowing the system to adapt to different claims and available contextual information [5].  One approach uses InstructGPT in a reciter-reader model [5]. Additionally, InstructGPT is leveraged for in-context learning within the question generator module [2]. The validator module also uses InstructGPT by prompting it with demonstrations to ensure the usefulness of generated question-answer pairs [4].

The claim verifier determines if sufficient information exists to validate a claim using InstructGPT's in-context learning ability [7]. The claim verifier, question generator, and validator modules of QAC HECK utilize external API-based large language models such as InstructGPT [10].

Therefore, at least three modules (claim verifier, question generator, and QA validator) within the QAC HECK system are implemented using Large Language Models.

The news encoder contains two sub-modules: a title encoder and a topic encoder [1]. The title encoder learns representations from titles [4], while the topic encoder learns representations from topics and subtopics [9]. The architecture of the news encoder, including these sub-modules, is illustrated in Figure 2 [1].

The news encoder uses the News Title, News Subtopic, and News Topic to generate the final news encoding vector ![The news encoder framework leverages hierarchical embeddings and attention to synthesize multiple layers of news content information into a unified encoding.](image5).

Therefore, the two sub-modules within the news encoder are the title encoder and the topic encoder.

The LSTUR-con and LSTUR-ini methods exhibit similar performance patterns as the mask probability *p* varies [7]. Specifically, their performance improves with an increase in *p* from 0, suggesting that a small *p* leads to overfitting on the long-term user representation (LTUR) due to its numerous parameters. However, performance declines when *p* becomes excessively large, possibly because useful information within LTUR is not effectively integrated [7, 9].

![LSTUR-ini and LSTUR-con performance with varying mask probabilities (p)](image8)

A moderate value of *p*, such as 0.5, appears most appropriate for both LSTUR-ini and LSTUR-con, effectively balancing the learning between LTUR and STUR [9]. LSTUR-con's performance is more stable, indicating that concatenating short-term and long-term user representations effectively retains information [8]. Both LSTUR-ini and LSTUR-con can achieve comparable performance [8]. The results of LSTUR-ini and LSTUR-con have similar patterns, with performance improving as *p* increases from 0 and declining when *p* is too large [7].

In summary, both LSTUR-con and LSTUR-ini show similar trends in AUC performance as the mask probability *p* increases, initially improving and then declining at higher *p* values, with LSTUR-con demonstrating more stable performance overall.

CodeBERT, a bimodal pre-trained model, has shown state-of-the-art performance in various natural language and programming language tasks [3, 7, 12]. CodeBERT is trained on both bimodal and unimodal data and can be fine-tuned for downstream tasks such as natural language code search and code-to-documentation generation [3].

The architecture of CodeBERT is Transformer-based [7, 12], and it can be trained with a hybrid objective function that includes masked language modeling (MLM) and replaced token detection (RTD) [7, 12]. The results in Table 4 suggest that CodeBERT pre-trained with RTD and MLM objectives achieves a gain over RoBERTa [4]. The model is pre-trained on code from GitHub repositories in 6 programming languages [9].

According to the table which displays performance metrics of different models across programming languages, "CodeBERT (MLM+RTD, init=R)" generally showed the highest performance across most languages and the mean average [image7]. Human evaluations reveal nuanced perceptions of Chameleon's performance relative to other models. The prompt evaluation process uses a majority vote to filter unclear prompts and prompts that don’t expect mixed-modal responses [1]. For example, annotators were asked to imagine themselves in a kitchen and come up with prompts like "How to cook pasta?" or "How should I design the layout of my island? Show me some examples" [9]. The prompts can be text-only or text with some images, and the expected responses should be mixed-modal, containing both text and images [9]. A variety of tasks were used to gather information, such as asking for advice, how-to instructions, explanations, or brainstorming ideas ![Task categories and prompt examples](image4).

Chameleon has the highest win percentage against Gemini+ (41.5%) and maintains competitive performance with the other models [image3]. For training, Chameleon represents images, in addition to text, as a series of discrete tokens and takes advantage of the scaling properties of auto-regressive Transformers [3].

The example prompts include a man-made setting analysis, where the model analyzes colors, patterns, and textures in an image and identifies the most challenging spot for a chameleon to blend in [5]. It then generates an image of a chameleon with the optimal pattern to camouflage itself and rates how successful each attempt is ![Camouflaged chameleon](image5). Another prompt example asks to be shown some cool, quirky-looking birds and to be told about them in 2–3 sentences [10].  Responses to prompts can include images with unique features ![Bird example](image5).

Based on the examples provided, there are at least 3 images used in the chat example figures.

The MMMU benchmark distinguishes itself from existing benchmarks through its breadth and depth, specifically designed to evaluate expert-level multimodal understanding and reasoning [1, 2]. Unlike many benchmarks focused on daily knowledge and common sense, MMMU covers college-level knowledge across 30 diverse subjects and 183 subfields, as shown in the distribution across disciplines ![The image is a chart displaying the distribution of 11.5K multimodal questions across six broad disciplines, 30 subjects, and 183 subfields.](image1).

Existing benchmarks often require only commonsense knowledge or simple reasoning but MMMU demands deliberate reasoning with college-level subject knowledge [6]. It includes a variety of image formats, such as diagrams, tables, charts, chemical structures, photos, paintings, geometric shapes, music sheets, and medical images, testing LMMs' perceptual capabilities extensively [6]. MMMU's design incorporates interleaved text-image inputs, necessitating that models jointly understand images and text, recall deep subject knowledge, and conduct complex reasoning [2]. The comparison between MMMU and other benchmarks highlights MMMU's emphasis on depth and breadth ![The image is a dual representation comparing the MMMU benchmark with other benchmarks.](image4).

Despite the progress, the results indicate substantial room for improvement, especially in domains with complex visual input and heavy reasoning with subject knowledge [12]. The benchmark poses significant challenges to current models, even advanced ones like GPT-4V, indicating the rigorous and demanding standards of MMMU [8]. MMMU is designed to measure perception, knowledge, and reasoning in LMMs, evaluating how well these models perceive and understand information across different modalities and apply reasoning with subject-specific knowledge [5].

The MMMU benchmark is designed to rigorously assess expert-level multimodal understanding, emphasizing breadth and depth of knowledge and reasoning, which reveals substantial opportunities for enhancing current models.

The inclusion of reference translations generally improves the performance of the COMET-RANK metric, as evidenced by the increase in scores across various language pairs [2]. In scenarios where English is the target language, models using reference translations demonstrate enhanced performance compared to those without, indicating the importance of reference information for accurate evaluation [1].

The table shows COMET-RANK scores with and without reference translations. ![This table shows the difference between COMET-RANK scores with and without reference translations.](image2)

Looking at the specific improvements (Δτ) in the table, we can identify which language pair benefits the most from including reference translations. For instance, the Δτ values reveal that the most significant improvement occurs in the de-en (German to English) language pair, with a substantial increase of 0.155 when reference translations are included [2]. Similarly, fi-en (Finnish to English) and tr-en (Turkish to English) also show considerable improvements with Δτ values of 0.119 and 0.132, respectively [2]. The COMET-RANK metric benefits from the inclusion of reference translations, with the German to English language pair showing the most significant improvement.

The DYGIE model utilizes a sentence-level BiLSTM to process input documents and generate token representations, which are essential for identifying entities, relations, and coreferences. The model begins by taking a document, splitting it into sentences, and processing each sentence through a Sentence-level BiLSTM to obtain token representations ![The DYGIE model processes text to extract entities, relations, and coreferences.](image1). This initial step is crucial for capturing the contextual information of each word within the sentence [4].

The BiLSTM leverages a concatenation of character representations, GLoVe word embeddings, and ELMo embeddings as input for each token [4]. This comprehensive input allows the model to create rich and contextualized vector space representations of each span [11]. By enumerating all text spans in each sentence, DYGIE identifies potential entities and computes locally-contextualized vector representations for each span [11]. This process sets the stage for the subsequent dynamic span graph, where global information is incorporated to refine these representations [11]. The refined span representations are then used to predict entity types, relation types, and coreference links in a multi-task framework [11].

The sentence-level BiLSTM in the DYGIE model serves to generate contextualized token representations that are fundamental for identifying and classifying entities, relations, and coreferences.

The DYGIE framework significantly outperforms existing methods in joint entity and relation detection tasks [4, 5]. DYGIE improves upon the state of the art in NER (Named Entity Recognition) by 7.1% and 7.0% for ACE04 and ACE05, respectively [2].

DYGIE achieves an F1 score of 87.4 for entity recognition on the ACE04 dataset, outperforming other systems [7].

The DYGIE system achieved the highest F1 score for entity recognition on the ACE04 dataset.

The Knowledge Graph Language Model (KGLM) is designed to overcome the limitations of traditional language models, which often struggle with generating factually correct text, especially concerning rare entities [1, 5]. KGLM addresses this by accessing an external source of facts encoded in a knowledge graph [1].

![The table presents a comparison of four models in terms of two metrics: PPL (Perplexity) and UPP.](image1)

According to Table 3, KGLM attains a substantially lower perplexity (PPL) than other entity-based language models, achieving a PPL of 44.1 compared to 76.1 and 85.4 for other models [11]. The table shows that KGLM outperforms ENTITY NLM, EntityCopyNet, and AWD-LSTM in both PPL and unknown penalized perplexity (UPP) [11]. Furthermore, KGLM's ability to generate rare tokens is demonstrated through its superior performance in unknown penalized perplexity [11]. Even when compared to GPT-2, KGLM often generates more specific tokens and can accurately complete facts for rare entities [6]. KGLM’s design enables it to select and copy facts from a knowledge graph, allowing it to generate information it has never seen before and out-of-vocabulary tokens [5].

![The table presents a comparison between two AI language models, GPT-2 and KGLM, in their ability to provide correct answers to various fill-in-the-blank input sentences.](image4)

The Knowledge Graph Language Model (KGLM) has the lowest perplexity according to Table 3 [11].

The MultiWOZ 2.0 and 2.1 datasets contain statistics regarding domain-slot pairs, with a focus on five specific domains: train, restaurant, hotel, taxi, and attraction [5]. These domains encompass a total of 30 domain-slot pairs [5].

The "hotel" domain includes slots such as price range, type, parking, booking details (stay, day, people), area, stars, internet, and name, while the "train" domain covers destination, day, departure, arrival time, booking for people, and departure time. "Restaurant" includes food, price range, area, name, booking details (time, day, people). "Attraction" includes area, name, and type. Lastly, "taxi" involves departure time, destination, departure location, and arrival time. ![The table presents the slots associated with different domains in the MultiWOZ datasets.](image3)

The number of dialogues varies for each domain across the training, validation, and test subsets [5]. For example, the hotel domain has 3381 dialogues in the training set, 416 in the validation set, and 394 in the test set [5]. Similarly, the train domain has 3103, 484, and 494 dialogues in the respective sets [5]. The restaurant domain contains 3813, 438, and 437 dialogues [5], attraction has 2717, 401, and 395 dialogues [5], and taxi includes 1654, 207, and 195 dialogues [5].

The MultiWOZ 2.0 and MultiWOZ 2.1 datasets include 30 domain-slot pairs across five domains, with varying numbers of dialogues in the training, validation, and test subsets.

The MMMU benchmark is designed to evaluate multimodal models on tasks requiring college-level knowledge and reasoning [1, 4]. The dataset includes 11.5K multimodal questions collected from college exams, quizzes, and textbooks [1]. The benchmark covers six core disciplines, including Humanities & Social Science [1, 4].

The selection of subjects for inclusion in MMMU was based on the principle that visual inputs should commonly provide valuable information [3]. To create the benchmark, over 50 university students specializing in various majors were recruited to assist in question collection [3]. These annotators collected multimodal questions from major textbooks and online resources [3].

MMMU contains 183 subfields in total, covering 30 subjects [12]. ![MMMU includes 11.5K college-level problems across six broad disciplines.](image8) Within the Humanities & Social Sciences discipline, one of the subjects is Sociology, which accounts for 2.48% of the questions [image1]. The total number of questions in MMMU is 11,550 [image5].

The Bi-LSTM Utterance Encoder is a crucial component in processing user input within the task-oriented dialogue system [12]. As depicted in the system architecture, the dialogue begins with user input, which in this instance is a movie request  ![The image depicts a proposed architecture for an end-to-end task-oriented dialogue system.](image1). The user input in natural language format is then encoded to a continuous vector via a bidirectional LSTM utterance encoder [12]. The user utterance at turn  𝑘 , denoted as  𝑈𝑘 , is processed through this Bi-LSTM encoder to generate an encoding [1].  This encoder maps the words of the user's utterance to an embedding space and uses bidirectional LSTM to capture contextual information [8].

The function of the Bi-LSTM Utterance Encoder is to generate an encoding of the user's utterance [12].

To render an entity, the model first determines the type of mention, identifying the parent entity from local entities, such as "Super Mario Land," and then selects a relation, like "PUBLISHER" [7, image2]. ![The model first determines the type of mention, identifies the parent entity from local entities, and then selects a relation](image2)
The model then identifies the specific entity to render, which is "Nintendo" in the case of the "PUBLISHER" relation, drawing from the local knowledge graph [7, image2]. When rendering "Nintendo" as a token, the model expands its vocabulary to include all word types in the aliases of the entity [7]. This process is illustrated with "Super Mario Land" being the parent entity and "Nintendo" being selected through the "Publisher" relation [7].

The model chooses an entity to render by identifying a parent entity and a relation within a knowledge graph [7, image2].

The tree traversal method involves traversing the tree layer by layer, selecting the most relevant nodes at each level [8]. The pseudocode for this method details how the algorithm progresses through the tree, computing cosine similarity scores and selecting top nodes at each layer to form sets [2, 11, 12].

The algorithm starts at the root layer, calculates cosine similarity between the query and nodes, and selects the top nodes based on their scores, forming a set [12]. The process continues to child nodes, selecting top nodes based on cosine similarity, forming subsequent sets [2]. This is repeated recursively for a number of layers.

The algorithm performs a top-k selection of nodes at each layer of the tree, prioritizing nodes with the highest scores derived from the dot product of nodes and a query, effectively filtering the tree traversed by prioritizing nodes with the highest scores ![Algorithm 1: Tree Traversal Algorithm.](image2).

The step 5, which corresponds to the loop through tree layers in the Tree Traversal Algorithm, recursively produces sets of top nodes until a predefined depth is reached [2]. The final step involves concatenating all the selected sets to assemble the relevant context to the query [2].

The pseudocode corresponding to step 5 of the tree traversal method involves recursively selecting top nodes at each layer to produce sets until a predefined depth is reached.

To enhance dialogue generation, a Retrieve and Refine model (RetNRef) was proposed to combine the benefits of both retrieval and sequence generation methods [6]. For the generator, a standard Seq2Seq model is used, while the retriever employs the Key-Value Memory Network [3]. The top-scoring utterance from the retriever is then used as input to the Seq2Seq model for refinement [3].

The RetNRef model was tested using various retrieval methods, including a Memory Network, random utterances, true labels, and nearest neighbors to true labels [12].  The model's effectiveness was evaluated using metrics like perplexity and human evaluations [4, 8]. The perplexity results indicate the True label with a PPL of 9.2 shows the best performance among the methods tested when used with a Seq2Seq model ![True label retrieval method has the lowest PPL score](image7).

One modification, RetrieveNRefine+, truncates the dialogue history to focus more on the retrieval utterance [9].  The engagingness scores of RetNRef variants are superior to Seq2Seq, with SetNRef++ slightly outperforming the retriever it conditions on ![The table shows engagingness scores for different models, including Seq2Seq and RetNRef variants](image2).

The RetrieveNRefine model, particularly the RetNRef++ variant, shows improvements in word statistics, making them closer to human responses by doubling the use of rare words [7].  The model can effectively learn when to choose the retrieval utterance and when to generate instead [5].

The True label retrieval method demonstrates the best performance in terms of perplexity when used with a Seq2Seq model.

The QAC HECK system is designed to verify claims through a multi-step reasoning process [1]. This process involves several key modules that work together to assess the veracity of a claim. The system begins with a claim verifier that assesses whether sufficient information has been gathered [1, 4]. If not, a question generator identifies the next relevant question to ask ![The image shows a process of question generation to verify claims](image4). The question-answering module then retrieves evidence and provides an answer [7]. The validator evaluates the usefulness of the question-answer pair [1, 4]. This iterative process continues until the claim verifier determines that enough information is available [4].

Once sufficient context is gathered, the reasoner module is activated. The reasoner utilizes the stored context to justify the veracity of the claim and outputs a final label, indicating whether the claim is supported or refuted [4]. As shown in an example, after answering questions about the depth of the Black Sea and the depth of sunlight penetration, a conclusion is reached about the claim's truthfulness ![The image illustrates the fact-checking steps and depth comparison related to sunlight and the Black Sea](image5). The final veracity prediction is accompanied by a comprehensive rationale [10].

The final step in the figure is to output the final veracity label based on all collected contexts.

Under attack conditions, the standard BERT model's performance suffers significantly ![The BERT model's performance significantly drops under attack conditions.](image2). However,  "BERT + Pass-through" and "BERT + Neutral" models exhibit relatively better performance when subjected to 1-char and 2-char attacks compared to the standard BERT model ![The "BERT + Pass-through" and "BERT + Neutral" models maintain relatively higher performance under the 1-char and 2-char attacks compared to standard BERT.](image2).  Specifically, "BERT + Pass-through" shows the highest performance improvement for 1-char attacks, indicated by the bold value of 84.5, while "BERT + Neutral" demonstrates the best performance under 2-char attacks, marked by the bold value of 82.5 [9, 12].  The "BERT + Pass-through" model brings adversarial accuracy back within a 5% range for swap attacks, mitigating adversarial effects in word-piece models by 21%, character-only models by 19%, and word/word+char models by over 4.5% [5].  Incorporating defenses restores BERT models to 88.3, 81.1, and 78.0 accuracy for swap, drop, and add attacks, respectively, compared to 69.2, 63.6, and 50.0 for adversarial training [9].

The BERT model with either Pass-through or Neutral defense performs best under 1-char and 2-char attacks.

The DS-DST model employs a dual strategy to handle both categorical and non-categorical slots, leveraging BERT for encoding and interaction [3, 6, 8]. The architecture of the DS-DST model involves direct interactions between the dialog context and domain-slot pairs for dialogue state tracking, as illustrated in ![The image is a schematic representation of the DS-DST model architecture.](image8).

A pre-trained BERT model encodes the dialogue context along with each domain-slot pair to obtain contextualized representations [6]. For categorical slots, the model selects the most plausible values from predefined picklists based on the contextual representation [6, 8]. The relevance between the aggregated representation and a reference candidate is calculated using cosine similarity [1].

The DS-DST model calculates the relevance between candidate values and the dialogue context by employing a pre-trained BERT model to encode contextual information and then uses cosine similarity to match the representations [1, 6].

Nuclear DNA repair mechanisms encompass multiple pathways that address various types of DNA mutations, as shown in the figure referenced [4]. These mechanisms include base excision repair (BER), which fixes single-strand point mutations by removing damaged bases and restoring the correct nucleotide sequence [5]. Nucleotide excision repair (NER) is another important system that can excise DNA lesions like UV-induced pyrimidine dimers and bulky adducts [6].

Direct reversal repair can directly repair UV-induced pyrimidine dimer formation and alkylation adducts, without needing to cut the DNA strand [11]. Mismatch repair (MMR) corrects mismatched bases resulting from DNA polymerase errors during replication, ensuring accurate DNA duplication ![MMR repairs mismatched bases.](image5). Recombination repair mechanisms target double-strand breaks, the most devastating mutation-induced lesions of DNA, and include homologous recombination repair (HR) and non-homologous end-joining repair [7]. Therefore, the figure illustrates several key DNA repair pathways that maintain genome stability.

RAR models generally outperform CLIP models in average precision across various metrics, especially in scenarios involving rare categories and fine-grained distinctions [1, 5]. The integration of RAR to MLLMs enhances the ability to discriminate among rare classes, demonstrated by a significant performance leap, surpassing the CLIP model by a large margin [1].

![RAR models achieve higher AP scores than CLIP models.](image7)

The retrieving and reranking mechanism effectively pools relevant information, providing MLLMs with a richer context for rare class identification [1].  On the V3Det dataset, RAR achieved a commendable improvement, surpassing the CLIP baseline [2].  This is due to retrieval-augmented approach, and allows MLLMs to navigate the extensive and fine-grained category landscape effectively [2].  Even when compared to CLIP+KNN, RAR managed to make comprehensive improvements, increasing the average top 5 accuracy across eleven datasets [7].

![RAR methods show performance improvements compared to CLIP+KNN across common and fine-grained datasets.](image4)

Regardless of the base model, RAR significantly outperforms GPT-4V in terms of accuracy [8]. From 1-shot to 16-shot experiments, RAR’s results consistently showed improvement over the CLIP+KNN method [9].  Specifically, RAR boosts the top-1 accuracy, illustrating how the ranking process of MLLMs effectively uses a nuanced understanding of context and detail to better align predictions with ground truth [10].  The experimental results also highlights the efficacy of fine-tuning strategy, where fine-tuning the MLLM with target datasets significantly bolsters the model’s ranking capabilities [11]. Overall, RAR demonstrates its viability as a generalizable and reliable method for enhancing the performance of MLLMs [6].

In summary, RAR models exhibit superior performance compared to CLIP models in terms of average precision, particularly in tasks requiring fine-grained recognition and handling of rare categories.

The DA RR Ranker model outperforms the Estimators in seven out of eight language pairs [5]. Even the MQM Estimator, trained on a smaller dataset, performs competitively [5]. Results from evaluations on language pairs with English as the target show that the DA RR model has strong correlations with human judgements [3]. It often outperforms metrics like B LEURT [3]. The LOGIC-LM model addresses logical reasoning problems through a structured, three-stage process [12]. It leverages both the natural language understanding of LLMs and the logical precision of symbolic solvers [12].

First, the problem is presented in natural language, and LOGIC-LM uses its problem formulation module to translate it into a symbolic representation using in-context learning [3, 5, 12]. This involves identifying key entities, facts, and rules [12]. An example of this process can be seen in the conversion of an analytical reasoning problem into a symbolic formulation using satisfiability testing ![The table shows an example of analytical reasoning with the corresponding symbolic formulation.](image6).

Next, the symbolic reasoner takes over, performing logical inference on the formulated problem. It uses methods like logic programming, first-order logic provers, and constraint optimization, depending on the problem's nature [12]. Finally, the result interpreter translates the symbolic answer back into natural language, providing a comprehensible solution to the original problem [2, 12]. This complete process, from problem formulation to result interpretation, is visually summarized in ![This diagram illustrates the three modules of the LOGIC-LM model: Problem Formulator, Symbolic Reasoner, and Result Interpreter.](image5).

The LOGIC-LM model solves problems by translating them into symbolic language, reasoning with a symbolic solver, and then interpreting the result back into natural language.

The number of candidates, documents, and tokens per document vary between WikiHop (WH) and MedHop (MH) datasets, influencing the complexity and characteristics of each dataset ![The table presents the minimum, maximum, average, and median values for the number of candidates, documents, and tokens per document in the WikiHop (WH) and MedHop (MH) datasets.](image4).  For the number of candidates, WikiHop has a wider range (min: 2, max: 79) compared to MedHop (min: 2, max: 9), but MedHop almost always has 9 candidates [4].  WikiHop has an average of 19.8 candidates and a median of 14, while MedHop has an average of 8.9 and a median of 9 [4].  In terms of documents, WikiHop ranges from 3 to 63, with an average of 13.7 and a median of 11, while MedHop ranges from 5 to 64, with a higher average of 36.4 and a median of 29 [4].  The number of tokens per document also differs, with WikiHop having a range of 4 to 2046, an average of 100.4, and a median of 91, while MedHop has a range of 5 to 458, a higher average of 253.9, and a median of 264 [4].

The MedHop dataset uses document sub-sampling due to its densely connected bipartite graph, limiting the document set to 64 [1]. The majority of samples in MedHop have 9 candidates due to the document selection process [4]. In WikiHop, a subset of documents relevant to the correct answer is provided to annotators, with a portion of cases considered as "follows" or "is likely" [8].

In summary, WikiHop generally features a broader range of candidates and document lengths, whereas MedHop is characterized by a higher average number of documents and tokens per document, with a constrained number of candidates.

The initial phase of the cold start process involves defining the system message and incorporating visual annotations, which are essential for querying instruction-response pairs within a dataset ![The image is a flowchart explaining the Sythus process for generating high-quality instruction-response pairs in eight languages](image6). The Sythus pipeline utilizes system messages to set the tone and style and visual annotations to provide image information [8]. This ensures the generation of high-quality instruction-response pairs [8].

Therefore, the first step of cold start is defining system messages and visual annotations.

GPT-4V possesses the ability to generate code for visual tasks [4]. For instance, it can generate Python code to draw curves and bar charts similar to those provided as input ![GPT-4V generates Python code for similar line and bar graphs](image3). It can also generate code in TikZ and SVG to create abstract images and emblem-like designs [12, 3]. However, the model's ability to generate code is limited to shorter equations, struggling with longer ones [12]. GPT-4V can also reconstruct tables into MarkDown/LaTex code ![The table shows sales volume, revenue, and profit data for five countries.](image7).

GPT-4V demonstrates coding capabilities with vision by generating code for visual tasks like creating graphs and converting handwritten equations to LaTeX.

The DS-DST model is designed to handle both categorical and non-categorical slots, leveraging a dual strategy to improve dialogue state tracking [7, 9]. It adapts a BERT-style reading comprehension model to predict slot values, interacting deeply between the domain-slot and context information [7]. The architecture includes a fixed BERT model for extracting value representations and a fine-tuned BERT model for processing domain-slot pairs and dialog context, connected through cosine similarity matching ![The DS-DST model architecture consists of two BERT models, one fixed for feature extraction and one fine-tuned for processing domain-slot pairs and dialog context.](image2).

DS-DST shows significant improvements over DS-Span, particularly for slots like `hotel-type`, `attraction-type`, `attraction-name`, `hotel-internet`, and `hotel-parking` [6].  These slots often have varied expressions that cannot be directly extracted from the dialog context, which impacts the performance of span-based methods like DS-Span [6]. In contrast, DS-DST can directly predict these values from candidate lists [6]. For instance, in one example, DS-Span incorrectly predicts `hotel type` [4]. The table also presents examples of dialogue turns where DS-Span struggles to extract ground-truth values because users don't always explicitly say 'yes' or 'no' when asked about internet or parking requests [1].

The accuracy for each slot type on the MultiWOZ 2.1 test set highlights these improvements [6]. The dual strategy of DS-DST effectively reduces errors for slots such as `attraction-type`, `hotel-internet` and `hotel-parking`, making it beneficial to treat these slots as categorical [10].

Based on the provided information, the specific accuracy of DS-DST for the `hotel-type` slot is not explicitly stated; however, the model demonstrates notable accuracy improvements for this slot compared to DS-Span [6].

CodeBERT is a novel pre-trained model designed for both programming languages and natural language, demonstrating state-of-the-art performance in NL-PL applications [4, 11]. Trained on a hybrid objective function, CodeBERT leverages both "bimodal" NL-PL pairs and "unimodal" data, enhancing its ability to generate code documentation [4].

![CodeBERT MLM+RTD achieves the highest BLEU score with 22.36, indicating its superior performance compared to other models.](image7)

When pre-trained with both Replaced Token Detection (RTD) and Masked Language Modeling (MLM) objectives, CodeBERT achieved a BLEU score of 22.36 [2, 12]. The model's architecture and training process enable it to outperform other models, including RoBERTa, in code-to-NL generation tasks [8, 1].

Therefore, the BLEU score for CodeBERT when pre-trained with MLM+RTD objectives is 22.36.

The NCF (Neural Collaborative Filtering) model is enhanced with personality information in several ways to improve recommendation performance [7]. One approach, NCF+Hard-coded Personality, incorporates all five OCEAN personality traits by scaling each personality score to sum to a unit value, creating a fixed 5-dimensional vector representing the user’s personality [4]. This vector is then concatenated with the user's latent vector [4].

Experiments conducted on the Amazon-beauty dataset reveal that NCF+Hard-coded generally outperforms other algorithms ![The table presents performance metrics for different algorithms across three datasets: Amazon-beauty, Amazon-music, and Personality2018.](image7). Specifically, NCF+Hard-coded often shows higher NDCG (Normalized Discounted Cumulative Gain) values compared to NCF with most salient personality [9].

Utilizing all five personality traits, as done in NCF+Hard-coded, proves more effective than relying solely on the most salient personality trait [9]. Although the improvement in the Personality 2018 dataset is less obvious, possibly due to dataset size, adding personality information generally enhances performance [2]. This enhancement is particularly noticeable in the Amazon-beauty dataset, where conscientiousness shows significant gains [8]. The methods for incorporating personality information into the NCF model, including the hard-coded approach, are illustrated in a diagram ![The image is a diagram illustrating a model that uses different methods to integrate personality trait scores represented by the OCEAN model, which includes Openness, Conscientiousness, Extraversion, Agreeableness, and Neuroticism.](image8).

In summary, NCF+Hard-coded generally performs well on the Amazon-beauty dataset, often outperforming other NCF variants by effectively utilizing all five personality traits.

SPECTER utilizes a Transformer model initialized with SciBERT to generate document-level embeddings [6]. The model is trained using a triplet loss function, where the goal is to minimize the distance between embeddings of a query paper and a related paper, while maximizing the distance between the query paper and an unrelated paper ![The SPECTER model uses triplet loss to ensure related papers are closer in the embedding space than unrelated papers.](image1). The effectiveness of different training signals on the CITE category can be seen in a comparison with SciBERT fine-tuned on various tasks ![SPECTER shows the best performance in CITE compared to SciBERT fine-tuned on different tasks.](image5).

SPECTER, which leverages citation graphs for pretraining, achieves a CITE score of 91.5, outperforming SciBERT models fine-tuned on co-view, co-read, co-citation, and a multitask combination of these, highlighting the importance of citation-based training [6]. The results of ablation studies on SPECTER also show how removing key inputs impacts performance, and different training approaches affects final scores ![The table shows different configurations of SPECTER and their performance metrics; SPECTER's default settings achieve strong results.](image4). SPECTER's overall performance also surpasses fine-tuned SciBERT models, further demonstrating the effectiveness of its embeddings [4].

The SPECTER model, without task-specific fine-tuning, excels across various tasks, demonstrating versatility and effectiveness [4, 6].  Specifically, in the "User activity" columns, SPECTER achieves high MAP scores, highlighting its ability to capture inter-document relatedness [8]. SPECTER also outperforms other models in the recommendation task, further solidifying its effectiveness [10].

The SPECTER training signal resulted in the highest score for the CITE category.

The ranking process refines classification decisions by employing a nuanced understanding of context and detail [6].
Specifically, Multimodal Large Language Models (MLLMs) can be fine-tuned to improve their ranking ability, ensuring they adhere to prompt formats and return results as expected [3].
![The image is a visual example of a ranking prompt for few-shot image classification. It includes: 1. An image labeled "Mercedes-Benz E-Class Sedan" on the left. 2. A top-k list (in descending order of likelihood for correct match) is shown, highlighting the Mercedes-Benz E-Class Sedan as the top result. This illustrates the process of using few-shot learning and ranking prompts to classify images.](image1)
One approach involves using k-NN clustering to find similar images and creating datasets for fine-tuning, which helps MLLMs rank results more accurately [1].In-context learning, which uses the model’s existing knowledge by providing it with specific examples directly within the input prompt, guiding the model to understand and execute the task of ranking without the need for explicit re-training [7].

RAPTOR constructs a tree structure by clustering chunks of text and generating summaries, enabling the system to load different levels of context into an LLM [1]. The system uses tree traversal retrieval and collapsed tree retrieval for information retrieval. The tree traversal starts with a query that is encoded into a vector; at each level, it retrieves the top nodes based on cosine similarity to the query vector, and then retrieves context from selected nodes, which are then combined with the query to generate an answer using an LLM. The collapsed tree also starts with a query that is encoded; the tree is collapsed into a single layer, and nodes are retrieved based on cosine similarity until reaching a threshold number of tokens. The retrieved context is combined with the query to produce an answer using an LLM. ![The image illustrates two mechanisms for retrieving information using tree structures: Tree Traversal Retrieval and Collapsed Tree Retrieval.](image1)

RAPTOR's design, especially its intermediate layers and clustering, allows it to capture a range of information from general themes to specific details [6]. The clustering approach uses soft clustering, allowing nodes to belong to multiple clusters, which is important because text segments often contain information relevant to various topics [8]. The construction of the RAPTOR tree, which includes clustering and summarization by LLM, forms a hierarchical structure that goes from the leaf layer up to the root layer. ![The image demonstrates how RAPTOR constructs a hierarchical tree by clustering and summarizing text data, working from the bottom (leaf) to the top (root) layers.](image7)

However, the provided information and images do not specify the colors of nodes that appear in more than one cluster in Figure 1.

SenseBERT is designed to improve upon existing language models by incorporating lexical semantic information during pre-training [2, 9]. This approach results in a model with enhanced word-level semantic awareness [2]. SenseBERT's performance on the Word in Context (WiC) task has been evaluated against other models, demonstrating its capabilities in lexical semantic understanding [1, 3].

SenseBERT achieves state-of-the-art performance on the WiC task [2, 3, 12].  For example, SenseBERT outperforms vanilla BERT models [3, 10]. ![SenseBERT achieves the highest score among the models listed.](image5) Specifically, SenseBERT\(_{\text{BASE}}\) surpasses the performance of the larger BERT\(_{\text{LARGE}}\) model [10, 12]. A single SenseBERT\(_{\text{LARGE}}\) model achieves the highest score on this task [3, 10, 12].

Even when compared to models incorporating WordNet knowledge, SenseBERT shows an improvement in lexical semantics, as reflected by its score on the Word in Context task [11]. The scores from different models on the WiC task are shown, where SenseBERT achieves a score of 72.1, outperforming ELMo, BERT with sense embeddings, BERT Large, RoBERTa, and KnowBERT-W+W [See image5].

SenseBERT demonstrates superior lexical semantic awareness on the Word in Context task compared to other models [10, 12].

The models were evaluated using joint accuracy, which is 1.0 only if all domain, slot, and value triplets are correctly predicted [1]. Table 2 presents results on test sets, with the models achieving top performance on MultiWOZ 2.0 and competitive performance on MultiWOZ 2.1 [2].

However, Table 2 is not provided, we can still infer from other tables. Based on the joint accuracy results presented in ![The table presents a comparison of different models based on their joint accuracy.](image4), DS-Picklist has the highest joint accuracy on the MultiWOZ 2.1 dataset.
DS-Picklist achieves a joint accuracy of 53.30% [image4]. Other models, like BERT-DST and ToD-BERT, have lower accuracy scores [image4]. DS-Picklist has the highest joint accuracy on the MultiWOZ 2.1 dataset [image4].

Training large NLP models requires substantial computational resources, leading to significant financial and environmental costs [4, 12]. The use of TPUs can be more cost-efficient than GPUs for certain workloads like BERT [1]. However, training these models still results in considerable carbon emissions [1]. For example, developing the model in our case study (approximately 58 GPUs for 172 days) would cost   $\S145{,}000$ USD plus electricity, about half the estimated cost to use on-demand cloud GPUs [7].

The computational cost associated with training models can quickly become extremely expensive, especially when tuning a model for a new dataset or performing the full R&D required to develop the model [5].  As shown in the table, the estimated cloud compute cost for training models can vary widely depending on the number of models trained, ranging from \$52–\$175 for a single model to \$103k–\$350k for nearly 5000 models ![The table compares estimated costs for models in terms of hours and expenses for both cloud and electric options:](image4).

The table details various models and their cloud compute costs, with GPT-2 being among them ![The table provides information about different models and their associated hardware, power consumption, and costs:](image5).

Based on the information, the cloud compute cost for training the GPT-2 model ranges from $1,478 to $4,625.

Human agreement on extracted rationales is crucial for evaluating the quality of these rationales [12]. Datasets with high Cohen's Kappa values indicate substantial agreement among annotators, suggesting that the rationales are consistently identified.

The table displays metrics, including Cohen's Kappa, for various datasets [3]. Datasets include Movie Reviews, BoolQ, e-SNLI, CoS-E, MultiRC and FEVER. Each of these datasets has a high Cohen’s Kappa, indicating substantial or better agreement [12].

To enhance the faithfulness of continuous importance scores, models assign these scores to tokens, and the area under the precision-recall curve (AUPRC) is measured [10]. Metrics for models assigning continuous importance scores to individual tokens are reported [3]. These models' performance is evaluated using downstream task performance metrics such as macro F1 or accuracy [3].

The e-SNLI dataset exhibits the highest reported Cohen's kappa score in Table 2, demonstrating the strongest inter-annotator agreement among the datasets listed.

The initial step in creating the MLQA dataset involves identifying parallel sentences from articles covering the same subject across different languages [12]. The contexts that contain those sentences are then extracted ![The image illustrates the extraction of parallel sentences and their contexts in different languages.](image6). This process leverages Wikipedia articles to source content in multiple languages [1]. The MLQA annotation pipeline begins with extracting paragraphs containing parallel sentences from articles on the same topic in each language [12].

The ATD spell corrector's performance varies across different types of attacks [2]. Specifically, it excels on keyboard attacks but struggles with other attack types, especially the "add" attack [2].

To evaluate spell correctors, movie reviews from the Stanford Sentiment Treebank (SST) are utilized, with the models assessed on their ability to correct misspellings introduced by various attack types like swap, add, drop, and keyboard attacks [7]. In a comprehensive attack setting, these attacks are mixed randomly for each word to simulate real-world scenarios [7].

The Word Error Rate (WER) is a crucial metric for evaluating the models. The most accurate variant involves backing off to the background model, resulting in a lower error rate of 6.9%, leading to the best performance on word recognition [1]. The most effective defense ideally has both low sensitivity and a low word error rate [4].

![The table presents a comparison of the effectiveness of different spell-correction methods across various types of spelling errors.](image5)

Based on the information, the WER for the ATD spell-corrector model under a 'Key' attack is not explicitly provided in the extracted text or images. More data would be required to answer the question fully.

The performance of different question types varies across languages, with "When" questions generally being easier and "Where" questions posing challenges [5, 7]. ![The image is a heatmap displaying F1 score differences stratified by English question words ("Who", "What", "When", "Where", "How") relative to the overall F1 score for the XLM model.](image1)The heatmap shows F1 score differences relative to the overall F1 score for the XLM model across languages; positive values indicate higher F1 scores, while negative values indicate lower scores for specific question words in each language [image1]. While "Where" questions are challenging for Spanish, German, Chinese, and Hindi, this is not the case for Arabic or Vietnamese [7]. The Restaurant14 dataset is utilized within D1 [1].
