DS-DST, a dual-strategy model for dialogue state tracking, improves upon DS-Span by jointly handling categorical and non-categorical slots [6, 9]. The architecture of DS-DST model leverages BERT models to process both candidate values and dialog context to effectively track the dialogue state ![The DS-DST model uses BERT models to process candidate values and dialog context for dialogue state tracking.](image7).

However, some slots benefit more from this approach than others [4, 7]. For instance, slots like `hotel-type`, `attraction-type`, `hotel-internet`, and `hotel-parking` show significant improvement because their values often have diverse expressions not directly extractable from the dialog context [7].  The joint accuracy comparison shows DS-DST's overall effectiveness against other models [2].  DS-Span struggles with values that aren't explicitly mentioned in the dialogue, such as "free wi-fi" being represented as "yes" for `hotel internet` [1]. In contrast, DS-DST can predict these values directly from candidate lists [7].

Despite these improvements, time-related slots, such as `taxi-leave at` and `train-arrive by`, which are treated as span-based slots in DS-DST, do not perform well because their values are not easily found through span matching in the dialogue context [4].  The dialogue examples also highlight how different models capture intents across turns, with varying degrees of detail [1, 1, 1].  The slot-level accuracy comparison also highlights the differences in performance improvement between DS-DST and DS-Span for the different slots ![DS-DST and DS-Picklist models show performance variations across different slots compared to DS-Span.](image3).  The table detailing slots and their statistics also highlight the challenges in accurately capturing slot values [5].
 
Time-related slots show the least performance improvement when comparing DS-DST to DS-Span.

The MMMU benchmark includes a significant number of multiple-choice questions [1]. Specifically, the dataset contains 10,861 multiple-choice questions, which account for 94.03% of the total questions [6].

Almost all questions within the MMMU dataset incorporate one or more images [7].  ![The dataset includes questions with images at the beginning, middle, and end](image6). 11,264 questions, or 97.52%, include images [6]. Therefore, the vast majority of questions are not only multiple-choice but also contain images [6].

The MMMU benchmark is designed to evaluate LMMs’ general multimodal perception and reasoning abilities [10]. The questions require both visual perception and deliberate reasoning with subject-specific knowledge [4]. ![The image highlights the dataset's focus on expert-level skills, diverse image types, interleaved text and images, and comprehensive disciplines](image1). The dataset covers 30 different subjects and requires nuanced perception and recalling domain-specific knowledge [10].

Approximately 94.03% of the questions in the dataset are multiple-choice, and 97.52% include images.

The training stability of Chameleon models is influenced by architectural innovations and training techniques [5]. Monitoring the uncontrolled growth of output norms is strongly correlated with predicting future loss divergence [9].

The training loss curve for Chameleon-7B without image generation does not suffer from instability issues ![The training loss curve does not suffer from instability issues](image7). However, the standard LLaMa architecture showed complex divergences due to slow norm growth in the mid-to-late stages of training [9]. It was found that to stabilize  Chameleon-7B , it was necessary to introduce dropout after the attention and feed-forward layers, in addition to QK-norm [6].

For Chameleon-34B, using dropout does not resolve divergences in the training loss, regardless of normalization reordering ![Using dropout does not resolve divergences in the training loss](image4). Norm reordering helps to reduce the severity of these spikes [6].

Based on the provided images and quotes, there are two subplots related to loss spikes: one illustrating training with and without QK-Norm for Chameleon-7B [4], and another demonstrating the effect of norm reordering on the training loss of Chameleon-34B [6].

The EN-TAG system aims to improve morphological agreement by incorporating speaker-gender tags during NMT training [1]. The performance of the EN-TAG system compared to the baseline (EN) system was evaluated on different test sets, including male-only, female-only, and those containing first-person singular pronouns [5].

![The table presents data comparing "EN" and "EN-TAG" test conditions across four test sets, with "EN-TAG" generally scoring higher.](image1)

The results for EN-FR show that the EN-TAG system generally outperforms the baseline EN system across all test sets, including those with male data (M), female data (F), first-person male data (M1), and first-person female data (F1) [9].  As hypothesized, the most significant improvement in BLEU score is observed in the female test set, especially in test sets containing first-person singular pronouns (F1) [10]. The EN-TAG system demonstrates statistically significant improvements over the baseline EN system in all four French test sets [9].

In summary, the EN-TAG system generally shows performance improvements over the EN system across various French test sets, with the most notable gains observed in female-specific test sets.

The $\mathrm{NCRF++}$ toolkit is designed to be both effective and efficient, allowing for the reimplementation of state-of-the-art neural models [1]. The toolkit supports flexible feature utilization, including both handcrafted and automatically extracted features [12]. The structure of the $\mathrm{NCRF++}$ model involves a char sequence layer, a word sequence layer, and an inference layer, which can use either Softmax or CRF ![The image shows the architecture of the NCRF++ model, including char sequence, word sequence, and inference layers.](image1).

The toolkit is designed to handle a variety of sequence labeling tasks, such as NER, chunking, and POS tagging [6]. Different models, utilizing combinations of character and word sequence representations, show varying performance across these tasks [10].  For instance, models based on "WCNN" consistently underperform "WLSTM" based models, demonstrating the advantages of LSTM in capturing global features [8]. The performance of different models on NER, Chunking, and POS tagging tasks is detailed in Table 1 ![The table compares the performance of various models on NER, Chunking, and POS tagging tasks, highlighting the CCNN+WLSTM+CRF model's high F1-value for NER and Chunking.](image3).

The best performance in NER, as shown in Table 1, is achieved by the "CCNN+WLSTM+CRF" model, with an F1-value of 91.35 [image3]. Furthermore, increasing the nbest size leads to significant improvements in both oracle entity F1-values and token accuracies [9]. As shown in Figure 3, increasing  nbest size improves both token-level accuracy and entity F1-value [4].  The graph shows how token accuracy and entity F1-value increase with the N best [image5].

The CCNN+WLSTM+CRF model achieves the highest F1-value for Named Entity Recognition (NER).

The C AUSAL C O T approach significantly enhances the performance of GPT-4, particularly in causal reasoning tasks [5]. This enhancement is evident across various evaluation metrics.

The data reveals that C AUSAL C O T achieves a notably higher overall accuracy of 70.40% compared to the vanilla GPT-4's 62.03% ![The table presents accuracy metrics for various models, with CAUSALCoT showing the highest scores across different categories.](image7). This improvement is also seen across different rungs of causal questions, where C AUSAL C O T consistently outperforms GPT-4 [5].

Furthermore, C AUSAL C O T demonstrates superior reasoning abilities on anti-commonsensical and nonsensical data. While the original GPT-4 model performs worse on anti-commonsensical data, C AUSAL C O T substantially improves the reasoning ability across all levels, showing it is particularly beneficial on unseen data [3, 10].

The fine-grained error analysis also shows that while the model is generally good at extracting causal graphs, the subsequent steps involving causal inference are more challenging [2]. The ability of C AUSAL C O T to enhance reasoning across different levels highlights its strength on unseen data, addressing the data contamination problem that affects LLMs [3].

C AUSAL C O T significantly improves the performance of GPT-4 in causal reasoning, particularly on unseen and anti-commonsensical data, making it more robust and reliable.

The D Y GIE system has been evaluated on several datasets, including ACE2004, ACE2005, SciERC, and the Wet Lab Protocol Corpus [2, 7]. The evaluation included the relation graph propagation layer for all datasets [2]. When coreference annotations were available, the coreference graph propagation layer was also included [2].

The results demonstrate that D Y GIE achieves substantial improvements on both entity recognition and relation extraction across the four datasets [11].  D Y GIE attains   $25.8\%$   relative improvement over the state of the art on ACE04 and   $13.7\%$   relative improvement on ACE05 for relation extraction [11]. Furthermore, D Y GIE improves   $11.6\%$   on the state of the art for ACE04-O and   $11.3\%$   for ACE05-O in overlapping entity extraction [12].

Notably, D Y GIE's performance is particularly strong in scenarios with overlapping entities [9]. It has shown improvements on benchmarks like ACE 2004, ACE 2005, and GENIA [9]. Removing the Relational Graph Convolutional Network (R-GCN) component from the Entity-GCN model impacts its performance, especially in tasks requiring multi-hop inference [3, 11]. Without R-GCN, the model's accuracy decreases, indicating the importance of this component in updating mention representations based on their relation to others [3]. In simpler terms, without the R-GCN, the model struggles to perform reasoning that requires multiple steps or connections between entities.

The "No R-GCN" configuration has performance of 62.4 in unmasked and 63.2 in masked settings, showing the effect of removing R-GCN from the model `![The table shows the performance of the model in masked and unmasked settings](image4)`.

The results suggest that W IKIP H OP genuinely requires multi-hop inference, as the best model is 6.1% and 8.4% more accurate than this local model, in unmasked and masked settings, respectively [11].  Even when a simpler graph is used by fully connecting all nodes, only marginal improvements are observed compared to using ELMo alone, further emphasizing the need for a more informative graph and sophisticated parameterization [6]. The model's performance also degrades as the input graph becomes larger, particularly with an increasing number of candidate answers [5, 12].

Removing the R-GCN component decreases the model's accuracy, highlighting its importance for multi-hop reasoning and informative graph processing.

The filter-then-rerank method is designed to improve performance by using SLMs to filter candidate labels and LLMs to rerank them, particularly for difficult samples [4, 2, 5]. By converting few-shot IE tasks to multiple-choice questions, LLMs can focus on sample-level decisions rather than sentence-level identification, which makes them more effective [2]. The "adaptive filter-then-rerank" approach uses SLMs to make preliminary decisions, forwarding only the hard samples to LLMs for reranking, thereby optimizing both performance and cost [5].

![The image shows a text box with instructions to identify the entity type of "The New Yorker." It includes the sentence:](image5)

The effectiveness of LLM reranking is confirmed by the performance gains achieved across different datasets. For example, InstructGPT with reranking provides an average F1 gain of 2.4% without SLM ensemble [9]. This improvement is particularly notable on hard samples, where reranking leads to substantial performance boosts [10, 11]. The selective reranking of hard samples by LLMs significantly enhances overall performance, as LLMs can effectively complement SLMs [6, 7].

![The table displays performance metrics for three datasets: FewNERD, TACREV, and ACE05. It has three rows indicating different sample conditions:](image3)

However, direct application of LLMs (Direct ICL) incurs higher financial and time costs compared to fine-tuning SLMs [4]. The filter-then-rerank approach offers a balance by minimizing the extra latency and costs associated with LLMs [4]. The filter-then-rerank paradigm consistently improves performance across various datasets and settings, confirming the effectiveness of LLM reranking [9].

Based on the information provided, the specific performance of the filter-then-rerank method without ensemble on the 50-shot TACREV dataset is not explicitly stated; further details may be available in Appendix G.1 and G.2 [12].

The distribution of neutral examples varies significantly across the datasets D1 to D4.  Datasets D3 and D4 have considerably fewer neutral examples in both their training and test sets compared to D1 and D2, which impacts the performance of sentiment classification models [5, 10].

![The table contains information about the number of positive, negative, and neutral entries for datasets D1 to D4 in both training and test sets.](image1)

Specifically, D1 has a substantial number of neutral examples in the training set, allowing classifiers to learn neutral-related features [10].  D3 and D4, however, have a very small number of neutral examples in both training and test sets, making it difficult to learn from them and causing even small prediction differences to largely affect the recall and macro-F1 scores [5].  This unbalanced label distribution on D3 and D4 can be addressed by leveraging knowledge gained from balanced document-level examples, which improves aspect-level predictions on neutral examples [4].  PRET and MULT are particularly helpful for datasets with unbalanced labels, like D3 and D4, leading to improvements in macro-F1 scores [1].  The combination of PRET and MULT can further enhance the recognition of neutral instances, compensating for the lack of training examples [12].

The number of neutral examples differs greatly among datasets D1 to D4, with D1 having more and D3 and D4 having very few neutral examples.

The model uses both word-level and character-level embeddings to capture different types of information. Character-level embeddings help the model capture subword information, such as morphological variations and capitalization patterns [12]. The Char Bi-LSTM layer processes character-level information to create character embeddings for each word ![Char Bi-LSTM processes character-level information to create character embeddings](image3). Word-level embeddings capture the semantic representation of each word, providing broader contextual understanding ![Word embeddings capture the semantic representation of each word](image3]. By concatenating character and word embeddings, the model can leverage both fine-grained subword details and the overall meaning of the word [6].

Models can be trained on the exact points from the target embedding space and have access to the target language’s original character sequences by finding translations [7]. The integration of both types of embeddings enhances the model's ability to understand and process language effectively [2]. Using word embeddings, the model can be trained on translated data, inheriting the benefits of both embedding-based and dictionary-based methods, with low resource requirements and access to character-level information ![Translation model performs best across all languages](image2).

The model uses both word-level and character-level embeddings to capture both semantic meaning and subword information, improving overall language understanding and processing.

The pre-processing step in the zero-shot recognition system enhances the performance of Multimodal Large Language Models (MLLMs) by adapting them to region-level recognition tasks [7]. This involves cropping the image regions based on proposal bounding box coordinates and subsequently resizing the cropped region to a fixed proportion [8]. As shown in the object detection datasets, objects can vary significantly in size and position within an image [8].

The "pre-process" section involves cropping images with bounding boxes, resizing them, and creating embeddings using an image encoder ![The diagram illustrates how pre-processing techniques like cropping and resizing assist in zero-shot recognition for object detection tasks using multimodal retrieval methods.](image8). This helps the MLLMs focus on the relevant objects, facilitating their identification in object detection tasks [8].

Two adaptations are made for CLIP and MLLMs for region-level recognition: Gaussian blurring and adaptive crop scale [7]. A proper amount of blurring can significantly improve classification accuracy by leaving enough context information while keeping the foreground object prominent [7].

The pre-processing step, including cropping and blurring, directs the MLLMs’ focus toward the relevant objects, thereby improving their ability to identify objects in object detection tasks [8].

The SnapNTell dataset distinguishes itself from existing VQA datasets through several key features. It includes a wide range of categorized entities, each represented by images and explicitly named in the answers [4, 6]. The question-answer pairs in SnapNTell require extensive knowledge for accurate responses, going beyond simple binary answers [3, 4]. The answers in SnapNTell are predominantly entity-centric, characterized by a greater depth of knowledgeable information pertaining to the specific entity depicted in the image [8].

SnapNTell stands out due to its larger variety of categories, number of distinct entities, and overall number of QA pairs [12]. The questions are highly anonymous, implying that they do not rely on common-sense knowledge or external information, setting it apart from other datasets [12]. The SnapNTell dataset includes 10 images for each entity [12].

Compared to ViQuAE, SnapNTell has 75,680 QA Pairs while ViQuAE has 3,700 [5].

Distant supervision, while useful for relation extraction, introduces noise [4]. DSGAN, a generative adversarial training method, addresses this by using a generator to produce true positives and a discriminator to distinguish between positive and negative samples [4]. The goal is to reduce the discriminator's performance while improving the generator's ability to predict true positives [4]. The DSGAN pipeline is independent of the relation prediction of entity pairs, so it can be used to filter noisy data [9].

The effectiveness of DSGAN can be evaluated by observing improvements in distant supervision relation extraction [6]. Datasets are relocated, and state-of-the-art models are trained to see if performance improves [6]. Models like Zeng et al. (2015) and Lin et al. (2016) benefit from this approach [6].  The pre-trained generator also performs well, but can't provide the boundary between the false positives and the true positives [3].

![The graph shows aggregate Precision-Recall (PR) curves for models based on PCNN, comparing the performance of models with and without DSGAN.](image3)

The accuracy on $N^{D}$ reflects the discriminator's performance, which decreases as the generator learns to produce more accurate true positive samples [8].  The generator and discriminator are modeled using CNNs [7]. The generator calculates the probability distribution over a bag of DS positive samples, and then samples according to this probability distribution [2]. High-confidence samples are treated as true positives by the generator but as negative samples by the discriminator, and vice versa [2].

![The flowchart illustrates the DSGAN training pipeline, where the generator samples from the DS positive dataset and the discriminator distinguishes between the samples.](image4)

As illustrated in the table, different models show performance improvements with the addition of DSGAN [8].

![The table shows the AUC values with and without DSGAN for different models, along with the p-values.](image8)

By comparing the AUC values in the table, PCNN+ONE showed an improvement of 0.015 (from 0.206 to 0.221), CNN+ONE showed an improvement of 0.012 (from 0.177 to 0.189), PCNN+ATT showed an improvement of 0.011 (from 0.253 to 0.264) and CNN+ATT showed an improvement of 0.007 (from 0.219 to 0.226) [8].

PCNN+ONE exhibited the largest improvement in AUC value after the addition of DSGAN.

Distributional models have been used in diachronic research for a while, with Jurgens and Stevens [1] conceptualizing a Word:Semantic Vector:Time tensor to quantitatively compare word meaning development over time [1]. The release of the Google Books Ngrams corpus spurred work in culturomics [12], and various studies employed different corpora like Amazon Movie Reviews, Twitter data, and the New York Times Annotated Corpus to trace semantic shifts [8].

![The timeline highlights key milestones in distributional models for tracing semantic shifts, including the use of Google Ngrams, advancements in prediction-based models, and the analysis of various corpora.](image1)

Key milestones include the introduction of the "Time tensor with Random Indexing" in 2010, exploration using the "Google Ngrams corpus" in 2011, work on "Word epoch disambiguation" in 2012, advancements in "Prediction-based models" in 2013, and the use of "Word embeddings" with "word2vec" in 2014 [image1].  The timeline highlights many important advancements in the study of semantic shifts [5, 11].

The key milestones in tracing diachronic semantic shifts from 2010 to 2017 involve advancements in methodologies, the use of varied corpora, and the development of word embedding models.

The image shows a right triangle, and to find the angle at the green arrow, the tangent function is used [3].  The tangent function states that tan(θ) = opposite/adjacent [3, 11]. Plugging in the values, tan(Θ) = 4/8, which simplifies to Θ ≈ 26.57° [3, 11].

ProgramFC uses reasoning programs to enhance the retrieval of relevant evidence from knowledge sources [1]. Iterative retrieval guided by the reasoning program yields better results because some information may only be revealed during the reasoning process [11].

![ProgramFC outperforms one-step retrieval on all datasets.](image2)

As shown in the figure, ProgramFC outperforms one-step retrieval on all datasets, with the largest improvement of 37.1% on HOVER 4-hop [11]. The iterative step-by-step BM25 retriever in ProgramFC improves retrieval performance compared to the one-step BM25 retriever used in the baselines [1].

ProgramFC demonstrates higher retrieval recall compared to one-step retrieval across various tasks.

The analysis of 150 error instances from GPT-4V's predictions reveals the distribution of error types. Expert annotators identified root causes of mispredictions based on their knowledge [12].

The distribution of these errors are visually represented ![This chart visually represents how different types of errors contribute to the overall error distribution in the evaluated data set.](image7).  Perceptual errors constitute the largest portion of inaccuracies in the GPT-4V model [5].  A significant root cause of domain-specific perceptual errors is a lack of specialized knowledge [4]. Reasoning errors also contribute substantially to the error distribution.

Based on the pie chart, the top three error types are: Perceptual Error, Lack of Knowledge, and Reasoning Error.

The Oracle KGLM shows specific performance in factual completion tasks [12]. KGLM can be directly controlled via modifications to the KG [10]. For instance, when asked "Barack Obama was born on", KGLM initially generates "August, 4, 1961" based on the original fact in its knowledge graph [10]. This illustrates KGLM's reliance on and accuracy with external knowledge sources [5]. KGLM obtains a lower overall perplexity [9].

The table ![The table shows that the KGLM (Oracle) model correctly predicted the birthdate 24 times out of 30 attempts.](image5) provides a breakdown of factual information extraction, including birthdates. Looking at the `birthdate` category, the Oracle KGLM correctly predicted the birthdate 24 times out of 30 attempts.

Therefore, the top-1 accuracy of the Oracle KGLM on birthdate prediction is 24/30.

The determination of fake news often involves analyzing which parts of a source story attract attention from different types of users, with suspicious retweeters and the words they focus on serving as key indicators [3, 9]. The GCAN model can highlight the evidence to explain why a tweet is fake [7]. For example, the tweet "Breaking: huge explosion of an #oil pipeline belonging to @saudi_aramco near sudair, #saudiarabia" was classified as fake news, with "Breaking" and "pipeline" being key highlighted phrases ![The image contains a visual representation related to the classification of a tweet as fake or real news](image1).

The Twitter15 and Twitter16 datasets are utilized for fake news detection [4]. Twitter15 contains 372 true and 370 fake tweets, while Twitter16 contains 205 true and 207 fake tweets ![The table presents a comparison of datasets labeled Twitter15 and Twitter16, likely related to studies of tweet veracity](image5). To determine which dataset has a higher ratio of true to fake tweets, we can calculate the ratios:
- Twitter15: 372/370 ≈ 1.005
- Twitter16: 205/207 ≈ 0.990

Therefore, Twitter15 has a slightly higher ratio of true to fake tweets compared to Twitter16.

The research utilizes contrastive learning, which involves pre-training models on datasets such as MedMNIST and CIFAR-10-LT [2, 3]. To extract image features, MoCo v2, a self-supervised contrastive method, is employed because its contrastive feature matrix can be regarded as cluster representations [9].  Instance discrimination is used as an alternative to select typical data and eliminate outliers, where data that is hard to discriminate from others is considered typical [3]. Different datasets from MedMNIST are used, including PathMNIST, BloodMNIST and OrganAMNIST [5].

![The table contains hyperparameters and configurations for a machine learning model](image1)

As shown, SGD (Stochastic Gradient Descent) is used as the optimizer [image1]. The learning rate is initially set to 0.1, and a learning rate schedule is implemented to reduce the rate on a plateau, with a factor of 0.5 and patience of 8 [image1].

Therefore, the optimizer used in this research is SGD.

The process of creating a comprehensive dataset involves several key steps, including filtering to ensure data quality and relevance. Initially, a list of entities is compiled from 22 primary categories [7, 8]. The filtering process is as follows: the initial list undergoes filtering by cross-referencing each entry with its corresponding Wikipedia page; entities lacking valid Wikipedia pages are removed from the list [7]. This is the "[1st Wiki filtering]: removing ones without wiki page" [9].

![The table shows different categories and the number of entities after each filtering step, starting from the original number of entities and reducing through the 1st Wiki filtering, 2nd Google filtering, and 3rd Wiki filtering](image4)

For each corresponding entity, images are sourced from Creative Commons (CC); further filtering is conducted by removing entities that didn’t have a sufficient number of images obtained via the Google Image Search engine [7]. This step is referred to as "[2nd Google filtering]: removing ones without enough images via google search API" [9]. There is a final filtering "[3rd Wiki filtering]: removing entity name with ambiguous wiki pages" [9]. After these filtering stages, the dataset is refined to include only entities with valid Wikipedia pages and sufficient image resources [7].

Therefore, the main steps in the filtering process are removing entities without Wikipedia pages, removing entities without enough images via Google Search API, and removing entities with ambiguous Wikipedia pages.

The QUOREF dataset has a negative to positive instance ratio of 169 [image4]. Data imbalance is a prevalent issue in NLP tasks, including machine reading comprehension [10].

Compared to other datasets, QUOREF exhibits a significantly higher imbalance [10]. For instance, CoNLL03 NER has a ratio of 4.98, and OntoNotes5.0 NER has a ratio of 8.18 [image4].  SQuAD 1.1 has a ratio of 55.9, while SQuAD 2.0 has a ratio of 82.0 [image4]. The high negative-to-positive ratio in QUOREF is due to the task formulation, where only two tokens are positive within a larger text chunk [10].

The ratio of negative to positive instances for the QUOREF dataset is 169, which is considerably higher than other datasets like CoNLL03, OntoNotes5.0, SQuAD 1.1, and SQuAD 2.0 [image4].

SenseBERT enhances word-meaning awareness through semantic level pre-training [11]. When training a linear classifier over the 'frozen' output embeddings, SenseBERT's parameters remain unchanged [10]. In this setting, SenseBERT BASE improves the score of BERT BASE by over 10 points [11].

The SemEval-SS Frozen results show that BERT BASE scored 65.1, while SenseBERT BASE scored 75.6 ![The table shows that in the SemEval-SS Frozen task, BERT_BASE scored 65.1 while SenseBERT_BASE scored 75.6](image6).

Therefore, SenseBERT BASE improves upon BERT BASE by over 10 points in the SemEval-SS Frozen task.

BERT-LARGE achieves the best performance among the models trained on C OMMONSENSE QA [11]. However, its accuracy varies depending on the type of knowledge required to answer the question.  Examples that require factoid knowledge have a lower accuracy of 38.4% [6]. Some questions require skills such as spatial, cause & effect, has parts, is member of, purpose, social, activity, definition and preconditions to formulate the answer  ![Skills and their frequency in the sampled data](image2). BERT-LARGE achieves an accuracy of 55.9% on the random split [3].

The accuracy of the BERT-LARGE model when answering questions about factoid knowledge is 38.4% [6].

RAR extends its utility to zero-shot recognition on object detection datasets by employing pre-processing steps such as cropping and blurring to focus the MLLMs on relevant objects [6]. The system crops image regions based on bounding box coordinates and resizes them to a fixed proportion, illustrated in the diagram ![The diagram illustrates how pre-processing techniques like cropping and resizing assist in zero-shot recognition for object detection tasks using multimodal retrieval methods.](image1).

The object detection procedure begins with cropping the image regions based on proposal bounding box coordinates, subsequently resizing the cropped region to a fixed proportion [6]. As shown in the example image, there are three bounding boxes (bboxes), each highlighting different objects: a flower arrangement, a saltshaker, and a vase ![The diagram illustrates how pre-processing techniques like cropping and resizing assist in zero-shot recognition for object detection tasks using multimodal retrieval methods.](image1). Each of these bounding boxes corresponds to a potential object that the model seeks to recognize and categorize [6].

In the example image, there are a total of three bounding boxes.

The Tversky Index (TI) offers the flexibility to control the trade-off between false negatives and false positives, and the hyperparameters α and β play an important role in TI [8]. To test how hyperparameters manipulate the tradeoff, experiments were conducted on the Chinese OntoNotes4.0 NER dataset and the English QuoRef MRC dataset [8].

The table shows the effect of hyperparameters in Tversky Index, and only lists α because β=1-α ![This table presents values across two datasets, "Chinese Onto4.0" and "English QuoRef," for various values of a parameter denoted as \( \alpha \).](image5). The highest F1 on Chinese OntoNotes4.0 is 84.67 when α is set to 0.6, while for QuoRef, the highest F1 is 68.44 when α is set to 0.4 [8]. The performance varies a lot as α changes in distinct datasets, which shows that the hyperparameters α,β actually play an important role in TI [8].

The optimal α value for the highest score in the Chinese OntoNotes4.0 dataset is 0.6, and for the English QuoRef dataset, it is 0.4.

The Retrieval-Augmented Generation (RAG) framework has evolved through several paradigms to improve the capabilities of Large Language Models (LLMs) [12]. Naive RAG involves basic indexing, retrieval, and generation steps, while Advanced RAG incorporates optimization strategies in pre- and post-retrieval stages [12]. Modular RAG enhances flexibility by introducing various functional modules [12].

The evolution of RAG is also visually represented through a diagram that shows the progression from Naive RAG to Advanced RAG and then to Modular RAG. Each stage incorporates enhancements to improve performance and flexibility. ![The diagram visually represents these methods as positioned on the axes of "External Knowledge Required" vs. "Model Adaptation Required".](image4)

Modular RAG introduces specialized components to enhance retrieval and processing capabilities. These include modules for search, RAG-Fusion, memory, routing, prediction, and task adaptation [1]. This comprehensive approach streamlines the retrieval process and improves the quality and relevance of retrieved information [1]. The image shows the iterative, recursive and adaptive retrieval augmentation process. ![Each type focuses on enhancing the retrieval and generation tasks differently to improve the system’s performance and flexibility.](image3)

Looking at the Iterative Retrieval icon on the left side, the Recursive Retrieval icon in the middle, and the Adaptive Retrieval icon on the right side, the image utilizes 6 distinct icons.

Chameleon-34B demonstrates notable performance in commonsense reasoning and reading comprehension when compared to models like GPT-4V [2]. In fact, Chameleon-34B achieves a $51.6\%$ preference rate against GPT-4V in pairwise comparisons [8].

Chameleon's capabilities extend to visual question answering and image captioning, where it attains state-of-the-art performance, surpassing models such as Flamingo and IDEFICS [2]. The task categories Chameleon excels in include brainstorming, comparison, and hypothetical scenarios, while it needs improvement in identification and reasoning [3].

The benchmarks used to measure commonsense reasoning and reading comprehension capabilities include PIQA, SIQA, HellaSwag, WinoGrande, ARC-Easy, ARC-Challenge, OpenBookQA, and BoolQ [7].
![The table presents data on the performance of different types of prompts in terms of "Wins," "Ties," and "Loses," along with their respective "Win rate."](image3)
The table shows the win rate of Chameleon on different types of prompts; for example, for the "Reasoning" prompts, the win rate is 59.1% [image3]. In comparison to other models, Chameleon-34B also shows competitive, and sometimes superior, performance on math and world knowledge tasks [10, 12]. The detailed performance of Chameleon and other models like GPT-4 can be found in benchmarks like GSM8K, MATH, and MMLU [10, 12].

Overall, Chameleon-34B shows a strong performance in comparison to GPT-4V, particularly in certain task categories and benchmarks [8].

The analysis of fact-checking claims involves various reasoning types [7]. Many claims require different types of domain knowledge, demanding a multifaceted approach [7]. For instance, verifying a claim might necessitate understanding that "Prod." corresponds to "Productivity" from a table caption, which is considered closed-domain knowledge [7, 10].

Simple lookup and comparison are frequently used, highlighting their importance in table-based reasoning. The distribution of reasoning steps indicates that many claims require multiple steps to verify, emphasizing the complexity of the task ![The histogram shows the distribution of reasoning steps in SCI TAB, with both shallow and deep claims represented](image6).

Simple lookup, used 20.6% of the time, involves retrieving values from specific cells, while comparison, used 19.5% of the time, involves comparing two numbers ![The table lists data analysis functions, including simple lookup and comparison, along with their usage proportions](image4). These functions, along with closed-domain knowledge (12.1%), are crucial for analyzing data.

Simple lookup and comparison are the most common functions in data analysis tasks, accounting for 20.6% and 19.5% of usage, respectively.

Machine translation (MT) systems often struggle with gender bias, performing better on stereotypical gender roles [3]. For example, translation accuracy differs significantly between stereotypical (e.g., female nurse) and non-stereotypical roles (e.g., male receptionist) [3].

According to the bar chart, Google Translate shows varying degrees of accuracy in translating stereotypical and non-stereotypical gender roles across different languages ![The bar chart shows that Google Translate's accuracy for stereotypical translations is consistently higher than non-stereotypical translations across all tested languages.](image1). The difference in accuracy highlights the gender bias present in the MT system [1, 3]. The chart specifically breaks down the percentages for stereotypical versus non-stereotypical translations in Spanish, French, Italian, Russian, Ukrainian, Hebrew, Arabic, and German [1].

Examining the accuracies, Hebrew (HE) shows the largest disparity: 76% accuracy for stereotypical roles versus only 38% for non-stereotypical roles ![The chart shows that the accuracy for stereotypical translations is consistently higher across all tested languages compared to non-stereotypical translations.](image1). This substantial difference of 38% indicates the most significant bias in gender role assignment for Hebrew within Google Translate [1].

Hebrew exhibited the greatest bias in accuracy between stereotypical and non-stereotypical gender roles when using Google Translate.

The MMMU benchmark distinguishes itself through its comprehensive approach to evaluating multimodal models, particularly in breadth and depth [1].  It covers a wide array of college-level knowledge spanning 30 subjects and 183 subfields, utilizing 30 heterogeneous image types [3].

Compared to other benchmarks, MMMU excels in both the breadth and depth of knowledge it requires, as illustrated in Figure 4 [1, 5]. ![MMMU excels in depth (reasoning) and breadth (knowledge) compared to other benchmarks like VQA, GQA, VisWiz, and others.](image5)

The breadth of MMMU is evident in its coverage of diverse image formats, ranging from photographs and paintings to diagrams and tables [10]. The benchmark includes 11.5K meticulously collected multimodal questions from college exams, quizzes, and textbooks [3]. The image types range from advertisements to diagrams [9]. ![The image is a horizontal bar chart showing the distribution of image types in the MMMU dataset.](image2)

Therefore, according to Figure 4 and the details provided in the paper, MMMU reflects the most breadth of knowledge compared to the other listed datasets [5].

The experiments compared S PECTER  embeddings with SciBERT, and the results indicate that S PECTER  embeddings are better at encoding topical information [9]. S PECTER's design incorporates hard negative distractors in the citation-based fine-tuning objective, which is crucial for performance [10]. As shown in ![The table shows different metrics for different configurations, the best scores in each category are bolded.](image1), removing the abstract from the textual input significantly decreases performance, and adding authors as input hurts performance [2].

When SciBERT is fine-tuned on task-specific signals instead of citations, its performance is generally inferior to using fixed representations from S PECTER [12]. As shown in ![This table shows that SPECTER consistently outperforms SciBERT fine-tuned on various co-citation tasks.](image5), SciBERT was fine-tuned on co-view, co-read, and co-citation datasets, and a multitask combination of these. The table compares the performance of S PECTER with SciBERT fine-tuned on different training signals, showing S PECTER outperforming SciBERT across most metrics [3].

The best performing SciBERT fine-tuned model is the multitask model, with an average score of 78.0 [5].

The inclusion or exclusion of certain metadata fields significantly impacts SPECTER's performance, with the removal of abstracts notably decreasing performance, and the addition of author names also resulting in a performance drop [8].  SPECTER outperforms other models across various tasks, demonstrating substantial improvements [7].

Removing the abstract from the textual input, relying solely on the title, leads to a significant decrease in performance, which shows the abstract's importance for the model [8].  Adding author names as input hurts performance, potentially due to the sparsity of author names in the corpus or suboptimal tokenization [8].

![Removing the abstract decreases performance while adding author names also hurts the performance](image1)

SPECTER's design incorporates hard negative distractors during fine-tuning, which proves crucial, as using only easy negatives reduces performance across all tasks [2].  The model is initialized with SciBERT pretrained weights and further trained on a specific objective, using the Adam optimizer with particular hyperparameters [1]. The citation-based pretraining objective is critical for SPECTER's performance; removing it and using a vanilla SciBERT results in decreased performance on all tasks [3].

![SPECTER uses SciBERT and triplet loss function to ensure the related papers are closer to query paper than unrelated papers](image2)

SPECTER outperforms SciBERT fine-tuned on end tasks and multitask combinations, showing its effectiveness [6].  It achieves an average performance of 80.0 across all metrics, a 3.1 point absolute improvement over the next-best baseline [7]. The model is pre-trained on the citation graph to generate document-level embeddings of scientific documents, useful for tasks such as classification and recommendation [4].

![SPECTER model achieves the highest scores across most metrics compared to SciBERT](image3)

The model shows substantial improvements across all tasks, with an average performance of 80.0 [7].  For document classification, performance is better than when trained on other baselines [12].  SPECTER also demonstrates superior performance in user activity prediction and citation tasks, outperforming baselines like Citeomatic [12].

![SPECTER excels in classification tasks and citation prediction](image4)

In summary, the inclusion or exclusion of specific features, such as abstracts and author names, significantly impacts SPECTER's performance, and its design choices, including hard negative distractors and citation-based pretraining, are critical for its effectiveness.

The  Entertainment & Music  and  Family & Relationships  domains contain the most informal sentences [9].

As shown in the table, "All Yahoo Answers" has a total of 40 million entries, with 24 million informal and 16 million formal [5]. The WinoMT dataset is composed by combining the Winogender and WinoBias coreference test sets [3, 11]. The WinoMT dataset contains 3,888 instances, balanced between male and female genders, and stereotypical and non-stereotypical gender-role assignments [3].

The table provides a breakdown of gender distribution across the Winogender, WinoBias, and WinoMT datasets. ![The table presents a breakdown of data across three categories (Winogender, WinoBias, and WinoMT) by gender classification (Male, Female, Neutral).](image3)

Winogender contains an equal distribution of male, female, and neutral instances (240 each) [11]. WinoBias has a large number of male (1582) and female (1586) instances, with no neutral instances. WinoMT combines these datasets, resulting in 1826 male, 1822 female, and 240 neutral instances [3].

The Winogender dataset has an equal number of male, female, and neutral instances, while WinoBias focuses primarily on male and female instances, and WinoMT combines aspects of both.

BERT's best performance reached 77% on the Argument Reasoning Comprehension Task, which was surprisingly close to the average untrained human baseline [1, 6]. However, this achievement was attributed to the model's exploitation of statistical cues present in the dataset [1]. The architecture of the BERT classifier involves processing claim and reason pairs with each warrant independently to obtain logits, which are then fine-tuned ![The image shows the architecture of a BERT classifier, which processes claim and reason pairs with warrants to generate logits, which are then fine-tuned.](image2).

When analyzing the warrants alone (W), BERT achieved a maximum accuracy of 71% [5, 10]. The addition of cues over reasons (R, W) and claims (C, W) accounted for the remaining six percentage points to reach its peak performance [5, 10]. This suggests that BERT's performance relies heavily on exploiting these spurious statistical cues [5]. The probing experiments further confirmed that BERT's peak performance could be attributed to the exploitation of these cues [10].

To address this issue, an adversarial dataset was created to eliminate the statistical cues [1, 12]. When trained and validated on this adversarial dataset, BERT's peak performance dropped to 53%, with the mean and median around 50% [9]. This indicates that the adversarial dataset effectively removed the spurious cues, providing a more robust evaluation of machine argument comprehension [9]. The test results of the BERT model and its different configurations are also shown in the table ![This image shows the test results of the BERT model and its different configurations.](image5).

In summary, BERT's test performance varies significantly across different configurations, with its high initial performance being attributed to exploiting statistical cues rather than actual argument comprehension.

GPT-4 and ChatGPT exhibit performance variations based on whether they are evaluated under general or specific settings. In citation evaluation, GPT-4 (0.5) achieves an alignment score of 90.9, a correctness of 97.6, a precision of 30.8, a recall of 42.1, and an F1 score of 35.6 in the general setting [6]. Under the specific setting, these metrics improve to 92.0, 97.6, 36.0, 43.6, and 39.4, respectively [6]. ChatGPT (0.5) also shows similar trends, with alignment increasing from 82.7 to 84.5, correctness from 94.5 to 94.8, precision from 25.2 to 29.9, recall from 47.4 to 49.0, and F1 score from 32.9 to 37.2 when shifting from general to specific settings [6].

![The table presents a comparison of performance metrics between two models, GPT-4 (0.5) and ChatGPT (0.5), under two different "Settings": General and Specific.](image6)

The improvement in performance metrics from general to specific settings suggests that clearer instructions in the form of specific questions lead to better knowledge utilization by the models [3]. Specific questions provide clearer instructions, guiding the models on which knowledge to apply, which inherently impacts the evaluation results [3]. In text evaluation, GPT-4 (0.5) scores 4.38 (Coherence), 4.77 (Consistency), 4.48 (Fluency), and 4.48 (Relevance) in the general setting, which increases to 4.48, 4.89, 4.64, and 4.72, respectively, in the specific setting [6]. ChatGPT (0.5) mirrors this trend, with scores improving from 4.64 to 4.57 for coherence, 4.89 to 4.94 for consistency, 4.45 to 4.71 for fluency, and 4.70 to 4.81 for relevance [6]. These results suggest that both models benefit from explicit contextual cues provided by specific questions, leading to enhanced text quality.

Therefore, specific questions generally enhance the performance of both GPT-4 and ChatGPT in citation and text evaluation due to clearer instructions on knowledge utilization.

Models like "CLSTM+WLSTM+CRF” and “CCNN+WLSTM+CRF" utilize the framework of word LSTM-CRF with character LSTM or CNN features, achieving state-of-the-art results [11].

The model, single-paragraph BERT, processes each paragraph independently as shown in Figure 2 [9]. The question and a single paragraph are input into BERT, which outputs several scores, including \(y_{\text{empty}}\), \(y_{\text{yes}}\), and \(y_{\text{no}}\) ![BERT processes a question and paragraph, outputting scores; the paragraph with the lowest y_empty is selected.](image3).

The lowest \(y_{\text{empty}}\) score is selected, and its corresponding answer is chosen as the final answer [9]. The selected paragraph's answer is chosen as the final answer [9].  This suggests selecting the most confident or relevant output among the question-paragraph pairs ![BERT processes a question and paragraph, outputting scores; the paragraph with the lowest y_empty is selected.](image3).

The model selects the answer from the paragraph with the best (lowest \(y_{\text{empty}}\)) score [5, 9].

Step-Back prompting, especially when combined with Retrieval-Augmented Generation (RAG), demonstrates notable performance improvements on multi-hop reasoning tasks like MuSiQue and StrategyQA [5]. Baseline models like PaLM-2L and GPT-4 show relatively low performance on MuSiQue, with 35.5% and 38.5% accuracy, respectively, highlighting the complexity of this benchmark [4]. Similarly, on StrategyQA, while baselines are stronger (82.8% and 78.3% for PaLM-2L and GPT-4, respectively), there's still room for improvement [4].

Traditional prompting methods like Chain of Thought (CoT) and Take a Deep Breathe (TDB) provide only marginal gains on MuSiQue and do not significantly improve performance on StrategyQA [4]. RAG alone improves model performance by approximately 4% on MuSiQue and 2% on StrategyQA [4]. However, the integration of Step-Back prompting with RAG yields the most substantial performance boost, achieving 42.8% accuracy on MuSiQue and 86.4% on StrategyQA, outperforming GPT-4 significantly [4].  ![The table highlights that Step-Back prompting combined with RAG significantly improves performance on both MuSiQue and StrategyQA datasets compared to other methods.](image6)

This improvement is attributed to the power of abstraction facilitated by Step-Back prompting, which enables more effective retrieval augmentation [4]. Specifically, Step-Back prompting with RAG can correct 15.4% of the base model's wrong predictions while introducing only 6.1% new errors [7]. Furthermore, it rectifies 12.7% of errors originating from RAG alone, with Step-Back only introducing 4.4% errors to RAG [7]. The error analysis in Figure 5 indicates that reasoning errors are the most common type of error made when using Step-Back prompting [9].   The integration of Step-Back prompting with RAG significantly enhances performance on complex reasoning tasks by leveraging abstraction and improving retrieval effectiveness [4].

The taxi domain achieved the highest zero-shot performance with 60.58% on joint goal accuracy [2]. This is close to the result achieved by training on all the taxi domain data (76.13%) [2].

The table compares the performance of trained single domain models versus zero-shot models across different domains, and taxi domain has the best joint accuracy in the zero-shot setting. ![The table shows the trained single and zero-shot performance for different domains.](image2)

The high zero-shot performance in the taxi domain is attributed to the fact that all four slots share similar values with the corresponding slots in the train domain [2]. The ability to share and transfer knowledge across domains is vital for DST models, especially when dealing with unseen domains [4]. Many slots, like 'area,' exist across different domains [4]. The TRADE model architecture facilitates this knowledge transfer by sharing parameters across multiple domains [9].

TRADE learns to track states without a predefined domain ontology and can perform zero-shot DST for unseen domains [9]. ![The diagram shows the architecture of the TRADE model.](image1)

Therefore, the taxi domain's high zero-shot joint accuracy is due to the similarity of its slots' values to those in the train domain, enabling effective knowledge transfer [2].

The collapsed tree and tree traversal methods are two querying mechanisms used by RAPTOR to retrieve relevant information [1, 9]. The collapsed tree approach flattens the multi-layered tree into a single layer, allowing for simultaneous comparison of all nodes [4]. In contrast, the tree traversal method goes layer-by-layer, pruning and selecting nodes at each level [4, 9, 10, 11].

According to tests performed on 20 stories from the QASPER dataset, the collapsed tree approach consistently outperforms tree traversal [6]. This is because the collapsed tree retrieval offers greater flexibility by searching through all nodes simultaneously, retrieving information at the correct level of granularity for a given question [6].

![The graph compares the collapsed tree and tree traversal querying methods based on F1 score at different context lengths, showing the collapsed tree method generally performs better.](image8)

As shown in the graph, the collapsed tree method (green line) generally has a higher F1 score compared to the tree traversal method (blue line) across different context lengths [6]. The collapsed tree method peaks at 2000 tokens [5, 8]. Therefore, the collapsed tree querying method generally performs better than the tree traversal method in terms of F1 score across different context lengths.

The LOGIC-LM framework integrates LLMs with symbolic solvers to enhance logical problem-solving [6]. It leverages LLMs to translate natural language problems into symbolic formulations, which are then processed by a deterministic symbolic solver. A self-refinement module further enhances the accuracy by revising symbolic formulations based on error messages from the solver [6].

LOGIC-LM's architecture includes a Problem Formulator, a Symbolic Reasoner, and a Result Interpreter, enabling it to address problems through logical inference and constraint optimization. ![LOGIC-LM's architecture includes three modules: Problem Formulator, Symbolic Reasoner, and Result Interpreter](image3) This approach contrasts with relying solely on LLMs, which can struggle with complex logical problems [6].

Compared to baseline models that depend solely on LLMs, LOGIC-LM shows significant improvements. It outperforms standard LLMs and Chain-of-Thought (CoT) prompting across multiple datasets [8]. The performance boost highlights the advantages of combining LLMs with external symbolic solvers for logical reasoning [8].

The adaptability and effectiveness of LOGIC-LM are evident across five logical reasoning datasets [10]. The delegation of multi-step logical reasoning to external symbolic solvers transitions the challenge from problem-solving to problem representation, mitigating performance degradation in complex scenarios [4].

GPT-4 generally achieves high execution accuracy with logical forms, accentuating the potential of symbolic solvers in bolstering the model’s logical reasoning prowess [12]. The high proficiency in transcribing problems into symbolic formats is notable, especially on synthetically generated problems [7].

LOGIC-LM significantly outperforms standard LLMs and CoT across all datasets when using GPT-3.5 [8]. This underscores the benefit of combining LLMs with external symbolic solvers for logical reasoning [8].
When using GPT-4 as the base language model, Logic-LM (without self-refinement) outperforms the two baseline models in all five datasets [8].

To classify tweets' credibility, various approaches were compared using the SemEval dataset [1]. The best performance in the close variant was achieved by NileTMRG, while IITP excelled in the open variant [1]. DeClarE, with its biLSTM, attention, and source embeddings, also showed promising results [1]. The models were evaluated on different datasets, including Snopes and PolitiFact, using metrics such as accuracy, macro F1-score, and AUC [2].

The configurations were also evaluated on the Snopes dataset, and the results are shown in the table ![The table shows the performance of different model configurations on the Snopes and PolitiFact datasets, measuring accuracy, Macro F1-Score, and AUC.](image4). DeClarE variants, including 'Plain', 'Plain+Attn', 'Plain+SrEmb', and 'Full', all outperformed LSTM-text and CNN-text models by a large margin on both datasets [5].

DeClarE obtains clear separability between credible versus non-credible articles in the Snopes dataset, as shown in the projections of article representations ![The figure shows projections of article representations, distinguishing non-credible articles from true ones, article source representations separating fake news sources from authentic ones, and claim source representations clustering politicians of similar ideologies.](image6).

The 'Plain+SrEmb' configuration of DeClarE achieved the highest macro F1-score of 0.82 on the Snopes dataset.

The MMMU benchmark distinguishes itself from existing benchmarks through its breadth and depth [4]. It covers college-level knowledge with 30 image formats, including diagrams, tables, charts, chemical structures, photos, paintings, geometric shapes, music sheets, and medical images [4].

![MMMU includes a diverse range of image types, with diagrams being the most numerous.](image1)

In contrast, prior benchmarks are heavily focused on daily knowledge and common sense, with limited image formats [4].  MMMU requires deliberate reasoning with college-level subject knowledge, going beyond the commonsense or simple reasoning required by previous benchmarks [4]. The comprehensive nature of MMMU is further highlighted by its inclusion of 11.5K questions across six disciplines and 183 subfields [12].

![The table details the composition of the MMMU dataset, highlighting its breadth across disciplines, subjects, and image types.](image2)

The benchmark's design emphasizes both expert-level visual perceptual abilities and reasoning with subject-specific knowledge [9]. The tasks demand the processing of heterogeneous image types and the application of domain-specific knowledge to deeply understand and reason about both text and images [9].
![The image illustrates the key challenges posed by the MMMU dataset, emphasizing the breadth of disciplines, heterogeneous image types, interleaved text and images, and the expert-level skills required.](image4)

The MMMU benchmark stands out due to its comprehensive coverage of college-level knowledge, diverse image formats, and requirement for expert-level reasoning compared to other benchmarks.

Excluding different data sources impacts the model's performance, particularly in the Ultra-Fine category, as evidenced by the performance metrics in the table. ![The table presents performance metrics across different datasets](image3).

The model achieves the best performance when trained on the complete dataset, as indicated by the "All" row [10]. The "Ultra-Fine" category is more challenging to predict than coarse-grained labels [10]. Head word supervision is particularly helpful for predicting ultra-fine labels [10].

Excluding "Crowd" data leads to a decrease in precision, recall, and F1-score for the Ultra-Fine category. Similarly, excluding "Head" data also results in a performance drop, highlighting the importance of head word supervision for ultra-fine labels [10]. Excluding entity linking ("EL") also negatively impacts the performance, though perhaps to a lesser extent than excluding "Head" data.

The performance metrics across different datasets illustrate the impact of each data source on the model's ability to predict ultra-fine labels [10]. Training with all data sources ("All") yields the best results, and removing either crowdsourced data ("– Crowd"), head word supervision ("– Head"), or entity linking ("– EL") reduces performance, indicating that each source contributes unique and valuable information to the model.

Excluding different data sources leads to a reduction in the model's performance on the Ultra-Fine category, indicating that each data source contributes valuable information for fine-grained entity typing.

The search query "Engineering AND Java NOT Manager" aims to find individuals skilled in both Engineering and Java, but explicitly excludes those who are managers [6]. While knowledge of Boolean modifiers may no longer be required, understanding how to construct accurate Boolean search strings remains a fundamental skill [2, 10, 11].

The Venn diagram ![The Venn diagram represents skills in Engineering, Java, and a third category, showing intersections between them.](image7)depicts the intersections of different skills [7]. In this diagram:
*   The intersection of "Engineering" and "Java" represents individuals with both skills.
*   The "NOT Manager" condition excludes anyone who falls into the "Manager" category.

The intersection between Engineering and Java is represented by 'E' and 'G' [7]. However, since we want to exclude managers, and 'G' represents the intersection of all three categories(Engineering, Java, and the third category, which is related to "Manager"), we should exclude 'G'. The result is the subset 'E', representing those with skills in both Engineering and Java, but not in the "Manager" category.

Therefore, the subset selected by the search "Engineering AND Java NOT Manager" is E.

The table shows the activities of Recruiter A and Recruiter B related to profiles and InMails, where Recruiter A sent 375 InMails and Recruiter B sent 75 InMails, respectively. To determine the number of non-response InMails, we need to consider the InMails that were sent but not accepted or declined. The table provides data on sent, accepted, and declined InMails, allowing us to determine the non-response rate for both recruiters ![The table presents data for two recruiters, A and B, and their activities related to profiles and InMails.](image5).

For Recruiter A, 375 InMails were sent, with 8 accepted and 37 declined. This means that 375 - 8 - 37 = 330 InMails did not receive a response. Similarly, for Recruiter B, 75 InMails were sent, with 14 accepted and 11 declined, leaving 75 - 14 - 11 = 50 InMails without a response. Adding these values together gives us the total number of non-response InMails for both recruiters.  Therefore, the total number of non-response InMails for Recruiter A and B is 380.

Bergen offers a variety of museums with activities suitable for children, as well as museums with historical collections such as The Leprosy Museum.

Old Bergen Museum lets you delve into the history of a living museum in the reconstructed Bergen of the 19th and 20th centuries [4].

For those interested in medical history, Leprosy Museum St. George’s Hospital provides a unique cultural monument with many stories [10]. This museum focuses on the history of leprosy, how widespread it was, and the efforts to eradicate the disease [10]. The culmination of these efforts was Gerhard Armauer Hansen’s discovery of the leprae bacillus in 1873 [10].

The Leprosy Museum St. George’s Hospital specifically focuses on educating visitors about the history of leprosy [10].

Bergen offers a rich tapestry of historical and cultural museums. Bryggens Museum marks the beginning of Bergen's history at the UNESCO World Heritage site Bryggen [12]. The walk includes ruins of the city’s first town hall and wooden buildings [12].

The oldest school building in Norway, dating back to 1706, hosts exhibitions about the Norwegian school system and society from the Middle Ages to the present [1].

Haakon’s Hall, dating back to the 13th century, stands as the largest building of the royal residency and a national cultural heritage site, offering a glimpse into the life of kings in the Middle Ages [6].

Old Bergen Museum allows you to delve into the history of Bergen with a unique collection of around 50 original wooden buildings that once stood in the center of Bergen, alongside an English-style park and a seawater pool [5]. ![Old Bergen Museum offers a nostalgic glimpse into Bergen's past with reconstructed 19th and 20th-century buildings.](image2)

Osterøy Museum displays how people in the countryside lived through old buildings, storytelling, and exhibits on textiles, costumes, weaving, and local building customs [3].

These museums collectively showcase Bergen's historical evolution, cultural traditions, and architectural heritage.

The LCD Monitor is designed to display 4K 2D color video from endoscopic and other healthcare imaging systems, making it suitable for use in various healthcare environments [3]. To ensure the best image quality, it's important to securely connect the video cables [4].
 
Different video connectors support various signal resolutions; for a 4096 x 2160 signal at 60 Hz, you can refer to the compatibility chart `![The checkmarks (✔) indicate the compatibility of each resolution and refresh rate with the specific video connector type.](image7)`.  From the chart, it's evident that DP 1.2 and HDMI 2.0 connectors are compatible with the specified signal [8]. If electromagnetic interference occurs, maintaining a minimum distance between RF communications equipment and the monitor can help prevent it [10].  Always use appropriate cables like 75 Ohm RG59 or above for HD-SDI and 75 Ohm RG6 for 3G-SDI to meet the SDI requirements [12]. When connecting additional equipment, ensure compliance with IEC60601-1-1 standards to maintain system safety and performance [2, 7]. Also, various immunity tests like electrostatic discharge and surge tests ensure the monitor functions correctly in different electromagnetic environments `![The table describes immunity tests for electrical devices according to IEC standards.](image6)`.

DP 1.2 and HDMI 2.0 connectors support a 4096 x 2160 signal at 60 Hz.

OBS is designed with a five-level reliability architecture, each addressing specific threats to ensure data durability and reliability [12]. At the storage media level, OBS detects and manages slow disks and bad sectors ![Level 1 focuses on detecting and managing storage media issues.](image8). Moving up to the server level, the system uses erasure codes to protect against FRU failures ![Level 2 protects against server failures using erasure codes.](image8). Cabinet redundancy at level 3 mitigates risks from PDU and switch failures ![Level 3 ensures redundancy at the cabinet level.](image8). To address data center-level threats like wind, fire, water, and electricity, OBS employs multi-AZ storage at level 4 ![Level 4 provides data center-level protection through multi-AZ storage.](image8). Finally, cross-region replication at level 5 protects against regional disasters like earthquakes, floods, and wars ![Level 5 protects against regional disasters through cross-region replication.](image8). This multi-layered approach ensures a robust and reliable storage solution.

OBS has passed the Trusted Cloud Service (TRUCS) certification and offers multi-level protection, including versioning, server-side encryption, and access control [4]. The five-level reliability architecture ensures data durability and reliability, with level-2 using erasure codes to protect against server failures [12].

Level-2 in the five-level reliability architecture of OBS uses erasure codes to protect against server failures [12].

To achieve optimal washing quality, ensure correct loading practices are followed [4]. It's recommended to load the lower basket first, followed by the upper basket [4]. Large and difficult-to-clean items should be placed in the lower basket, such as pots, pans, lids, serving dishes, and bowls [12]. Serving dishes and lids should be positioned on the sides of the racks to avoid blocking the rotation of the top spray arm [12].

Hollow items like cups, glasses, and pans should be loaded with the opening facing downwards to prevent water from collecting inside them [3, 11]. Dishes and cutlery must not lie inside one another or cover each other [3]. To prevent damage, glasses should not touch each other [3]. The upper basket is designed for more delicate and lighter dishware like glasses, coffee, and tea cups [3].

![The image shows a dishwasher rack with a numbered guide indicating different dishware items](image2)

Curved items or those with recesses should be loaded aslant to allow water to run off [3]. All utensils should be stacked securely to prevent them from tipping over [3]. Ensure all utensils are placed so that the spray arms can rotate freely during washing [3]. Long bladed knives stored in an upright position are a potential hazard [3]! Long and/or sharp cutlery items, such as carving knives, must be positioned horizontally in the upper basket [3]. Do not overload the dishwasher for good results and reasonable energy consumption [3]. Non-compliance with loading instructions can result in poor washing quality ![The image contains a warning sign that says: "WARNING: Non compliance with the loading can result to poor washing quality."](image4).

![This table lists numbered items commonly used for dining](image3)

Following the loading instructions is crucial for achieving the best possible wash results [3].

Load the dishwasher thoughtfully, placing items in the correct baskets and ensuring that they do not obstruct the spray arms for optimal washing quality.

However, if you find that both the refrigerator and freezer sections are too warm, several factors could be the cause, such as frequently opened doors, adding a large amount of food, or experiencing very warm or cold room temperatures ![Control panel with dials for adjusting freezer and refrigerator temperatures.](image3). In such cases, adjustments are necessary.

The recommended settings to address this issue are a Refrigerator Control setting of 4 and a Freezer Control setting of B ![Guidance table for adjusting refrigerator and freezer settings based on different conditions.](image5). This adjustment should help to achieve the desired temperatures in both sections [3].

When both the refrigerator and freezer sections are too warm, the recommended settings are a Refrigerator Control of 4 and a Freezer Control of B.

The thermal resistance values for different package types of the 8051AH and 8751BH microcontrollers can be found in the thermal resistance table ![The table provides thermal resistance information for various electronic parts.](image5). The junction-to-ambient thermal resistance (θja) and junction-to-case thermal resistance (θjc) indicate how well the part dissipates heat to the surrounding environment and the case, respectively. For the 8051AH, the thermal resistance depends on the package type [7]. For instance, the 8051AH in a 40-Pin Plastic DIP (Prefix P) has a θja of 45°C/W and a θjc of 16°C/W. The 8051AH in a 40-Pin CERDIP (Prefix D) has a θja of 46°C/W and a θjc of 15°C/W, the 8051AH in a 44-Pin PLCC (Prefix N) has a θja of 36°C/W and a θjc of 12°C/W.

Similarly, the 8751BH also has different thermal resistance values depending on its package type. The 8751BH in a 40-Pin Plastic DIP (Prefix P) has a θja of 40°C/W and a θjc of 14°C/W. The 8751BH in a 40-Pin CERDIP (Prefix D) has a θja of 41°C/W and a θjc of 13°C/W, the 8751BH in a 44-Pin PLCC (Prefix N) has a θja of 33°C/W and a θjc of 11°C/W.

In summary, the 8751BH generally exhibits lower thermal resistance values compared to the 8051AH for the same package type.

FASS (Faculty of Arts and Social Sciences) offers diverse graduate programs designed for professional development and in-depth research [1]. These programs cater to various interests, providing opportunities for students to enhance their potential as intellectual leaders [12].

Many graduate programs at FASS provide opportunities for both coursework and research, allowing students to tailor their studies to their specific interests and career goals.

To adjust the strap size of your smartwatch, begin by measuring your wrist's circumference using the ruler that comes with the watch [3]. Position the ruler about two fingers away from the bottom of your palm [3].

![The image appears to be instructional, showing how to adjust or use a wrist strap or band, likely for a watch or fitness tracker.](image3)

Select the appropriate strap size based on your measurement and fasten the nail buckle [8]. Adjust the strap based on your wrist's circumference [1]. Fasten the airbag buckle to finish adjusting the strap [10]. You may also need to separate the airbag cover from the body of the watch by pressing the cover button and pulling up the airbag [2].

![This image appears to be a diagram or illustration showing the mechanism of adjusting or removing a wristband, likely for a watch or wearable device.](image8)

Align one side of the strap to be installed with the watch body, push the lever inwards, and fasten it [12]. To ensure accurate SpO2 measurements, make sure the watch fits properly and the monitoring module directly contacts your skin [5]. The watch body should be in the middle of the back of your wrist, with the edge below the ulnar styloid process, and the watch face should be about two fingers away from your palm [6].

To adjust the strap size of the smartwatch, measure your wrist, select the appropriate strap size, and fasten the buckles, ensuring a snug and accurate fit.

The 8751H microcontroller has specific input and output voltage requirements that differ somewhat from related models such as the 8751BH and 8752BH. For the 8751H, the voltage on the  $\overline{{\mathsf{E A}}}/\mathsf{v}_{\mathsf{P\mathsf{P}}}$ pin to  $\mathsf{v s s}$ is  $-0.5\mathsf{v}$  to  $+\,\pmb{21.5V}$ [2].

The input low voltage (VIL) and input high voltage (VIH) define the threshold voltages for digital inputs, while output low voltage (VOL) and output high voltage (VOH) define the voltage levels for output pins ![The table provides electrical characteristics for various voltage parameters associated with certain microcontroller models (8751H, 8751H-8, 8751BH, 8752BH).](image1). The logical input current also varies between models [3].

For the 8751BH/8752BH, the voltage on any other pin to  $\mathsf{v_{S S}}$ is  $-0.5\mathsf{V}$  to  $+\,\mathsf{7v}$ [2]. This is a notable difference from the 8751H. These voltage specifications are crucial for ensuring the correct operation and preventing damage to the microcontroller.

The input and output voltage specifications for the 8751H microcontroller differ from those of the 8751BH/8752BH models, particularly regarding the maximum voltage allowed on certain pins.

To measure your wrist circumference, you can start by placing the ruler that comes with the watch through the buckle [8]. Make sure to position the ruler about two fingers away from the bottom of your palm [8]. Then, pull the ruler until it touches your arm, but not too tightly, and record the position indicated by the arrow [2].

To ensure an accurate measurement, wear the device correctly, positioning the watch body in the middle of the back of your wrist [5]. The edge of the watch body should be below the root of the ulnar styloid process, without pressing on it or being too far away [5]. The center of the watch's face should be about two fingers width away from your palm ![Illustration of the proper placement of a wrist-worn device](image3).

Based on the measurement, select the appropriate strap size and then fasten the nail buckle [3]. You can adjust the strap according to your wrist's circumference ![Illustration of the method for finding the radial pulse](image5), and select the strap and airbag based on the scale value [7]. Finally, align one side of the strap to be installed with the watch body, push the lever inwards, and fasten it ![Illustration of a hand with a smartwatch on the wrist](image1).

Properly measure your wrist circumference by positioning the ruler correctly, ensuring it's snug but not too tight, and noting the measurement to select the appropriate strap size.

To connect to another Mac using Migration Assistant, begin by following the Setup Assistant instructions on your MacBook Air until you reach the "Do You Already Own a Mac?" screen and select "from another Mac" as your transfer source [4]. Then, choose your wireless network and click Continue [4].

If you didn't use Setup Assistant initially, you can still use Migration Assistant later by navigating to the Applications folder, opening Utilities, and double-clicking Migration Assistant [6].

![This image shows a screenshot of Apple's Migration Assistant. It's used to transfer data from one Mac to another](image1).

On the other Mac, open Migration Assistant, located in /Applications/Utilities/, and click Continue [12].  When prompted for a migration method, select "To another Mac" and click Continue [7]. When you see the Connect To Your Other Mac screen with a passcode displayed, complete the remaining steps on the other Mac by entering the passcode in Migration Assistant [1, 8].

![This image is a screen prompt for connecting to another Mac](image8).

Connecting to another Mac using Migration Assistant involves selecting the appropriate option during setup or opening the Migration Assistant application, ensuring both Macs are on the same network, and entering the displayed passcode to initiate the transfer.
