The Naval Medical Research Center (NMRC) reinstituted its Annual Mess Night, also known as a Dining Out, for officers and guests [5, 12]. This event follows a strict Naval protocol, rooted in traditions from the Vikings and the British Navy, but includes unique references to the history of Naval Medical research [1]. The evening involves time-honored customs such as an invocation, the presentation and approval of the beef, and junior officers reciting "poems and odes" about the research accomplishments of their Naval predecessors [1].

![People in naval uniforms are gathered for a formal dining event, highlighting the traditional aspects of the ceremony.](image4)

The Dining Out provides a platform to reflect on the contributions and sacrifices within Navy Medicine. For instance, Hospital Corpsman 1st Class Brian Knetsch presented the Prisoner of War/Missing in Action table, creating a moment to honor fallen comrades [6]. The event also serves as an opportunity to acknowledge the ongoing work and dedication of those involved in Navy Medicine research and development [8]. The President of the Mess acknowledged everyone's professionalism and dedication [8].

![Two people in naval dress uniforms are standing next to three other people at the Dining Out.](image2)

The President of the Mess introduced speakers like Doll, who discussed the history of Navy Medicine research and development, encouraging junior officers to become future leaders [10]. The event concludes with a toast to the United States Navy while "Anchors Aweigh" plays [7]. Such events underscore the Navy's commitment to medical research and its impact, encapsulated in the slogan "America’s Navy: A Global Force for Good" [3]. The Dining Out is a blend of tradition, recognition, and forward-looking encouragement within the Naval Medical Research Center.

NAMRU-3 significantly contributes to medical research capacity building in countries recovering from conflict, such as Liberia [1]. They focus on building medical capacity with Ministry of Health laboratories, as seen in their partnership with the Defense Threat Reduction Agency (DTRA) in Afghanistan [3]. This collaboration enhances biodefense and disease surveillance efforts, crucial for force health protection.

NAMRU-3 also trains laboratory and administrative staff, establishes inventory systems, institutes quality control procedures, and develops national laboratory biosafety and quality control plans [5].  ![People are gathered around a table in what appears to be a laboratory setting](image7). This includes training for Afghan scientists and technicians on laboratory operations, diagnostic procedures, and research ethics [8, 9].  Researchers at NAMRU-3 developed modules covering parasitology, bacteriology, bioscience facility management, clinical epidemiology, and other key areas [10]. Moreover, NAMRU-3 has been involved in establishing hospital laboratories and providing training for diagnostic laboratories [12].

The Naval Submarine Medical Research Laboratory (NSMRL) focuses on the submarine force and human factors, acting as the primary human technology laboratory for the Commander, Submarine Forces (CSF) [6]. NSMRL conducts medical, psychological, and human performance research, provides reviews of human systems projects, and develops innovative concepts for CSF [6]. NSMRL also conducts investigations in diving medicine [6].

Both NAMRU-3 and NSMRL's missions align with U.S. military operations by enhancing force health protection, building medical capacity in strategic regions, and optimizing the health and performance of specialized units like the submarine force. In summary, NAMRU-3 and NSMRL significantly contribute to medical and scientific research, directly supporting U.S. military operations through capacity building, force health protection, and the optimization of human performance.

The Naval Medical Research Center (NMRC) plays a significant role in both international medical initiatives and local advancements. Internationally, the USNS Mercy, with NMRC personnel like Cmdr. Charmagne Beckett, conducts humanitarian missions, such as the Pacific Partnership, which began as a response to the Southeast Asia tsunami [4]. These missions provide medical care, including surgeries and screenings, and veterinary services, alongside non-medical projects and subject-matter expert exchanges [1]. For instance, in four host nations, over 49,000 patients received care, and more than 900 surgeries were performed [1].
![A person in military uniform standing on the flight deck of the USNS Mercy, with a scenic view of the sea and distant land in the background.](image3)
NAMRU-3, another component of the NMRC, has been instrumental in building medical capacity in Afghanistan since 2006 [8]. This includes establishing hospital laboratories, providing training to Afghan scientists and technicians, and developing comprehensive training plans [3, 5, 6]. These efforts focus on improving laboratory operations, diagnostic procedures, and biosafety [5, 11].
![Several people wearing lab coats gathered around a table, likely in a laboratory setting, demonstrating or explaining something using documents and lab equipment.](image8)
Locally, the NMRC's Bone Marrow Research Directorate supports military contingency by researching and innovating in DNA-based typing for marrow transplants, which is crucial for casualties exposed to radiation or chemical warfare agents [10]. Furthermore, the C.W. Bill Young DoD Marrow Donor Program, part of the NMRC, facilitates genetic testing to match potential donors with patients, following donor drives at military bases [12]. The NMRC supports medical advancement by developing laboratory quality control plans [11].

The NMRC enhances both international medical capabilities and local medical treatments.

U.S. Naval Medical Research Units (NAMRU) engage in various activities, including training and research, to support military personnel and local communities. NAMRU-3 collaborates with the Liberian Institute of Biomedical Research (LIBR) on projects focusing on disease vector surveillance, detection of vector-borne viral pathogens such as malaria, and vector control [3]. This collaboration expands Liberia's capabilities in vector-borne disease surveillance, benefiting both the Liberian Armed Forces and the entire population [3]. The collaboration extends to military-to-military engagements with the Armed Forces of Liberia (AFL) through vector control training efforts [5]. ![NAMRU-3 collaborates with Liberian authorities to enhance disease surveillance.](image4)

NAMRU-3's efforts in Liberia are particularly important as the country recovers from a prolonged civil war that severely damaged its infrastructure [7]. The training provided by NAMRU-3 has improved the ability to protect soldiers and their families from disease [9].  Additionally, insecticide spraying and geospatial mapping, carried out by NAMRU-3 in collaboration with the Navy Entomology Center of Excellence (NECE), have eliminated malaria infections in U.S troops [10].  ![Personnel from NAMRU-3 and the U.S. military collaborate with Liberian forces at their headquarters.](image7)

The Rickettsial Diseases Research Program trains individuals in regions endemic to rickettsial diseases to assess and mitigate the risk to military and civilian personnel [2, 12]. Scientists from Kazakhstan received training at the Naval Medical Research Center (NMRC) on molecular assays as part of a collaboration with the Cooperative Biological Engagement Program (CBEP) [6]. The Patient Condition Occurrence Frequency (PCOF) tool, developed by the Naval Health Research Center (NHRC), provides occurrence probabilities of disease and injury types, aiding military medical planning for various scenarios, including humanitarian assistance and disaster relief [8, 11].

The U.S. Naval Medical Research Units support military personnel and local communities through disease surveillance, training, and research collaborations, enhancing health protection and medical capabilities in various regions.

The Patient Condition Occurrence Frequency (PCOF) tool plays a crucial role in enhancing medical mission planning within the military [3]. This tool provides a repeatable, organized, and robust method for estimating patient condition probabilities, moving beyond anecdotal estimates [3, 5]. It generates tables that show the probabilities of various disease and injury types sustained in different scenarios, including combat and non-combat situations [6].

![The image shows four people standing outdoors, possibly in a park during autumn.](image6)

These PCOF tables cover casualty categories such as wounded in action, non-battle injuries, disease, and outpatient visits [6]. The tool is designed to function across the range of military operations (ROMO), including humanitarian assistance, disaster relief, defense support of civil authorities, and combat operations [6]. By using the PCOF tool, planners can tailor baselined, mission-centric data to more precisely fit anticipated missions, aiding decision-makers in understanding the types of patient conditions to expect [7].

![The image shows a group of military personnel in uniform posing in front of a helicopter with a red cross emblem.](image7)

The PCOF tool helps inform decision-makers on the types of patient conditions to expect during a contingency [7]. Combat data sets are derived from operations like Enduring Freedom and Iraqi Freedom, while humanitarian assistance PCOF tables use data from operations like Continuing Promise and Pacific Partnership [12]. Disaster relief PCOFs are developed from literature reviews and subject matter expert input [12]. Once accredited, NHRC's PCOF tool will be approved as the Joint patient occurrence generating application [9].

![The image shows U.S. Marines and Sailors seated inside a military aircraft, preparing for deployment to Afghanistan as part of Operation Enduring Freedom.](image2)

The PCOF tool enables a more accurate estimation of patient streams, which are essential for health care simulations [6]. This tool represents a significant advancement, providing a functional and accurate means of estimating PCOFs, which was previously lacking in the military medical planning community [6].

The PCOF tool provides an effective and accurate method for estimating patient condition probabilities, which is essential for medical mission planning in various military operations [5, 6].

The USNS Mercy Pacific Partnership 2012 focused on providing medical, dental, and veterinary care to host nations, as well as conducting subject-matter expert exchanges [10]. During its 56-day mission, the USNS Mercy provided care to over 49,000 patients and performed over 900 surgeries [10].

![The USNS Mercy crew members and Project HOPE members are posing for the photo in a clinical room](image5)

The ship also conducted veterinary services, treating over 7,000 livestock and domestic animals [10]. Aboard the ship in Guam was Beckett, fulfilling the role of Internist and Infectious Diseases Officer [1]. The staff also participated in over 60,000 hours of subject-matter expert exchanges covering topics like first aid, nutrition, and public health [10]. An example of someone in military uniform standing on the flight deck of the USNS Mercy can be seen in ![A person in military uniform stands on the USNS Mercy flight deck](image8).

In contrast, the C.W. Bill Young DoD Marrow Donor Program, operated by the Navy and Georgetown University [2], aimed to register service members as potential marrow donors [4, 12]. The program supports military contingency by addressing marrow toxic injury from radiation or chemical warfare agents [3]. Genetic testing is performed on cell samples to match potential donors with patients needing transplants [2]. As shown in ![A person is swabbing another person's mouth, possibly for a medical test or DNA collection](image3), oral swabs are collected to determine potential donors. The program had over 730,000 DoD volunteers, with over 5,200 having donated marrow for patients with potentially fatal diseases [12].

The USNS Mercy Pacific Partnership 2012 provided direct medical and humanitarian aid to thousands, while the DoD Marrow Donor Program provides a critical resource for those needing marrow transplants, addressing both battlefield injuries and broader medical needs.

Military research collaborations play a crucial role in addressing specific health challenges by leveraging resources and expertise across different sectors [3]. These collaborations often focus on diseases prevalent in developing countries, which can also affect deployed warfighters [7]. For instance, research includes evaluating the effects of changing demography and land use on malaria transmission, which is significant for the health of deployed warfighters ![This image depicts the emblem of the U.S. Naval Medical Research Unit-2 (NAMRU-2), Pacific.](image2).

One approach involves training individuals in regions endemic to rickettsial diseases, enhancing the assessment and mitigation of risks to both military and civilian personnel [10, 12]. This is exemplified by scientists from Kazakhstan receiving training on molecular assays at the Naval Medical Research Center (NMRC) as part of a collaboration with the Defense Threat Reduction Agency (DTRA) [4].

These collaborations facilitate technology transfer, ensuring that biomedical developments move from the laboratory to practical applications for the warfighter, and potentially benefiting the general population through commercialization [1, 3, 8]. This includes exploring novel methods of anchoring prosthetics and using synthetic oxygen-carrying fluids to reduce tissue damage from hemorrhagic shock [7].

Moreover, medical advances are often accelerated during wartime, emphasizing the importance of systematic data collection and analysis in combat environments [6]. Research conducted in these settings must adhere to stringent human subject protection regulations [5, 9]. An example includes efforts of personnel in transit, likely preparing for deployment to Afghanistan as part of Operation Enduring Freedom ![The image shows U.S. Marines and Sailors seated inside a military aircraft.](image7).

Such collaborations result in new diagnostic tools, treatments, and preventive measures, strengthening global health security and improving the well-being of both military personnel and civilians.

The Naval Submarine Medical Research Laboratory (NSMRL) is described as an operational medicine laboratory focusing on the submarine force and human factors [10]. NSMRL was established as the Commander, Submarine Forces’ (CSF) primary human technology laboratory, covering all physical and mental aspects of submariner health and performance [10].

NSMRL conducts medical, psychological, and human performance research and offers objective reviews of human systems-related projects and technology proposed for CSF use [10]. The newsletter also mentions NSMRL's capabilities in diving medicine and underwater communications, enhanced by the acquisition of NAVSEA’s new DP1/2 diving system [9]. NSMRL tests diving equipment for general Navy use and refines operating instructions [9]. Hopefully, the newsletter gave a peek into the operational research world of NSMRL [1].

![This image shows people in lab coats gathered around a table in a lab, likely in a scientific or educational context.](image8)

NSMRL serves as CSF's primary human technology laboratory, addressing the health and performance of submariners and conducting research in diving medicine and underwater communications [10, 9].

NAMRU-3 has been actively involved in bolstering Afghanistan's public health capabilities since 2006 [5]. Their initial efforts focused on assessing the capacity of laboratories, staff, and support facilities, starting with the Central Public Health Laboratory (CPHL) in Kabul [9]. Subsequently, they broadened their scope to include additional facilities in Kabul and planned to extend their program to other regions of Afghanistan [9]. To that end, NAMRU-3 established five hospital laboratories and specialized units for virology, bacteriology, and serology within the CPHL [10].

![People in lab coats are gathered around a table in a lab, with one person demonstrating or explaining something.](image5)

NAMRU-3 has provided training for various diagnostic laboratories [10]. They also developed training materials tailored to the Afghan context, considering cultural practices [8]. In 2011, NAMRU-3 trained 160 Afghan scientists and technicians in laboratory operations, diagnostic procedures, and research ethics [3]. Additionally, NAMRU-3 hosted nine Afghan trainees from the Central Public Health Laboratory in Kabul for a bacteriology training workshop [2]. To further enhance training effectiveness, a comprehensive plan was developed for 2012 based on identified needs and gaps [3]. These modules covered diverse topics such as parasitology, bacteriology, bioscience facility management, clinical epidemiology, miomedical equipment repair, laboratory quality management system, serology, molecular biology, and virology [1].

![Several people stand in front of a building with signage for the Headquarters Armed Forces of Liberia and the Ministry of National Defense.](image7)

Moreover, NAMRU-3 conducted workshops to train laboratory and administrative staff on proper procedures, inventory management, quality control, and the development of national biosafety and quality control plans [6]. These efforts were part of a broader collaboration with the Defense Threat Reduction Agency (DTRA) Cooperative Biological Engagement Program (CBEP) to enhance biodefense and disease surveillance in Afghanistan [11].

NAMRU-3 conducted extensive training activities in Afghanistan, covering laboratory operations, diagnostic procedures, and public health capacity building.

The immune system targets malaria parasites through the interaction of CD8+ T cells with infected liver cells, leading to the elimination of the parasite [image5]. This involves the presentation of Pf peptide on the liver cell surface, engagement of the CD8+ T cell, and the release of perforin and granzymes, ultimately inducing apoptosis [image5]. The process also involves IFN-γ and Fas/FasR interactions, further contributing to cell signaling and apoptosis [image5]. This immune response is crucial for identifying novel antigens for malaria vaccine development [image5].

The illustration shows that the immune system uses CD8+ T cells to target malaria parasites in infected liver cells.

The Naval Medical Research Center (NMRC) embodies the intersection of military research and civilian healthcare advancements through technology transfer and collaborative projects [1, 11]. The NMRC enterprise facilitates local and regional partnerships to support the health and readiness of military personnel, which often leads to broader benefits for the general population [12]. This is achieved through Cooperative Research and Development Agreements (CRADAs) and commercialization of Navy Medicine inventions [4, 11].

For instance, Lt. R. Vince Gerbasi (NMRC, Infectious Diseases Directorate) leads a malaria-focused collaboration using mass spectrometry to identify novel antigens for potential vaccine candidates [3]. ![The image is a graphic illustration showing the interaction between a CD8+ T cell and a liver cell in the context of malaria infection.](image7) This research has significant implications for both military personnel deployed in malaria-prone regions and for civilian populations in developing countries where malaria is prevalent [3]. Capt. Eileen Franke Villasante, Head of the Malaria Department at NMRC, exemplifies this connection, bringing her expertise from the Navy to global health discussions [10].

The Joint Combat Casualty Research Team (JC2RT) further illustrates this collaboration. Originally deployed as the Deployed Combat Casualty Research Team (DC2RT) during combat operations, these teams have evolved to include members from all three services and transitioned to Afghanistan [8]. ![The image shows a group of military personnel in uniform posing in front of a helicopter with a red cross emblem.](image6) Their mission is to systematically record, collect, validate, and analyze data to accelerate medical advances and decrease morbidity and mortality associated with combat injuries [7]. USCENTCOM dictates research priorities, focusing on areas such as pre-hospital care, hemorrhage, traumatic brain injury, and prevention [5]. The urgency to capitalize on the "research window of opportunity" due to anticipated troop drawdowns highlights the importance of this work [7].

NMRC's efforts in malaria vaccine research and the JC2RT team's work reflect a synergistic relationship between military research and civilian healthcare advancements, leveraging military needs to drive innovations that benefit a wider population [11, 7].

The Joint Combat Casualty Research Team (JC2RT) plays a crucial role in conducting combat-relevant research in deployed environments [6]. The JC2RT transitioned to Afghanistan as operations tempo decreased in Iraq [2]. Members of the JC2RT are embedded with medical assets throughout Afghanistan [2].

The JC2RT's mission is to systematically record, collect, validate, and analyze data to facilitate medical advances that can decrease morbidity and mortality associated with combat injuries [1]. As shown in ![A group of military personnel in uniform are posing in front of a helicopter with a red cross emblem.](image6), the team comprises personnel from various branches of the armed services. The JC2RT Team 13 has prioritized enrollment and conduct of currently approved protocols as well as the judicious and expedient processing of new protocols [1].

The JC2RT team in Afghanistan is tasked with overseeing, coordinating, facilitating, and conducting combat-relevant research to improve medical outcomes for combat casualties.

The C.W. Bill Young Department of Defense Marrow Donor Program utilizes cotton swabs to collect cell samples from potential donors [8, 9]. These samples are then sent to the program's Donor Center and Laboratory [9]. At the lab, staff members perform genetic testing on the cells obtained from the oral swabs to match potential donors with patients in need of marrow transplants [9].

![The image shows a person swabbing another person's mouth, possibly for a medical test or DNA collection](image8)

The collected information from the cotton swab is entered into the National Marrow Donor Program registry [3]. If a match is found between a registered individual and a patient, further testing is conducted to confirm the match and assess the donor's suitability for donation [3].

Therefore, the cotton swab is used in the DoD Bone Marrow Program to collect cell samples for genetic testing to identify potential marrow donors.

The transformation of data into business value progresses through distinct levels of analytics, each building upon the previous one to increase both the degree of intelligence and the business value derived [8]. The initial stage involves simple reporting, which describes "What happened?" ![Standard Reports](image8). This progresses to ad-hoc reports that answer questions about quantity, frequency, and location [8]. More sophisticated techniques like OLAP drilldown help pinpoint the exact location of problems [8]. Alert systems then suggest necessary actions based on the analyzed data [8].

Statistical analysis explores the reasons "Why is this happening?" ![Statistical Analysis](image8), which then leads to forecasting, which considers "What if these trends continue?" [8]. Predictive modeling aims to forecast "What will happen next?" [8]. Finally, optimization seeks to determine "What's the best that can happen?" [8]. This entire progression reflects a data-driven process where raw data is refined through reporting, analysis, and action, ultimately leading to increased business value ![Data-driven process from data to value](image1). Moreover, pushing data through an "analytics value chain" from collection and analysis to decisions, actions, and impact is crucial [3]. Being only partway along the chain does not yield the intended results [3]. Ultimately, analytics is about impact, where insights must lead to changes and tangible outcomes to be considered valuable [4].

The process of transforming data into business value progresses through a structured analytics value chain and increasing levels of analytical sophistication, each adding greater insight and impact.

The Disciplined Agile framework provides several strategies and considerations for exploring the initial scope of a project, which are essential during the project's early stages. In the "Inception" phase, one of the key process goals is to "Explore initial scope" ![The image is a mind map illustrating "The Process Goals of Disciplined Agile Delivery (DAD)."](image1). Several elements contribute to how this initial scope is explored [5].

The framework considers various levels of detail, ranging from goal-driven approaches to detailed specifications, including requirements envisioning for a light specification or opting for no specific level of detail initially ![The image is a diagram related to exploring initial scope within the context of Disciplined Agile.](image5). View types such as usage modeling, domain modeling, process modeling, and user interface modeling are taken into account, allowing for a comprehensive understanding of the project's scope [5]. Modeling strategies can range from informal to formal sessions, including interviews to gather necessary information [5].

Work item management strategies also play a crucial role, with options like a work item pool, work item list, requirements backlog, or formal change management being considered [5]. Furthermore, the framework addresses non-functional requirements through acceptance criteria, an explicit list, or technical stories [5]. Actively participating stakeholders and discussing requirements are useful ways to explore the scope in the "Construction" phase, as well as gathering initial requirements in the Inception phase, which contributes to properly defining the scope [7].

The Disciplined Agile framework addresses scope exploration through varied modeling techniques, levels of detail, and stakeholder involvement.

The analytics value chain emphasizes the importance of moving data through a complete cycle, from collection to impact, to derive value [1]. As stated, insights without action result in no value" [2]. This aligns with the levels of analytics, where each stage builds upon the previous one to increase both business value and the degree of intelligence, ultimately leading to informed action.

The levels of analytics progressively transform raw data into actionable insights, starting with basic reporting to answer "What happened?" and advancing to predictive modeling and optimization to determine "What will happen next?" and "What's the best that can happen?" ![Levels of analytics demonstrates the progression from data to value](image7). The "action" stage in the analytics value chain is directly supported by the insights gained from the higher levels of analytics.

The data-driven process turns data into value by reporting, analysis, and action ![The flowchart illustrates a data-driven process that transforms data into value](image2). Analysis differs from reporting, focusing on "Why?" rather than just "What?" and aiming to answer questions and provide context through storytelling [5]. By understanding the "why," organizations can take more effective actions, completing the analytics value chain and realizing tangible value.

Together, the Analytics Value Chain and Levels of Analytics provide a structured approach to ensure that data is not only collected and analyzed but also translated into actionable insights that drive meaningful business outcomes.

During meiosis I, homologous chromosomes pair up, and genetic material is exchanged between non-sister chromatids via crossing over [1]. This process, also known as synapsis, results in a tetrad formation with four chromatids [1].

![The diagram includes labels in both English and Arabic to explain these components and processes.](image6)

As illustrated in the meiotic stages, the spindle and microtubules attach to kinetochores, which are essential for chromosome movement [6]. The chromosomes then align along the metaphase plate [6].  Following metaphase I, homologous chromosomes, not sister chromatids, separate [5]. Meiosis I reduces the chromosome number by half [5].

![The image is a diagram of the stages of meiosis. It includes:

- **INTERPHASE** (الطور البيني) in a green box.
- **MEIOSIS I: Homologous chromosomes separate** (الانقسام الاختزالي الأول: تنفصل الأزواج الكروموزومية المتشابهة) in a blue box.
  - **PROPHASE I** (الطور التمهيدي الأول)
  - **METAPHASE I** (الطور الاستوائي الأول)
  - **ANAPHASE I** (الطور الانفصالي الأول)](image2)

Metaphase I involves the alignment of tetrads at the metaphase plate, facilitated by spindle fibers and microtubules, leading to the separation of homologous chromosomes.

Prefabricated formwork involves using pre-engineered modules with metal frames and various surface materials [6]. This approach is designed for speed and efficiency, enhancing accuracy and minimizing waste in construction [8]. Gang forming, a key advancement in prefab forming, groups multiple forms together for simultaneous movement, facilitated by specialized hardware [3, 12].

Formwork systems are available which need to be worked only from one side [1]. Prefabricated forms offer high-quality materials and perform well across different jobs, reducing costs [11]. These systems simplify both erection and stripping processes, allowing for removal and replacement at any point [5]. Well-maintained forms also ensure more reuses [4].

An example of prefabricated formwork are metal formworks used for shaping concrete during the pouring and setting process ![Metal formwork on a dirt surface](image1). Concrete columns are also constructed using prefabricated formwork, complete with scaffolding and access ladders ![A 3D model of a construction formwork for a concrete column](image7). Additionally, concrete foundations utilize wooden frames as formwork, highlighting the advantages of pre-fabrication in construction ![Wooden frames at a construction site being used to shape a concrete foundation](image8). The image of a construction site further exemplifies the use of formwork panels in shaping concrete structures with metal rebar and scaffolding ![Construction site featuring reinforced concrete structures with formwork panels](image2). Finally, gang forming uses large concrete form panels lifted by cranes on construction sites, streamlining the construction process ![Concrete form panels lifted by cranes during construction](image6).

Prefabricated formwork examples include metal formworks, concrete columns with scaffolding, and concrete foundations using wooden frames.

These maps can be generated using tools like the Wikidata Query Service [8, 5, 7], which allows users to query and visualize data, including geographical coordinates [7]. By comparing these maps, one can observe patterns, such as the concentration of volcanoes along the Pacific Ring of Fire and the distribution of airports near the equator. The transition from business intelligence to business analytics significantly enhances data handling and insights generation by moving beyond simple reporting to more advanced analytical techniques. Business intelligence focuses on descriptive reporting, answering "what" happened, while business analytics delves into prescriptive analysis, addressing "why" something happened ![Reporting focuses on descriptive analysis, while analysis is more prescriptive](image7). This shift means that while business intelligence transforms "Data → Information," business analytics goes further by combining "Data + Information → Insights" [7].

![The diagram illustrates the progression from Business Intelligence to Business Analytics, showing an increase in both business value and degree of intelligence as one moves up the hierarchy](image8). This progression involves evolving from standard reports that simply state "What happened?" to more sophisticated methods like statistical analysis to understand "Why is this happening?" and predictive modeling to forecast "What will happen next?" [8]. This ultimately allows for optimization to determine "What's the best that can happen?" [8]. By pushing data through an "analytics value chain" from collection and analysis to decisions, actions, and finally impact, organizations ensure that they derive maximum value from their data [12].

The transition from business intelligence to business analytics enhances data handling by generating more insights.

Prokaryotes reproduce through a process called binary fission [3]. This process involves several key steps to ensure the creation of two identical cells from a single parent cell [2]. Initially, the single circular chromosome duplicates, and these copies start to move apart from each other [7].

![The image illustrates bacterial cell division, specifically binary fission.](image8)

As the cell elongates, these chromosomal copies continue to separate [7, 10]. Finally, the plasma membrane grows inward at the midpoint, dividing the cell into two identical daughter cells [7].

![The image appears to be a simplified diagram of a bacterial cell, specifically depicting a prokaryotic cell structure.](image5)

Therefore, binary fission in prokaryotic cells involves duplication of the chromosome and separation of copies, cell elongation, and division of the plasma membrane to form two cells.

The "Needs Exploration" phase is crucial in producing a potentially consumable solution, emphasizing a deep understanding of stakeholder requirements and adapting to their changing needs ![This image illustrates the process of producing a potentially consumable solution](image3). This phase relies on active stakeholder participation to ensure the elicited requirements are truly representative of what is needed [3]. Methods such as high-level requirements specification, split (A/B) testing, detailed requirements specification, and Acceptance Test-Driven Development (ATDD) are employed to gather comprehensive insights. Just-in-time (JIT) model storming and look-ahead modeling further aid in refining these requirements [3, 5]. Addressing changing stakeholder needs is facilitated through various strategies, including work item management, prioritization techniques, change acceptance protocols, and different levels of stakeholder interaction [5]. The approach to requirements "specifications" on advanced teams involves executable Acceptance tests over specification documents [1].

Requirements envisioning and modeling are essential components that help in clearly defining the needs [4]. Furthermore, the elicitation of requirements from distributed stakeholders ensures a broad and inclusive understanding of what the solution should achieve [10]. Agile modeling practices such as iteration modeling, model storming, and the creation of executable specifications contribute to a flexible and efficient development process ![Agile modeling practices are shown in this image](image2). Overall, a combination of proactive engagement, diverse elicitation methods, and adaptive planning ensures that the "Needs Exploration" phase effectively shapes the solution to meet stakeholder expectations [3, 7].

The key components of the 'Needs Exploration' phase include active stakeholder participation, diverse elicitation methods, and adaptive planning to meet stakeholder expectations.

During telophase, the nuclear membrane reforms around the separated sets of chromosomes, which have moved to opposite ends of the cell ![The image depicts a cell undergoing telophase and cytokinesis, which are stages of cell division.](image8). Cytokinesis, which often overlaps with telophase [8], involves the division of the cytoplasm [2]. In animal cells, this is achieved through a cleavage furrow [image2], while in plant cells, a cell plate forms from vesicles containing cell wall material to divide the cell into two [10]. The cell plate grows outward to reach the edges, dividing the contents into two cells [10]. The chromosomes are separated and pulled toward opposite poles of the cell during anaphase [image7]. The final result is two separate but identical daughter cells [image6].

In telophase, the nuclear membrane reforms around the separated chromosomes, and during cytokinesis, the cytoplasm divides, resulting in two distinct daughter cells.

A data-driven culture thrives on several key components that promote informed decision-making and continuous improvement. The diagram highlights core elements such as testing and open sharing of information, which foster transparency and collaboration within the organization. The approach should be iterative and focused on continuous learning, with a mindset geared towards self-service analytics empowering individuals to access and interpret data independently. Strong data leadership is essential to champion the importance of data and guide the cultural shift [8].

Cultivating an inquisitive and questioning attitude encourages critical thinking and a deeper understanding of the data. Prioritizing goals ensures that data analysis is aligned with strategic objectives, driving meaningful outcomes [8]. Broad data literacy across the organization ensures everyone can contribute to and benefit from the data-driven environment [11]. Organizations should also innovate through experimentation and encourage hypothesis generation to embrace surprises and learn from the market ![The diagram illustrates elements of a data-driven culture, including testing, open sharing, iterative learning, self-service analytics, data leadership, inquisitiveness, goal-oriented approach, and broad data literacy.](image8). A collaborative, inclusive, and open environment, coupled with a fact-based testing mindset, are also crucial [2]. However, organizations should avoid the HiPPO effect, where decisions are based solely on the opinion of the highest-paid person, instead relying on data insights [4].

The key components of a data-driven culture are testing, open sharing, iterative learning, self-service analytics, data leadership, inquisitiveness, a goal-oriented approach, and broad data literacy.

The analytics value chain is a process that transforms data into value by moving it through a series of stages [2]. This chain involves pushing data from collection, through analysis and decisions, leading to action, and finally resulting in impact [2]. Simply being partway along the chain is not sufficient to realize the full value [2].
![The flowchart illustrates the transformation of data into value through reporting, analysis, action, and ultimately, value creation.](image4)
This process starts with data, which is then used for reporting, followed by in-depth analysis to gain insights. These insights then drive action, ultimately leading to increased value [image4]. Therefore, the analytics value chain effectively transforms data into value through a structured process of collection, analysis, decision-making, action, and impact.

Mendelian inheritance explains the reappearance of traits in the $\mathsf{F_{2}}$ generation and the observed ratios [11]. As  ![The image illustrates a genetic cross diagram, showcasing the inheritance of traits in plants](image1), in the parental generation, a cross between homozygous dominant (PP) and homozygous recessive (pp) plants results in a heterozygous $\mathsf{F_{1}}$ generation (Pp) that all display the dominant phenotype. The $\mathsf{F_{1}}$ hybrids (Pp) produce gametes with a 1:1 ratio of P and p alleles, and the $\mathsf{F_{2}}$ generation shows a phenotypic ratio of 3 purple to 1 white [11].

The segregation of alleles during gamete formation and their subsequent recombination during fertilization explains why the recessive trait reappears in one quarter of the $\mathsf{F_{2}}$ offspring [4, 11].  The genotypic ratio in the $\mathsf{F_{2}}$ generation is 1 PP: 2 Pp: 1 pp, illustrating how different combinations of alleles result in the observed phenotypic ratios ![The image illustrates Mendelian inheritance.](image4).

Mendelian inheritance explains the 3:1 phenotypic ratio and the underlying 1:2:1 genotypic ratio in the $\mathsf{F_{2}}$ generation through the principles of allele segregation and independent assortment.

In a monohybrid cross, the F₂ generation reveals specific phenotypic and genotypic ratios [3]. As shown in the genetic cross diagram, the parental generation consists of homozygous alleles (PP for purple flowers and pp for white flowers) ![The image illustrates a genetic cross diagram, showcasing the inheritance of traits in plants.](image3).

The crossing of these parents results in the F₁ generation, where all offspring are heterozygous (Pp) and display the dominant purple phenotype [3]. The subsequent F₂ generation, derived from the F₁ hybrids, exhibits a phenotypic ratio of 3 purple to 1 white and a genotypic ratio of 1 PP: 2 Pp: 1 pp ![The image illustrates a genetic cross diagram, showcasing the inheritance of traits in plants.](image3). This means that for every four plants, approximately three will have purple flowers, and one will have white flowers. Genotypically, one will be homozygous dominant (PP), two will be heterozygous (Pp), and one will be homozygous recessive (pp) [3].

The F2 generation of the plant cross shows a phenotypic ratio of 3:1 (purple to white) and a genotypic ratio of 1:2:1 (PP, Pp, pp).

In Australia, permanent "protection visas" are generally reserved for individuals who arrive in the country legally [7]. People who arrive in Australia without a valid visa are typically only eligible to apply for temporary visas [7].

![Permanent Protection Visas are not available for those without valid visas](image7)

Specifically, those who arrive by boat without valid visas may be returned to their country of origin or taken to a regional processing country [7]. Therefore, a person cannot apply for a permanent “protection visa” in Australia if they arrive without a valid visa.

Australia allows humanitarian protection and refugee status requests from abroad when protection is sought through a resettlement program administered by the United Nations, another designated referral agency, or by private sponsorship [4]. However, most countries require an applicant’s physical presence at the border or within the country’s territory [4].

For Australia, permanent "protection visas" are for those arriving in Australia legally, while people without valid visas can only apply for temporary visas. Boat arrivals without valid visas are returned or taken to a regional processing country. Refugee visas are typically for applicants assessed and referred by UNHCR for resettlement. For subclass 202 (Global Special Humanitarian visa), applicants must be proposed by family or organizations in Australia and be outside Australia and their home country. ![The table outlines Australia's asylum and humanitarian protection policies.](image7)

No, an applicant cannot be granted a subclass 202 visa if they are already in Australia.

To determine the minimum separation distance, we need to use the appropriate formula based on the frequency range and the transmitter's output power, as described in the provided tables. The transmitter operates at 500 MHz with a maximum output power of 10 W.  Electromagnetic propagation can be affected by environmental factors [2].

The relevant frequency range from the table is "80 MHz to 800 MHz" ![The table provides information on the separation distance per frequency of a transmitter, given different rated maximum output powers (in watts)](image2). The formula for this range is \(d = \left[\frac{3.5}{E_1}\right] \sqrt{p}\)

Where:
- \( d \) is the separation distance in meters.
- \( P \) is the maximum output power in watts.
- \( E_1 \) is a constant.

Given \( P = 10 \) W, we can find the separation distance \( d \) directly from the table provided in image2 for 10 W in the 80 MHz to 800 MHz range. The table indicates a separation distance of 3.8 m. Field strengths from transmitters cannot be predicted theoretically with accuracy [1].

Therefore, the minimum separation distance required for a 10 W transmitter operating at 500 MHz is 3.8 meters.

3.80

ValueEdge is structured around three primary sections designed to streamline the software development lifecycle [6]. These sections include Insights, Acceleration Modules, and Services, each playing a critical role in managing and optimizing the development process. The Insights section focuses on key phases such as Plan, Build, Test, Deliver, and Run, providing a structured approach to project management [6]. The Acceleration Modules offer specific tools for Strategy, Agile, Quality, Functional Test, Performance, Release, and Ops, enhancing efficiency in these areas [6].

Supporting these modules are Services like Traceability, Data Lake, Integration, Security, and Orchestration, which ensure seamless operation and data management across the platform [6]. ValueEdge integrates with a variety of tools, including OpenText, Jira Software, Jenkins, Selenium, ServiceNow, Slack, Azure DevOps, and Git, facilitating a connected and efficient workflow ![integration and compatibility](image6). These integrations ensure that ValueEdge can adapt to and enhance existing development environments [2]. The platform's modular design allows organizations to start with a single service or leverage multiple modules to augment their toolchain, tailoring the solution to their specific needs [5].

ValueEdge's architecture enables data-driven organizations to measure and manage flow efficiency, providing insights into development velocity, project duration, and quality [6]. By unifying business and technology goals, ValueEdge helps eliminate waste, optimize resource investment, and streamline the entire SDLC, ultimately maximizing ROI [11]. This comprehensive approach ensures that teams can deliver continuous value to customers by enhancing and observing value streams, achieving consistent delivery through industry-standard enterprise Agile frameworks [3].

ValueEdge framework is divided into Insights, Acceleration Modules, and Services, integrating with tools like Jira and Jenkins to optimize the software development lifecycle.

Bergen offers a diverse range of experiences, catering to various interests and age groups. For science and technology enthusiasts, the Bergen Science Centre – Vilvite provides interactive exhibits for both children and adults [1]. At Vilvite, you can explore the human body, learn about nature's cycles, cycle a 360-degree loop, experiment with water, participate in creative workshops, and watch science shows [1, 12].

For those interested in marine life, the Bergen Aquarium is a must-visit. It showcases fascinating creatures from tropical rainforests to the Arctic, including sea lions, penguins, otters, and crocodiles. Daily feeding sessions and films are also available [10, 12].

To appreciate Bergen's landscape, one can ascend Mount Fløyen via the Fløibanen funicular, where a playground, nature trails, and canoeing on Skomakerdiket lake await [6]. Alternatively, the Ulriken 643 cable car offers panoramic views of Bergen, the sea, islands, fjords, and mountains [4, 6].

![The Fløibanen funicular is ready to transport people up Mount Fløyen.](image1)

Vestkanten offers a variety of activities including a water park, spa, bowling, minigolf, skating, curling, shops and restaurants [2].

For a unique insight into Norwegian aquaculture, the Storeblå Aquaculture Visitor Centre offers a modern exhibition and RIB boat trips to a fish farm where visitors can see salmon up close [11].

These attractions offer a wide array of activities from science exploration and marine life encounters to scenic views and cultural experiences.

The monitor uses a combination of blue and amber LED lights to indicate different operational modes [4]. When the blue light is on and the amber light is off, it signifies that the monitor is powered on and displaying an image ![Monitor is in power on mode.](image5). If both the blue and amber lights are on, the monitor is actively searching for a signal ![Monitor is actively searching for a signal.](image5).

Conversely, a blue light off and an amber light on indicates that no signal has been found or the monitor is in standby mode ![Monitor is in standby mode.](image5). When both the blue and amber lights are off, it can mean the monitor is in soft power off mode because the soft power button was pressed, or it is in hard power off mode with no image displayed ![Monitor is in hard power off mode.](image5).

Different LED light combinations indicate the monitor's power status and signal detection.

The map-making workshop aims to teach participants how to create various types of maps using Wikidata, with a structured approach across three modules [3, 11, 12]. The learning objectives are divided into basic, intermediate, and advanced levels ![The image is a promotional graphic for a map-making workshop.](image5).

Module 1 focuses on understanding the steps to make basic flat and layered maps in Wikidata using geo-referenced items and SPARQL queries ![The image is a presentation slide or instructional graphic related to creating maps using Wikidata.](image7). This involves creating various basic flat and clustered maps using SPARQL queries [3]. Participants learn to create layered maps where groups of items can be toggled on and off ![Learning objectives are displayed for each module, from basic flat and layered maps to advanced off-Wiki maps.](image3). The map shows the concentration of location markers in the Netherlands and Belgium, possibly representing data used in these exercises ![The image shows a map with numerous orange location markers concentrated in the Netherlands and parts of Belgium.](image2).

Module 2 advances to embedding Wikidata-driven maps in other Wikimedia projects, such as Wikipedia and Commons [3, 8]. Participants learn to use OpenStreetMap, GeoJSON, and the Mediawiki Kartographer extension in addition to SPARQL ![Learning objectives are displayed for each module, from basic flat and layered maps to advanced off-Wiki maps.](image3).

Module 3 covers creating interactive, layered Wikidata-driven maps for use off-Wiki, such as in regular HTML pages [3, 4]. This module uses Python and Jupyter notebooks ![Learning objectives are displayed for each module, from basic flat and layered maps to advanced off-Wiki maps.](image3). A Jupyter notebook guides users step by step in creating a Wikidata-driven layered map that can be used off-Wiki [4, 7].

The learning objectives for creating and embedding maps using Wikidata are structured across three modules covering basic map creation, embedding maps in Wikimedia projects, and creating interactive off-Wiki maps.

Structured markup errors can significantly impact SEO performance by hindering search engines' ability to understand the content on a webpage, as shown by the high number of errors in the "Structured Markup" table across different data types, especially "Blog" and "Article" which use schema.org markup ![The table shows a high number of errors in structured markup, particularly in Blog and Article data types](image7). Additionally, issues with meta descriptions, such as duplicates, being too long or short, or even missing, also negatively affect SEO as search engines rely on this data for indexing and ranking, with a substantial number of duplicate, long, and short meta descriptions, as well as missing title tags ![The image shows a high number of duplicate, short and long meta descriptions, and also missing title tags](image3). The graph also displays the time spent downloading a page in milliseconds, which may indicate that the issues with meta descriptions may slow down download times.

Therefore, fixing structured markup errors and meta description issues is crucial for improving SEO performance.

The primordial gut diagram illustrates various anatomical structures and regions in the developing embryo [8]. It includes the pharynx and the esophageal region, key components of the early digestive tract ![The image is an anatomical illustration of the upper digestive and respiratory systems.](image7).

The diagram also depicts the gastric and duodenal regions, precursors to parts of the stomach and small intestine, along with the midgut and hindgut, which are sections of the embryonic digestive system [8]. The primordial gut diagram depicts the pharynx, esophageal region, gastric and duodenal regions, midgut, hindgut, heart, aorta, celiac artery, superior and inferior mesenteric arteries, yolk stalk, vitelline artery, allantois, and cloaca [8].

One significant barrier to adopting an integrated customer management approach is a siloed organizational structure, where different departments or business units operate in isolation [4]. This is reflected in the challenge: "There is no single ownership of the experience resulting in siloed approaches and misaligned goals," which affects 52% of respondents ![This image highlights that 52% of respondents feel there is no single ownership of the customer experience, leading to siloed approaches.](image6). The bar chart also indicates that 46% of respondents identify being "too siloed by business line/product/brand" as a barrier, further emphasizing the prevalence of this issue within organizations ![The bar chart shows the challenges preventing the business context.](image6).

Another key barrier lies in the realm of resources. Specifically, 36% of respondents cite a lack of resources to support an integrated customer management approach as a significant impediment ![This image demonstrates the bar chart illustrating the factors.](image6). Additionally, the absence of adequate technical infrastructure is a challenge for 28% of respondents, highlighting the importance of having the necessary technological capabilities in place [image6].

Furthermore, the inability to measure the influence of activities on customer behavior is a barrier for 27% of respondents. This reflects a broader issue of not measuring what matters most, such as customer engagement, conversion, and satisfaction [11]. Companies often focus too much on reach and not enough on engagement, leading to a lack of insightful data [2].

The major barriers preventing the adoption of an integrated customer management approach include siloed organizational structures, a lack of resources and technical infrastructure, and the inability to measure the influence of activities on customer behavior.

For a built-in installation of an integrated dishwasher model, the dishwasher should be near existing inlet and drain hoses and power cord [8, 9]. Ensure the appliance is positioned in the desired location, resting against the wall and adjacent cabinets [7]. The space between the cabinet bottom and the floor is adjustable for either a 60 cm or 45 cm wide model (600 mm or 450 mm), as illustrated in ![Diagram showing installation space for a dishwasher with specific measurements](image3). Also, less than $5\;\mathsf{m m}$ should be left between the top of the dishwasher and cabinet, with the outer door aligned to the cabinet [1]. If the dishwasher is installed at the corner of the cabinet, ensure there is adequate space when the door is opened [4]. A minimum space of 50mm should be left next to the dishwasher to ensure proper door operation, as shown in ![Illustration showing the space required next to a dishwasher for door operation](image8).

The installation should also ensure the dishwasher is level, as indicated in ![Illustration showing how to level an appliance using a screwdriver](image1), and secured in place using the appropriate method for the work surface [11]. The surrounding furnishings must be resistant to condensation if the dishwasher door opens automatically at the end of the program [12].

For a built-in installation, the space between the cabinet bottom and the floor is adjustable for either 600 mm or 450 mm, depending on the model width.

Gestalt psychology emphasizes our ability to perceive meaningful perceptions [6]. These perceptions are often prioritized over spatial relations, focusing on conciseness [4]. This approach has led to the development of Gestalt Laws of Grouping [8].

The principles of Gestalt psychology are visually represented in the design of the word "GESTALT," where each letter or pair of letters illustrates a specific principle, such as closure, proximity, and similarity ![The image illustrates various Gestalt principles with the word GESTALT.](image2). For instance, Closure is demonstrated by the letters "G" and "E," where we perceive a closed shape even though part of it is missing [11]. Proximity is shown by the letter "E" made of small rectangles grouped together [1, 10].

The principles of Gestalt psychology are visually represented in the design of the word 'GESTALT' through concepts like closure, proximity, and similarity.

Many marketers incorrectly calculate attribution for transactions [11]. A common problem in marketing is that performance attribution of marketing campaigns is excessively attributed to the First Click or Last Click [4, 10, 12]. Often, the "Last Click" is either Paid Search (PPC) or Organic Search (SEO) [10].

![The image is a bar chart showing how marketing attribution is calculated.](image2)

According to the bar chart, the most common method is attributing activity to the most recent touchpoint [image2]. 52% of marketers attribute activity to the most recent touchpoint [image2]. This highlights a reliance on single-touch attribution models, which may not accurately reflect the complete customer journey [1, 5]. To gain a more accurate understanding of channel contributions, marketers should utilize a tracking mechanism that measures all ad types and looks beyond the last ad when attributing value [1].

The most common method marketers use to calculate attribution is attributing the activity to the most recent touchpoint.

The Gestalt principles explain how visual elements are grouped to form a whole [5, 3, 9]. One of these principles, continuity, suggests that elements aligned within an object are integrated into perceptual wholes, even when there are intersections [4, 2]. Similarly, objects that are visually close are seen as part of a group, and this is called proximity [7]. Another principle, similarity, is applied when objects of similar shape and color are grouped together [11]. These principles suggest that our perception eliminates complexity to observe reality in its most simplistic form [10].

![The word “GESTALT” employs principles such as proximity, similarity, and closure to illustrate Gestalt psychology.](image8)

Between 2005 and 2006, healthcare IT priorities shifted towards reducing medical errors and improving patient satisfaction, while financial support remained a significant and growing challenge for IT implementation.

OBS has system-defined policies and roles that support common operations, and these are detailed in tables [5]. The granularity of permissions can be managed using either Roles or Policies [9]. Roles offer coarse-grained authorization, whereas Policies offer fine-grained control [9]. Access to OBS buckets and objects can be controlled using different methods [10]. Several roles and policies dictate the operations a user can perform within OBS, such as Tenant Administrator, Tenant Guest, OBS Administrator, OBS Buckets Viewer, OBS ReadOnly Access, and OBS Operate Access. Each role has specific permissions for operations like managing buckets, objects, and their configurations, as indicated in the tables.

Operations such as listing buckets are permitted for most roles, while creating or deleting buckets is restricted to Tenant Administrators and OBS Administrators ![The table details the permissions for different roles in relation to OBS operations.](image7). Operations like managing logging, tags, and lifecycle rules are generally limited to Tenant Administrators and OBS Administrators ![The table displays various operations and identifies which roles have permissions to perform them.](image2). The ability to delete folders, download files, and manage object versions varies depending on the assigned role, as some roles have broader permissions than others ![The table displays permissions for various operations related to object storage.](image3). Certain roles have permissions to configure object ACLs and metadata, while others are limited to read-only access ![The table outlines different operational permissions for various roles.](image5).

The learning objectives of the map-making workshop are structured into three modules, each building upon the previous one to enhance map creation skills [6, 1]. Module 1 focuses on the basics, teaching participants how to create flat and layered maps within Wikidata using geo-referenced items and SPARQL queries ![Learning objectives of module 1](image3). Module 2 advances to embedding Wikidata-driven maps into Wikimedia projects like Wikipedia and Commons, incorporating tools such as OpenStreetMap and GeoJSON [6]. Finally, Module 3 delves into creating interactive, layered maps that can be used off-Wiki, employing Python and Jupyter notebooks alongside the previously learned tools [6, 3, 11].

The ultimate goal is to enable participants to develop interactive, layered, off-Wiki maps driven by Wikidata, as highlighted in the workshop description ![Workshop aims to teach how to make off-wiki maps](image8). This involves a progression from basic map creation to more advanced techniques that allow for broader application and customization of maps [7]. The workshop aims to provide examples and code snippets that participants can adapt with basic SPARQL, Wikidata, and Python skills [5].

The learning objectives cover creating basic maps, embedding them in Wikimedia projects, and developing interactive maps for external use [7].

To properly operate the dishwasher, it's important to follow a sequence of steps that ensures efficient and safe use. Before starting, it's advisable to remove larger food residues from the dishware ![The image is an illustration showing a plate with food residue, including a fishbone and a bone, indicating the act of removing larger food residues from cutlery or dishware](image1).

First, load the dishwasher by pulling out the lower and upper baskets, placing the dishes inside, and pushing the baskets back in [10]. It’s recommended to load the lower basket first, followed by the upper one [10]. Proper arrangement of items, considering height and placement, is essential for effective cleaning ![The image appears to be an illustration showing how to load items in a basket or rack, such as a dishwasher](image5). Next, add detergent to the dispenser ![The image is a simple illustration showing someone filling a dispenser](image7) and ensure the water supply is fully turned on [10].

Then, insert the plug into the socket, making sure the power supply matches the specifications outlined in the product information [10]. Close the dishwasher door and press the Power button to switch on the machine; the screen should light up ![The table lists functions and descriptions for dishwasher buttons](image3). Select the desired program using the Program button ![The table lists functions and descriptions for dishwasher buttons](image3); the corresponding light will turn on [10]. Finally, press the Start/Pause button to begin the wash cycle ![The table lists functions and descriptions for dishwasher buttons](image3), and the dishwasher will start its cycle ![The image is an illustration of a dishwasher with motion lines](image8).

To operate the dishwasher, load the dishes, add detergent, turn on the power, select a program, and press start.

The workshop aims to teach participants how to create maps using Wikidata, even for those with beginning programming skills [1]. The learning objectives are structured into three modules, progressing from basic to advanced techniques [11].

Module 1 focuses on creating basic flat and layered maps within Wikidata using geo-referenced items and SPARQL queries ![This image shows a map module focusing on creating basic flat and layered maps in Wikidata.](image8). Module 2 covers embedding Wikidata-driven maps into other Wikimedia projects such as Wikipedia and Commons [11]. Module 3 advances to creating interactive, layered off-Wiki maps that can be used in regular HTML pages [11]. This module uses basic Python and Jupyter notebooks ![This image shows a graphic illustrating map making learning objectives, resources, and examples.](image4).

Resources include SPARQL examples and Python code snippets to build upon [4, 6, 7, 8]. The workshop provides examples and adaptable code snippets for different skill levels [1]. Participants can learn to create various map types, including flat, clustered, layered, embedded, and interactive maps [2, 10]. The process involves using tools like OpenStreetMap, GeoJSON, and the Mediawiki Kartographer extension, alongside SPARQL and Python [11].

The learning objectives include understanding the steps to make basic flat and layered maps, embedding maps in Wikimedia sites, and creating Wikidata-based off-Wiki maps, supported by resources like SPARQL queries, Python code, and tools for creating and customizing maps.

In summary, new international students should secure housing, complete registration with SAO-Student Support, arrange for banking services, and set up mobile communication to settle in at NTU.

Gestalt psychology explains how we perceive forms as wholes, independent of their parts [3, 6]. The principles, including proximity and similarity, guide our perception to group elements together based on closeness and resemblance, helping us see objects as part of a group [4, 11].

![The letter GESTALT uses various principles of Gestalt psychology to demonstrate visual perception.](image7)

Our minds tend to simplify complex information to create meaning, and the Gestalt theory emphasizes conciseness and global regularity in perception [10, 12]. We also tend to complete objects that are not whole, filling in the visual gaps through closure [8]. For example, elements are grouped together if they form a regular, simple, and orderly pattern [7]. As demonstrated, these principles dictate how our minds organize and interpret visual information, creating a cohesive and meaningful understanding of the world [1, 7].

The 8751H exhibits unique electrical characteristics, notably in its power supply current (\(I_{CC}\)) and certain timing parameters. Specifically, the maximum power supply current (\(I_{CC}\)) for the 8751H and 8751H-8 is 250 mA, differing from other models like the 8031AH/8051AH/8051AHP (125 mA) and the 8032AH/8052AH/8751BH/8752BH (175 mA) [8].

Regarding timing, there are different timing parameters for the 8751H compared to other devices, such as the oscillator frequency, ALE pulse width, and other parameters related to memory and instruction cycles, as detailed in the table ![Timing parameters for 8751H and other devices, including oscillator frequency and pulse widths.](image2). Further timing considerations are shown in the timing diagram, which illustrates the relationships between various signals, such as ALE and PSEN, which would be vital to understanding how the microcontroller interfaces with external memory ![Signals like ALE and PSEN are coordinated in a digital system.](image4).

Several AC characteristics, including load capacitance, are specified under operating conditions [4]. Additionally, capacitive loading on Ports 0 and 2 may introduce noise pulses, potentially necessitating the use of a Schmitt Trigger to qualify ALE in certain situations [1].

The 8751H microcontroller demonstrates a higher power supply current and distinct timing parameters compared to other listed devices.

Certain postures can lead to inaccurate blood pressure readings [10]. To ensure accurate measurements, it's important to avoid specific positions and movements. Refrain from measuring while standing or lying down, or when your body is under pressure, such as sitting cross-legged or on a low sofa [7, 10]. Measuring in a moving vehicle should also be avoided [7].

Therefore, incorrect postures include measuring while moving, not being still, or not using the standard measuring posture with the watch at heart level.

The Wikidata map-making workshop aims to teach participants how to create various types of maps using Wikidata [4, 12]. The workshop is structured into three modules, each with specific learning objectives. Module 1 focuses on the fundamentals, teaching participants how to make basic flat and layered maps using geo-referenced items and SPARQL queries within Wikidata ![Module 1 focuses on basic flat and layered maps.](image1).

Module 2 builds upon the basics, focusing on embedding Wikidata-driven maps into Wikimedia projects such as Wikipedia and Wikimedia Commons [7]. This module expands beyond SPARQL to include OpenStreetMap, GeoJSON, and the Mediawiki Kartographer extension [7]. Participants learn how to integrate maps directly into Wikimedia platforms [8].

Module 3 advances to creating interactive, layered Wikidata-driven maps for use off-Wiki, in regular HTML pages [7]. This involves using tools and techniques from the previous modules, along with basic Python and Jupyter notebooks [7, 9].

![The workshop covers creating maps using Wikidata, embedding them in Wikimedia projects, and creating interactive off-Wiki maps.](image2)

The key difference between the modules lies in the increasing complexity and application of the maps. Module 1 is about foundational map creation within Wikidata; Module 2 is about integrating these maps into Wikimedia projects; and Module 3 is about creating advanced, interactive maps for external use [7].

The key learning objectives for each module progress from basic map creation to embedding maps in Wikimedia projects and finally to creating interactive off-Wiki maps.

As more hot dogs are consumed, the utility derived from each additional hot dog decreases, eventually becoming negative, which reflects diminishing marginal utility [6]. This is illustrated by a table showing that the first hot dog yields a utility of +10, while the utility decreases to -10 by the sixth hot dog ![The table shows diminishing utility as more hot dogs are consumed.](image4).

This concept is further demonstrated in another table where utility decreases with each hot dog consumed until it dramatically increases at the 64th hot dog, symbolizing tying a competitor for a championship ![The table shows diminishing marginal utility and a jump in utility at 64 hot dogs consumed, symbolizing a championship tie.](image2). This pattern of diminishing returns implies that enjoyment drops, and switching to another choice becomes preferable [6]. The overall trend of diminishing utility with increased consumption suggests that consumers will eventually seek variety to maintain satisfaction [6].

Utility decreases with each additional hot dog consumed, reflecting diminishing marginal utility and influencing consumers to seek variety.

When loading a dishwasher, it's important to consider the arrangement of both cutlery and dishes to ensure optimal cleaning performance [5]. Curved items or those with recesses should be loaded aslant so that water can run off, and all utensils should be stacked securely to prevent them from tipping over [4]. Utensils should be placed so that the spray arms can rotate freely during washing [4].

Hollow items like cups, glasses, and pans should be placed with the opening facing downwards to prevent water from collecting [4]. Dishes and cutlery should not lie inside one another or cover each other [4]. To avoid damage, glasses should not touch one another [4]. The upper basket is designed for more delicate and lighter dishware such as glasses, coffee, and tea cups [4]. Long bladed knives stored in an upright position are a potential hazard, and long or sharp cutlery should be positioned horizontally in the upper basket [4]. Do not overload your dishwasher, as this affects cleaning results and energy consumption [4]. We suggest that you place large items and the most difficult to clean items are to be placed into the lower basket [9].

```markdown
![Cutlery should be arranged in an organized manner in the dishwasher rack.](image3)
```

Large items and difficult-to-clean items should be placed in the lower basket, such as pots, pans, lids, serving dishes, and bowls [9]. Serving dishes and lids should be placed on the side of the racks to avoid blocking the rotation of the top spray arm [9]. The bandwidth of different human senses varies significantly, impacting how much data each can process [11]. Taste has the lowest bandwidth, followed by hearing and smell, which are comparable to the data transfer rate of a hard disk ![Hearing and Smell are likened to hard disk speeds in terms of bandwidth](image1). Touch has a higher bandwidth, similar to a USB key ![Touch has a bandwidth similar to a USB Key](image1). Sight has the highest bandwidth, analogous to a fast network connection ![Sight is compared to network speeds in terms of bandwidth](image1).

Therefore, the senses in ascending order of bandwidth are: Taste, Hearing and Smell, Touch, and Sight.

Meiosis involves two distinct divisions, meiosis I and meiosis II, each with specific characteristics. During meiosis I, homologous chromosomes separate, reducing the chromosome number by half [11]. This process is visually represented with stages like prophase I, metaphase I, and anaphase I ![Illustration of stages of meiosis I](image5). In contrast, meiosis II involves the separation of sister chromatids, and the chromosome number remains the same [11]. Anaphase II shows chromatids separating and moving to opposite poles, eventually leading to the formation of new nuclei during telophase II ![Diagram and microscope images of meiosis II phases](image6).  The separation of sister chromatids is a key event, ultimately forming haploid daughter cells ![Illustration of meiosis stages](image2]. Meiosis I reduces the chromosome number, while meiosis II separates sister chromatids, maintaining the chromosome number in each of the daughter cells [11].

Meiosis I involves the separation of homologous chromosomes to reduce the chromosome number by half, while meiosis II involves the separation of sister chromatids, maintaining the chromosome number.

Alibaba Cloud's architecture includes several key components working in tandem to ensure high availability and efficient traffic management. The AliCloud DNS integrates with Server Load Balancers to distribute incoming traffic [7]. These load balancers then manage traffic across multiple ECS (Elastic Compute Service) instances, which provide the actual computing resources for applications [7]. This setup allows for optimal performance and redundancy, ensuring that applications remain accessible even during traffic spikes.

The Server Load Balancer is critical for managing traffic and maintaining application availability [7, 10]. It monitors the health of servers and distributes application requests to those with optimal performance [10]. This is especially important during peak times, such as Alibaba's Global Shopping Festival, where traffic volumes are extremely high [7]. Services like Anti-DDoS Basic integrate with ECS to protect data and applications from security threats [9]. The high-speed infrastructure ensures that web-based products and services are constantly available to customers [3].

![The diagram shows AliCloud DNS connected to Server Load Balancers, which distribute traffic to ECS instances.](image7)

In the architecture described, the AliCloud DNS goes through two ECS components via a Server Load Balancer [7].

To program the lock bits (LBx) in the 875XBH, specific pin configurations are required, as outlined in Table 3 [9]. The general setup mirrors the standard EPROM programming procedure, but P2.6 must be held at a logic high [12]. Other pins like Port 0, Port 1, and P2.0-P2.3 can be in any state [12].

The programming setup for the 875XBH requires that it runs with a 4 to 6 MHz oscillator because the internal bus transfers address and program data to internal registers [1, 9].  ![The image shows a microcontroller configuration with a 4-6 MHz oscillator.](image1) The  $\overline{{\mathsf{E A}}}/\mathsf{v}_{\mathsf{P\mathsf{P}}}$ pin also receives the programming supply voltage during EPROM programming [10].

When using the quick pulse programming algorithm, Vpp should be $12.75 \pm 0.25$ volts [11]. The ALE/PROG pin is pulsed low for 100 microseconds, repeated 25 times, as illustrated in Figure 9 [11]. ![The image shows ALE/PROG waveforms with 25 pulses for programming.](image3)

Table 5 describes the function of the lock bits, and if the lock bits are not programmed, the on-chip Program Memory can be read out for verification [2, 8]. ![The table details lock bit configurations and their enabled logic functions.](image4)

The pin configurations for programming Lock Bits (LBx) are detailed in Table 3, with specific levels for RST,  $\overline{{\mathsf{P S E N}}}$ , ALE/PROG,  $\overline{{\mathsf{E A}}}/\mathsf{v}_{\mathsf{P P}}$ , P2.7, P2.6, P3.6, and P3.7 [9]. ![The image details the pin configurations for various modes, including programming lock bits.](image5)

In summary, programming the lock bits in the 875XBH requires setting P2.6 to high, applying the correct voltage and pulses to  $\overline{{\mathsf{E A}}}/\mathsf{v}_{\mathsf{P P}}$  and ALE/PROG respectively, and configuring other pins according to "Security" levels specified in Table 3 [12, 9].
