The Wikidata Map Making Workshop is structured into three modules, each with specific learning objectives [4, 10]. Module 1 focuses on creating basic flat and layered maps using geo-referenced items and SPARQL queries in Wikidata [4, 6]. Module 2 advances to embedding Wikidata-driven maps into Wikimedia projects like Wikipedia and Commons, utilizing OpenStreetMap, GeoJSON, and the Mediawiki Kartographer extension [2, 4]. Module 3 culminates in creating interactive, layered Wikidata-driven maps for use off-Wiki in regular HTML pages, incorporating Python and Jupyter notebooks [4, 7].

The modules are visually represented in several images. The composite image shows a map with colored markers and highlights "MODULE 1 Basic flat & layered maps," indicating the foundational aspect of the first module ![The image highlights Module 1, focusing on basic flat and layered maps](image1). The slide outlines the "Learning objectives" across the three modules, showing the progression from basic to intermediate to advanced map-making skills ![This infographic lists the learning objectives for each of the three modules in the workshop](image5). Module 1 is also visually represented with a map of Belgium, the Netherlands, and Germany, illustrating the creation of basic maps using geographic data and SPARQL queries ![Module 1 teaches how to make basic maps using geographic data and SPARQL queries](image6). Another image showing the "Learning objectives" for each module visually summarizes the workshop's structure, highlighting map examples and resources for creating and embedding maps ![This image is a collage of screenshots outlining the learning objectives for the Wikidata map-making workshop modules](image8). The workshop covers making flat, clustered, layered, embedded, interactive, on-Wiki, and off-Wiki maps from sets of geo-referenced items in Wikidata [11].

The learning objectives for each module in the Wikidata Map Making Workshop progress from basic map creation to embedding maps in Wikimedia projects and creating interactive off-Wiki maps, as visually represented through maps and instructional graphics.

The diagram illustrates how dynamic data from devices like mobile phones, PCs, and tablets interacts with the enterprise cloud disk service system built on Huawei Cloud, while static data is stored in OBS [8]. End users can directly request and read the static data from OBS, and the system also uses lifecycle management to automatically change storage classes for objects, reducing storage costs [8]. The enterprise cloud box service system includes components like ELB, ECS, RDS, and VBS, providing a reliable and inexpensive storage system with low latency and high concurrency that automatically scales storage capacity [9].

![The diagram illustrates the interaction of devices with the enterprise cloud system, distinguishing between dynamic and static data and showcasing components like ELB, ECS, RDS, and OBS.](image8)

The dynamic data on end user browsers and apps directly interacts with the service systems deployed on Huawei Cloud [5]. Requests for dynamic data are processed and returned, while static data is stored in OBS, allowing business systems to process it over the intranet and end users to directly access it from nearby high-speed nodes [5]. OBS also provides storage for cloud albums of Huawei mobile phones, supporting access for hundreds of millions of users and ensuring high data durability and service continuity through various technologies [10].

Based on the information presented in the enterprise cloud box flow chart, the end-use mobile electronic devices include mobile phones, PCs, and tablets.

The lead funnel progression illustrates the transformation of leads as they move through different stages, from initial contact to becoming sales-won opportunities [7]. This process begins with total leads, which are then converted into Marketing Qualified Leads (MQLs), Sales Accepted Leads (SALs), Sales Qualified Leads (SQLs), and finally, Sales Won Opportunities (SWOs) [10].

![The image shows a series of data metrics related to sales and marketing performance.](image2)

The conversion rates between these stages highlight the efficiency of the marketing and sales processes. For example, the conversion rate from lead to MQL is 52.07%, while the conversion rate from SQL to SWO is 6.67% [image2]. These rates are crucial for understanding where the funnel is most effective and where improvements are needed [9]. By contrast, the conversion rates at various stages of a sales funnel show the average conversion rates across industries; inquiries convert to names at 2-5%, contacts to leads at 4-8%, SALs convert at 45-75%, SQLs convert at 45-60%, and closed leads convert at 20-30% [7]. These metrics provide a benchmark for assessing performance [2].

![The image displays cross-industry average conversion rates at various stages of a sales funnel.](image7)

Analyzing lead sources shows different conversion ratios, average transition times, and lead volumes [image4]. For instance, leads from the website convert at 47.77% with an average transition time of 14 days, whereas leads from sponsorships convert at only 5.44% but take 70 days to convert [image4]. Understanding these variations helps in optimizing marketing efforts by focusing on the most effective channels [5]. The effectiveness of marketing efforts should ultimately be tied to outcomes such as driving webpage visits, video views, online sales, or event registrations [6]. Analyzing the cost and membership trends alongside program-specific data provides additional insights into marketing performance, enabling better decision-making and resource allocation [image3, 3].

In conclusion, conversion rates in lead funnel progression, when compared to marketing diagnostic average conversion rates, helps diagnose marketing opportunities created across the organization [11].

Gestalt psychology emphasizes our ability to perceive and maintain meaningful perceptions [1]. One key principle is the "law of good Gestalt," which focuses on conciseness and the idea that we tend to eliminate complexity to observe reality in its simplest form [7, 10]. This concept is fundamental to Gestalt theory [7].

To understand visual perception, Gestalt principles provide a framework for how we group elements together. For instance, elements are perceptually grouped together if they form a regular, simple, and orderly pattern [6].  Continuity is also important, as elements of objects tend to be grouped together if they are aligned within an object [8].

While the principles of Gestalt psychology provide a framework for visual perception, they do not directly address trends in U.S. healthcare spending or the Space Race. However, visual representations of such data, like the timeline of the Space Race and the bar chart showing healthcare spending, can be interpreted through the lens of Gestalt principles, where viewers seek simplicity and patterns to understand the information presented [6].

The original question asks about the U.S. healthcare spending as a percentage of GDP from 1960 to 2007, and how this trend relates to the Space Race timeline. The bar chart shows a numerical value to its right, ranging from 5.2 to 16, ordered from most recent (2007) at the top to oldest (1960) at the bottom. The numerical values increase over time, indicating growth or an upward trend. Without additional context, it's unclear what the specific data represents.
![The data from 1960 to 2007 is displayed on a horizontal bar chart.](image7)
The "Space Race" graphic tracks the progress and competition between the two superpowers [8]. Events such as the Cuban Missile Crisis, the assassination of JFK, the moon landing, and the end of the war in Vietnam are marked in the timeline [8].
![The image shows a graphic representation of the "Space Race" between the United States and the Soviet Union, covering the period from 1957 to 1975.](image8)

The U.S. healthcare spending as a percentage of GDP increased from 1960 to 2007, as shown in the bar chart, but the correlation between this trend and events in the Space Race timeline is not visually evident in these images.

The analytics value chain emphasizes the importance of deriving impact from data, where simply collecting and analyzing data is insufficient; the insights must drive decisions and actions to create value [4]. Reporting and analysis are crucial steps in this chain, each with distinct roles. Reporting is descriptive and backward-looking, focused on answering "What?" by transforming data into information through reports, dashboards, and alerts without necessarily providing context ![Reporting delivers descriptive information](image4). Analysis, conversely, is prescriptive and forward-looking, answering "Why?" by adding context and storytelling to transform data and information into insights that drive findings and recommendations ![The progression from standard reports to optimization showcases increased intelligence](image7).

The progression from business intelligence to business analytics involves increasing levels of intelligence and business value, where standard reports evolve into optimization strategies [11]. The transition involves moving from asking "What happened?" to determining "What's the best that can happen?" implying that business analytics builds upon the foundation laid by business intelligence to enable more informed and strategic decision-making ![The data-driven process transforms data into value](image1).

Reporting raises questions, while analysis answers them, contributing to a more comprehensive understanding and informed decision-making process [4].

In summary, reporting and analysis are both essential components of the analytics value chain, with reporting providing the foundational information and analysis delivering the insights needed to drive impactful actions and achieve business value.

Timber, often in the form of plywood and planks [2], is a common material for formwork, easily cut to shape on-site [1]. A typical plywood thickness used is 18mm [4], although thicker plywood might be necessary if the concrete weight causes bowing [5].

However, for sheeting used in slabs, beam, column sides, and beam bottoms, a thickness of 25mm to 40mm is recommended, as shown in ![Dimensions for sheeting range from 25mm to 40mm](image3). This suggests that 25mm sheeting is an appropriate size for certain timber formwork applications.

Wooden formwork is a traditional method, involving various sizes of timber members [8, 9, 11], as seen in ![Wooden formwork is used for casting concrete columns](image4). Minimum sawing and cutting are recommended to allow for material reuse [12]. The construction diagram also illustrates timber spacers and boarding as components of formwork [image5].

Therefore, 25mm sheeting is an appropriate size for timber formwork, particularly for slabs, beam sides, and beam bottoms.

The Engine Control Unit (ECU) is a crucial component in modern automotive engine management systems [2, 11]. The ECU, also known as power-train control module(PCM) or engine control module(ECM) [11], determines the amount of fuel and the ignition timing that an internal combustion engine needs to keep running [11].

The ECU's central role is evident in the system diagram, where it connects to various sensors and injectors. ![The image is a diagram depicting the flow of information and control in an engine management system](image1). These sensors, such as the Engine Temperature Sensor, Intake Air Temperature Sensor, Mass Air Flow Sensor, Throttle Position Sensor, HEGO Sensor, Crankshaft Sensor, and Camshaft Sensor, provide input to the ECU, which it uses to monitor engine operating conditions [9]. The ECU then controls the opening of the injectors to manage fuel injection [3]. As shown in the fuel injection system block diagram, the "DETECTING SYSTEM" sends signals to the "CONTROL SYSTEM", which then manages the "FUEL METERING SYSTEM" [image2].

The ECU determines the quantity of fuel to inject based on parameters such as throttle pedal position and engine temperature [4]. The ECU also adjusts the ignition timing to optimize power and economy [5]. Furthermore, the ECU manages idle speed by monitoring engine RPM via the crankshaft position sensor and controlling a programmable throttle stop or idle air bypass control step per motor [6].

In summary, the Engine Control Unit (ECU) monitors engine conditions, controls fuel injection, manages ignition timing, and regulates idle speed to ensure optimal engine performance.

Binary fission in prokaryotic cells involves a series of well-defined steps that result in cell division [3, 4, 8]. Initially, the single circular chromosome duplicates, and the copies start to separate from each other [11]. The bacterial DNA within the cell replicates, ensuring each daughter cell receives a complete copy of the genetic material ![Bacterial DNA replicates inside the cell](image8).

Next, the cell elongates, and the chromosomal copies separate further [2, 11]. This ensures that the genetic material is properly distributed as the cell prepares to divide ![A bacterial cell contains genetic material inside a bacterium](image1).

Finally, the plasma membrane grows inward at the midpoint to divide the cells, resulting in two identical daughter cells [3, 11]. These steps ensure the creation of two separate, identical cells from one original cell ![A prokaryotic cell contains genetic material](image4).

The three steps of binary fission are chromosome duplication and separation, cell elongation with further separation of copies, and division of the cell by inward growth of the plasma membrane.

In standard consumption economics, focusing is often considered bad [6]. Diminishing marginal utility suggests that the enjoyment from consuming additional units of a good decreases [2]. For example, the utility derived from each additional hot dog decreases as more are consumed, eventually leading to negative utility ![The table shows diminishing utility from consuming hot dogs, where each additional hot dog provides less satisfaction, eventually becoming negative](image8).

However, in competitive contexts, such as competitive eating, the cumulative effect of focus may be beneficial [9]. While standard consumption economics suggests enjoyment drops and a switch to another choice should be made [2], competitive scenarios can alter preferences due to differential outcomes.  ![The image shows diminishing marginal utility and differential outcome related to hot dog consumption; utility jumps dramatically at 64 hot dogs in the differential outcome scenario](image1). In this context, focus and continued practice, even with diminishing marginal utility, can lead to competitive mastery [12] and improved activity outcomes due to cumulative experience [11].

Therefore, while standard consumption economics views diminishing marginal utility as a reason to switch choices, competitive contexts may require focused practice despite this diminishing utility to achieve mastery and improve outcomes.

The cell cycle includes interphase, where the cell grows and duplicates its contents [11]. Early in the division process, chromosomes duplicate into two sister chromatids joined at the centromere [4]. Mitosis involves the division of the nucleus, and cytokinesis involves the division of the cytoplasm [5].

Image 3 depicts interphase, prophase, and prometaphase, illustrating how the cell prepares to divide its genetic material ![Illustration of interphase, prophase, and prometaphase](image3). During prometaphase, the nuclear envelope fragments, and kinetochore microtubules connect to the chromosomes [3, 4]. ![A cell in prometaphase with microtubules attached to kinetochores](image4).

Image 6 shows a cell in anaphase, where chromosomes separate and are pulled to opposite poles ![A cell in anaphase with chromosomes being separated](image6). Image 7 shows telophase and cytokinesis, where the nuclear membrane re-forms and the cytoplasm divides ![A cell in telophase and cytokinesis, showing the division into two daughter cells](image7).

Therefore, slides 12 and 14 show prometaphase, anaphase, telophase and cytokinesis.

Needs Exploration and Elicitation Methods are vital for addressing stakeholder needs by employing strategies that ensure requirements are understood and managed effectively. In Disciplined Agile, understanding stakeholder needs is a continuous process that adapts to changing conditions ![This image presents the process goals of Disciplined Agile Delivery, highlighting key areas such as inception, construction, transition, and ongoing activities](image7).

Needs Exploration involves various techniques such as active stakeholder participation, high-level requirements specification, and split (A/B) testing [6]. These methods, along with acceptance test-driven development (ATDD), Just-in-time (JIT) model storming, and look-ahead modeling, ensure a comprehensive understanding of what is required to produce a potentially consumable solution [6]. Addressing changing stakeholder needs involves employing strategies like active stakeholder participation, indirect communication via proxies or electronic means, and various elicitation methods [4]. Elicitation Methods, such as Just-in-time (JIT) model storming, look-ahead modeling, all-hands demos, and iteration demos, are used to gather requirements in a flexible and timely manner [4]. Requirements envisioning is facilitated through these methods [6]. This iterative approach allows for continuous feedback and adaptation to new information ![This image highlights different agile modeling practices, showing interconnected elements that contribute to efficient and flexible software development](image5).

The work item management strategies, including work item pools, stacks, requirements backlogs, and formal change management, play a crucial role in managing and prioritizing stakeholder needs [4]. These strategies, combined with prioritization techniques based on business value, risk, due date, operational emergency, and dependency, ensure that the most important needs are addressed promptly [4]. Furthermore, advanced teams utilize executable acceptance tests over specification documents, ensuring that requirements are not just documented but also tested [10]. Business analysts may be needed to support product owners in complex domains or when stakeholders are geographically distributed, ensuring that stakeholder needs are effectively captured and communicated [5]. The approach to scoping involves considering the level of detail, view types, modeling strategy, work item management strategy, and non-functional requirements, ensuring a structured approach to understanding and addressing stakeholder needs ![This diagram showcases strategies and considerations for scoping in a disciplined agile framework](image3).

Needs Exploration and Elicitation Methods ensure stakeholder needs are understood, prioritized, and addressed effectively throughout the agile project lifecycle.

The Bergen Guide 2022 highlights the historical and cultural importance of both the Osterøy Museum and the textile industry museums in the region. Osterøy Museum is set "in a beautiful setting in the cultural landscape of Osterøy" [10]. It showcases the lives of people in the countryside outside Bergen, connecting objects with the "living cultural heritage of textiles and costumes, weaving and local building customs" [10].
![Osterøy Museum showcases rural life and cultural heritage.](image1)

On the other hand, the guide also mentions several museums dedicated to the textile industry, such as the Salhus Tricotage Fabrik. A visit to this museum helps one learn "about the textile industry in Western Norway" [6] within "a listed textile factory dating from 1859" [6]. This museum, along with Arne Fabrikker, which was "the biggest textile factory in Norway in the 1950s" [1], illustrates the industrialization of Western Norway and its impact on the local community [1].
![Salhus Tricotage Fabrik provides insights into the textile industry's history.](image2)

Both museums offer unique insights into different aspects of the region's heritage. While Osterøy Museum focuses on rural life and traditional practices, the textile industry museums, including Salhus Tricotage Fabrik, highlight the region's industrial past and its impact on society.

In conclusion, the Osterøy Museum preserves rural traditions, whereas textile museums document the region's industrial evolution and its societal effects.

The cell cycle is an ordered sequence of events essential for cell division [5]. It consists of two main stages: interphase and the mitotic phase [5]. Interphase involves the duplication of cell contents, including growth, increase in cytoplasm (G1 phase), and the duplication of chromosomes (S phase), as well as preparation for division (G2 phase) [2].

The mitotic phase includes mitosis and cytokinesis [4]. Mitosis is the division of the nucleus, and cytokinesis is the division of the cytoplasm [4]. During prophase, chromosomes become visible as the chromatin condenses ![The image shows a cell during the prophase stage of mitosis.](image4). The chromosomes duplicate during the S phase [1, 7], and each chromosome appears as two sister chromatids joined at the centromere [8].

Interphase prepares the cell for division, containing the G1, S, and G2 phases ![This image depicts the stages of cell division, specifically illustrating the process of mitosis.](image6). Prometaphase follows, characterized by the breakdown of the nuclear envelope and the attachment of microtubules to kinetochores on the chromosomes ![The image shows a cell in the process of cell division during the stage of prometaphase.](image5). The cell cycle is a continuous loop, progressing from one phase to the next to ensure accurate cell division ![This image is a diagram representing the cell cycle. It is divided into two main parts: Interphase and the Mitotic Phase (M).](image1).

The main stages of the cell cycle are interphase (G1, S, G2 phases) and the mitotic phase (mitosis and cytokinesis).

To derive value from data, it must be pushed through an "analytics value chain" [12]. This chain consists of collection, analysis, decisions, action, and finally, impact [12]. It's not enough to stop partway along the chain [12].

The flowchart visually represents this process, starting with data and leading to value ![The flowchart shows that after Reporting, the next step is Analysis, which is followed by Action, ultimately leading to Value.](image5). After data is collected, the process flows from reporting to analysis, where in-depth examination occurs. The insights gained then drive action, leading to increased value or benefits ![The table illustrates that "Reporting" is descriptive and answers "What?", while "Analysis" is prescriptive and answers "Why?".](image3).

According to the "Analytics Value Chain" flowchart, Analysis comes between Reporting and Action.

In Pro mode, different metering and focus modes offer specific advantages depending on the shooting scenario. Metering modes, such as matrix metering, center metering, and spot metering, each measure light in distinct ways, allowing for tailored exposure settings [8]. Matrix metering is ideal for natural landscapes as it measures light across the entire frame ![Matrix metering measures light across the entire frame and is ideal for natural landscapes](image5). Center metering focuses on the light near the center of the screen, making it suitable for portraits ![Center metering focuses on light near the center of the screen and is ideal for portraits](image5). Spot metering, on the other hand, focuses on light from a specific region, such as a subject's eyes, providing precise exposure control [5, 8] ![Spot metering focuses on light from a specific region and is ideal for focusing on the subject's eyes](image5).

Focus modes also play a crucial role. AF-S (single) is best for stationary subjects, ensuring they remain sharp [4]. AF-C (continuous) is designed for moving subjects, continuously adjusting the focus to keep them in focus [4] ![AF-C focus mode is for moving subjects](image4). MF (manual) mode allows you to manually touch the subject to focus in on them, giving you control over the focus point [4] ![MF mode allows manual focus on a subject](image4). By selecting the appropriate metering and focus modes in Pro mode, photographers can optimize their camera settings to achieve the best results in various shooting conditions [9].

Pro mode in cameras enhances photography by offering metering modes tailored for different scenes and focus modes optimized for stationary or moving subjects [9].

The Master of Arts (MA) and Master of Science (MSc) programmes are available by research, while coursework options are further divided into disciplinary content, education domains, and professional practice ![Overview of Master's and Doctoral programmes by research, coursework, and doctoral programmes.](image6).

The disciplinary content courses, such as MA (Applied Linguistics) and MA (Humanities Education), alongside MSc (Exercise & Sport Studies), MSc (Life Sciences), MSc (Mathematics for Educators), and MSc (Science of Learning), cater to different academic interests [6]. The duration and mode of study vary, with options for full-time and part-time study, and modes including coursework or coursework with a dissertation ![The image is a table listing various academic programs with information on the duration for full-time and part-time study, as well as the mode of study.](image2). The MSc (Exercise & Sport Studies) and MSc (Life Sciences) programmes by coursework with disciplinary content allow for a maximum of 3 years of full-time study.

The conversion rate from Marketing Qualified Leads (MQL) to Sales Accepted Leads (SAL) varies significantly across different datasets, indicating the efficiency of lead qualification and the alignment between marketing and sales teams. One dataset shows a conversion rate from MQL to SAL at 1.50% ![Conversion rates from MQL to SAL is 1.50%.](image4). Another dataset indicates a conversion rate of 4-8% from contacts to leads, which can be interpreted as the MQL stage, and a 45-75% conversion rate at the SAL stage ![MQLs convert at 4-8% and SALs convert at 45-75%.](image7).

The differences in these conversion rates suggest variations in lead quality, the criteria used to define MQLs and SALs, and the effectiveness of the processes for transitioning leads between marketing and sales.  A low conversion rate, such as 1.50%, could mean that marketing is passing leads to sales that are not truly ready, resulting in wasted effort for the sales team [10]. Higher conversion rates, indicate better lead quality and alignment between marketing and sales. Different marketing programs affect metrics such as members, new names, cost per member, and cost per new name, ultimately influencing lead quality and conversion rates ![The table shows program costs and membership trends.](image3). A well-defined lead scoring system is crucial for accurately assessing a prospect's interest and readiness, ensuring that only the most promising leads are passed on to sales [10]. Lead source also impacts conversion rates, as different sources produce leads of varying quality and readiness [1, 2, 6]. For example, leads from AppExchange convert at 50.88%, while those from Sponsorship convert at only 5.44% ![Conversion ratio for leads from AppExchange is 50.88%, whereas leads from Sponsorship is 5.44%.](image5). The effectiveness of converting leads to opportunities can be measured by the Lead to Opp Index, as seen across different marketing sources ![Table shows marketing sources and their performance metrics.](image6).

The conversion rate from MQL to SAL reflects how well marketing efforts translate into sales opportunities, so the conversion rates vary.

Reviewing troubleshooting tips can help solve common problems [9]. Sometimes the dishes are not drying due to the wrong program or low-quality cutlery [image8]. Selecting a more intensive program may help clean your dishes [image7].

Several common dishwasher problems can arise, such as dishes not being clean due to items blocking the spray arms or dirty filters [image3]. Cloudiness or white spots may appear on glassware and dishes, respectively [image3]. Black or grey marks may also appear on dishes [image3]. Other issues include detergent being left in the dispenser, or the dishes not drying properly [image3].

![The image shows a dishwasher rack with a numbered guide indicating different dishware items](image1)
Problems such as the dishwasher not starting due to a blown fuse, low water pressure, or an improperly closed door can occur [image6]. Water not being pumped from the dishwasher may result from a twisted drain hose, a clogged filter, or a clogged kitchen sink [image6]. Suds in the tub can be caused by using the wrong detergent [image6]. Spilled rinse-aid or using detergent with colorant can stain the tub interior [image7]. Rust stains on cutlery, and knocking or rattling noises can also occur [image7].

![The image contains a warning sign that says: "WARNING: Non compliance with the loading can result to poor washing quality."](image2)

There are a variety of problems the dishwasher may encounter before calling for service.

For users adhering to UL Listed and CSA safety standards, specific electrical components are required. The cord type needs to be a minimum Type SJT, and at least 18 AWG [6].

 To ensure the device operates safely and reliably, it's important to use an approved Power Cord with earthing-contacts that conforms to the safety regulations of each country [3]. This attention to detail helps maintain grounding reliability, especially when the equipment is connected to a receptacle marked “Hospital Only” or “Hospital Grade” [6].
 

Furthermore, the installation environment plays a crucial role; adequate air circulation should be ensured to prevent internal heat build-up [8]. The device should not be placed on surfaces or near materials that may block ventilation holes and should be kept away from heat sources, direct sunlight, excessive dust, mechanical vibration, or shock [8]. This warning sign  serves as a reminder to be cautious and aware of potential hazards [2].

The second safety guideline for users with UL Listed and CSA approval is to use a cord type with a minimum rating of Type SJT and 18 AWG [6].
